review_title: Great Place to Work with plenty of opportunities
pros:
*Awesome learning ground
*internal rotation highly encouraged, able to take up new jobs and learn new things
* Great benefits and facilities
cons:
*Brutal performance ranking system. Still stuck in the past utilizing bell-curve ranking system (forced ranking). You can be a star performer and still ranked average.
* Career growth can be slow-linked to above and below point
*Plenty of office politics/favoritism. Not impossible to maneuver but can be difficult depending on your personality or if you're new to work life.
*C&B philosophy which is rather obsolete compared to close competitors. Not to say they pay poorly but certainly can be improved rather than being defensive on it being one of the best.

review_title: Intel - some things are great, some things need work
pros: Intel has great benefits and, depending on what group you are in, give you a lot of flexibility and respect.  I love the "about three weeks of vacation per year" and the fact that no one is tracking my hours.  They care if I get my job done, not if I left fifteen minutes early.  Work can be challenging (in a good way) and I have worked with some of the smartest and most competent people I have ever met.
cons: Those who can't do sometimes wind up managing.  And as a software engineer at a hardware company you are a red haired step child.  Intel knows how to make world class silicon, their processes and techniques are stellar.  But they haven't grasped that software is different, and without software the best silicon in the world is just a really expensive doorstop.

review_title: Disappointing
pros:
Perks/salaries  are average. for software. 
Work / Life balance is good for me (but I've heard of departments where it's not)
Management is approachable, but it differs in other departments
cons:
In the first 6 weeks I was moved to 3 different teams after a bait and switch move got me there. 
Could not get an answer on the value added to the corporation on any team I was on there
The RCG program didn't seem to hire particularly competent junior engineers who could work independently. 
Every 6 months the projects get cancelled and later resurrected by another team. 
The top management can't seem to focus or communicate their aims. 
The culture was a bit cultish consisting of a mix of H1Bs handcuffed by immigration policies and people who worked there solely for many years who were unaware of the industry in general.

review_title: Lots of pressure to perform; not much reward
pros:
* Free Fruit - get your 5-a-day
* Active sports & social club so easy to make friends. Staff generally very friendly.
* Very little traffic in Shannon - good for short commutes.
* Are good about working from home if needed. But you *will* be working.
cons:
* FOCAL (annual review system) ranks you against your team mates. About 5% of people *must* be given worst rating - means no bonuses - even if your an ok engineer. Bad for moral, work/life balance stress-levels & co-operation within teams. Lots of time and effort spent on high-visibility activities that are not relevant even to Intel.

* No time for learning & exploring new tech. Some good training courses given on x86 architecture but nothing on the highly complex software each engineer ends up having to master basically on their own.

* Engineers are not financially rewarded. Project Managers tend to be hired at Grade 7 but Engineers at Grade 6. Only the top 10% perfomers approx even considered for promotion in any year. Typical pay increase without promotion is 2%.

review_title: Is there any way to take this company private?
pros:
The people (rank and file):  intelligent & committed.  The constant influx of RCG's is a great source of energy and ideas; they keep us all young.

The technology: we've changed the planet for the better and have the potential to do it again.
cons:
Pay:  The stock market funded a big piece of compensation in the '90s.  Now that we rely on base pay it's a problem.. it doesn't even keep up with inflation.  So the reward loop for employees is broken and we end up busting ass for the shareholders who don't care about anything but the numbers.  This forces a short term bias but more importantly, employees have lost their sense of ownership. 

Internal systems: Average at best. (SAP and it's ilk)  There's so much emphasis on chasing cost through unbundling and wringing out costs on the parts that more time is spent coordinating all the moving parts than just doing the job in the first place.  I guess that's what comes from working for engineers (vs. professional managers).

review_title: Has been a great place to work, but unsure that it will continue to be so in the future.
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: The work can be very challenging and it is unlikely a good engineer will become bored. Your coworkers will come from all over the globe and will demand the very best out of you.
cons: The environment has changed a lot over the past decade. It is less rewarding financially as most compensation is only salary since stock is flat. There is far less personal growth available as the company is mostly downsizing this decade. What growth does occur is outside the US sites. Supporting and working with coworkers in Asia, Europe, and Israel requires significant work schedule flexibility. Meetings often occur at 7am and 9pm on the same day.

review_title: No growth opportunities & trapped on nightshift forever.
job_title: Manufacturing Technician in Rio Rancho, NM
pros:
The benefits package is very good with the exception of healthcare costs (roughly 2x that of other semiconductor manufacturers for the EXACT SAME COVERAGES).
Intel actively promotes a clean and safe working environment and does a good policing.
Plenty of growth opportunities FOR DAYSHIFT WORKERS.
cons:
There is no 24 hour on-site Implant engineering coverage for New Mexico nightshift (you have to call a sleeping engineer at home for guidance), very inefficient.   Some other areas do have 24/7 coverage, however.
There is absolutely no growth opportunities for Implant nightshift workers unless you are "in" with the senior management, at which point they will do anything they can to accomodate your needs (typical "good ol' boy network).  
They will constantly remain understaffed so that they can refuse your request for an internal transfer.
They will hire people off the street for dayshift while constantly denying your request to transfer from nights to days by telling you that they're understaffed on nights and your too experienced to be allowed to go.

review_title: Negative, egocentric, cult-based management culture
pros: Good benefits. Industry leading expertise in semiconductor engineering and manufacturing. Massive assets and capabilities. Best for people who have worked there for many years.
cons: Suffering effects of being a long-term monopoly on the processor platforms for PCs.  Missed the turn to mobile and now suffering mightily as PC sales are plunging.  Culture based on process-based manufacturing mindset, and misguided use of "process" to drive organization design. Senior executives admit the management culture does not value "emotional intelligence" - leading to micro-management, fear and mistrust pervasive throughout the culture.  Business group "silo" structure and harsh political environment lead.  Almost impossible for newcomers to be accepted into the culture ... and therefore it is not open to or able to assimilate new ideas. This myopic aspect is a direct challenge to the stated strategy of becoming more customer focused (outside-in vs. inside-out).

review_title: Your Manager makes the difference
job_title: Business Development Manager in Portland, OR
pros: Intel focus' on results and not where you work, this gives you the freedom to extend a vacation and take your computer along as long as your getting results.  The people at Intel are very smart and professional which makes it easier to get your job done.  Projects at Intel are always exciting and I enjoy seeing my projects out in the world.
cons: Short budget cycles make for some short sighted middle management.  Intel maintains grade salary caps so if your in your grade for a while you can cap out on salary even if your doing well, which means your either forced to push up or you flatten out.  Just depends on where you are in your career.

review_title: AutoCAD drafter
job_title: AutoCAD DRAFTER/FACILITIES ASSISTANT (Lab)/TOOL INSTALL in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
pay is great.
cafeteria is really nice.
cons:
NO JOB SECURITY.
one false move, rub them the wrong way, and you're out.
I think I was there almost 4 months (Ronler Acres) (I was at Hawthorn Farm before that, great place; 7 months), with nothing but good news about my job.  100% of work product was accepted by managers and supervisors.  In the last 20 minutes of my employment at Ronler, there were all these complaints about my work that no one had heard of before.  
There's something new at Intel.  It's sort of like being hauled out onto the front steps and being executed while the other employees look on (yea, it's a warning).  The new thing is, "Don't think that you get to keep your job.  It's not yours to keep.  You're an at-will employee, and I can prove it!"  The new thing is, we'll fire you if you get any bad reviews.  And of course, these are TOTALLY objective reviews with no personal agenda behind them at all.  
Don't worry about "your" job, we'll let you know..., 20 minutes before you're gone.

review_title: Procurement Manager
pros: many talented people work at Intel and there are always a multitude of internal job opportunities. You could spend your whole career with Intel and have 10+ completely different jobs.
cons: The company claims to rate performance based on meritocracy; however, at higher grade levels, the company is very political and it's not uncommon for the people at the director level to make sub-optimal decisions to protect their scope of work or size of their business group.  Furthermore, the Focal system (Intels annual performance rating system) is being changed starting in 2016; but the old system was broken and people were rarely held accountable to their grade level expectations universally. There were pockets of the company which were merit based, but far too many areas that were politically based and was who you knew or where friends with which then determined your performance rating.

review_title: Vision keeps changing. Poor SW investment
pros:
Lot of innovation work in diverse fields - great place to learn and grow your skills
Bright people. Great work ethics. Have never seen discrimination based on gender, race etc.
Best semiconductor company in the world
cons:
Most of the innovation does not lead to successful products. Mostly processors and Ethernet products are successful
SW innovation is not taken seriously. Company's DNA is silicon.
The vision keeps changing from PC to Platform to IoTs  back to more processor focused Datacenter because nothing else really succeeds in marketplace
Company does not think about products from consumer point of view. They only try to fit IA in the products somehow and does not properly invest in great user experience which can only be provided by SW innovation and building large scale capability in applications/services

review_title: Long time employees are not paid well compared to new entrants
pros: Very diverse and talented crowd. Great opportunities to work on cutting edge stuff.
cons:
1. I've been working for 10 yrs and started when salary scale was lower. Now I have peers / lower grade people entering from other companies and earning way more than me. The increments every year don't do enough to raise the base pay to what the market pays. Even though HR claims they equalize to the market, I happen to be just above the minimum bar and I don't get flagged in such checks. It hurts to work really hard to be paid far worse than your peers. I'll probably quit the company eventually just for this reason.

2. Extremely bureaucratic. Every little thing goes through enormous amount of process slowing things down. I've spent several weeks just writing documents and powerpoint to get approval for work that takes 2-3 days. At this rate Intel can never catch up with the current fast moving world.

review_title: Ruthless employer that doesn't stand by its values.
pros:
You'll learn fast and get great insight in to how such a large structural organization works. 
Great pay, but be prepared to work 24/7 for it.
cons:
To many cons. The company talks about being part of a team, but the review process pits worker against worker.  Every year, one person in a team will be delivered a poor review. It's about measuring your work against other team members.  This may work for those selling a number of units, but in the world of SW engineering, it's impossible to compare. It's like comparing apples with oranges. 
Strong hierarchy of managers and above. Anyone below will have to rely on the good will of their manager to do well. If you have a bad manager (which there are many at Intel) then you can forget about a career. 
Although flexible working hours are offered, women are under pressure to perform, and work long hours. This may not fit well with family life. 
Anyone with talent soon works out that they don't stand by their values, and leaves.

review_title: Intel - ample flexibility and opportunities, just don't overwork yourself
pros: Lots of flexibility and opportunities. With sufficient motivatation and potential, an employee can accomplish just about anything. Politics and challenges exist and it takes outrageous personal effort and dilligence to accomplish large things (especially if you are doing it from the "bottom-up") - but as you build allies in management, things happen. I also feel that employees can learn a tremendous amount working at Intel that can be useful within Intel or after Intel. I feel personally like I have been able to learn new and marketable skills constantly throughout my time at Intel.
cons: It is a big company and as such tends to be impersonal. Enough people are willing to invest their whole life in work that it can take a significant amount of effort to move mountains and have a home life. Like other companies, invest your time in relationships with co-workers - this is what makes it personal, fun, and enables you to build your own virtual organization chart of people motivated to get stuff done.

review_title: Great Benefits, good overall company
job_title: Mechanical Technology Development Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Great benefits, especially for families!  Generally good flexibility with life if you can "turn off" work at home. There are MANY internal opportunities to move around within the company, even to other countries if you have the right skill sets (usually engineering management).
cons: Work/Life balance can be manager specific and internal customers can be a pain.  Given the truly global reach of Intel, it is never "off time" with Intel and it can eat you alive if you let it... There is A LOT of bureaucracy that really slows down the company and decisions and can make daily work very tedious.  In many positions you are expected to do far more then a specific job role...though that can be refreshing at times.

review_title: Manufacturing Tech for R&D
job_title: Research and Development Technician in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good pay,great benefits, love the sabbatical. Good team mates who are smart and work hard. Supports flexible schedule for family and educational needs.
cons: Extremely high stress on a daily basis, always talked down to by most PHd engineering. Company laid off some of its best workers 2 years in a row. That brain-drain has put them in a very bad situation. CEO claims they need to downsize, yet they are still hiring people like crazy. Seen several people die from stress overload in my 13yr career. No amount of pay is worth that level of stress.

review_title: Software Automation Engineer
pros: Intel Benefits are excellent such as  Sabbatical, STP, RSU, bonuses... etc.  Pay is not compatible at all. I worked there officially 9+ years.
cons: Focal is very tough and so much power given to even first level managers.  Unfortunately, lots of favoritism and body body things happens at Intel and a hard working NEVER gets repaid.  Focal/Review system MUST change and much more management accountability MUST happen if the company is to survive.  Our new Intel-Media group got sold to Verizon and Intel never gave a darn about veteran employees such as myself.  They would not allow us to transfer and I even lost my Sabbatical, all because I sacrificed it for the Intel Media group that I was working for 2 straight years.  After working there for 9+ years I never got to take my Sabbatical, even though I was eligible to take it after 7 years.

review_title: You probably don't want to work here.
pros:
1. We are essentially a monopoly in the processor business.
2. If you kiss the right butt at Intel, you can survive anything.
cons:
1. We are essentially a one product company and we seem to be incapable of succeeding at anything else.
2. Our marketing has been hideous since the late 1990's and we have no idea how to fix it.
3. Executives are rotated into jobs they have no experience in or ability to succeed at and the company suffers for it.
4. The morale is hideous and there are many people like me who pretend to be happy working for the company, when we really could care less anymore.
5. The SET was a complete disaster. Intel let go of a lot of talented people and kept a lot of sycophants and suckups. Even worse, the good people who remain are still angry at the company.
6. There is a marked lack of executive talent in the upper ranks and it's hard to see where our company is headed. 
7. No recent college graduate in their right mind would pick Intel over places like Google and Yahoo.

review_title: Great place to work with flexible hour
pros: in house sports facilities are well-equipped, vast rotation opportunity, work life balance as it allows flexible working hour and paid time off
cons: training provided is not too condusive as some local site leaders do not equip a good communication skills; the employee bonus is below average and increment can be as low as zero or a standard 3% annually

review_title: Retired from Intel
pros: Great benifits, emplyee stock purchase plan, health plan, reasonable pay, work life balance. Teams work well together with some oppertunities to relocate, learn new skills.  Great volunteer seperation package for those not terminated, but encouraged to retire early.
cons: Avoid posting oppinions on the internal or external social sites.  They have zero tolerence for any reporting of anything that could be seen as not PC.  Review process can be difficult.  Suspect the early seperation package offers are used to prevent age discrimination lawsuits. Retirement eligibility is age 55 and 15 years employment.

review_title: Flexible, but homogeneous.
pros: Intel offers many opportunities for professional development.  There are classes available for professional development, and the pursuit of certification and higher education is encouraged and supported.  The atmosphere is very relaxed with no set work schedules or days.  You can take personal/vacation days at your discretion - to no set limit as long as your projects are current.  Most work does not have a fixed deadline - so stress is low.  To sum it up in one word: flexible.
cons: The people are not very diverse.  While many cultures are represented among the workforce - most employees are middle aged males with technical degrees fitting a typical "geeky" stereotype.  This is not the case company-wide, but in a building where technical work is done, most folks are very technical and logical.  Few people provide drastically varying perspectives.  To sum it up in one word: homogeneous.

review_title: Its been a good experience. Exactly the kind of career starting job I was hoping to land after college.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Just a very solid industry leading company.  The base pay could be better but the bonuses are pretty good. Oregon is a great place to live.
cons: Work life balance is there for some but non-existent for others. Not everyone pulls their weight. Not all teams work at the same level of intensity. Poor track record in hiring and retaining individuals from underrepresented minorities groups, though the company is trying to improve this.  Both Oregon and California have high state income tax.

review_title: After a year, I felt that Intel was no longer the place for my personality and professional development.
job_title: Component Design Engineer in DuPont, WA
pros: Intel is a stable company that isn't going away anytime soon.  Many managers emphasize working hard to achieve recognition and success, which is quite true.
cons: Intel managers often emphasize getting things done without regard to doing things "correctly" or "thoughtfully" or "elegantly".  Also, the managers I worked under had little to no regard for the future of my career nor my professional development.  That said, it's very easy to become complacent and stagnant in the current role and without any growth potential within the team & company as a whole.  Also, the job can become quite demanding with little to no benefit or value for the employee.

review_title: Great global organization. Screwed up expat managers.
pros:
Brand name. 
Cutting edge technology
Brilliant engineers
cons:
However good an organisation its your immediate management that matters. After 2 years I will know I will never again work for Indian American Bosses in India. Indians returning to plum posts (in India) after wining the coveted green cards, bring with them the worst of both (Indian and American) work cultures. 
 They enforce forced rankings within their teams to pit employees against each other even when they know it comes at an expense to team performance 
They treat white-men as gods and never question orders of their American masters. this is the only qualification due to which they are hired for these important management positions otherwise local managers are much more result-oriented while at the same time understand and treat people better
They treat Indians as slaves and completely disregard the opinions of Indian subordinates while encouraging sycophancy 
They have no  respect for others time and space
They believe women are not as capable as men and only hire them to "boost morale" within team
They lack of integrity and easily lie to shift blame from themselves or take undeserved credit

review_title: a short title
pros: There are always issues that need to be addressed at Intel so there is no shortage of work. If you get bored, it's not hard to move around into other positions to try on new hats.
cons:
Although Great Place to Work and work life balance are Intel values, there is actually very little work life balance. Hours at the office can be very long depending on number of meetings and when they are scheduled. Weekends and nights are not off limits and you are almost always on call depending on how many members are you on your team. 

Promotion process is very slow and does not reward high performing newcomers. You are graded against your team and if you have more experienced members in your team, they will receive promotion first.

review_title: Manufacturing Equipment Technician
pros: Highly technical process and equipment, hence strong structure of manufacturing engineering. This assists with the continuous improvement as with Moore's Law. The advent of the 450mm wafer is an example of this type of progress of continuous improvement as with more chips less waste.
cons: Very tall structure to support the relentless drive of exponential development. Hence as a result a highly documented processes e.g. Intel CBP Corporate  Business Principles. Its my experience if all employees are not on a level playing pitch (E.g. Cyber risk assessment)  as with responsibilities (SWOT analysis) as applies to CBP (E.g. Confidential information being released to unauthorised third parties. Ref: Public communications and filings, CBP section 3.3 ),its very difficult to obtain equality (E.g. ISO 27005 IT Threats and Vulnerabilities ) free from cyber harassment.

review_title: Thoughts from a retiree
pros: Exceptional benefits. Competitive pay; extremely competitive pay and bonuses if you're position is graded mid-level or above exempt. Flexible work-life balance. Generally a great group of people to work with. I would recommend the company to a friend, but I would also recommend the friend get as much information as possible from as many sources as possible and be aware of the situation they are being hired into.
cons: Company leadership claims to be out of touch or unaware of how business group leadership and managers have historically applied performance management guidelines. Communication (company to managers; managers to employees) not a strength and is my opinion is often role modeled in the way guideline changes are not communicated real-time to managers and employees. I would recommend that employees be proactive in their performance and career conversations with their managers. At the time of my departure organizational trust between the company and its employees and managers was an issues.

review_title: Great company but can be high stress
pros: (1) well paid; (2) they share the wealth with regard to stock options; (3) sabbatical every 7 years; (4) high caliber fellow workers
cons: The average employee at Intel would be an all-star at many other corporations.  So when they put you into competition with one another for the annual review (and try to distribute very talented people across a bell curve), it can be very stressful.  In addition, the bar is typically set very high in terms of your productivity and the quality of your work.  Intel is known for ENDLESS meetings.  If a good portion of the week is taken up with meetings, when are you supposed to do the work that will result in completion of your deliverables?  Get ready to submit weekly status updates, documenting what you accomplished across several categories.  Yes, there is the sabbatical every seven years (but you might feel as though you produced 14 years worth of work in those 7 years).  Spend the several month sabbatical in a sanitarium, recovering from the past seven years.  Then go back and do it again.

review_title: Mixed Bag
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Large company means you can move around to different positions without taking a pay cut.  It also means there is a lot bureaucracy, which you can be a part of, make good money, and do little real work.  A lot of people are very happy doing that.
cons: General fear of industry standard tools.  This isn't the whole company, and they were using a few when I left.  But in general they create their own, which ends up being meaningless on your resume to any company outside of intel.  Also, the reason they create there own is that the people who do so get more credit for that than using an industry standard tool.  This creates a cycle of creating new internal tools that replace old ones constantly to get that credit.  As a result the tools are never very refined.

review_title: Sr. R&D Engineer
job_title: Senior R&D Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Salary, bonuses, benefits, growth, learning, experience, and interesting projects/products.
cons: 60-80 work hour weeks hit hard. You are given a new project that no one has done before, give you the oldest tools on the manufacturing floor to figure it out... No work life balance while you see your friends in jobs that do not require them to work on the manufacturing floor leave at a decent time every day... There are 10 people freaking out about an issue in a meeting per 1 person on the manufacturing floor actually working on how to solve the issue. To many PowerPoint and meeting "engineers" and not enough actual engineers who do the actual work and experiments. I am seriously looking on how I can get out in my current role.

review_title: Toxic Environment
pros: Salary is good and benefits are decent, but you're expected to work a lot hours for it and be available even on vacation. Great parental leave program. Tuition reimbursement is good, if you can get approved for the program.
cons: The expected hours are insane. The minimum is 50 hours and more like 60-80, especially if you have on-call. Everyone is doing the job of 2 or 3 people and AZFSM is purposely understaffed (and is proud of it). There is a lot of blocking for moving internally, even within your site or organization. Focal is meaningless and ratings are based on whatever your manager wants to give you. Development is following your manager's path. Unless you get promoted, your salary will never be as high as a new college graduate at the same grade level.

review_title: Competitive, yet rewarding, with great pay
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Salary and benefits are second to none
Finance rotation program is like having a brand new job every two years
Working in finance provides the opportunity to see the entire business and competitive landscape
Work in mid to higher level grades help produce CFO qualities
Work from home option sporadically
cons:
Forced culture after years of layoffs resulting in turmoil
Like most companies, your success is relatively dependent upon having a good manager as good work can go unrecognized by managers who are not involved in the day to day
A lot of smart people, but sometimes too much time is spent to make simple business decisions
Terrible systems

review_title: The truth behind Intel
pros: Even in a slowing economy, studies have shown that people will not give up their computers or internet connectivity.  Intel creates a viable product with a global footprint that allows it to be competative even during harder times.  Innovation and creativity is reflected in the companies 80% market share, and management understands it is the employees that make this happen.  Benefits are market competative, opportunity is greater than anywhere I have seen.  Great products, bright future, and being rewarded fairly makes Intel a great place to work.
cons: Intel hires the brightet people in the industry.  Advanced degrees are par for the course, those degrees (in most cases) coming from tier one universities.  If you are looking to stand our immediately or be a big fish in a small pond, it is very hard to do here.

review_title: Intel is a fantastic place to have a stable, rewarding career, but you most likely will not get rich.
job_title: Supply Demand Operations Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel is an international, stable, high tech company that is changing the world by designing and manufacturing the most complex, powerful computer chips in history.  Intel offers many opportunities to learn, grow and travel and is full of talented, dedicated, hard-working employees.  In this time of economic uncertainty, worldwide recession etc, it's wonderful to be at a company like Intel.
cons: The company, while being a technology leader, is narrowly focused on the microprocessor and PC business, where growth is slowing.  Forays into other technology businesses (commmunications chips, flash memory, networking etc) have been largely unsuccessful.  As a result, Intel's stock is ragebound - floating between low teens to upper 20s in the last few years.  So you won't get rich working at Intel unless you work your way up the ranks, but you can have a stable, rewarding career nonetheless.

review_title: Intel offers a mixed bag of opportunity!
job_title: Program Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: While it is changing, Intel hires really bright people. If you like working along side people that get it, even when the company doesn't allow you to execute, it's a good place to be.
cons: As a program manager, it's easy to see that the company has many great programs in place that theoretically should make it easy for employees to seize opportunities, unfortunately a lot of managers (at least in my department) could care less about them.  When I first joined Intel, the company was moving fast, things were changing fast, and opportunity to work on cool projects was everywhere.  The company is still moving fast, as is the industry, but over the past few years there has been a much stronger focus on cost containment and as a result, this is no longer the place to be if you want to be setting trends instead of following them.

review_title: Look out for yourself and no one else
pros:
Very professional environment
Lots of intelligent people
Lots of hard working people
cons:
*Don't be a team player - you're rewarded for what you do (ie nice guys finish last)
*Observing job performance is subjective. Managers don't know who does the work
*Squeaky wheels get the grease. Being a good soldier means you're last in rankings, first for layoffs
*Be a professional meeting goer. Assign analysis work to others during the meeting and just speak during meetings.  Fools the managers ALL the time.  Seriously, some ppl do close to no work except attend mtgs.
*Exec managment gets great compensation, and they're kind of out of touch with working class compensation
*Competitive environ means long hours and stress, if you care about doing well on your review
*Too much red tape. Bosses make decisions, thus there are no empowered employees
*Management might be scared to challenge their bosses, although they have constructive criticism (layoffs the past few years but company is now spending $10B on acquisitions, lawsuits, etc).

review_title: Tired of watching my collegues walk out the door ...
pros: Fast-paced, high-impact, everyday is a new day, we are the best at what we do, sink or swim mentality -- good thing -- weeds out those who don't 'fit" quickly, zero tolerance for slackers.
cons: Constant down-sizing, re-sizing, right-sizing of the organization.  The environment is frenetic enough without constantly having the sword of Damacles over your head -- not optimum for high performance and possibility thinking.

review_title: A company that has lost its way
pros: You work with really smart people who want to do their very best. Great problem solvers and  want to collaborate to solve problems. Access to the best technology, tools, etc.  If you are in the right spot you work very very very hard and long hours.  But it can be soo fun! Because of this I would recommend this to a friend if they knew what they were getting into.
cons:
Tons of slackers.  There is deadwood that needs to be cleared out. Lots of people who are afraid to take risks. Too conservative in their products and marketing of them. Decision making is slow and everyone that helps you they feel that they can make your decisions for you. Senior management is not egalitarian at all. There is a class system even though within the company mantra there is not. 
Intel uses internal benchmarks to determine if their products are competitive and drinks their own marketing information.

review_title: Good company, lots of politics
pros:
Excellent engineering skills, upper management is open and honest about strategy, industry, etc.  
Most engineers are very good at their job, and are very dedicated.  The entire company is very tech-centric.  I've worked at companies that aren't this way, and it is refreshing to see upper management really understand the tech industry.
cons: Lots of politics!  Also, middle management seems to have a hard time accepting that the Intel way of doing things is no longer the universal way.  There tends to be a lot of people there that think that the rest of the world is waiting for Intel to produce something before it will buy it.  Trouble is, that's no longer the case.  Lots of internal politics, also.  A poorly worded email at the wrong time can kill your entire yearly review.

review_title: Great place for fast paced growth and big challenges
job_title: Technical Lead in San Jose, San Jose
pros:
I work at Intel Costa Rica as software developer. Even though the pay is good and according to your skills and how much you are willing to give (time, extra effort, etc) your salary can increase considerably quick. 
    I consider  that working with so many capable people from so many different countries is the biggest advantage. This will quickly broaden your vision of the world and will help you grow at a quicker pace than most of the people persuing a similar career path.
   If you are someone who loves a good challenge this is the place for you, once you proof yourself to your peers and management, the challenges will come big and often. As soon you are starting to get into the comfort zone, something big will shake you.
cons: Everyone here is extremely ambicious and competitive (in a good way), and things move fast. If you want to stand out and go up the ladder you have to apply yourself and be able to work hard and commit even when your plate is already full.

review_title: let go for unfair reasons
pros: Smart and dedicated population.  Great infrastructure
cons: New CEO takes no prisoner in his restructuring - he has shifted the culture 180-degrees from caring about employees to looking at them as expendable pawns in his game.  Cutting people based on unfair statistics and calling it "meritocracy."  Truth: mid-year promotion with a raise and stock for a senior technical SW female resulted in a zero raise and stock at the annual review (which is standard) and his policy of "meritocracy" caused her to be fired without any appeal or review (and he stands on stage touting "diversity" the same day it happened).  Same scenario for a manager who was out for a few months recovering from a kidney transplant.  Also fired without any review or concern.  If you want to work at Intel be aware that you are very much your WWID and little more.  Keep your resume and external network ready, because you are not in control of your future.  Better yet, join a company that values you and your skills as a real person...

review_title: A process development technician's perspective
pros:
Best technology development in the world.  Intel's manufacturing process is always at least 6 months ahead of any other semiconductor manufacturer in the world  and is usually the best in class.  Intel has beat every manufacturer in the world in producing products with High K / Metal Gate transistors.  
Incredibly safe environment to work in.  The safety of the workers is always priority one in everything that goes on here.
Many opportunities to advance with only light to moderate stress levels.
cons: Red tape, lots of it.  Sometimes there are just too many hoops to jump through to get something done.  Reliance on others to get projects done can be a pain in the arse too.  What would take me only 5 minutes to accomplish sometimes takes a week when forced to relying on someone else to do it.

review_title: Great People Great Benefits - bureaucracy is a bit much but Good company overall
pros:
Great people to work with
Great benefits overall
Great skill-set, learning environment
Career Progression is also quite good until you start hitting the Manager Lvl and above
cons:
Once you have been hired in at a "do-er" level - even after many years with the company it is difficult for them to see you in a Manager or Above level. Will almost neve see someone get to a Mgr/Sr Mgr or VP level unless hired directly from the outside. If you LEAVE Intel and then come back you have a greater chance of that happening. Most re-hires almost always come back with increased pay regardless of whether they bring any additional skills back with them.
Level of bureauracy is hard to wade through also. Takes a bit of time to get ideas through or a new process approved.

review_title: Grinding out incremental improvements belatedly
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: If you want a 9ish to 5ish sort of job, this is your place.  No one works on weekends, and no one but managers (and moi) seem to even check their email when not at the office.  The stock recently moved a little for the first time in ten years.  I have very fortunate to have been blessed with the opportunity to learn some new programming things, but I would not count on learning anything new (that's transportable) if you've been doing any kind of embedded development for any length of time.
cons: A dearth of genuine software innovation.  What seems to be a lemming-like mindset amongst many employees; too often it seems like a joyless rut for many.  It's in Santa Clara. ;)  But, as with anything, it is what you make of it, which is sometimes a bit of a trial.

review_title: Really depend on the team
job_title: Software Engineering Manager in Portland, OR
pros:
There are some managers that do care about growing the employee.  There are some top notch engineers that you can learn a lot from and are fun to work with.  Intel does a little of everything, so there's opportunity to find something you can be passionate about.

Work life balance is great because you'll be competing against very average engineers.
cons:
Lack of a standard hiring bar causes the caliber of management and engineering talent varies too widely from team to team.  This makes transferring to teams for career development or collaboration across teams difficult because teams don't trust each other.

Compensation is not competitive enough to attract the best talent across the board.  A selected few can be compensated extremely well, but the need to fight to become those selected few makes it difficult for engineers and teams to collaborate.

review_title: Stable company; slow career growth; lacking leadership from senior management
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: A stable company; benefits (e.g. medical, retirement) are above average. Intel is the leader in the industry.  You would have a chance to work with the cutting edge technologies and flexibility on the projects you would like to work on.  If you would like to study, the company has good education program to help employees to get their education.
cons: Very competitive among groups and individuals. Career development is very slow. It's very hard to get into the management positions.  Senior management lacks leadership especially in the software division. Because of the competitive edge, individuals seem not to work closely to each other even within the group.  Knowledge sharing is really lacking.  Communications between groups and individuals are very bad. Over-classification of technical information makes sharing much harder. External websites would have more information than internal websites.

review_title: Extremely competitive place to work but great experience on your resume.
pros:
Extremely competitive place to make you grow professionally and intellectually. Other companies like to hire people with Intel experience. 
The company has been consistently profitable (gross and net) so bonus / profit sharing is also reliable as part of your compensation.
cons:
Intel likes individual contributors to work (and excel) on a very narrow and specific area, so after a couple years it could be darn right boring unless you are a geek, and management doesn't encourage you to change assignment (even they say so).
The company culture is very process driven (after all this is a manufacturing company) so the downsides are too many meetings, and too many process and marketing people who are not really contributing. 
Extremely competitive place so there's a lot of politics, turf war, and strong-arm tactics.
Top heavy so promotion is hard to come by when you hit grade 8 or 9.
Too many smooth talker and marketing people.
Many recent graduates (undergrad and graduate school) but hardly any gray hair; go figure.

review_title: Became a true intrapreneur and was allowed to grow to my potential
pros:
Flexiblity in regards to work schedule and telecommuting since it is a global organization
Opportunity to work on challenging work and leverage an intelligent knowledge base
Strong focus on employee development
The opportunities for advancement are there, but it is up to "you" seek the opportunities and shine - take advantage of the 1:1's with your manager.
Excellent benefits
I loved my "job" but the culture was stifling
cons:
Analysis paralysis
Bureaucracy
They like "yes" people, which I am not
Short sightedness - focuses on short-term vs. long-term sustainable gains
Risk adverse - need more innovative, fresh idea thinkers
Morale has significantly decreased over the years - it went from a "great place to work" to dreading my days in a matter of two years

review_title: Slave labor conditions: MUST Read
pros: Challenging and interesting work on cutting edge tools and technologies.
cons:
Extremely poor work life balance. To max. the profits squeeze the entry level engineers. Managers want 24 X 7 coverage from same employee. The only way you get leave is if you are sick/ burnout / take leave. Frequent  on call coverage. wokring on late wekenights/ weekends. Beginners beware and stay away. you have been warned. Gullible international graduate stundets are ready to take up any job after graduating and are the largest demography in this job role. Even though you are hired for shift 1 (40 hours per week) but it is onlky on paper. In reality it will be minimum 60 hours...and beyond since you are hired as an exempt and your hours dont.. count..You OWN the tool and Intel OWNS you . work permeates every aspect of your life...
Process engineers are considered expendable assets since if one leaves there are hundreds in line to replace..huge attrition rate in the fab roles. There is no uniform structure or system for training. most of the training is on the run. Money can be a driving factor only for so long. No proper feedback.

review_title: Pick your team wisely
pros: In general, people are good. Great benefits and pay.
cons: No work-life balance. Politics get in the way of getting anything done. If you aren't in management, your opinion is not valued and they will find any way possible to make your time there difficult if they deem you not "Intel quality". Like someone once told me, "Intel is where engineers go to die". I also found as a female working there, the environment was even more closed-minded to you. Don't be mislead by all their advertising of "women in engineering" or claiming they want to hire more females. I endured plenty of discrimination in my time there.

review_title: Great people working hard on unclear goals and strategies
job_title: IT Program Manager in DuPont, WA
pros: World class products and technology.  Resources to invest in interesting projects.  Many great people.  True integrity as an organization.
cons: You are expected to work like you are in a crisis - all the time.  Your manager has too much control over your career and life.  Only ~50% of the employees actually add value or generate revenue - the rest spend their time communicating, updating and justifying what they are doing - all at a "Type A" frenetic pace.  You are responsible for your own employability (which is OK) but the company really has no idea what skill they will need beyond ~ 6 months.  Consequently, they lay off existing employees and then hire the skills that are needed for today.  Very wasteful and demoralizing.

review_title: Interesting
pros:
-Great upper management
-Flexible work hours
-ESPP
-RSU stock bonuses
-Smart, work oriented people (no babysitting other employees)
-Empowerment environment (figure everything out for yourself)
-Ability to work on cunning edge technology and change the work with your ideas
-Fast paced & dynamic working environment
-On site gym
-Working meals
cons:
-Have to be in a position for at least 3 years
-If you transfer to a different division your 3 years in position get reset
-Your tech manager has the biggest weight on your performance reviews
-When you get a job there they will almost always push you down in title to reduce quicker rise to management positions, will still pay you well for your experience

review_title: Great compensation but poor leadership at all levels and burn-out rate is high
pros: Great compensation and healthcare benefits. 3 weeks of vacation first year of employment.  Very smart people in the trenches.  Ability to move around company when projects get shut down rather than face lay-off.
cons: Overall very poor leadership. Too many career lifers with no outside perspective. Build it and they will buy attitude. Marketing teams treated poorly. Individual contributors get promoted without leadership training or having people management skills.  Engineers held hostage to project at hand only to have it shut down after sacrificing family and personal time. Lack of teamwork and sink or swim attitude is rampant across all functions as is outsourcing! Trend toward laying off non-management level employees over 45 through performance "review" system.

review_title: Decent company to work for, but not what it used to be.
pros: its go-go days appear to be behind it, and it has stumbled with its vision and leadership over last 10 yrs.   that being said,  its a decent place to work for with decent benefits for a mature company.   work is usually challenging, but it depends on your group and how motivated you are.
cons: being a big company,  it is quite political.   the key is getting into a good group  where you have supportive management, flexibility/balance  with your work/personal life, freedom to do your job, and good/trustworthy people to work with.  Get in the wrong/bad group and its not fun.  Lately the company is making efforts to downsize ... I expect that to continue, but in a moderate way.

review_title: A Place to Move Around
pros: Intel has a lot of different opportunities to try new things. You can move between hardware, software, firmware or any of the business management jobs quite easily. Not to mention working on cutting edge technology and a wealth of very talented and fun people to work and learn from. Intel is the most diverse company I have ever worked with, and this is one of the main factors I like about the company.
cons: Intel is big. Very big, and the groups just dont communicate with each other. This causes a lot of political positioning and works against progress. This is the most frustrating factor at times and can be quite distracting. It always seems to take too much time to make decisions and I often feel we miss opportunity because senior management has a hard time making the hard choices.

review_title: Good Company
pros: Intel is certainly an international company and has very diversified work force.  Employees come from almost every corner of the world. You can meet people from different cultures.  Most people I worked with were very technical and professional.  Employees showed respect to one another.  I liked the working environment and culture.   Never needed to worry about there was not enough technical challenges to work on.   I can always look for new advance technology for future project or find better ways to do existing work. It is a good starting place for young people to build their working experience.  Overall, Intel is very good company to work for.
cons: Sometime work can be very stressful and work in long hour.  The project timeline is getting shorter and shorter (in some situations, it can be good).    Sometimes there might be too many meetings.

review_title: Good company - but you have to sift through the garbage to find the hidden gems that make it worthwhile
pros: Intel does provide more than fair compensation.  They have a focal process that is at least designed to be fair, but a lot of things have recently been removed that I believe made the process more transparent.  They claim it was for expediancy reasons, but who knows...
cons: Lots of bueracracy.  Work is very slow unless its becomes a priority to management.  Unfortunately, Intel has a very weak hiring process, and a lot of bad apples get in.  20% of the workforce does 80% of the work.

review_title: A good place to start your career, but move on if you want to gain "real world" experience.
pros:
-good learning opportunities
-good technology
-excellent benefits
-good for new college grads only
-tolerant of all races, gender, religions, etc
-excellent training opportunities
-8 week sabbatical after 7 years of service (if you make it that long)
cons:
-bureaucratic management--sometimes takes way too long for decisions to be made and implemented
-mean culture--very cut throat
-tends to overwork employees
-too competitive focal review process
-not enough pay for scope of work 
-a bit of nepotism - many employees married or related to one another (oftentimes they hide it by using different last names)
-job duties are often too segmented--unlike other companies where you get a wider scope of responsibilities.

review_title: Challenging work but very impersonable and cut-throat
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: It's a great company to gain experience working with the latest technologies and some of the smartest people anywhere. There are always opportunities to move into other roles, either permanently or on a temporary assignment. The company has done a lot in recent years to improve the stale cube environment.
cons: Work/life balance is non-existent. There is a reason they give all employees laptops and it's not because they want you to telecommute (only one day a week is allowed)... it's because they expect you to be available for early morning or late night calls, weekends and holidays.  The pfmn management system rewards individual accomplishments over team/company goals, so there is very little collaboration or knowledge sharing.

review_title: Unusual Intel Co employment practices
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Glendale, CA
pros: Intel drives you hard, You're really pushed to do things you wouldn't ordinarily do, maybe think out of the box. Intel may be credited with making you a better engineer. The company rates workers every year through a rigorous process it calls Focal.
cons:
employees complain that this summer's layoffs, which cost more than 1,100 people their jobs across the country, undermined that culture by changing the rules in the middle of the game.Intel tried unsuccessfully to keep the layoff secret. Then it altered the way it selects workers for job cuts, moving away from the way it had handled previous layoffs. The cuts fell disproportionately on older workers too, and a newly applied rule bars laid-off workers from ever being rehired. us, and upsetting the people who are left, adversely affecting morale.
In a letter to laid-off employees, Intel said it was letting them go because they came up short in Intel's internal performance metrics, which is simply not true.

review_title: Highly competitive, unfriendly co-workers
pros:
+ Compensation, bonuses, and benefits are great
+ Upper management keeps everyone informed of what is going on and seems to be competent
+ Fairly easy to move around to different positions if you aren't happy with your work
+ Flexible vacation and time off
cons:
- The people. Most people are *very* competitive and will only help you if they have something to gain from it. Even those that aren't competitive often wait days or weeks to respond to an e-mail, and are condescending when they eventually do respond.
- Every project is separate and you need permission from multiple managers to even read any documents or access files. Getting permissions often takes several days or even weeks. It feels as if they don't even trust their own employees.
- Tools are all custom designed and often (poorly) replicate already available software. Very little documentation is available for them. A major part of my job involves fighting with the tools so I can do my actual job.

review_title: Sr Software Engineer
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: There is a wealth of knowledge and tools available that you can take advantage of from the people to the actual knowledge base available. You have a good selection of benefits to choose from and every year, they've always given employees time to meet with the different benefit options on site. Hours are flexible and that is always a good thing in achieving work life balance.
cons: This company has a tendency to select managers without soft skills. I have witnessed first level managers who never challenged upper management for fear of receiving a bad review. So much for challenging the status quo. Best advice is to find a manager who has the backbone to stand up for his/her team, otherwise you end up managing your manager. The review process they have in place is ugly!

review_title: Recent college grad at Intel
pros: Bragging rights to all your friends, notoriety, the feeling of joy you get from being part of something relevant and successful. The benefits are great.
cons: Lack of training to get yo up to speed with their projects. Then they expect you to produce a high volume of work in a short amount of time with no training. You can't "google" how to do things at Intel because it's is all cutting edge and confidential - so you can't get assistance online. The pay isn't as good as Microsoft. Managers rank employees via charts and graphs that don't tell the whole story. In an attempt to streamline/assembly-line employees and their productivity, they sacrifice trust. But perhaps this is just one of those things that makes all corporations have a bad rep.

review_title: Tough times
pros:
1) good pay & benefits
2) opportunity to try different roles around company
3) on finance side, big focus on development and cool rotation program  that allows you to grow fast and move up
cons:
1)  work life balance ...it depends on org, but terrible in most of the finance roles
2) the times are tough and the morale in the company is low...never ending cycle of layoffs and cost cutting is weighing on everybody
3)  management that has hard time getting employees buy into their strategy
 4) management that seem to value external companies more than internal talent
5) environment seems to be getting very political, especially in upper management (and trickling to mid-mgmt)

review_title: Not recommended unless you're close to retire.
pros: Pay is OK at low-cost geos like Oregon, Chandler and Folsom, benefits are decent. Most groups have good work-life balance.
cons:
1. No Career future. Company hasn't have much growth for many years and failed to deliver 10nm process mode again and again.
2. Year-to-year pay increase is negligible, sometimes even less than inflation rate.
3. Meritocracy is dead, promotion is not guaranteed even if you did excellent work, you may need to wait for your turn because limited budget for promotion.
4. No job security. The company laid off 10000+ employees without obvious reason.
5. The skillset learned at Intel, especially software, are outdated in IT industry. The longer you stay, the less possible you will be able to launch a job elsewhere.

review_title: Intel is as good as your first line manager is.
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: The pay is good.  The company is stable.  There are a lot of great, intelligent coworkers.  You have the freedom to switch jobs after a year if you want.
cons: Intel has serious problems with first line managers.  It is so inconsistent.  I've had some great ones and some really bad ones.  Senior management seems to really have it together though.  There are also so many people here working on their small part that you have to be really careful to make sure that you include all of the people affected and this can sometimes really slow things down.  A lot of people have to work with oversees customers and other engineers, which can mean early mornings or late nights at work.

review_title: Limited career growth.  Execs who can't make decisions or be up front with their long term plans.
pros: The money isn't bad and benefits are pretty good. Lots of great people are still in the engineering workforce and some parts of Intel function pretty well.
cons:
Where to start?  The culture is highly political.  If you work in manufacturing or one of CPU design teams you can find an old boys' network to join.  Outside of that you can forget about advancement.  The ranking and rating process used during evaluation is a relic from the 1980s: it rewards throwing others under the bus and disincentivizes teamwork.  

Innovation was killed off in the early 2000s and replaced with a series of silos.  If you don't color inside your own lines you're going to be punished.

Messages given to employees are constantly of bad news and impending problems.  Employee morale is low and workers are treated more like cattle than anything else.

review_title: My Experience @ Intel After 2.5 Years
job_title: Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Being such a large company, it's nice knowing that you will have a job if you are competent in the least bit.  They also encourage internal transfers and strive to keep individuals within the company.  The benefits are pretty good (free soda\pop, gym, volleyball court, etc.)  From my experiences, work-life balance really depends on the person; if you let yourself work 60 hour weeks people will rely on you to do so. If you want to be out at 5pm every day and not pick up your laptop at home, that seems to be accepted as well. Your performance review may not be off the charts, but that balance is an option.
cons:
Intel is not necessarily a "fun" place to work; I'd estimate the average employee to be in their late 30's\early 40's. 

In my product related group, there's a sizeable ramp time before you feel like you're contributing in a meaningful way.

Being such a large company, you may spend days trying to track down the person who owns a particular piece of information vital to your job.

review_title: Typical Big Tech Pros and Cons
pros: Cutting edge technology and innovation -- the company really does touch billions of lives through its tech.  Super smart, super helpful people all around.  Lots of incredible benefits if you take advantage of them.  The longer you are here, the easier it is to see opportunities that you can develop into.  Leading in diversity efforts and corporate social responsibility.
cons: Large company -- you can get lost or stepped on if you are not a self-starter or go-getter.  Tech company that is trying to catch hold of growing markets.  That's exciting, but like in any tech company, it comes with a lot of re-orgs and interrupted career paths.  Older company with many people who have worked here for decades - feels hierarchical.

review_title: Construction Project Manager
job_title: Construction Project Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Great company overall! 
Brand name, very unique/challenging projects, Flexible schedule, work/life balance, amenities, corporate culture (relaxed),  diversity (low/mid level), technology and benefits (education, health, time off etc...)
cons:
Low Base salary (yearly raises are very small), very limited growth opportunities, too many redundant meetings, unclear/not transparent focal review process, some decisions are made by senior leaders without getting any input from the tactical team, not much diversity at the senior leadership level.
Some managers aren't good leaders, do not inform expectations, frequent performance feedback which has led to a climate of mistrust. Document everything!
No grade level adjustment review process for employees to obtain post graduate advanced degrees or certifications related to their field. Basically means a new hire with the same profile will be placed at a higher grade.

review_title: Way behind in technology
pros: Stable job, decent pay, multiple locations to pick from, interesting type of work.
cons: IT department is Intel's weakest link and IT's incompetency is dragging the whole company down. We are supposed to be developing cutting edge technology while we are given ancient computers that break all the time. Many people I know can't even do their jobs because they have to deal with computer problems on daily basis. On a given 40-hour week, I spend easily 10-12 hours dealing with computer issues because Intel is too cheap to give me a properly functioning computer. I honestly stopped caring long time ago. All IT department ever does is to send spyware and bloated software to our computers which makes our computers even slower and clumsier. It's impossible to develop cutting edge technology when you work with computers and tools that are clumsy, slow and buggy.

review_title: A Great Place To Work
pros:
I was working at Intel GDC at Mexico.

The great things about Intel GDC:
- Healthcare Benefits
- Paid Vacation time and Medical Leave
- Paid Maternity Leave
- You can change your role or change group or organization within a Year inside Intel
- Lots of free courses about multiple languages and roles
- Human approach
- Free fruit and juice at the cafeteria
- Cafeteria on site
- Free and well equipped Gym on site
- Massage, Dental Care and Nursing on site
- Various activities and after-work groups
- Payslip Bonuses 
- Intel offers Bus Shuttle for most parts of the city
cons:
- Some of the methodologies their are using are very old
- Knowledge sharing within higher grades and lower grades its almost impossible
- The "No Retaliation" policy its not always true (depending of the person you had the issue with)
- The pay is not very competitive, its just average or little below the average
- The interview process can last more than a month sometimes
- The Site its very far from many bus routes (but the shuttle its an option)
- They really dont try to retain talent

review_title: Good company
pros: A Good work place. Lots of innovation and exposure to new technologies. Industry leading technical leadership. Best open door policy. Good work life balance and good benefits. Senior management is caring and open abt communications. frequent layoffs and reacting to downturns in economy is troubling, our company stock shows no momentum and thats a worry from both the financial sense and from a job security sense. investing in new tech very risky. frequent layoffs and reacting to downturns in economy is troubling, our company stock shows no momentum and thats a worry from both the financial sense and from a job security sense. investing in new tech very risky.
cons: frequent layoffs and reacting to downturns in economy is troubling, our company stock shows no momentum and thats a worry from both the financial sense and from a job security sense. investing in new tech very risky.

review_title: Good Company with too much organizational chaos
pros:
Friendly encouraging environment - Corporate Services is excellent
Good salary
Excellent technical work
People are friendly to work with
Really a GPTW in some aspects - team building/quarterly etc.,
Excellent work culture especially for women
cons:
Too much deadline stress -sometimes weekly deadlines
Too many organizational changes - one week a team/org is called by one name and the next week that is called by some other name
Need time to focus on actual work more rather than reporting in terms of weeklies/biweeklies/monthlies etc.,
Many dotted line managers in addition to one direct manager and who all exercise equal importance over your focal appraisal - and also they are located around different parts of the world - they have no clue as to what you work hands on.

review_title: Intel needs to inspire people to save the world
pros: There are so many opportunities if you are interested in career growth, especially with the company being worldwide and having many divisions.  Intel is in every industry it seems. There is so much potential for innovation.
cons: A lot of bureaucracy.  If you want to get anything done, you need to know the right people that aren't afraid to make a decision. Too my CYA inside, rather than all standing together for the same cause and move forward.  Because there's been layoffs in the news, its created more fear in the system, causing people to be more defensive of what they are doing - this causes overlap and unncessary tension between organizations.

review_title: Product Marketing Engineer
job_title: Product Marketing Engineer in Gig Harbor, WA
pros: Best benefits in the business.  You don't see how good the benefits are until you leave the company.  Generally speaking, the pay is better at Intel.  This isn't always the case but appears to be so right now in early 2016.  Intel has a LOT of very smart people.  Compared to other companies where I've worked, there are very few employees who don't pull their weight.
cons: Having a lot of smart people means that to be average at Intel you have to be one of the best and brightest in the general population outside of Intel.  Annual performance reviews are TOUGH.  A certain percentage of employees have to receive poor performance appraisals.  A poor performance review is the first step toward the door.  The company asks a lot of it's employees.  It's the employee's job to draw the line and say, "I've got enough on my plate, I can't take any more."  Most people can't say that and as a result most people are overworked and are in some state of burning out.

review_title: Equipment Module Team Technician
job_title: Equipment Module Technician/Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: Good to above average pay. Great benefits. Sabbaticals every 4 years (1 month) and 7 years (2 months). Great people who are experts in the semiconductor field, some of the best in the industry.
cons: Unrealistic goals. Lack of respect for people exists, which is different at different locations. Rank and rating process is an unfair process and needs to be revised. Really take a look at how many people are working 60-80 hours in a week and sacrificing their family life, just to stay afloat at work due to unrealistic workloads.

review_title: What is your Strategic Vision?
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great Benefits, Work Life Balance (Depending on the group you work in), Free Fruit and Beverages.
cons: Intel is a place with diverse experience groups. I've been at 7 different groups during my 10+ years at Intel, there are (were) groups with experienced people who knew what to do, some groups are meticulous to the T on business process development where much time and energy is spent on creating a business process just to see that the business priority changes as soon as the business process is developed, some groups give you a wild wild west experience. The company is Middle Management Heavy, seems as if nothing was learnt after the not so recent past SET changes. Keeping a flat management structure with a better employee rating process would really help in improving the conditions for the company.

review_title: Intel honest review
pros: Intel has excellent benefits including very nice bonuses based on performance. Honestly Intel pays very well compared to the industry. Great company to gain experience and education. Excellent opportunities and easy to join the company if you are new collage grads.
cons: Company has a lot of down turns which initiate layoffs especially for workers that have been working for the company 15+ years, even if you have had all successful reviews. The annual review process is cumbersome and needs a major upgrade to the process. Part of the annual reward process gives you stock options which don't really measure up to much anymore. The new GPTW new cubicle environment does not work well at all. Upper management makes decisions changing the way people have to perform work and take little to no feedback from the workers that have to follow the process. Work life balance used to be one of the best in the industry however that has changed over the years especially since most people are expected to do the work of 2-3 people after people are let go.

review_title: Smartest People I've Worked With
job_title: Director of Engineering in Portland, OR
pros: Great place to spread your wings and test your limits. You will always find multiple people smarter than yourself or a group to work with that shares your common interests or directions. There is a very high value on strategic competency, and with that comes incredible autonomy. With the appointment to lead a problem solving team often comes an open checkbook and the awesome responsibility that entails.
cons: As with academic environments, you put a bunch of really smart people in a room and there is often debate, sometimes too much debate unless there is a strong leader who can implement clear processes. Easier said than done. The overhead for managers to lead multi-geography teams for either projects or management structure is overwhelming and from what I've seen continues to be a major stumbling block to execution efficiency. Constant iteration of business plans, because there is staffing to do so in Marketing/Planning is a heavy burden compared to other companies, to the technical staffs.

review_title: Intel overall is a good place to work.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Intel upper management has tried hard the last couple of years to genuinely listen to and act upon employee concerns and suggestions. Things do seem to be changing for the better since the previous downsizing in an attempt to create a leaner and faster responding company. Intel also has some really good benefits in addition to competitive salaries.
cons:
Intel is a large company and as such suffers some of the same politic type issues that all large companies seem to share. Although management is trying to streamline processes, it is fairly slow to implement them, although it is happening slowly.
Sometimes I think that Intel is relying too much on certain types engineering job functions offshore. This leads to some awkward meeting times as well as some quality issues that could have been avoided by doing the functions locally.

review_title: Great Company For Those Looking for Stability and Structure
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: Loved the free coffee and fruit, as well as the Corporate Shuttle that made it easier to collaborate with team mates.  High integrity, strong values and great people.  Most people at Intel are "lifers" and enjoy great benefits and perks.  For example, President Obama visited the Intel campus and I won the lottery so that I could attend and see POTUS in action.  Very cool.
cons: Difficult to see your ideas implemented, since there are nearly 100,000 people seeking to have their ideas implemented, and can be easy to feel stifled.  Leadership bench and leadership team is average to weak, except for a sprinkling of true star performers throughout the company.

review_title: It's the Best Place to Work for All Generations!
pros: Open Atmosphere, Great Place to work for all generations including Millennials, Work From Home options, benefits are as good as they come, Free air plane shuttle to ride between 3 US states, C-level officers are approachable available  and they make time for their employees, access to tremendously smart people, working "smart" is rewarded, rotations and cross company movement is encouraged, free tickets to football / basketball/ baseball / theater shows / family events etc. , big time bonuses, diversity and gender equality efforts, leader in green technology, largest manufacturer in the United States, sabbaticals every 4 years of 4 weeks or 7 years of 8 weeks, 10 paid holidays, 3 weeks paid vacation which jumps to 4 weeks after 10 years, very easy to have a 20 year career here, total compensation high, internal social networking platforms, volunteering during the day is encouraged, education reimbursement nearly $50,000
cons:
-Base Salary is average
-Difficult to get into management
-Different business units have different cultures

review_title: Treading water
pros: Intel has a great foundation in its core businesses that bring in substantial revenue at great margins.  It also has a very deep talent pool of people who are passionate about and dedicated to the work that they do.  The compensation is very good as well.
cons: Intel has been treading water for a long time, trying to get into break into new markets and then achieve similar margins to those it has in the client and server CPU space.  To date, success has been very limited.  In my observations from a long career there, I just don't think that the current management has the know-how to drive substantial increases in revenue.  I do, however, believe that the company is somewhat vulnerable to a downturn in the market or a competitive threat who is seeking to get a share of the lucrative server market.  Intel just laid off 11% of the workforce or 12000 people during a time when revenue is largely flat.  If they experience a decrease in revenue, I expect things will get much worse regarding layoffs.

review_title: Diversity is Job #1
pros:
- Good pay/benefits (except dental coverage)
- Smart engineers and technicians that care about quality
- Manufacturing processes and capabilities are world class
- Good work/life balance in many departments. Generally supportive of single parent needs
cons:
- Improving URM (Under Represented Minorities) ratios is absolutely Job #1. All other company goals and strategies (including shareholder value) are way down the list. This impacts everything from promotions, to hiring practices, to who gets laid off, to business unit performance expectations. 
- Support orgs like Corporate Services (facilities) and IT are a mess. The arrogance and hubris of the senior leadership in these two groups is stunning. Senior leaders act more like little dictators protecting their fiefdoms rather than coaches and mentors. 
- The HR Department is really the HR Legal Department. All HR policies and decisions are guided by what is legally defensible in court. The real goal/purpose of Intel HR is litigation avoidance, not "Human Resources".

review_title: So much convenience and yet so much unnecessity
pros: Benefit is one of the best if not the best, got daily fruits some more. Half year and year end bonus, medical checkup, birthday, gym, inter building shuttle vans and buses and many more. So flexible as well - flexi time, flexi payroll bank, this and that. And you have lots of vendor and expert like feng shui master  visiting the company too add fun / value for your working day.
cons: Intel unfortunately overdo many things. There are so many things that could be simplified.There are $2K+ large posters at buildings and it's renewed  every few years in every buildings!  multiple feedback on Manager performance, employee, or peer  "360" feedback every year. Also peer audit, Internal Audit, and external consultant audit for some of the control. Also compulsory course to remind you to be honest and a lots more training just to look beautiful at hours spent management report.

review_title: Lots of good and lots of bad to consider
pros: Bleeding edge company, fast paced, crazy great opportunities if you are willing to work hard and get a job that leverages your talent.  Work hard, be a good obedient beast of burden and you could go really far here till Moore's Law ends or Intel changes!
