cons: Strong cultural, have to come as a new college graduate, research carefully as the layoffs really focused on older, successful people.  They like young bucks that work hard, listen and adapt to the strong cultural.  It is the intel way or the highway.   The larger business x86 is in contraction and management still hasn't been successful in finding new areas of growth.  If they don' find new growth areas there will be more reductions at the company so consider that if you join!

review_title: Too many meetings, re-org every year (almost), work life imbalance
pros: Strong team culture  but this too can be hampered by too many re-organization of org structures almost every year.
cons:
Too many levels of org structure causing the need for many updates meeting (day & night) for stakeholders to "buy-in" and understand the progress.  This causes lengthy decision-making process and slows down progress.

Emails are used like IMs and you are expected to reply soon as you can causing backlogs of emails if you dont keep up.  

With every new management  change, new slogans and re-org strategies are deployed without fully understanding the implication on the  business impact and work process.  When asked the managements for updates on their next move, the standard answers given were - it is  WIP and we dont have the answer yet for now.

Simply difficult to maintain work-life balance due to demand of work requiring you to jump into meetings as & when needed , and that could mean  early morning , throughout the day and then later in the night.

review_title: Not what it used to be...
pros: Large company with it's fingers in pretty much every technology.  Some groups can be very fun/exciting to work in some can be down right dreadful.  If you enjoy politics and games then this may be the place for you.  It's very easy to move from group to group with-in the company.  Great place for junior engineers to get started and learn a variety of technologies.
cons: Serious disconnect between upper/lower management.  Upper wants more risk taking and collaboration.  Lower wants no risk, perfection from software deliveries and turf warfare.  Every year it's "do more with even less" until Engineers hit a breaking point and leave groups, which just exasperates problems.  The domino effect is very real when this happens and it can be difficult if you are the last person standing.

review_title: Not what it used to be...
pros: Large company with it's fingers in pretty much every technology.  Some groups can be very fun/exciting to work in some can be down right dreadful.  If you enjoy politics and games then this may be the place for you.  It's very easy to move from group to group with-in the company.  Great place for junior engineers to get started and learn a variety of technologies.
cons: Serious disconnect between upper/lower management.  Upper wants more risk taking and collaboration.  Lower wants no risk, perfection from software deliveries and turf warfare.  Every year it's "do more with even less" until Engineers hit a breaking point and leave groups, which just exasperates problems.  The domino effect is very real when this happens and it can be difficult if you are the last person standing.

review_title: Broken Culture = Broken Company
pros:
Intel is still a virtual monopoly in PCs and servers
Massive company with massive resources and political clout
cons:
The company has lost its cultural and strategic footing.  Former CEO BK was as clueless as he was immoral and left the company with loads of debt from seemingly random acquisitions, hundreds of mostly useless yes men and women VPs and a middle management layer that progressed because of political instead of technical acumen.  Oh and 10nm is still late.
The loyalty that many employees once felt to Intel is mostly gone.  Replaced by H1Bs, 26-year-old Bain Consultants and Powerpoint jockeys.  Intel culturally doesn't know how to innovate, work with partners or serve customers.  It's just going through the motions and using its political clout until the inevitable and its monopolies are no more.
Oh yeah and the free fruit and drinks aren't at all campuses anymore!

review_title: Treats employees well but reorgs and layoffs create lots of uncertainty
pros: Egalitarian, tries to focus on being a great place to work, lots of established channels for communication through the ranks.  Great benefits - hard to match them elsewhere.  Two-month paid sabbatical every seven years is a wonderful benefit.  Managers have lots of discretion so it's great if you have a good manager who is creative about effective management techniques and supportive of your efforts.  You own your own employability so responsibility is on the employee to make things happen and to be accountable, which is equitable and fair.
cons: Lots of reorganizations.  Some people have had as many as 4 or 5 different managers within a 1-2 year time span.  Rolling layoffs over the last couple of years have created uncertainty and angst.  Stock performance has not been good so the days of having valuable stock options appear to be gone.

review_title: Feel free to pull your head out anytime now, and TRY to use some common sense!
pros: We build some very good products, so for a manufacturing company there is relative stability.
cons:
Over worked if you are a factory worker.  I work three times harder now then I did 15-20 years ago, and I make less money adjusted for inflation.  That's without factoring in rising gas prices!
Intel doesn't believe in giving cost of living increases.  That's okay if you're senior management and already making an excellent wage with nice perks to boot.

review_title: Great people with many senior political managers without a clue about the right thing to do to keep people motivated
pros: Intel has always had great talent where people work hard. Most organizations have created a good team environment, with flexibility to help with work-life balance.
cons: Over the past 5 years (despite making billions per quarter in net profit), Intel continues to allow upper management to make decions for short-term gain. Senior HR managers at the top of the list are the ones that need a wake-up call. Many of the great people that were there that wanted to stay have left. Sad to see what was one of the best working environments in the world, which Andy Grove created, to be marginalized by ass-covering, non-risk taking drone managers.

review_title: Great benefits and opportunities with an enjoyable and rewarding culture
job_title: Systems Validation Engineer in Hudson, MA
pros: Competitive pay, strong benefits, quarterly team events, lots of opportunity for growth and advancement. You get a sense of pride when you see the products you worked on being demanded by your friends and family. Very flexible in terms of working from home, vacation and sick time. The yearly feedback process is constructive and fair, providing employees with the knowledge they need to actually advance their careers, rather than simply punish them for not performing.
cons: Work comes in waves, some months it will be slow, others will be very intense (this obviously depends on where in the company you work). Legacy reuse tends to cause a lot of headaches.

review_title: Get a job at Intel if you want to work on silicon, but stay away from the groups that try to design systems.
job_title: Senior Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Very large corporation.  You'll never loose your job, even if you sit and watch movies at your desk.  Good work life balance if you don't care about advancement.  Relatively good job mobility within the company.  Travel budget is semi-infinite.  New CEO was a good choice because his background suggests he'll focus on architecture and manufacturing.
cons: Very political.  The groups that design tablets, phones, laptops, desktops, etc. think they are doing a bunch of work at the companies that actually make these devices actually do.  If the job says "platform" in the title, watch out.  Very hard to advance in the org unless you are connected and have the right friends. Intel Values are touted as important but basically ignored (and I've worked in places where the values actually guide the company).

review_title: Good pay and respect their employees
pros: Compared to other high tech companies which can be sweatshops, Intel affords a reasonable work-life balance.  Yes, there are insane jobs (because people choose to make them that way) ... but on the whole, I'm personally very satisfied with the work-life balance and ability to learn new things even after 20 years at the company.
cons: Intel really goes out of its way to retain its employees, but sometimes that means it places people without the right qualifications to drive successful businesses in a brutally high paced, globally competitive marketplace.

review_title: Great Place to Work. Just do not be blind to the fact that bad things happen everywhere...
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, San Jose
pros: Most people you work with are true professionals, who work hard and play hard. High Leadership is truly committed to the company goals and to keep an open work environment that fosters career growth and keep company leadership status. Your career can be as diverse as you may want. Great time flexibility.
cons: No succession pipelines means that you really need to figure out a career path in a place that can be a maze of alternatives and opportunities. The lack of structure may make your growth more in fits and starts than a continuous process.

review_title: Great place to work - rewards its long-time employees and gives graduates/interns an amazing start to their career.
job_title: Customer Business Analyst in Swindon, England
pros:
Middle management and upwards has some commercially strong, intelligent managers. Good to work for and great to learn from.

"Great Place to Work" initiatives are great for staff buy-in and loyalty.

Generally happy to promote from within.

Benefits are top-notch.

Flexibility with working from home etc., is brilliant.
cons:
Often difficult to map out a career path although good support offered if you can see your next step.

Middle and Senior management is great, first-line management made up of some shockingly poor choices.

Could do with some more rotations to avoid feeling "stuck."

review_title: Intel is a better place for talkers than for doers.
job_title: Senior Staff Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: For a technology company Intel is a stable place to work.  Intel has very good benefits.
cons:
The culture seems to promote talking over doing.  Where I worked there were about 5 man hours of talking for every man hour of engineering execution.
 The review process is like a bet episode of "Survivor".  Employees are pitted against each other in a zero sum game.  You are rated by people who have no idea what you are responsible for.  The way to get good reviews is to attend a lot of meetings and say things that are seen as "Impactfull".
  The HR department seems to just be a web site without any humans.  The HR department is like Dell Technical support -- but without the call center.

review_title: Senior Process Engineer at RA3/4
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Decent place for fresh college graduates to begin their careers
Great pay and benefits
Get to work with top notch engineers
cons:
If you're not a fresh college graduate willing to sacrifice your quality of life and soul for a few years of work experience, please look elsewhere.
No work life balance
Discussions regarding career development with manager were non existent
Hoards of people leaving with few/none hired to replace them. Extra work is piled on engineers left behind with no pay increase
Culture of individual achievement vs teamwork breeds a toxic culture of everyone for themselves. This really interferes with team dynamics and project allocation as everyone fights to survive the next round of layoffs
Semiconductor industry is currently very competitive and unforgiving to big companies like Intel that are slow to implement changes to counter competition from companies like global foundries, Samsung, TSMC.

review_title: A good place to begin your career, just don't get stuck there.
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Fairly easy to get in.
Good healthcare and retirement benefits.
cons:
As happens with many large companies, the structure is very bureaucratic, and relevant information is disseminated (or not) very slowly.
Many incompetent managers who know very little about how to effectively manage teams and provide career guidance.
Unfair review system which other users have mentioned.
There are a certain set of people who are deemed star performers and always make it to the top 10% of the raking and therefore handed a higher salary and stocks.  Again, as other users have said, a lot of this depends on the perception you create rather than the actual work you do.
You also get penalized in the focal process for switching to a different group midyear and being ranked with longtime members of the new group.

review_title: Not at all a technical company anymore!
pros:
Employee friendly
Lots of goodies
Good work life balance
cons:
If you are looking for a technical software job, this is not the company anymore. You will get service company like jobs like fixing static code analysis issues, legacy bug fixing etc. Typical of an MNC, where US and EU employees get to do the important work whereas India is seen as a maintenance center only.

 Zero onsite opportunities.

Any paper or presentation opportunities are few and far between and mostly gets cancelled by your managers.

Managers have 0 roadmap and you are left in the dark about the future. Have worked in 2 business divisions, one of which thankfully closed and the other called IOTG is worse than a service company. 
Few managers in IOTG even openly discourage you from attending traingings, presenting or publishing papers and patents. 

Come with very very low technical expectations if you are in software.

review_title: Intel admits to losing female engineers at a high rate, but won't address hostile work environment issues
job_title: Senior Quality Engineer in Hudson, MA
pros:
Intel is a very large corporation, and even if your division is eliminated, it would probably be possible to find another position within the company if desired.

It is possible to work from home when necessary.
cons: Innovation is suppressed and resisted; the "copy exactly" philosophy applies to almost all engineering work.  The organizations are suspicious of one another and do not collaborate.  Intel management cultivates a blame-oriented culture.  Political battles can destroy the career of even a low level engineer.  Hostility toward female engineers is accepted; especially those that introduce new ideas and change.  Lower level managers do not act when a female is targetted by sexist treatment.  Vulgar, demeaning comments and vicious, unfair criticism during presentations in large meetings are tolerated, and even participated in by managers.  If a complaint is lodged, HR completely supports management without doing a proper investigation.  Co-workers are allowed to review each other, and a good, productive engineer can have their future compromised by jealous co-workers.

review_title: Results oriented
pros: Work with excellent people who will challenge you.  Results oriented and focused on the key mission.    Develops employees into project leaders and continuous improvement
cons: If you're not passionate about what you do, or understand what skills you love to work with, and know how to adapt them to this environment, you will burn out.  This is a large technology company that focuses on engineering and manufacturing microprocessors.  Every job needs to directly or indirectly support that mission.  Like other large corporations, Intel has its share of challenges, and it's working through & despite those challenges to succeed at your job that can derail a career focus.  Know what you bring to the table and demand to be recognized for it.

review_title: Solid company to grow in but behind the curve in many ways
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Jerusalem, Jerusalem
pros:
- Good benefits.
- Job security
- Big company - many career paths and technologies to learn.
- Reasonable work/life balance compared to others
- If you are from a non-US location, good opportunities for relocation assignments.
cons:
- For SW engineers, it is far from the best place to be. Intel is a leader in HW and manufacturing process but has a lot to improve in SW practices and services.
- Disconnected from the end user.
- Slow to react to industry trends.
- For some people it is the "government job of the Hi Tech industry"
- Working in a non-US location can be at times frustrating as for some parts of the company all decisions are made by US managers.

review_title: A Lot to Like, But...
pros:
An impressive collection of very smart, driven  people who build some of the most advanced and complicated products on the planet. The sabbatical is an amazing benefit (8 weeks of paid time off every seven years). 

The company is currently executing well in a market environment where the sand is still shifting under our feet.

Good compensation and benefits, including their generous tuition reimbursement program that paid for two-thirds of my master's degree.
cons: Company is going through a cultural overhaul, and while words like "velocity" get thrown around a lot, decision-making is still VERY bureaucratic with seemingly endless reviews, stakeholder management, and excessive cat-herding. The same decisions (and all the prep/process that goes with them) are sometimes made several times. Very few opportunities to meaningfully advance a career if you're based in Santa Clara. Lots of lip service paid to "careers" at Intel, but mostly winds up being lateral moves from job to job.

review_title: IT professional
job_title: Technical Project Manager in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Good pay and benefits.  Superior technologists as peers, smartest people in the world.  Engaging work and great company values.  Career opportunities exist for those who are self-starters, want to exceed expectations every year, and who live in the right geographies.  Very rewarding and engaging work, great management team below GM in my team.
cons: IT site strategy ("co-located teams are more effective") has caused numerous people to relocate, and even then some were not retained.  Many IT jobs are not collaborative (project teams are spread across entire regions).  Forcing organizations to locate in just a few cities has caused congestion and impacted many lives.  Executive management is difficult to read, and their decisions don't always seem to make sense or align with the company values that the rest of us live by.

review_title: I have not found another company as amazing as Intel till date
pros:
Job security- they shut down a group with 3000 people in our site, but handled the situation so well that many got internal placements, some left on their own and all is well now.

Growth - Appraisal cycle is present every year and talent is fairly appreciated.

Work life balance - goes up and down like any other company, but good overall.

Opportunity- if you find a better team or you do not like the current team, you can change it after completing 1 year in the current team.

Facilities - There is amazing transport facility at multiple timings to all corners of Bengaluru
Gym, Yoga, Games, free cool drinks, they give u a fruit everyday.
cons:
Cons of intel are cons of any organisation

Like-
Some teams might not have good work
You might not get a decent manager, but who cares, you can always switch to a different team.

review_title: Intel, rapidly moving at the speed of a slug!
job_title: Staff Hardware Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Very competitive high tech environment. Lots of opportunity for those new to the industry to learn.
cons: Dog-eat-dog world... too many management layers. Although meritocrisy is always talked about, the rules only allow 10~15% of employees to get a promotion. In the last several years, the average rate of salary increase has been below the inflation rate, less than 5%!

review_title: Infrastructure Engineer from manufacturing
pros: Decent Pay with average benefits and vacation days. Flexible work schedule and the ability to work from home. Restricted stock units if you perform well.
cons: Working in the operational side of manufacturing, be prepared to WORK and put in long hours. I was on-call for the factory every 4 weeks or so for a week at a time. Had to work just about every holiday to support changes in the factory. Nobody outside the infrastructure  group really understands what you do (other than support everything that's on the network) so it's a very thankless job.

review_title: Admin
pros: Great benefits and on-site facilities (gym, doctor, physio, bank, etc.  Good work/life balance.  Fast paced environment with plenty of career and growth opportunities for exempt level employees.  Volunteering in the community is encouraged and supported.  Paid sabbatical.  Great  place to work if you're happy to remain an Admin Asst throughout your time there.
cons: Incredibly difficult to get out of the Admin role (regardless of level of education or experience).  Expect a long uphill battle if you want to move to a different role (and it still may not happen).  The r&r of the Intel Admin has changed and the scope has increased dramatically, particularly with all the layoffs that have occurred over the last few years (with admins picking up the slack),  however, perceptions and compensation have not.

review_title: Intel can be great if some changes are made.
pros: There is a lot of good lateral movement opportunities (especially when you are dissatisfied with your own job).  Good pay and benefits overall, although can't speak for all jobs.  Lots of good managers within the company and very good direction overall.
cons: Upper management has some serious work to build trust with employees again.  With cuts and some questionable movements into new areas while discounting other more lucrative areas, sometimes it is hard to trust what is going on at the highest levels.  The review process pits employees against each other, which creates an adversarial environment.  Also, it's not always the person who does the best job but the person who is able to do show he does the best job instead.

review_title: Intel - Great Place to Work-if you want a government job, with a private firm payscale. No new-tech learning here
pros: Great Work-Life Balance, Decent payscale, Pressure & Learning varies greatly across orgs
cons:
Very Low-morale subsidiary, with clear lacking of leadership & direction. Seen mostly as a low-cost, outsourced site, for shipping off low-grade projects that the US Groups are too bored to work on. Existence of satraps, by the blessings of their US masters, who run some orgs as high-school disciplinary entities. Few employees dare to utilize the great 'open & direct' culture of intel, fearing well-placed fear of retaliation.  

A coterie of senior management (Indians who worked in Intel US for 10+ years, and wanted to return home with a promotion) are allied together, who, for the benefit of making their jobs easier/hassle-free stomp down on brilliant employees with genuine ideas that would help the company. This coterie are greatly harming Intel India.

review_title: Excellent Company to work for!
pros: Intel has outstanding benefits (including bonuses, which is amazing these days!) and normally has LOTS of opportunity for advancement o tor make latteral moves into new jobs/areas. You will work with a lot of highly intelligent folks and will be challenged like never before...but I guess that's how you become the best in the world at what you do?!!
cons: Salaried employees are expected to work a lot - the mantra goes "whatever it takes to get the job done". Also, I was quite shocked, as were many of my co-workers, when I was identified as one of the employees who was selected for "redeployment" (Which is Intel speak for "Laid off") after 12 years of dedicated service.

review_title: Inhale and Exhale
job_title: Senior Firmware Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great pay, great bonuses, mostly good people.  Lots of projects, lots of groups.  Company has A LOT of cash to do things like fly you to other states for meetings on the corporate jets.
cons: Hiring boom, followed by layoff boom.  Lather, rinse, repeat.  BE VERY CAREFUL with your career.  Everything your manager says about you is noted, and when the layoffs come, 1 simple comment from you manager can make the difference between you being on the street, or having continued employment.

review_title: Not a meritocracy driven place
job_title: Software Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Still have some smart and hardworking engineers left.

Can choose a work-life balance path if that's what you are looking for. 

Good for immigration paperwork and filing. Very timely and streamlined system as far as immigration paperwork goes. Much of the credit is due to to Fragomen.
cons:
Too many people managers, program managers and miscellaneous task trackers who do not contribute anything. However they set up meetings and other useless unproductive tasks and waste people's time.

Company makes arbitrary rules every year to find a way to financially shortchange employees. 

Very tight fisted with raises. Sub par compensation.

I am not privy to internal policies but it does seem like women are unduly favored.

Lots of layers of fat that have been cruising for decades.

Penny wise and pound foolish management. Fly multiple planes from site to site every day for carrying useless managers to attend meetings, however will not provide dinner to engineers working late at night week after week.

review_title: Intel has really deteriorated over the years
pros: Intel used to to work you you hard and pay you well with stock options and parties/events. You worked with creative people in a diverse environment  You could take risks and be rewarded.  The benefits were good and there was a sense of camaraderie..... It used to energizing to work there.
cons: In the last 7-8 years, probably 70-80% of all new hires have been Indian. It drove down the wages, the bonuses and destroyed the work culture. Not that they are bad people in any sense, but they overwhelmed the culture.  Gone is the work ethic and self starters.  Intel used to be diverse, now it is not.  It is heavy into diversity as long as that diversity doesn't include grey haired white people.  People don't trust management anymore

review_title: Intel observations
job_title: RF Embedded Systems Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Intel is a great Multinational company with a variety of businesses.  The processor business and server groups are the big money makers for the company.  The benefits and compensation are generous.  There are many on site facilities (my experience is Chandler AZ) that allow to the employee to get things done that would normally require the employee to leave work.  Examples are a fitness center and outdoor recreational areas.  The is on site medical, dental, optometry, etc
cons: Intel is a very big company with big company issues.  Most projects are done over multiple sites.  This means that there is a lot of travel and early/late phone calls.  You need to work a lot of hours to get things done and do a lot of coordination

review_title: Marketing Director
pros: Strong culture of success. Well compensated. Good benefits that keep improving. Broad management and employee training program. Committed employees who do what they say they will do on projects and teams.
cons: Harsh and hard driving culture. Growing scarcity mentality increases competition among teams and peers. Continually increasing expectations of performance make it difficult to feel successful for more than a moment. Expectation to work nights, weekends and vacations as common practice makes work life balance a bit tricky. Big swing to hire from outside at senior levels beginning to create "us" vs "them" culture which is very damaging, especially in marketing!! Seems to have lost a bit of its soul in recent years.

review_title: Boring, stable, good W/L balance
job_title: Program Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: People move around a lot. You'll often run into people who have worked at Intel 10+ years and have a new role every 3 years. Most managers understand that you have a life and enable it. The product and the work aren't sexy, but they're stable. It's a 30 year old company, but they do evolve to stay on top. Time off isn't great, but your schedule is usually flexible. Pay is fine, it's low for tech, high for manufacturing. Of course you'll spend half your salary on housing if you're in the Santa Clara office.
cons: Boring. Slow moving if you want to make change and you have to get 8 stakeholders on board plus a few managers. Very technical, they have their own language that take a while to learn.  Pay isn't great for silicon valley/tech.

review_title: Good in the short term, but lacking long term direction
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Chandler, AZ
pros: Good benefits, especially when compared to the local market in Arizona instead of other tech companies.
cons: A constant sense of dread. Being paranoid is a good thing sometimes in business, but at Intel I think it has crossed over the line into feeling like something is really going wrong. The technology problems, market changes, ruthless competition, it all adds up and sometimes driving past the old Motorola plant on the way to the office you can’t help but feel like this is what it must have felt like there before they gave up the ghost too.

review_title: Crushing bureaucracy
job_title: Systems Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Very little, everything is offset but horrific bureaucracy and lack of accountability.
cons:
Most corporate operations groups range from utterly useless to straightforward malicious. 
* Building management ignores requests for adequate air conditioning where everyone is forced to wear sweaters. When you look up hundreds of similar requests in the system from different employees which were ignored, they start running around checking things out, in the end not doing anything to resolve the situation.
* Trying to put your group's product online using company network is virtually impossible, as they will demand insurmountable amount of documentation, dragging the whole process for months, finally denying your request. Save yourself time and heartbreak, and go with "shadow" IT hosting like AWS.
* Part of IT support and certain operations are based offshore with totally clueless and lazy personnel, who will ignore your requests to save your data, until it passes the expiration date and becomes unrecoverable.
* Open space office surrounded by conference rooms and phone booths where people yell on top of their lungs all day, making your workday miserable.

review_title: Intel a very challenging work environment
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Intel hires the best and the brightest.  You work with some of the greatest minds in the industry.  Intel always pushes the envelope.  The work is cutting edge.  It's always difficult but rewarding technical problem solving.  It's a fantastic environment for techincal challenges.  There is a lot of teamwork and information sharing.  You always learn something new and interesting.  Intel is a huge company and you have great opportunity to try new roles in different areas.  It's hard to get bored with your job.
cons: You work a lot of hours.  There is continual pressure to produce more results, take on increased level of responsibility.  As a technical female, I find the coporate culture to be very male oriented.  That being said, I am never disrespected for my gender.

review_title: 1 year in, happy with my job
job_title: Senior Process Engineerq in Hillsboro, OR
pros: This is my first real job after getting my PhD, so I don't have much else to compare it to.  I'm also relatively new, having only been here 10 months.  That said: The things I like about the job:  The pay is very good.  Great perks, competent coworkers, challenging work, fun technology.  There is a lot to learn, and a lot of it is very interesting and worthwhile from a basic science and understanding perspective.
cons: The job is very challenging, thus occasionally stressful.  Long hours are expected, and being on-call is as bad as everybody had warned.  There is a steep learning curve for new hires, and high expectations on getting up to speed quickly.  Seemingly endless meetings and often unnecessary training hinder the learning and doing processes.

review_title: You Can Have A Lifetime Career Here
pros:
- Great employment practices at Intel will provide for a well-balanced work/family balanced career.
- Values have glued the company and its employees together for over 4 decades.  Adherence to them will change not only your professional but personal ethics, values and approaches in life.
- Flexibility in the company shows they  understand current work environments from being expected to be in the factories or operational divisions to telecommuting, depending on the job role.
- The Open Door policy allows employees to talk to one another without going through a direct manager to do so.
cons:
- New organizational leadership is going through some churn as expected periodically.  This will shrink and grow organizations.  Out of this will either present opportunities within the company or provide a window to exit.
- Learning engineering acronyms provides a challenge to most new entrants.  Resources are provided to help with that learning.

review_title: Big company, lots of politics.  Success all depends on your team and manager.
job_title: Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Lots of flexibility to work remotely, Ability to move around the company and learn a new job/ discipline but mostly lateral moves, interesting technology and very competitive in the chip space.  Benefits are good and on par with other companies.  Their sabbatical is attractive if you plan on staying with a company for a long time.
cons: Pay is ok if you're outside of the Bay area but not as competitive as other tech companies in the valley.   Not many perks either.  Your success all depends on who you know and work for.  Very political.  Lots of ok talent.  Intel doesn't attract the best in Silicon Valley but if this is your 1st company out of college, go for it.   Very very difficult to move up.  Flat organization.   Too many meetings that are very unproductive.

review_title: Intel is one of the best employers I have worked for so far
pros: Great minds, really intelligent people good at what they do, great benefits and competitive salary, amazing flexibility to each individual to choose what they want - extra work to prove themselves or work-life balance - the company doesn't look down at anyone.. you get what you want..
cons:
Average age of employees is on the higher side, can make things look little dull compared to other companies with employees full of energy and youth.. 
In a company so old, there are always processes for everything, which can make the company very systematic but at the same time very slow in everything they do.. 
Also, due to these processes, promotions are based on tenure rather than your ability.. so one bright chap might get saddled with a manager who became a manager only because of his longer tenure..

review_title: Good place to work with lots of opportunity but also lots of bureaucracy
pros: The company is large enough that you can have multiple jobs and even careers without changing your employer. There are many bright people with good ideas. It is difficult to find other companies where you can have such strong influence over technology in the world and capabilities. The benefits are very thorough along with many small perks that make it a place to be proud of.
cons: As with any large company, there is significant bureaucracy. From both a decision making standpoint as well as work environment, politics tends to be more important that facts, data, and doing things the right way. This can be particularly evident with the generally poor people management.

review_title: DevOps Engineer
pros: Big company.  If you're on the right team you can get the budget you need to succeed.  Being on a campus is like being in a city, just about everything you need is on campus, almost no reason to ever leave.
cons: Feel like a cog in the wheel.  Don't seem really encouraged to stand out.  Bonus is not based on individual performance so the hardest working guy gets the same amount as the slacker.  Pay grade structure is unknown, seems to want specific skills for you to move up, doesn't look at what you bring to the table, what you do for your team, group, company etc.

review_title: Interesting company
pros: Good people, fun place to work. High energy, lots of challenges. Loved my job there up to the last manager.
cons:
Sometimes, the company can focus on making square pegs fit into round holes to the exclusion of common sense. And, as with most companies, one poor manager can break your career.  

Intel is the only company I ever worked for where I received a poor review (an actual written CAP) for "answering people's questions too quickly".  As part of my corrective action plan, I had to STOP answering people when they would ask a question in a meeting or by email, and wait until the end of the day or the next day to provide an answer.  It was felt by my manager that when I responded with an answer too quickly, it made the questioner feel like I wasn't taking them or their question seriously enough. By waiting to answer, I would make them feel they had asked a "difficult" question worthy of research.

review_title: Gender pay gap
pros: Good work life balance,great benefits and great coworkers
cons: Gender pay gaps need to be evaluated more. Although the company has stated it has properly done an internal audit and that they feel that that are at 100% conliance, they are not.  When you have a male counterpart with same experience and no degree making more then $1000 more a month take home than a female with a degree, there is something wrong.

review_title: Far too American
pros: Good pay if on shift. Good Bonus structure. lots of perks. Education assist program. Its a good place to start off your career. Perfect for your first "proper job".Its hard work but enjoyable. To get anywhere you need to be in the Managers good books.
cons: Too American. The intel ditty from the ads constantly playing. You can't get it out of your head. Its brainwashing. Everything is acronyms. Everything called by its American name is very annoying. for instance, calling the "bin" the "trash". Work/ life balance can be tough. If your on shift you will only get a weekend off if your on annual leave. This is the main reason staff turnover is high. Experienced staff will find the culture hard to get used to. Its more suited to new Graduates who don't know what its like to work anywhere else.

review_title: Career growth is questionable
job_title: Senior Process Technical Director Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Overall, it is a great place and Intel is one beast of a corporation where you have potential to grow in very wide variety of areas.
cons: You have opportunities, but is it offering real career growth will vary with individuals. Usually within TMG environment, you get to see your growth profile getting reset  back to square one when you try to opt career/expertise widening within organization and your commitments seldom get recognized. More often than not talents and skills of pretty smart people are not utilized or noticed properly. I have worked with few managers and once you are stuck with a bad manager, pretty much you are done. Upper management prefer to stick with versions of managers and your growth can be stunted by manager issue related Focal yearly appraisals.

review_title: Intel Finance = Career Logjam with very limited growth potential
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Flexible (most groups emphasize a work life balance)
Finance has a rotation program that enables one to rotate to a new role every 18-24 months if interested.
cons:
1) Bureaucracy
2) Intel Finance = career logjam.  It is ok for the first few years but you will soon realize that there is very limited opportunity for advancement to the manager level or above.
3) Intel Finance management = coasting and checked out.  Most of the senior managers at Intel Finance in Arizona have been with the company 15 or 20 years and are just there to collect a paycheck (if you can find them).  Intel has a great sales pitch that they want Type A personalities that want to work hard and advance, but there is a serious disconnect between those they recruit and senior management - many of whom are incompetent & likely could not land a job elsewhere.

review_title: Not for the faint of heart...
pros: Working for the world's largest semiconductor company brought certain pride.  Competitive pay package with Total compensation = base salary + employee bonus + profit sharing + stocks since some high tech companies have scaled back / eliminated employee stocks.  Intel is a good training ground for new college graduates.
cons: "Ranking and Rating" (R&R) aka "Rank and Spank", the annual performance review process, drives the hyper-competitive environment within Intel (not necessary a bad thing).  However the going gets rough when everyone performs but someone has to pad the curve.  So this puts a lot of stress on the employees.  Also information sharing and team work often suffers as a result.  The manager is the only voice representing the employees in a R&R session.  So a person can get the short end of the stick if s/he does not get along with the manager even though the process is supposed to be objective.

review_title: Great Flexibility
pros: Intel has an excellent focus on people, sometimes to a fault.  Work / life balance is actually a priority, and their maternity / paternity benefits are great.  Internal job transfers are fairly easy to come by, allowing a lot of job variety without leaving the company.
cons:
From an operational performance standpoint, the company is not as good as it thinks it is.  It made a great call to convert to microprocessors in 1985, and has maintained an almost accidental performance advantage since then.  Since 50+% margins are basically automatic, even in bad times, the senior management is slow to adopt any real improvement ideas.
Pay has not caught up with the reality of the company's stock performance.  They make an argument about total compensation being great (inclusive of stock options), but since 1999, that argument does not hold water.

review_title: Great opportunities
job_title: Software Engineering Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: A great benefit was the ability to move to different positions and maintain benefits.   It is like I had 4 different careers at Intel with the opportunity to work in different groups and do new things.    I had numerous opportunities for industry training courses to refine and improve skills and ideas.  Wonderful employee opportunities abound at Intel.
cons: Intel is a large corporation. Any large organization has a certain amount of bureaucracy; intel is no exception.

review_title: It was great, and there are still pockets of greatness but I see most areas in decline.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Fundamentally, they make good products and are a world class, stable company.  There are a variety of jobs to do and if you work at it there is plenty of room for professional growth.  The pay is comparable and fair.  There are travel opportunities.
cons: All but the very factory-centric jobs are in decline.  If it's not tied to the immediate bottom line, its turning into a slow-moving bureaucratic company and its getting worse every day.  That makes it difficult to make meaningful changes.  There are expectations of many international late night meetings.  If you don't push back and learn to control it, they will take all the time you will give them.

review_title: It was great, and there are still pockets of greatness but I see most areas in decline.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Fundamentally, they make good products and are a world class, stable company.  There are a variety of jobs to do and if you work at it there is plenty of room for professional growth.  The pay is comparable and fair.  There are travel opportunities.

If you don't push back and learn to control it, they will take all the time you will give them.

review_title: Stay away if you think you're good
job_title: Research Scientist in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Specific to Intel Labs: Good work/life balance. Decent pay
Intel-Specific: Great healthcare. Free coffee. Free fruit.
cons: Company struggling for direction, zero vision (in labs), turf-wars. With the diversity of work we do, we should have found far more opportunities for revenue accretion, which we sadly do not. Very CPU-centric thinking that's killing innovation, and hurting productivity

review_title: Comfort will trap you here
pros: Pretty good pay, great benefits and vacation, flexible working conditions and schedule allowed, lack of micro-management, nice people, looks great on the resume
cons: Uninspiring, stressful, monotony.  People follow stupid inefficient processes just because they were told to, instead of thinking for themselves.  Some co-workers at your same level shouldn't be, and they lack the education/intelligence.  It can be so dry.  You aren't appreciated or recognized very often.  The yearly review process doesn't reward based off of merit, it rewards whether you played the political game well--you are expected to create new tools, processes, or other extra work that isn't even real value-add, just to say you did something extra that year.  There is a lot of obvious favoritism, and you can get ahead if you feel like digging deeper into the BS and swallowing it.  Seniority is often prioritized over actual merit.

review_title: Good place to learn and start a career. Not the employer of choice for the long term.
pros: Intel is a good place to start you career.  You get experience not only in technical matters but also in corporate bureaucracy.  There are interesting problems to work on and plenty of chances to move around (at least when the economy is good).
cons: That pay is below what is expected for the type of work done.  Hours can be long.  Managers don't care how long it takes you to finish your work.  All the managers try to brainwash you in the Intel culture.  Not sure if all parts of that culture is productive.  There can be a lot of red tape to get something done.  There are more meetings than there should be, but that is true for a lot of companies.

review_title: Musical Chairs
pros: Pay and benefits are fine.  It's an OK place to work if you find the right group or get into the right "good old boy" network.  If you find that right place to work, it's very stable.  The right place to work is somewhere not tied to specific projects and tied to a physical place.
cons: Constant "raise the bar" attitude.  Constant downwards pressure on US based headcounts.  There's a constant undercurrent of which group is next to be downsized.  Some 2nd and 3rd level managers are good, the majority are mediocre and stay in place because of the "good old boy network".  The outside job market in the US is lousy and the poor stock performance make it so the mediocre people stay put.

review_title: Intel clearly is a "great place to work"
pros: 8-week sabbaticals every 7 years, free coffee, soda, and fruit; wonderful "perks" like tickets to sporting events or live shows. They pay us well and some of us are lucky enough to work in new, modern workspaces. Plus they have things like foosball tables and message chairs when you need to take a break. Did I mention a corporate jet that all US employees can take?
cons: Intel has a tendency to take over your life; it's a global company and we have peers all across the globe. The means late night or early morning meetings. Travel is not easy, so it can mean some day trips that start at 5am and end at 8pm - though you do get to sleep in your own bed.

review_title: Decent pay, good benefits, but no growth opportunity and no raises.
pros: Pay is good for education level required. Benefits are very good. Sabbatical is a great benefit.
cons: No raises greater than 2.5% in the past 12 years despite multiple years of record revenue. New hires come in at 30-50% higher salary than existing employees. No career advancement opportunity if in Engineering/Manufacturing (transfers out of the department are not allowed). Engineers and technicians are expected to work through their all of their breaks everyday.

review_title: Working at Intel
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Very challenging environment, work with smart people, Reasonable base salary, excellent bonus and profit sharing programs, excellent other perks, good job satisfaction
cons: Office politics has gotten worse over years, sometimes decisions take longer time and can be frustrating, annual focal review process has been complicated but improving

review_title: Still a great place to work
pros: This is a platform company to begin with your career, in which you can dream what you want and might actualize what you dream. The attractiveness for me to work with Intel is the opportunities this company offers to me to get chances to utilize what I learned in school or out and plug into the real work place. Since this is a platform, you can get the chance to integrate different resources across industries. This is a fantastic and lots of fun!
cons: Because the company is huge , employees from remote office cannot get good chance to immerse and experience the core culture or values of such a great company.

review_title: Great Place to Work
pros: Solid total compensation and tremendous benefits.  Only company I know of that still offers a sabbatical program for every employee.  We had significant healthcare costs over the last year and never had to worry about more than the deductible.  Low turnover is a reflection that they treat employees well.  Work/life balance is great in sales, part of the benefit of having only a few thousand salespeople driving $60B in revenue.
cons: Low turnover also means few opportunities to move up and highly skilled people all competing for those positions.  The culture has waned over the years, but the stated values of constructive confrontation, regular 1:1's with your manager, and assumed responsibility are as good as they come.  The CEO actually looks at statistics on the frequency of employees badging in (versus working from home).  T&E budgets have gotten ridiculously tight since he came into the role.

review_title: Top heavy
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Hudson, MA
pros: Salary, benefits, flexible work hours, location outside Boston
cons: Long list of people waiting for promotion.  Very senior, top-heavy organisation.  Constant feeling that the group will be downsized by "corporate".  Some very ineffective junior management that are protected by minority status creates conflict and morale issues.  Very motivated people struggle to find opportunities to set themselves apart.  Culture does not support risk taking, so status quo is hard to change.  Long, multi-year, aggressive schedules burn out the engineering staff with no demonstrable reward at review time.  Work-life balance suffers as prevailing opinion becomes one of working less to get that raise as that is the only lever left to the employee.

review_title: A lot of back stabbing for survival!
job_title: Process Engineer in Rio Rancho, NM
pros:
Top semiconductor company. a lot of smart people and nice human beings.. Good investment in research and development. some flexibility with life-work balance (even though in some teams it's a joke)
I also loved the volunteering work we used to do as teams. Intel does a lot of community work and helps the community unfortunate people. they really take that seriously (didn't see that in other companies I worked for)
cons:
a lot of back stabbing from colleagues. Can't blame them: they are under constant pressure to be among the best or face termination. A lot of politics!!! a lot of retaliation from managers.
Managers sometimes are simply not born to be managers. there should be another option to promote people (other than making them managers). I had a terrible manager at Intel. When they don't know how to direct you, they simply blame you for all their weaknesses.

review_title: Don't work in the fab
pros:
Benefits and work life balance
free soda
cons: I seen some people who do nothing get promoted.  My direct manager does not have any idea what I do and questions work he doesn't understand.  Don't expect to leave the fab once you are in there.  Managers promise everything and deliver nothing. Some process engineers in my area don't have a clue on what they are doing.  They usually give us the wrong information, we find the right way and do it, and the engineer gets credit for our work. When I asked how I can I get promoted was told by manager once you find that out let me know so I can do it. CYA  is my main job function.   I was told several times just be happy you have a job. Working on the fab floor is just that a job not a career.  A career you have pathway a job is something you just do.

review_title: I thoroughly enjoyed working with intelligent, stimulating people.
pros: In IT people were very experienced with at minimum 10 years at Intel so all knew what they were talking about and mutually respected each other and were enthusiastic about the project and working there. Security and access to needed data or information was the biggest pain as justification was always needed with sign offs by supervisors. I was allowed to build a dimensional model without any interference. My knowledge and experience was accepted.
cons:
Security and access to needed data or information was the biggest pain as justification was always needed with sign offs by supervisors.
Data modeling architecture is fiercely controlled with reviews. This is good but a painful step as the architects only know 3rd Normal form when the dimensional model is denormalized.

review_title: Great place to work!
pros: There is a real push from upper management to make work life balance a reality. There are numerous opportunities to move laterally and up, not necessarily in your group but by moving teams... Which is still great for a company this size. Training is amazing here they really focus on getting people up and running and set you up for success!
cons: Management moves around, so you're never managed by the same person for too long, this could be a pro or a con. You can easily get jaded and lose vigor after hitting so many walls /obstacles when implementing change- a company this size hasn't been around for 45+ years because it changes easily. Intel is a smooth running Goliath and tends to throw paperwork at you if you try to change it.

review_title: Was a great place to work in previous years
job_title: Technology Development Process Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
-Good health benefits
-Very safety oriented
-Fairly stable company
-Support a healthy Work-Life balance.
-Free soft drinks/coffee in the cafeteria.
-Awesome retirement benefits.
-Support the local education system (K-12, community college, universities)
-
cons:
-Too big (High-level managers and even the CEO knew my name the first few years, then it lost that "personable feel" as it grew).
-Too much beaurocratic red-tape in decision making.
-Difficult to get into a position that fully utilizes a persons skills.
-Performance review process is weak.
-Yearly raises are minimal, and often non-existent due to "lack of funds".
-Lay-offs are done "across the board" using set-in-stone guidelines, with no exceptions to "critical needs" of a group.
-Lay-offs are occurring more and more frequently.

review_title: Worst Company
pros: Big Campus. Free fruits and beverages. Good Salary package.
cons:
Well! There are 100s of cons in this company. Few of them are listed below:

1. No peoples value. Contigent Workers are treated like slave here. They are not given any respect inspite 100% of the work are done by Green Badge contract employees only.

2. All regular employees are very old people without having any knowledge. The culture is so bad that they want to be addressed as sir like typical govt/PSU office.

3. Regular employees does not do any work and whatever comes to them is given to contract employees. Because of that they are losing all their skills as well.

4. Pathetic work place. No proper ventillation in work place. Lightings are so poor, you will have headache by end of the day. May be new buildings are good, but old buildings are not in working condition with no space, desk etc.

5. Whole campus is so crowded. They are hiring more people than the capacity and hence no more looks like corporate office.

review_title: Good place to work if you like challenges.
pros: Due to the very nature and complexity of what we're doing at Intel... the workplace is very challenging.  I don't care how well-educated or intelligent an employee is, he or she will always be able to find something to challenge them here.  On top of the challenging environment... one of the key benefits is we now get free beverages.  That's right!!! I'm talking about name-brand beverages... Coke, Pepsi, Mountain Dew ... even Sobe!  In the morning we have a delightful assortment of hot beverages:  Coffee, Tea, Hot Cocoa, Caffeine-Free coffee, vanilla-coffee, Irish cream coffee, and hazelnut coffee.  Oh, I almost forgot... they also have fresh flowers delivered to the front lobby every morning.
cons: Your performance and job satisfaction is directly related to your manager.  Though... it's a very large company, so if you're bright and network well, there's alway other jobs available.  Working in a giant cube-farm can also be a little depressing.

review_title: Why wait to die Hell on Earth at the local Intel Office or fab is here.
pros: resume builder, looks good after you leave. Stock Purchase plan provides about 12% gain.  Profit Sharing plan is actually nice. Big campuses often have gyms, outdoor areas, restaurants.
cons: REDEPLOYMENT is a living hell. Raises/Salaries get behind market pay because "can't get good ratings multiple years in a row." Cut throat rating system against other employers makes for a hyper competitive environment. Intel IT the victim of constant unreasonable cost cutting. Rating system is unfair -- management knows this but does it anyways. Quotas for reviews are pre-determined managers have to argue for top ratings in big meetings against other managers. Ranking (seems to have stopped) but they would numerically order people. Top dogs would get lots of $$, everybody else nothing. NO 401k match. NEVER sign anything if they try to lay you off/fire you -- talk to a lawyer before you waive your right to sue.  NEVER sign a bad review.

review_title: A sinking ship
pros:
The employees are, in general, top-notch
Middle management seems to be doing a reasonable job.
Pay and benefits are good.
cons:
Senior management is lost.  They don't know how to deal with the eroding PC market.  Instead of innovating they are retreating.  At this point they are chasing buzzwords.  "Forget about the PC market, we are going to be in Internet of Things and drones and one other current buzzword area I can't remember."
Expect a 1.5% raise each year whether you need it or not.  So starting salary can be good, but it doesn't even keep pace with real inflation.
For your career development, you are on your own.  First-line managers have no time to help you advance/guide your career...they are project managers, not people managers.
For the recent layoffs in 2016, the criteria was 1 "strike" and you are out.  And the strike was just receiving a lower stock allocation.  You can be rated as "Successful" and still be terminated.
The mood inside Intel right now is tomb-like.  Everyone is on edge.  Everyone is wondering whether they will be terminated next.

review_title: Pathetic IT Working Condition
pros: Good benefits but are turning to be bad!
cons: Believe me, I was employed for last 5 years and have seen things changing from heaven to hell here at Intel. Politics is like BJP and Congress. If one takes an action, other will definitely oppose. No team spirit. Team members are busy in playing politics at all levels including with the other team members of same project. They work for their success, not for projects or team success. People will say call it out in case you need help...... and when you call it out, you will be first questioned on your skills that why you cannot do it and this will reflect in your annual appraisal too. Talk anything to managers on your concerns and they will make you feel that it your own mistake which lead to the concerns and you should have handled or done things differently. Believe me, I had joined as College Graduate, but now I am out with very limited skills in demand in outside world. Your legs and hands gets broken slowly without even you realizing. That's the power of Intel. "Intel Inside, Amazing Things outside"

review_title: Struggling company
pros: Good work life balance if you want it.
cons: Intel made me an offer at a higher grade and then switched it when I joined. Confronted manager about it and said nothing he could do. Then I switched teams which lead to different title with more pay, a couple of months later HR switches title back to lower pay. My manager only changed title back AFTER focal. The pay in oregon is terrible and there is no career advancement. There is no incentive to take initiative and do more than whats asked. Expect reorgs at least once a year.  Intel is slowly cutting benefits: no GPTW, no snacks on fridays, 401k matching isn't what it used to be, change RSU allocation to short change you. Intel can't make any headway into new areas; AI/5G/SSDs are all failures.

review_title: Great place to work, as long as the hours match your life.
job_title: Intel Contract Employee in Hudson, MA
pros: Intel is a true meritocracy. If you do the work and excel, you can go as far as you want. The pay was excellent for a person with no experience in the field, and there were plenty of intangible benefits as well. Quarterly bonuses for meeting production goals and parties and events were all part of the Intel experience. If I had the opportunity, I would work there again without hesitation.
cons: The 12 hour overnight shifts I was hired for were very difficult on my home life. If you have a family or small children, I would think hard about how you're going to make it work. But for the right person, it's a fantastic opportunity.

review_title: Mediocre
job_title: Senior Packaging Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
1. Good pay for Arizona

2. Good work/life balance 

3. Great company to retire
cons:
1. People are looking to coast. Most of the employees are 40+ and honestly there to find a place to settle down through retirement. They get their kids through AZ's public school system and send them off to private colleges all around the country with the $$ saved due to the affordable cost of living in Phoenix. 

This attitude has a direct affect on the culture. Short-term solutions. Lots of powerpoints focused on the wording rather than the actual work done.

2. Highly political: It's understood that its the nature of any large organization to have politics inherent. However the issues at Intel are petty - but the consequences have been severe.

3. Egos. A lot of the Grade 10 employees are living in the glory days of the past.

4. Constant comparison to Apple/Google, and a pathetic effort to emulate their culture.

review_title: Great Place to Work
job_title: Engineering Applications Developer in Chandler, AZ
pros: If you're a self-driven, competitive, highly technical person, then Intel is the place for you. There are numerous opportunities to move around in the company so you certainly feel "stuck". They reward handsomely for good work and in general there is a "work hard, play hard" mentality. At least twice a year there are various team building events and they're usually a lot of fun.
cons: Work can get intense. If you lose focus or get disenchanted, better get back in gear quickly or seek help. There's a yearly employee rating system that if you happen to land in the bottom 10%, you're very likely to be on the list for the next round of layoffs. Also, if you're too sensitive or emotional, some of the personalities you encounter may seem harsh, or lack empathy.

review_title: Worse work life balance
pros:
1. Good work place environment
2. Wonderful people to work
3. Communicated excellent work life balance during recruitment
cons:
1. Managers force people to come to office over weekends
2. Sets up team/work meetings over weekend
3. US team always wants meetings at India late evenings
4. Management prepares schedules by including weekends and public holidays
5. All team members are forced to deliver work during weekends and late evenings
6. What is given on your appointment letter and what is told during interviews is totally different compared to the real work load, stress, prolonged working hours.
7. Management is only focused on how much more can I stretch the team and take control of the personal/family time.
8. People are discouraged from taking personal time off 
9. Management is unhappy if employees fall sick
10. Management gives you big theory about work life balance while recruitment just to pull you out of competition.

review_title: It was a Great Place to Work
pros:
Pay and Benefits are good.  Though they have eroded each year to save money on the bottom line. 

I was really proud of and loved working there.  However, that slowly changed over the years.  Now it is no longer a good place to work.   I am sad to write this short review, I could say more but cannot bring myself to do so.
cons:
I am sad to say that I cannot recommend taking a job with Intel.   I wish I still could.  My old co-workers tell me I am lucky to have left. 

You compete for a rating against your peers and team members.   Ratings are force fit into a bell curve.  5%-10% Outstanding or Exceeds Expectations, 80% successful which really means you are not good enough, 5%-10% Improvement required (you better find a new job!)

review_title: Your career is in your hands....So if you want to get it-you get it
pros: Corporate culture - I like that ideas and opinions are welcomed. Also like that the company takes care of career development  and if you know (and say!) what you need to grow - in 9 cases of 10 you will get it...sooner or later...I was lucky with 2 managers out of 5 I had. With a good manager you can really enjoy your work at Intel because a right manager knows whta the available resources are at Intel and how to use them to keep you moitivated and to help you grow. Unfortunately, it does not work with a bad manager. A good thing is that at average, bad manager does not stay for long at Intel
cons: Is more about talking and less about doing, it';s also quite a strong cost pressure currently which impacts your enjoyment of working at Intel :)

review_title: Good pay, stable place to work, respectful people - but stuck in their ways
pros:
-Very competitive pay compared to other companies in industry 
-Good benefits
-Good work/life balance - ability to take time off, vacation
-Very respectful management
-Ability to work with very smart, capable people
-Excellent training for new employees
-Casual environment (can be a plus for many people, personally its a negative for me)
-Stock purchasing plan for employees
cons:
-Harsh criticism 
-Pay is stable, but low raises yoy and few options for variable pay (in most fields) 
-Little room for innovation or creativity 
-Often feel like a very insignificant cog in an enormous machine (would be similar to most large companies I assume)
-There are opportunities to advance, but you might need to be at the company 5, 10, 15+ years to get anywhere meaningful 
-Lots of politics

review_title: A company with a strong set of core values, it's fair and stable.  However a bit behind the times.
pros:
Intel is a very respectable place to work.  The core values are taken seriously.  Job stability is very strong, and it is very, very hard to fire someone unless there is good reason.
A lot of talented and knowledgeable engineers work there, and one can learn a lot.  It is also a good place to grow career-wise up to a certain point.
cons: Intel is a bit behind the times when compared to other tech companies in Silicon Valley.  It does not nurture creativity, idea-sharing, and there is a lot of red tape and bureaucracy.  They do hardware extremely well, but still have a long way to go in terms of software development.  Decisions are very, very slow-moving, and the campuses themselves are extremely ugly and lifeless.

review_title: Poorly skilled managers. No longer a knowledge based company
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Portland, OR
pros:
Structured training.
That's all I can think of.
cons:
Archaic old out-of-date Intel one-dimensional thinking culture. 
Green & Blue badge discrimination thingy is killing the company.
Wrong hiring, promotion & staff retention criteria & strategy. Only ppl who follow the system are promoted. Technology, culture & innovation interrupters are cocooned up & pushed aside.  
Unwillingness to change biz model. Self harrakiri in this open globalized fast paced world.
Poor raise, promotions, reward & benefits.
Too many incompetent & inexperienced managers, red tape, paper work & redundant system.
Politically debilitating manoeuvres while real issue remain unresolved.
Short-sighted planning.
Long working hours. Poor work life balance.
Insistence usage of old legacy process, defectivity & metrology tools in the name of copy exact when process capability & windows are no longer robust.
Missed out on many marts purely due to ego.
Dwindling native mart share, ASP & yield.
Going to be eclipsed in cash hoard, mart cap, yield, innovation, mart share & ASP in all segment by Europeans & Asian rivals pretty soon.
Rampant over-capacity issues. Idling tools.
No longer attract the best talent.
Repeated program failures.
Slow delivery & rampant delays. 
Headed the way of Nokia, RIM, HP, Dell & MSFT

review_title: Big company with all the good and bad side effects
pros: Intel generally takes good care of its people, way more than an average company. It also has the resources to save projects in "all hands on deck" situations. And of course, being the biggest semiconductor manufacturer provides some security in uncertain times.
cons: "Only the paranoid survive" is a classic Intel saying and over the years this has led to an ultra-conservative culture where disruptive ideas have little chance for success. Also a good personal network is mandatory if you need cross-group assistance. While Intel is still financially sound there is a lot of uncertainty caused by the trend to smaller compute devices which can be felt across business units.

review_title: Intel Inside for Half a Lifetime
pros: Compensation package is good.  Sabbaticals every 7 years.  The stability which only comes in working for a giant, although, given recent events in Mass & Costa Rica (& probably in New Mexico during the next 3-5 years), it's not quite what it used to be.  Promotion from within is the norm, rather than external candidates (look at the CEO, for an example).
cons: Middle management in stasis.  The ideas & beliefs of senior management (which often have some validity) rarely make it into actual practice at the lower management levels.  The company is too hung up on proponents of the buzz word programs "lean", "mX", "six sigma", rather than managers who are truly technically competent, & have any general semblance of actual leadership.  Oh yes...you will work.  Long & hard.  As much as you can give.  And then, a bit more.

review_title: Fast moving company great money demanding work enviroment
pros: Safety is number one for Intel, great salary, benefits and 3 bonuses a year. Management are very professional for the most part but there is always the odd exception. Lots of variety in your job so you won't get bored. Intel say that you are in charge of your own development which gives you the chance to get what you want. 9 years there and I would definitely go back.
cons: Shift work 12 hour shifts 3 day one week and 4 day the next week one month days and one month nights. You need to be prepared and aware of that and does take time to adjust. There are big demands if you are up to it and the do work on a system that the bottom 5 or 10 percent get no pay increase and no shares. This is the way that they work.

review_title: Strong Culture
pros: Intel has a strong culture and heritage, which permeates more aspects of daily work life than at any other company I've worked at.  In many ways this is good:  people generally love the company and what it stands for, and the core values (accountability, risk taking, etc) are real and recognized a lot and not just fluff as in many companies.  Vast majority of people work very hard at Intel, but work life balance is respected, even at high levels.
cons: Everything is highly process-driven, and it can be a challenge to learn the processes if joining Intel mid-career and you're used to just getting to work on your ideas.  It is a very large company with perhaps overly bureaucratic approval processes and highly structured annual timelines that must be intercepted if your work is to have an impact.  These issues often suppress good ideas.  These are long-recognized problems, and some of this is changing to make the company more nimble and more fun.

review_title: Fulltime employees harass contractors to exit
job_title: Principal Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: They pay good hourly rates
cons: The fulltime employees gang up against contractors. They harass the contractors in a systematic way so that they get fed up and go. Then they hire Indian interns and make them slog misusing the fact of visa dependency and financial vulnerability of the interns. The interns are made to work over 15 hours per day. The work culture in the Perceptual Computing group has gone to pieces. Its terribly rogue politics.

review_title: A company in turmoil
pros: Salary, benefits, medical package, work on interesting things, work with great people, good work life balance if you can figure out how to make it work.
cons:
Up front, I'm not a disgruntled employee fired during the latest round -- I left to take a job somewhere else because I could see the writing on the wall.  

Intel is clearing house.  They are getting rid of thousands of seasoned employees.  Imagine what that does to morale?  Imagine what happens to a project you're working on when all the tribal knowledge that keeps everything running smoothly is shown the door. 

Is that where you want to work?

review_title: Only the Strong Survive!
job_title: Senior Instructional Designer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
-Intel allows employees a high level of autonomy in finding solutions to projects. --Great Benefits!
-Great company for safe workplace, environmental care, human rights. 
-You can experience lots of new things, but Intel likes to take shortcuts so you must earn what the industry standard is to really take advantage of it.
cons:
-Despite its innovation for products, management can be slow to respond and without much vision.
-Wishy-washy on working flexibly (working remote, flex time, etc.)
-You must learn to work in a meritocracy where employees are rated against each other yearly. This leads to great competitiveness which undermines the team atmosphere. In some people, this works to encourage hard work; in others, it is a license to back-stab others to get ahead. 
-This place is not for everyone: You must maintain your work-life balance fiercely or you will work all the time and be sick.
-Always be one- up on your co-worker.
-Own your own employability (training, learning at industry-levels) to avoid the rolling lay-offs.


-

review_title: Intel is a safe place to work but you could do better.
job_title: Process Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Number one microprocessor producer in the world. Intel may not have the best design all the time but the manufacturing skills are at the top of the industry. On the manufacturing side and design there are a lot of smart people to match your wits with.
cons: Ranking and rating system is very cut throat. Industry comparison pay is low. Intel used to depend on stock options as a lure but the stock and the company is becoming more like a GM or Ford. Intel is not really a place where you can be happy doing your job well or better every year. If you have a stellar year  you are rewarded. However, if you do the same thing the next year slightly better, you are punished for not doing more.

review_title: Intel - Excellent compensation, too much management.
pros: Excellent name, great compensation, a huge amount of resources to use towards silicon manufacturing and chip debug.  I never had issues or problems getting time off for family issues, vacation, or work-life balance.  As long as you get your work done, everything is up to your schedule.
cons:
Numerous layers of beauracracy.  Lots of meetings, task forces, etc.  At it's worst it's ripped straight out of Dilbert.  When the going gets rough, Intel slashes lots of "non-critical" departments (user research, product development, etc) only to refill those positions a year or two later, sometimes with the same people.  

The career development/focal evalutaion process is murky at best, and often left me dissatisfied with the lack of control over my career and the lack of meaningful feedback from management or others.

review_title: Great Place to Work if you make the most of it :)
pros: Being such a large, world-wide company, Intel has many opportunities for career changes and exploring new business areas and work locations.  Having worked in several different groups I've always found the general employee population to be bright, affable, and willing to help out when needed.  Lastly, Intel is celebrating its 40th year anniversary by encouraging its employees to volunteer in the community -- the One Million Hours Volunteered in 2008 initiative truly shows Intel's good will in communities around the world.
cons: Earning promotions to higher paying positions with greater responsibility may take longer than expected due to its long-established ranking & rating system.  As a young leader in the company I've been frustrated by management's lack of attention to new employees who show exceptional ability to make an impact at the company.

review_title: Intel: Closer to the wafer is safer.
pros: Interesting work at good pay, variety, constant mild change, good benefits, a clear idea of what to do and not do.
