review_title: Software Engineer at Intel
pros: Work as Software engineer in a company who gets money from Hardware is an interesting challenge, not everybody can get what this really involves but once you got it it becomes an interesting job. You can take advantage of work with a big team of very talented people abroad a lot of years and being part of a system made to do great things.
cons: Being a giant company things are slow and sometimes not the most optimum, at same time this become an opportunity area that you can deal with but it will depend the team you are in.

review_title: Former Intel Veteran
pros: I have been well compensated at Intel for my hard work over the last quarter century. And the benefits have been great (bonuses, stock, etc.)
cons:
As of Q2 of 2016 Intel is not the same company. Radical unprecedented changes in a short amount of time. The new culture does not favor older people. My comments are echoed by many!!! 

One more important comment.....I would give more weighting to the reviews given from Q2 2016 onward, given the substantial changes in the company starting in Q2.

review_title: Intel Corp from a career employee
pros: Great technology, great products, great history, great employees, strong leadership up until current CEO. Great place to work if you are in silicon development.
cons: CEO Brian Krzanich is a mediocre leader. The hiring of Murthy Renduchintala was a mistake. Intel has been diverging from it's long history of promoting from within, which has demonstrably been more unsuccessful than not, based on the longevity of external hires, their performance, and many other factors. The most recent reduction of workforce was the most ill-conceived, ill-executed in the 48-year history of the company.

review_title: Smart people, big problems
pros: You will work with dedicated, intelligent, hard working people.  Benefits and pay are great.  Problems to solve are complex.
cons: Top leadership isn't.  Have recently cut back on looking for what is next to double down on 4 "big bets." which is tactical but not very forward thinking.  Employees should be worried about competition, but instead are worried about what management is going to do to their team next.

review_title: Intel is trying... but there are issues.
pros: Every one is generally really smart. They want to do the right thing. They have superior technology. Their diversity aims are working and more representation is increasing better skill sets & options for career mobility.
cons:
Most of the time they have zero understanding of real customer requirements and they have a lens of what they believe is the right thing to do without alot of data on why... 
There is alot of politics. 
But mostly there is a lack of constructive confrontation so everyone often talks behind your back and you find out often too late or in a way that is not helpful and you are basically screwed.

review_title: Software Engineer
pros:
One can work on great products.
The pay is OK.
No micromanagement (in the team I work with, this of course varies greatly by team).
Pretty much every upper level manager was an engineer before stepping into management roles, they understand products, they understand the work that goes on in the trenches.
cons:
The location of the main Gdańsk office is horrible - long commute. A boring building outside they city, boring rows of employee desks in open spaces, no colors, can't open windows. Like a cattle farm. But I guess that is normal for such US companies.
The second (much smaller) office in Gdańsk is in a pretty good location in center though.

review_title: Intel is a great place to find and grow your career path.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Intel is a large, diverse company that can provide growth opportunities for people with varied career goals.  They are very open to letting employees change jobs when it provides growth opportunities.  

It is very rewarding to be part of a project that can potentially change the world.  Most of the groups I have been on are filled with great, fun-loving individuals.
cons: Like any large corporation, Intel has it's share of bureaucracy that is sometimes frustrating to deal with.  Also, it is sometimes difficult to remove an under qualified employee once he / she has been at Intel for over a year.

review_title: Intel, great place to rise if you are aggressive.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Compensation to stress ratio is very good. Excellent opportunity to advance if you want to. It is a big company, so there are a lot of areas to move around to. Moving to new areas is supported if you are not happy in your current area. There are many sites to work at, so you have a variety of locations that you can live in. Bonuses are significant, so as you advance, bonuses become more significant to your overall compensation.
cons: Big corporation, so you can get lost. Need to be proactive to advance. The decoration is a little sterile. Everyone has a small cubicle, so don't expect to ever get your own office.

review_title: He does not come across as an honest leader.
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great and smart people to work with. Great learning environment for someone new to the industry. Nice corporate culture and events. In the Semi conductor industry, intel is not only a world leader, but it is also one of the most stable companies in the high tech industry
cons: too much work, always bring work home. Like other tech companies, intel has a heavy work load that it passes to its engineers. compared to other companies, intel is known to pay less. Also, it is hard to leave intel once your there. (that could be viewed as a good thing)

review_title: Found your self in other company -  Numonyx ,  flash memory Intel and ST micron spin off join venture
pros: If company has an  interest in you , you will get all you need to reach goals to succeed in your job  (training , study option on company pay , relocation... )
cons:
No sentiments to loose very skilled personal , time/money invested, employees that were inspired by  Intel  values and did all for company success , many of them just found them self fired , sold as part of the dying flash business . 
At the same time Intel preferred to hire new employees to it's new 300 mm Fab .

review_title: Great people, interesting work, good benefits, mediocre recognition
job_title: Product Development Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros:
Interesting and engaging work
Great financial and health benefits.
Good bonuses and stock options
Lots of opportunities for lateral motion within the company -- they expect you to learn different parts of the business and eventually take on more responsibility
cons:
Recognition for individual efforts is a bit spotty -- if you've done something you think is great, be sure to champion your accomplishments to your manager.
Some of the bonuses are tied to vague, quasi-measurable things that are beyond the control of any individual employee. This is offset a bit by the RSUs given out to reward individual performance after annual reviews.

review_title: Good company, good management, stagnant industry.
pros: Intel is a good employer and goes to great lengths to show their appreciation to their employees.  Overall, i think Intel is a well run company with a strong culture and good management.
cons: Salary and benefits are ok, but other "perks" are somewhat behind other tech companies.  Intel painstakingly benchmarks its salaries against other companies to make sure it is competitive...but just barely competitive.  The annual performance review process is the most demotivating and demoralizing experience an employee can go through.  Intel is also a very top heavy organization leaving little opportunities for advancement beyond the first few rungs of the latter.

review_title: Good technology, good engineers, rigid culture, dull atmosphere.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Many very smart people, lots of projects and areas to work in.  Location choice (between California, Oregon, Arizona, Massachusetts, and a few smaller sites).  Option to work from home at least some days.
cons: A lot of bureaucracy: weekly and monthly status reports.  Not a lot of initiative.  Ultimately, it's a manufacturing company so that side of the business dictates the rules.  A lot of collaborative work involves participants in different sites and countries, so meetings, including regular ones can be scheduled at odd hours.  Massive buildings full of grey cubicles.

review_title: Work harder, not smarter...  there is no life outside of work
pros: The compensation and benefits are good.
cons: We are expected to work every evening and every weekend.  Holiday's too.  Work-life balance is non-existent.  I've never even heard the term mentioned.  Processes and tools make what should be the simplest tasks challenging and time consuming.  The organizations are overloaded with governance which stifles productivity and brings decision making to a crawl.

review_title: Strategic Planning
pros: Really smart people work there -- lots to learn from them. Leading edge technology company that can influence trends around the world.
cons: Turning into more of a cut-throat environment that seems to not be geared towards more seasoned employees. They tend to overinvest in some trending markets (e.g. phones) when it is clear, the ROI is not there and for other markets they pull-out before the full business plan can be implemented.

review_title: A Fine Company to work for
pros: Excellent Benefits: Health, Dental, Life Insurance, Managed Health Network, Sabbatical every 7 years or mini Sabbatical every 4. Extraordinarily focused on employee safety. Free fruit and drinks. Compressed work week with a 16% differential for night shift.
cons: Training is good, but often can be ignored, or devalued. Huge difference between groups within the company. Research and development is an engineering driven group and can be hostile towards technician/worker bees, High Volume Manufacturing is management driven with Engineering input and is much more suited towards the employee.

review_title: Intel Security Group - Don't work here.
pros: The checks clear and the comp and benefits are good.
cons: No one has the company's best interest at heart. Everyone (especially sales) is only in it for themselves, has zero integrity, zero accountability, zero understanding of what it means to be a team or work in a sophisticated technology company and not a start up. I am perplexed the, at times, flat out unethical behavior of the sales team. The lying, not only to people internally but to customers. The lack of professionalism is rampant. The good 'ole boy mentality and exclusionary culture, especially to women and minorities. I'm amazed that Intel hasn't fired everyone and started over from scratch; as it seems that may be the only solution to expel the stench and stigma of the McAfee culture in this cesspool environment.

review_title: Agile Project Manager
job_title: Agile Project Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: Excellent benefits package, including cash bonuses and stock options. The "doers" are extremely smart/intellectual people and it is an honor to work with them.
cons: "Command and control" old school of management, despite many attempts to change that. Transition Change Management challenges left and right, as the company really wants to reward the many years of sacrifice offered by those managers and is making every effort to re-train them.

review_title: Competitive company with notable accomplishments that can hopefully continue to make meaningful improvements
pros:
• Great work benefits (retirement, health benefits, etc.) which is expected from a top global company
• Admirable company that strives to exceed expectations every quarter
• Always in the news for good stories and accomplishments
cons:
• Corporate hive-mind culture — many people are just cogs in a well-oiled machine that can emphasize in more team comraderie
• A lot of bureaucracy  and red-tape when it comes to roles and responsibilities
• Many good, intelligent workers are overworked and many are under-compensated for the work they contribute
• Yearly performance review program needs improvement

review_title: Being inside "Intel INSIDE"
job_title: Platform Applications Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Its being great so far. Work - Life -Balance is almost perfect.  Alot of thing s to learn and lots of Veterans too. Innovating and expanding business portfolio to include other technologies and not just Chips. With the BRAND name you can Expect only the best from the BLUE TEAM. glad to be part of the BLUES!!!!
cons: Dont have anything for now.

review_title: Great Employer
pros: Great team, which came out of a start-up, very flexible work hours, good atmosphere, cutting edge product, leadership has high aspirations and drive to make this a world-class team. The campus itself is nice and provides a lot of amenities on-site.
cons: Probably one of the most corporate companies in the semiconductor business, which brings a fair amount of red tape and inflexibility. Flow of information is still inadequate. While the campus is nice and well connected, it is also a good bit outside of Dublin.

review_title: Hope the stock gets to 33!!
job_title: Senior Information Security Analyst in Folsom, CA
pros: Name recognition, international business exposure, great people to work with, exposure to leading edge technology, can jump around in jobs, realy good training if you take advantage of it and work life balance is achievable.
cons: Not too many, but don't expect upper management to tell you what is really happening.  Ethical behavior in other countries questionable.  The golden 90's were a lot of fun, but seems like just a place to get a paycheck since 2001.  Expect China to start producing x86 clones at low costs for their citizens as decisions regarding intellectual property development and access are business driven to low cost geos to produce.  Oh wait, it's already happening http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loongson.

review_title: Not for those who like working with human beings.
job_title: Industrial Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: If you want to design microprocessors or semiconductor technology, this is the place.  The technology is as good as it gets, though it can be difficult to pursue new ideas within the existing bureaucracy.  There are advantages to working for a market leader in terms of resources, technology, marketing, etc.
cons:
People are simply meat puppets.  "You own your own employability" is the excuse for having no management investment in employee development.  It's a cold, competitive culture.

Only the paranoid survive is taken by many employees to be paranoid about their fellow employees rather than the competition.  It's so very big there are pockets of excellence and pockets of crap.  It's difficult to know which is which before you sign up.

review_title: The old Intel is gone.
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: There are/were a lot of smart people there and there are many interesting projects. When times are good, the bonuses can be hefty.
cons:
Management is overly risk-averse, worried more about a project failing than of doing nothing and being beaten by the competition. The old data-driven Intel is long gone and is now run by sales and marketing types, with decisions now based on the best sales pitch.
    Intel is no longer a growth company, with all the rewards that go along with it. The stock is unlikely to double in the foreseeable future as microprocessors become commodities and the huge profit margins disappear.

review_title: Great place to work, but you better be ready to go for it.
job_title: Senior Hardware Systems Engineer  in DuPont, WA
pros: Successful company with lots of opportunity worldwide and a history of never quitting.  Employees are great to work with and most of management is pretty good as well.  Compensation is pretty well rounded, though upsides have been a little weak over the last years (options / stock performance)
cons: High stress, stock performance not great, lots of opportunity to work too much (have to make sure you keep a work/life balance focus).  Senior leadership does a pretty good job most of the time, but shows moments of indecision.  Lately there has been lots of focus on improving decision making, and I think that has generated some improvement.

review_title: excellent communications
pros: They have very competitive salaries when you factor in all the elements such as bonuses, stock plans, benefits, etc.  In particular, the bonus structure really rewards employees when the company performs well.  Full range of benefit choices and opportunity to customize to fit your needs.  The larger sites have thousands of jobs so there can be lots of career opportunties if you take the time to build a network of contacts.
cons: The daily workflow can be process heavy at times with lots of emphasis on metrics and indicators.  The annual performance review process, which I consider fair overall, still promotes individual achievements over teamwork.

review_title: Capricious treatment of contractors due to impatient management with unrealistic expectations
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Pay is above average, at least for contractors.  Ability to work on leading technologies.
cons: Getting set up to work in the Intel environment is very time consuming because of overly bureaucratic restrictions needing oodles of permissions to access even the most basic information needed to perform your work.  Access to documents and tools particularly difficult for contractors, with minimal help from company employees, for very complex systems and tools filled with undefined Intel specific acronyms and jargon.  Yet contractors are expected to perform useful work almost immediately despite the enormous information vacuum in which they are placed.  Don't be surprised if you are summarily canned without warning because an impatient manager thinks you should be able to skip the learning curve that always applies to working with new technologies and systems.

review_title: Wonderful job, until the money stopped flowing freely
pros: Great times with some great people,  Technician jobs really were not stressful overall.
cons: When the money flow was reduced, they couldn't remember how to entice their employees to help out and try to reduce spending. Their preferred to just cut jobs and send more work overseas, closing plants in USA.

review_title: Typical Big company, but stable and has plenty of room to move around
pros:
- Working on the design of high performance microprocessors
- Ability to move laterally and try out different department
- Flexible work schedule.
- Great volunteer and giving back to community program.
cons:
- Big company feel. It depends on your group. You could feel like sinking in the ocean trying to reach the surface for anybody to notice you.
- Everybody is trying to get themselves noticed as well. Competition could be fierce.
- Level of bureaucracy is high. Decision making process is pretty slow.

review_title: Not what it once was
pros:
Great benefits
Excellent salaries, bonus opportunities, health and 401k contributions
Vacation time of 3 weeks first year is OK
cons:
Hard environment.  Intel will suck your life away if you let it.  

Individual contributors are promoted to management without getting proper training.  Many managers at Intel have no people skills and don't know how to get the most out of their teams without resorting to aggressive behavior.

360 performance reviews are abused.  Managers can still override and color negatively any input they receive.

Intel Oregon has made a feeble attempt at making the company a better place to work by the perfunctory on-site salon, pool tables and work-out facilities.  Clearly trying to compete for young talent, but Intel will never feel like a Google.

review_title: Hardware engineer review.
pros:
Innovative company leads to top talent accumulation and development. Great place to practice and improve your engineering skills. Great work atmosphere.

Best compensations in town! Unlimited mayor medical insurance, minor medical insurance, stock benefits, two food stamp cards, and flexibility in working hours.
cons: Slow changes; don't expect financial increments in promotions or work rotations; a masters done while in the job doesn't land you a better position within the company. Yearly evaluations are biased towards perceptions; you need to do a lot of extra work to clear this up. Manager may not be the product supervisor or have little technical background to understand your work.

review_title: It was a better place to work 10 years ago
pros: The pay is better than average for the semiconductor industry, good benefits and some of the best heath care you can get anywhere.
cons:
Intel is a great place for people who are very driven and who like to work 24/7 and dare I say, are sociopaths. Consequently there are quite a few managers that fit the description. 

The company is slowing shrinking and there is a lot less money in microprocessors than there used to be. The jobs are a lot less fun as everyone has to do more with less.

review_title: QA Intern
pros: Good pay and benefits, even for interns. People are generally pretty friendly. Nice facilities with good selections of food from the cafe.
cons:
Lots of pressure to complete projects but projects often just get dumped in reorgs. This happened during my internship twice. If you're working in software, work with the expectation that your project will never see the light of day.

There's a lot of competition for attention without actually delivering anything. This goes with the prior issue in that people spend so much time fighting for attention and funding for their projects that the projects themselves are mismanaged and poorly executed.

review_title: Big company in fast-paced industry
pros: Intel is a large multi-national company so there is a lot of opportunity to move around. Compensation and benefits are at or above average compared to most peers. Work/life balance is better than some other tech companies I know.
cons: The competition in the microprocessor industry is getting fiercer and Intel has not been able to penetrate the mobile computing market (phones, tablets). Intel needs to adapt and innovate more quickly or they will continue to struggle. The culture is a bit old school (more like HP and IBM, less like Google and Apple).

review_title: Attention to Talents Out There
pros:
Pro: 
Free Fruits
Great benefits and facilities
cons:
Cons: 
Be very prepared If you are joining remote team
When you suggest something, they expect you to run it (not together as a team)
Quoting a senior direct org leader: " Intel do not owe you." 
Be very prepared if remote managers only wants contribution and expect you know as a newbie
Be very clear if you want them to hear you out to avoid them from selective listening or judgmental based on perception given (they will mark you)

review_title: Culture change
pros: Benefits are good ( bonuses, stock, 401k, health, etc), the work is interesting and can be rewarding, colleagues are in general great to work with
cons: Work-life balance is a large issue, especially given the change In tenor from management.  Job cuts using criteria that until the middle of last year was unheard of, and instead of using  the traditional "redeployment" pool to re-place the targeted individuals, people were terminated and walked out the door with no option to return.

review_title: Senior Process Engineer
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: In general, good teaming experience and people.  Peers are willing to listen to ideas and opinions. Challenging projects. Average opportunity to present your work and efforts to higher level management. Better than average salary and benefits package.
cons: Management heavy who lack listening skills. Often they do not follow up with agreements and stated promises. Worse then average opportunity system. Poor work/life balance chiefly due to the management communications, bad leadership, and indecisiveness. Atrocious annual performance review system and the way it is managed.

review_title: You'll learn a lot but you're more than expendable
pros:
Good pay
Good benefits
You'll learn a lot.
cons:
You're more than expendable. When management gets bored of your project, they lay you off, sometimes your entire business group, even when it angers their customers.

You deal with a ton of bureaucratic junk daily. 

You'll learn how to be a political waste of space faster than you'll learn good engineering. It's all about who you can throw under the bus to get ahead, not the actual merits. People will present your work as their own if you help them and aren't there to correct them.

review_title: Intel Senior Staff Software Engineer
job_title: Senior Software Architect in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Diverse workforce
Advancement criteria clearly defined
Great benefits
cons:
Strong emphasis on individual contribution fosters competitive instead of cooperative behaviors
Software engineering practices and capabilities in my org are decades behind the industry
Inexperienced software engineers utilized to design complex systems
Widespread lack of critical thinking and root cause analysis
Continual cut backs in IT are negatively impacting productivity for the rest of the company

review_title: Great.
pros: Friendly staff, management helped me push my internship goals to learn more about the industry, gave me enough independence to sink my feet in, but gave me enough support without feeling like i was drowning. My director let me sit in important planning meetings to really understand the organization, and allowed me to get the first try in creating media packets, and information packets to really get experience.
cons: I was there in a downsizing time, especially in the marketing department. there was definitely tensions, and i could see the beginnings of a subtle panic.

review_title: Great place to work.
pros: Market leader.  Raises above the fray and is a model leader in the industry, the company is constantly under attack from both competitors as well as lunatic enthusiasts.
cons: The size of the company has draw backs, especially in decision making process.  This has improved greatly over the past two years, but just size makes it difficult to

review_title: Overall good choice for employer
pros: Growth opportunities, competitive compensation package coupled with heavy work/life balance focus. Great people in a casual work environment. Intel values and culture are good, and it's not uncommon for personal lives to be improved from a (subconscious) propogation of the values to your personal lives.
cons: Stock performance. Competition for senior management to fill next CEO role tends to result in many managers disappointed and leaving the company. Ever since Andrew Grove stepped down from CEO in '98, the stock has been flat-lined. There are obvious challenges here, but somehow we need to figure out the secret to re-energizing the growth. I keep hearing Atom, but we'll see.

review_title: Fun Internship, not sure about full time
pros: Intel is a large company that has a lot of resources. As an intern I got to work on a cool project.  There wasn't much oversight as I was given an independent project to work on for the duration of the internship, so I didn't have much interaction with management. There was also a good mix of young and old developers.
cons: The workplace environment definitely needs improving -- the sea of cubes isn't exactly the most exciting.  There seems to be a lot of groups that have members in different locations.  There didn't seem to be any real perks, and as far as the intern experience goes, there weren't many organized activities.

review_title: Intern Experience @ Intel
job_title: Undergraduate Technical in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Biggest chip company. They are stable and have been making lots of money for a long time. The CEO seems to be doing a very good job.

The benefits are starting to get better, free pop/coffee now as well as free fruits.

I never experienced their health plans; but from what I've heard they are pretty good.
cons:
There are some good management; but there are bad eggs as well. The bad ones are slow and stupid and way too consevative. They try and understand things they have no hope in understanding. They imped the company's pace.

A lot of people here are conservative (which is a good thing), but sometimes too conservative.

review_title: Could be worse, I could be working in the Taliban
pros: Easy job, not much going on
cons:
Not much upside, not much downside either, 35 hours a week, some like it some don't, 1-1 meetings with your manager every week, could be a pain, uptight culture, speaking up is encouraged but be ready to be ridiculed by more senior people,

Overall it isn't the worst place to be but it certainly isn't better

Company restructures fairly often, about every 3 years just because they really can't seem to figure out what exactly they need or don't need, lots of new ventures but let's face it, if the ventures don't have x86 in the project name, 10/10 times it'll be a bust

review_title: Keep your resume updated!
pros: Industry Leader, emphasis on safety, sabbatical benefit, good employee bonuses, nice severance packages and notice to employess who were about to be laid off
cons: Average a layoff every 2 years, hard to advance, limited opportunities, job security unstable (unless you live in China.)  As a worker in the fab you are evaluated by people who hardly ever set foot in your work environment....hence they tend to have their perspective marred by brownnosers and extroverted personalities....great place to work as long as you do not work in wafer operations

review_title: Green badge vs Blue badge
pros: High tech environment, new technology happening all the time, nice buildings. lots of perks for Blue badges, workout room, nice cafe
cons: Green badges are treated as a sub-life form even though there are more green badges than blue badges on this site and Intel could not get the job done with out green badges. very poor collaboration between green badges and blue badges.

review_title: Finance Intern
job_title: Finance Intern in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great pay and great benefits especially as an intern. Plenty of intern events (taken out to many dinners/napa valley wine trip/beach trip). The projects are normally very interesting and even if they aren't, it's really up to you to talk to your mentor/boss about it or finish your deliverables so that you can move on to more interesting stuff.
cons: It can feel somewhat political at times especially within the financial department where you have to be very subtle and worm your way into making influential decisions within the corporation.

review_title: Challenging, High Pressure, Job Satisfaction, but pay can be improved
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Pulau Pinang
pros:
You get the chance to work in the world class, world leading team in CPU/Chipset designs.
Flexi hours allowed when needed.
Employee benefits are good: insurance, car loan and housing loan subsidy, free fruits
cons:
1. Schedule intensive
2. High pressure
3. Competitive, during yearly focal review, quota is normally set (~5%) that these 5% employees will be rated as BE (Below Expectation) and IR (Improvement Required). As the names imply, there will less than 1% or no increment for the 5% population.

review_title: Challenging, High Pressure, Job Satisfaction, but pay can be improved
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Pulau Pinang
pros:
You get the chance to work in the world class, world leading team in CPU/Chipset designs.
Flexi hours allowed when needed.
Employee benefits are good: insurance, car loan and housing loan subsidy, free fruits
cons:
1. Schedule intensive
2. High pressure
3. Competitive, during yearly focal review, quota is normally set (~5%) that these 5% employees will be rated as BE (Below Expectation) and IR (Improvement Required). As the names imply, there will less than 1% or no increment for the 5% population.

review_title: Great Place to Work
pros:
Get to work with the best engineering brains
Highly tolerant of various working styles. Very flat (non-hierarchical) workplace
Tremendous diversity (not just of the cultural kind, but of the problem solving kind)
cons:
It is a big company and has some characteristics of that. Sometimes there are too many stakeholders and managers with their own axes to grind & little fiefdoms and turfwars to wage. Not for the weak-willed

Like in many other places.. no pain, no gain. You have to clock some crazy hours to be successful.

review_title: Positive
pros: The company does a great job to support and take care of it's employees.  Whether it's career advancement and or education, to health, to work life balance.  The two managers I had the pleasure to work with supported me and my work and fought for me when my contract was up to keep me longer.  I defnitely felt like my work made a positive impact on the company.
cons:
Intel has a unique culture of work hard and play hard.  That culture tends to get caught up in over thinking and too many meetings.  It could be difficult to get any actual work done.  
If you don't like being walled in by gray cubes you won't like working there.

review_title: Engineering Technician
pros: Great company all and all.  Good pay.
cons: Intel has a very hard time promoting within.  I have worked here for 7 years.  All focals have been successful or better (Scale of 1 to 5, I rank 3 or better every year) never below successful.  I have a BS in EET.  I have worked the position of Engineer in charge of multi million dollar machines, and I cannot get promoted.  As much as I love Intel, I may have to leave so I can meet my long term goal of being a titled Engineer.

review_title: Great place to work!
pros: Intel's salary ranges are above average in the semiconductor industry. Great benefits with a paid 8 week sabbatical every 7 years of service. Intel's corporate culture is by far the best I've ever worked in. Work/Life balance is valued at Intel.
cons: I work a compressed work week schedule which I have learn to love and hate. I get 3 and 4 days off but during my work week I see very little of my family and hardly ever make it to dinner. I do get to make up that time on those long 4 days off on a short work week though.

review_title: Great work, good work-life balance
pros: Can work on top technologies, and there is a good chance to make an impact. The company has very good values. There is good work-life balance in the company.
cons: A large organization, moves slowly. Needs to be more nimble in the software category. Pay is average, but there are other benefits. Less number of job grades, so promotions are slow. Teams usually consist of few very good people and mostly average folks.

review_title: Flexible work, Very nice people and atmosphere, average to above average talent, average Pay
pros: flexibility to work in your own time or telecommute ; transparency and great leadership ; You wont get rich from the pay but the bonuses and stock options make you want to stay longer. Family feeling within your team and emphasis on your happiness, career etc. great incentive systems and multiple events.
cons: As mentioned, very nice people but many are looking for lifestyle work and it's hard to get excited or collaborate sometimes on a project. Not enough young buzz in the company, most employees are on the older side then other tech companies around.

review_title: Intel software engineer
pros:
1. Chance to work on cutting-edge hardware and influence hardware decisions.
2. More laid back (but that is changing now)
cons:
1. SSG (Intel's Software and Service Group) thinks of itself as a software company, but doesn't have the same attitude. This is abundantly clear when you visit real software companies.
2. Review system (called "Focal") is a pain. In addition, performance isn't always directly rewarded during end of year reviews (you could have a really super couple of years and still not get adequate recognition).
3. Pay isn't competitive with software companies.
4. Benefits -- no 401K matching for instance.

review_title: On average a good experience
job_title: Process Engineer in Rio Rancho, NM
pros:
Decent salary.
Excellent benefits and on-site amenities.
Cutting edge technology. 
Good work/company culture (for the most part).
Lots of technically excellent people.

On average, I had a very good experience at Intel (though I'd advise you NOT to take a position in NM but to instead go to Arizona, California or Oregon).
cons:
Cyclical layoffs.
New Mexico site is pretty much dead and waiting to be shut down (like the Massachusetts site).
Some managers are completely incompetent and are in position solely through political maneuvering.

review_title: A good 17 years
job_title: Automated Equipment Technician (AMHS) in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Pay and benefits were very good.  Facilities were well maintained.  Excellent Gyms.  Industry leader in products.
cons: Over time, Corporate Leaders have shifted from being more concerned about employees, to being more concerned about shareholders and profits.  Pay increase has failed to raise ant any level close to profit increase.  Different Fab cultures are radically different limiting ease of transitions.  Employee advancement is severely limited in direct relation to advanced education.

review_title: A good 17 years
job_title: Automated Equipment Technician (AMHS) in Rio Rancho, NM
