job_title: IT Program Manager in DuPont, WA
pros: World class products and technology.  Resources to invest in interesting projects.  Many great people.  True integrity as an organization.
cons: You are expected to work like you are in a crisis - all the time.  Your manager has too much control over your career and life.  Only ~50% of the employees actually add value or generate revenue - the rest spend their time communicating, updating and justifying what they are doing - all at a "Type A" frenetic pace.  You are responsible for your own employability (which is OK) but the company really has no idea what skill they will need beyond ~ 6 months.  Consequently, they lay off existing employees and then hire the skills that are needed for today.  Very wasteful and demoralizing.

review_title: Interesting
pros:
-Great upper management
-Flexible work hours
-ESPP
-RSU stock bonuses
-Smart, work oriented people (no babysitting other employees)
-Empowerment environment (figure everything out for yourself)
-Ability to work on cunning edge technology and change the work with your ideas
-Fast paced & dynamic working environment
-On site gym
-Working meals
cons:
-Have to be in a position for at least 3 years
-If you transfer to a different division your 3 years in position get reset
-Your tech manager has the biggest weight on your performance reviews
-When you get a job there they will almost always push you down in title to reduce quicker rise to management positions, will still pay you well for your experience

review_title: Great compensation but poor leadership at all levels and burn-out rate is high
pros: Great compensation and healthcare benefits. 3 weeks of vacation first year of employment.  Very smart people in the trenches.  Ability to move around company when projects get shut down rather than face lay-off.
cons: Overall very poor leadership. Too many career lifers with no outside perspective. Build it and they will buy attitude. Marketing teams treated poorly. Individual contributors get promoted without leadership training or having people management skills.  Engineers held hostage to project at hand only to have it shut down after sacrificing family and personal time. Lack of teamwork and sink or swim attitude is rampant across all functions as is outsourcing! Trend toward laying off non-management level employees over 45 through performance "review" system.

review_title: Decent company to work for, but not what it used to be.
pros: its go-go days appear to be behind it, and it has stumbled with its vision and leadership over last 10 yrs.   that being said,  its a decent place to work for with decent benefits for a mature company.   work is usually challenging, but it depends on your group and how motivated you are.
cons: being a big company,  it is quite political.   the key is getting into a good group  where you have supportive management, flexibility/balance  with your work/personal life, freedom to do your job, and good/trustworthy people to work with.  Get in the wrong/bad group and its not fun.  Lately the company is making efforts to downsize ... I expect that to continue, but in a moderate way.

review_title: A Place to Move Around
pros: Intel has a lot of different opportunities to try new things. You can move between hardware, software, firmware or any of the business management jobs quite easily. Not to mention working on cutting edge technology and a wealth of very talented and fun people to work and learn from. Intel is the most diverse company I have ever worked with, and this is one of the main factors I like about the company.
cons: Intel is big. Very big, and the groups just dont communicate with each other. This causes a lot of political positioning and works against progress. This is the most frustrating factor at times and can be quite distracting. It always seems to take too much time to make decisions and I often feel we miss opportunity because senior management has a hard time making the hard choices.

review_title: Good Company
pros: Intel is certainly an international company and has very diversified work force.  Employees come from almost every corner of the world. You can meet people from different cultures.  Most people I worked with were very technical and professional.  Employees showed respect to one another.  I liked the working environment and culture.   Never needed to worry about there was not enough technical challenges to work on.   I can always look for new advance technology for future project or find better ways to do existing work. It is a good starting place for young people to build their working experience.  Overall, Intel is very good company to work for.
cons: Sometime work can be very stressful and work in long hour.  The project timeline is getting shorter and shorter (in some situations, it can be good).    Sometimes there might be too many meetings.

review_title: Good company - but you have to sift through the garbage to find the hidden gems that make it worthwhile
pros: Intel does provide more than fair compensation.  They have a focal process that is at least designed to be fair, but a lot of things have recently been removed that I believe made the process more transparent.  They claim it was for expediancy reasons, but who knows...
cons: Lots of bueracracy.  Work is very slow unless its becomes a priority to management.  Unfortunately, Intel has a very weak hiring process, and a lot of bad apples get in.  20% of the workforce does 80% of the work.

review_title: A good place to start your career, but move on if you want to gain "real world" experience.
pros:
-good learning opportunities
-good technology
-excellent benefits
-good for new college grads only
-tolerant of all races, gender, religions, etc
-excellent training opportunities
-8 week sabbatical after 7 years of service (if you make it that long)
cons:
-bureaucratic management--sometimes takes way too long for decisions to be made and implemented
-mean culture--very cut throat
-tends to overwork employees
-too competitive focal review process
-not enough pay for scope of work 
-a bit of nepotism - many employees married or related to one another (oftentimes they hide it by using different last names)
-job duties are often too segmented--unlike other companies where you get a wider scope of responsibilities.

review_title: Challenging work but very impersonable and cut-throat
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: It's a great company to gain experience working with the latest technologies and some of the smartest people anywhere. There are always opportunities to move into other roles, either permanently or on a temporary assignment. The company has done a lot in recent years to improve the stale cube environment.
cons: Work/life balance is non-existent. There is a reason they give all employees laptops and it's not because they want you to telecommute (only one day a week is allowed)... it's because they expect you to be available for early morning or late night calls, weekends and holidays.  The pfmn management system rewards individual accomplishments over team/company goals, so there is very little collaboration or knowledge sharing.

review_title: Highly competitive, unfriendly co-workers
pros:
+ Compensation, bonuses, and benefits are great
+ Upper management keeps everyone informed of what is going on and seems to be competent
+ Fairly easy to move around to different positions if you aren't happy with your work
+ Flexible vacation and time off
cons:
- The people. Most people are *very* competitive and will only help you if they have something to gain from it. Even those that aren't competitive often wait days or weeks to respond to an e-mail, and are condescending when they eventually do respond.
- Every project is separate and you need permission from multiple managers to even read any documents or access files. Getting permissions often takes several days or even weeks. It feels as if they don't even trust their own employees.
- Tools are all custom designed and often (poorly) replicate already available software. Very little documentation is available for them. A major part of my job involves fighting with the tools so I can do my actual job.

review_title: Sr Software Engineer
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: There is a wealth of knowledge and tools available that you can take advantage of from the people to the actual knowledge base available. You have a good selection of benefits to choose from and every year, they've always given employees time to meet with the different benefit options on site. Hours are flexible and that is always a good thing in achieving work life balance.
cons: This company has a tendency to select managers without soft skills. I have witnessed first level managers who never challenged upper management for fear of receiving a bad review. So much for challenging the status quo. Best advice is to find a manager who has the backbone to stand up for his/her team, otherwise you end up managing your manager. The review process they have in place is ugly!

review_title: Recent college grad at Intel
pros: Bragging rights to all your friends, notoriety, the feeling of joy you get from being part of something relevant and successful. The benefits are great.
cons: Lack of training to get yo up to speed with their projects. Then they expect you to produce a high volume of work in a short amount of time with no training. You can't "google" how to do things at Intel because it's is all cutting edge and confidential - so you can't get assistance online. The pay isn't as good as Microsoft. Managers rank employees via charts and graphs that don't tell the whole story. In an attempt to streamline/assembly-line employees and their productivity, they sacrifice trust. But perhaps this is just one of those things that makes all corporations have a bad rep.

review_title: Tough times
pros:
1) good pay & benefits
2) opportunity to try different roles around company
3) on finance side, big focus on development and cool rotation program  that allows you to grow fast and move up
cons:
1)  work life balance ...it depends on org, but terrible in most of the finance roles
2) the times are tough and the morale in the company is low...never ending cycle of layoffs and cost cutting is weighing on everybody
3)  management that has hard time getting employees buy into their strategy
 4) management that seem to value external companies more than internal talent
5) environment seems to be getting very political, especially in upper management (and trickling to mid-mgmt)

review_title: Not recommended unless you're close to retire.
pros: Pay is OK at low-cost geos like Oregon, Chandler and Folsom, benefits are decent. Most groups have good work-life balance.
cons:
1. No Career future. Company hasn't have much growth for many years and failed to deliver 10nm process mode again and again.
2. Year-to-year pay increase is negligible, sometimes even less than inflation rate.
3. Meritocracy is dead, promotion is not guaranteed even if you did excellent work, you may need to wait for your turn because limited budget for promotion.
4. No job security. The company laid off 10000+ employees without obvious reason.
5. The skillset learned at Intel, especially software, are outdated in IT industry. The longer you stay, the less possible you will be able to launch a job elsewhere.

review_title: Intel is as good as your first line manager is.
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: The pay is good.  The company is stable.  There are a lot of great, intelligent coworkers.  You have the freedom to switch jobs after a year if you want.
cons: Intel has serious problems with first line managers.  It is so inconsistent.  I've had some great ones and some really bad ones.  Senior management seems to really have it together though.  There are also so many people here working on their small part that you have to be really careful to make sure that you include all of the people affected and this can sometimes really slow things down.  A lot of people have to work with oversees customers and other engineers, which can mean early mornings or late nights at work.

review_title: Limited career growth.  Execs who can't make decisions or be up front with their long term plans.
pros: The money isn't bad and benefits are pretty good. Lots of great people are still in the engineering workforce and some parts of Intel function pretty well.
cons:
Where to start?  The culture is highly political.  If you work in manufacturing or one of CPU design teams you can find an old boys' network to join.  Outside of that you can forget about advancement.  The ranking and rating process used during evaluation is a relic from the 1980s: it rewards throwing others under the bus and disincentivizes teamwork.  

Innovation was killed off in the early 2000s and replaced with a series of silos.  If you don't color inside your own lines you're going to be punished.

Messages given to employees are constantly of bad news and impending problems.  Employee morale is low and workers are treated more like cattle than anything else.

review_title: My Experience @ Intel After 2.5 Years
job_title: Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Being such a large company, it's nice knowing that you will have a job if you are competent in the least bit.  They also encourage internal transfers and strive to keep individuals within the company.  The benefits are pretty good (free soda\pop, gym, volleyball court, etc.)  From my experiences, work-life balance really depends on the person; if you let yourself work 60 hour weeks people will rely on you to do so. If you want to be out at 5pm every day and not pick up your laptop at home, that seems to be accepted as well. Your performance review may not be off the charts, but that balance is an option.
cons:
Intel is not necessarily a "fun" place to work; I'd estimate the average employee to be in their late 30's\early 40's. 

In my product related group, there's a sizeable ramp time before you feel like you're contributing in a meaningful way.

Being such a large company, you may spend days trying to track down the person who owns a particular piece of information vital to your job.

review_title: Typical Big Tech Pros and Cons
pros: Cutting edge technology and innovation -- the company really does touch billions of lives through its tech.  Super smart, super helpful people all around.  Lots of incredible benefits if you take advantage of them.  The longer you are here, the easier it is to see opportunities that you can develop into.  Leading in diversity efforts and corporate social responsibility.
cons: Large company -- you can get lost or stepped on if you are not a self-starter or go-getter.  Tech company that is trying to catch hold of growing markets.  That's exciting, but like in any tech company, it comes with a lot of re-orgs and interrupted career paths.  Older company with many people who have worked here for decades - feels hierarchical.

review_title: Construction Project Manager
job_title: Construction Project Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Great company overall! 
Brand name, very unique/challenging projects, Flexible schedule, work/life balance, amenities, corporate culture (relaxed),  diversity (low/mid level), technology and benefits (education, health, time off etc...)
cons:
Low Base salary (yearly raises are very small), very limited growth opportunities, too many redundant meetings, unclear/not transparent focal review process, some decisions are made by senior leaders without getting any input from the tactical team, not much diversity at the senior leadership level.
Some managers aren't good leaders, do not inform expectations, frequent performance feedback which has led to a climate of mistrust. Document everything!
No grade level adjustment review process for employees to obtain post graduate advanced degrees or certifications related to their field. Basically means a new hire with the same profile will be placed at a higher grade.

review_title: Way behind in technology
pros: Stable job, decent pay, multiple locations to pick from, interesting type of work.
cons: IT department is Intel's weakest link and IT's incompetency is dragging the whole company down. We are supposed to be developing cutting edge technology while we are given ancient computers that break all the time. Many people I know can't even do their jobs because they have to deal with computer problems on daily basis. On a given 40-hour week, I spend easily 10-12 hours dealing with computer issues because Intel is too cheap to give me a properly functioning computer. I honestly stopped caring long time ago. All IT department ever does is to send spyware and bloated software to our computers which makes our computers even slower and clumsier. It's impossible to develop cutting edge technology when you work with computers and tools that are clumsy, slow and buggy.

review_title: A Great Place To Work
pros:
I was working at Intel GDC at Mexico.

The great things about Intel GDC:
- Healthcare Benefits
- Paid Vacation time and Medical Leave
- Paid Maternity Leave
- You can change your role or change group or organization within a Year inside Intel
- Lots of free courses about multiple languages and roles
- Human approach
- Free fruit and juice at the cafeteria
- Cafeteria on site
- Free and well equipped Gym on site
- Massage, Dental Care and Nursing on site
- Various activities and after-work groups
- Payslip Bonuses 
- Intel offers Bus Shuttle for most parts of the city
cons:
- Some of the methodologies their are using are very old
- Knowledge sharing within higher grades and lower grades its almost impossible
- The "No Retaliation" policy its not always true (depending of the person you had the issue with)
- The pay is not very competitive, its just average or little below the average
- The interview process can last more than a month sometimes
- The Site its very far from many bus routes (but the shuttle its an option)
- They really dont try to retain talent

review_title: Good company
pros: A Good work place. Lots of innovation and exposure to new technologies. Industry leading technical leadership. Best open door policy. Good work life balance and good benefits. Senior management is caring and open abt communications. frequent layoffs and reacting to downturns in economy is troubling, our company stock shows no momentum and thats a worry from both the financial sense and from a job security sense. investing in new tech very risky. frequent layoffs and reacting to downturns in economy is troubling, our company stock shows no momentum and thats a worry from both the financial sense and from a job security sense. investing in new tech very risky.
cons: frequent layoffs and reacting to downturns in economy is troubling, our company stock shows no momentum and thats a worry from both the financial sense and from a job security sense. investing in new tech very risky.

review_title: Good Company with too much organizational chaos
pros:
Friendly encouraging environment - Corporate Services is excellent
Good salary
Excellent technical work
People are friendly to work with
Really a GPTW in some aspects - team building/quarterly etc.,
Excellent work culture especially for women
cons:
Too much deadline stress -sometimes weekly deadlines
Too many organizational changes - one week a team/org is called by one name and the next week that is called by some other name
Need time to focus on actual work more rather than reporting in terms of weeklies/biweeklies/monthlies etc.,
Many dotted line managers in addition to one direct manager and who all exercise equal importance over your focal appraisal - and also they are located around different parts of the world - they have no clue as to what you work hands on.

review_title: Intel needs to inspire people to save the world
pros: There are so many opportunities if you are interested in career growth, especially with the company being worldwide and having many divisions.  Intel is in every industry it seems. There is so much potential for innovation.
cons: A lot of bureaucracy.  If you want to get anything done, you need to know the right people that aren't afraid to make a decision. Too my CYA inside, rather than all standing together for the same cause and move forward.  Because there's been layoffs in the news, its created more fear in the system, causing people to be more defensive of what they are doing - this causes overlap and unncessary tension between organizations.

review_title: Product Marketing Engineer
job_title: Product Marketing Engineer in Gig Harbor, WA
pros: Best benefits in the business.  You don't see how good the benefits are until you leave the company.  Generally speaking, the pay is better at Intel.  This isn't always the case but appears to be so right now in early 2016.  Intel has a LOT of very smart people.  Compared to other companies where I've worked, there are very few employees who don't pull their weight.
cons: Having a lot of smart people means that to be average at Intel you have to be one of the best and brightest in the general population outside of Intel.  Annual performance reviews are TOUGH.  A certain percentage of employees have to receive poor performance appraisals.  A poor performance review is the first step toward the door.  The company asks a lot of it's employees.  It's the employee's job to draw the line and say, "I've got enough on my plate, I can't take any more."  Most people can't say that and as a result most people are overworked and are in some state of burning out.

review_title: Equipment Module Team Technician
job_title: Equipment Module Technician/Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: Good to above average pay. Great benefits. Sabbaticals every 4 years (1 month) and 7 years (2 months). Great people who are experts in the semiconductor field, some of the best in the industry.
cons: Unrealistic goals. Lack of respect for people exists, which is different at different locations. Rank and rating process is an unfair process and needs to be revised. Really take a look at how many people are working 60-80 hours in a week and sacrificing their family life, just to stay afloat at work due to unrealistic workloads.

review_title: What is your Strategic Vision?
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great Benefits, Work Life Balance (Depending on the group you work in), Free Fruit and Beverages.
cons: Intel is a place with diverse experience groups. I've been at 7 different groups during my 10+ years at Intel, there are (were) groups with experienced people who knew what to do, some groups are meticulous to the T on business process development where much time and energy is spent on creating a business process just to see that the business priority changes as soon as the business process is developed, some groups give you a wild wild west experience. The company is Middle Management Heavy, seems as if nothing was learnt after the not so recent past SET changes. Keeping a flat management structure with a better employee rating process would really help in improving the conditions for the company.

review_title: Intel honest review
pros: Intel has excellent benefits including very nice bonuses based on performance. Honestly Intel pays very well compared to the industry. Great company to gain experience and education. Excellent opportunities and easy to join the company if you are new collage grads.
cons: Company has a lot of down turns which initiate layoffs especially for workers that have been working for the company 15+ years, even if you have had all successful reviews. The annual review process is cumbersome and needs a major upgrade to the process. Part of the annual reward process gives you stock options which don't really measure up to much anymore. The new GPTW new cubicle environment does not work well at all. Upper management makes decisions changing the way people have to perform work and take little to no feedback from the workers that have to follow the process. Work life balance used to be one of the best in the industry however that has changed over the years especially since most people are expected to do the work of 2-3 people after people are let go.

review_title: Smartest People I've Worked With
job_title: Director of Engineering in Portland, OR
pros: Great place to spread your wings and test your limits. You will always find multiple people smarter than yourself or a group to work with that shares your common interests or directions. There is a very high value on strategic competency, and with that comes incredible autonomy. With the appointment to lead a problem solving team often comes an open checkbook and the awesome responsibility that entails.
cons: As with academic environments, you put a bunch of really smart people in a room and there is often debate, sometimes too much debate unless there is a strong leader who can implement clear processes. Easier said than done. The overhead for managers to lead multi-geography teams for either projects or management structure is overwhelming and from what I've seen continues to be a major stumbling block to execution efficiency. Constant iteration of business plans, because there is staffing to do so in Marketing/Planning is a heavy burden compared to other companies, to the technical staffs.

review_title: Smartest People I've Worked With
job_title: Director of Engineering in Portland, OR
pros: Great place to spread your wings and test your limits. You will always find multiple people smarter than yourself or a group to work with that shares your common interests or directions. There is a very high value on strategic competency, and with that comes incredible autonomy. With the appointment to lead a problem solving team often comes an open checkbook and the awesome responsibility that entails.
