Intel is clearing house.  They are getting rid of thousands of seasoned employees.  Imagine what that does to morale?  Imagine what happens to a project you're working on when all the tribal knowledge that keeps everything running smoothly is shown the door. 

Is that where you want to work?

review_title: Only the Strong Survive!
job_title: Senior Instructional Designer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
-Intel allows employees a high level of autonomy in finding solutions to projects. --Great Benefits!
-Great company for safe workplace, environmental care, human rights. 
-You can experience lots of new things, but Intel likes to take shortcuts so you must earn what the industry standard is to really take advantage of it.
cons:
-Despite its innovation for products, management can be slow to respond and without much vision.
-Wishy-washy on working flexibly (working remote, flex time, etc.)
-You must learn to work in a meritocracy where employees are rated against each other yearly. This leads to great competitiveness which undermines the team atmosphere. In some people, this works to encourage hard work; in others, it is a license to back-stab others to get ahead. 
-This place is not for everyone: You must maintain your work-life balance fiercely or you will work all the time and be sick.
-Always be one- up on your co-worker.
-Own your own employability (training, learning at industry-levels) to avoid the rolling lay-offs.


-

review_title: Intel is a safe place to work but you could do better.
job_title: Process Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Number one microprocessor producer in the world. Intel may not have the best design all the time but the manufacturing skills are at the top of the industry. On the manufacturing side and design there are a lot of smart people to match your wits with.
cons: Ranking and rating system is very cut throat. Industry comparison pay is low. Intel used to depend on stock options as a lure but the stock and the company is becoming more like a GM or Ford. Intel is not really a place where you can be happy doing your job well or better every year. If you have a stellar year  you are rewarded. However, if you do the same thing the next year slightly better, you are punished for not doing more.

review_title: Intel - Excellent compensation, too much management.
pros: Excellent name, great compensation, a huge amount of resources to use towards silicon manufacturing and chip debug.  I never had issues or problems getting time off for family issues, vacation, or work-life balance.  As long as you get your work done, everything is up to your schedule.
cons:
Numerous layers of beauracracy.  Lots of meetings, task forces, etc.  At it's worst it's ripped straight out of Dilbert.  When the going gets rough, Intel slashes lots of "non-critical" departments (user research, product development, etc) only to refill those positions a year or two later, sometimes with the same people.  

The career development/focal evalutaion process is murky at best, and often left me dissatisfied with the lack of control over my career and the lack of meaningful feedback from management or others.

review_title: Great Place to Work if you make the most of it :)
pros: Being such a large, world-wide company, Intel has many opportunities for career changes and exploring new business areas and work locations.  Having worked in several different groups I've always found the general employee population to be bright, affable, and willing to help out when needed.  Lastly, Intel is celebrating its 40th year anniversary by encouraging its employees to volunteer in the community -- the One Million Hours Volunteered in 2008 initiative truly shows Intel's good will in communities around the world.
cons: Earning promotions to higher paying positions with greater responsibility may take longer than expected due to its long-established ranking & rating system.  As a young leader in the company I've been frustrated by management's lack of attention to new employees who show exceptional ability to make an impact at the company.

review_title: Intel: Closer to the wafer is safer.
pros: Interesting work at good pay, variety, constant mild change, good benefits, a clear idea of what to do and not do. On the whole, if combines most of the best aspects of working at a large corporation with few of the stifling drawbacks: the internal blogs get pretty caustic, but I've never heard of anyone getting even reprimanded for it, and it can even change things for the better. Managers are expected to be able to do what their reports are doing, and I see them doing it every day.
cons: Outside the fabs, not so secure. Possibly not as energetic and flexible as you have heard. Some areas/groups/divisions are stuck in neutral with no plan for overhaul--not mine, but that's what I've heard.

review_title: it is the BEST company among others, it molds people to become excellent employee.
job_title: Material Handler/Machine Operator in Makati City
pros: for my 13 years of being a part of the company i've learn a lot in terms of knowledge, responsibility, customer orientation, personal improvement and good working attetude. the company molds its people to better one and trains to become successfull not only for the benefit of the company but also to our own family.
cons: during the global crisis i experience minimum additonal salary but still i'm grateful to be a part of the company because they still consider the needs of their people by giving other incentives to suffies the needs of their people.

review_title: Great Place To Work
pros:
1. Advanced technology - I get all the tools that I need to work effectively with. My favourite is my softphone. I can make calls through my pc while working from any location as long as I have internet connectivity.
2. Flexible work hours - This allows me to balance my responsibilities as a working mum.
3. Support for mothers - Moms-to-be carparks right in front of the lobby, mother's room for nursing mothers, Planet Blue (internal online forums) to buy and sell baby/kids' stuff and to ask for advice.
4. Lots of internal job opportunities - Employees are encouraged to rotate to different job functions for their career development.
cons:
1. Ever-changing structure - You need to learn to adapt and move with the change.
2. Intel acronyms everywhere - You lose track of the conversation if you don't keep up-to-date with the acronyms. Thankfully there's an Intel Acronyms Dictionary available online.
3. Decision-making is slower due to the large organization size, and thus, more approval levels.

review_title: An "OK" place to work, not "GREAT" as marketed
job_title: Program Manager in San Jose, San Jose
pros: Cash bonuses are good, way over market average. Lots of flexibility, depending on your manager, lots of in-house perks (gym, clinic, massages, food vendors, sports area, shop, discounts). Lots of career development. There's order and structure in the majority of areas. Raises are a hit-and-miss, I've seen raises ranging from 3% to 30% for the same role, the same year.
cons: Has become too political - too many sacred cows. Not recommended for a long-term career, as the farther you go up the grade/salary scale and/or seniority, you´ll eventually be targeted for termination as you´ll be "too old" or "too expensive". HR  is way too political, serves only to prevent employees from forming an union, does little or nothing when facing sexual harassment, manager bullying, threats and such, especially if it comes from the "sacred cows".

review_title: EZ Grind but not for a new career
job_title: IT Software Development Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great benefits, flexible work schedule (get your work done up to you when and how long it takes), autonomy, Intel Shuttle. Really good for a safe career that you can autopilot
cons:
The work was dreadful. It was really boring and not at all challenging or cutting edge. There are times where you will be confused why you seniors are getting paid much more than you when it doesn't seem like they are doing much more work. It was tough to get modern software development practices in such an old company a lot of things were legacy and basics like Agile was considered groundbreaking... 
Promotions and rewards not based merely on merit. It also depends on seniority so you will have to wait your turn to promote.
Base pay was also pretty meager, they try really hard to comp with stocks but stocks vest in 4 years.

review_title: Just outa college, not a bad joint at all! The paychecks won't bounce, that's for sure.
pros:
-Work with very talented, ambitious, smart people
-Lots of areas to make lateral moves if you decide to switch focus (marketing,sales,technical,engineer)
-VERY direct communication with co-workers/managers. career dev, work/life balance, performance are all talked about openly
-everyone is so damn motivated! This rubs off which is great, but becomes stressful/tiring at times
-always enjoyed the people I've worked with, who are much older than me but fun to work with.
cons:
-working environment, grey cubes 
-super competitive. You'll need to be a workaholic to be noticed, which goes for most big tech companies 
-marketing group is very flat which makes promotions nearly impossible
-managers don't get paid more so you'll see a lot of 15 year veterans that aren't managers
-low moral due to headcount reduction over the years
-lots of ppl feel overwhelmed with their workloads

review_title: Leap Ahead or Fall Behind?
job_title: Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- World class manufacturing leadership and technology
- Big company perks/benefits: profit sharing contribution, sabbatical every 7 years, free fruit and drinks
- Overall good work/life balance, though it can be dependent on your team/manager
- Relatively stable during the economic downturn
cons:
- Compensation not competitive with the rest of the industry
- Too many meetings and politics. Slow decision making
- Focal process riddled with flaws. Raises have been stagnant for the past couple of years
- A lot of dead weight employees and managers at all levels. Too many incompetent first line/mid managers
- Complicated branding and awful marketing campaign
- Recent acquisitions/divestitures questionable

review_title: A great company ruled by Expat Managers
pros:
Great Work life balance
Decent salary, not a pay master
Great on campus facilities compared to other companies in India
Good employee benefits.
cons:
Bloated expat managers. All top management and their sub-ordinates are expats who come to India to have vacation for a few years before relocating back to US. 
Very hard to get promoted.
Relocation to US is really very hard especially if you are hired within India. However its a piece of cake for those who came from US.
Indian hires are not treated on par with their NRI counter-parts working in India.
Too much of bureaucracy. 
No room for meritocracy.Managers are biased towards employees who have same/similar technical skill sets as them. So employees in adjacent domain are always ignored.
Hardly a few groups work on good technology. You will find that the business model in India is more like a services model.

review_title: Good Company For Millennials Looking For Corporate Experience
pros:
Work-life flexibility
Amazing maternity leave program
Strong Culture
Encourages employees to be autonomous but can find collaboration when necessary
Stability
Low turnover
Women In Senior Roles
Cross-training opportunities
Global experience
Exciting products
Competitive salary (negotiate up because you might be stuck with this salary for a long long time)
Bonuses
cons:
You're working for a big company, and you can imagine what comes with that
You are in charge of your own destiny. If you don't seek support, mentoring and help you won't get it
Some slowness that comes with working in corporate
You need to be a strong person to work here and stand up for your ideas or you might get crushed
Company is working on refurbishing its brand
You will have some early and late meetings due to global co--take them from home and take a break during the day

review_title: Good money but difficult culture
pros: Had a very successful career. Made lots of money via bonuses and stock options. After regular email reminders from HR that I was eligible for retirement,  I decided to accepted enhance retirement package because the money was too good to pass and I felt the next time.
cons: The review process known as focal  is based on the philosophy of ranking and rating (R&R)  employees against grade level peers instead of against job requirements and responsibilities hindered collaboration and team work.   It was more important to have a personal relationship with the managers and be politically connected rather than being productive and delivering. Promotions were limited within the organization and regardless of grade level.  So if employees in different grade levels earned promotion, only one would get it.

review_title: Intel is not a good place for Mechanical Engineers
pros:
Intel pays well compared to other companies in Portland, OR.   

Intel has good health benefits.

Portland is a  wonderful place to live.
cons:
Intel does not appreciate the mechanical engineering discipline.  Intel CCG does not promote mechanical engineers like it does EE's.   Mechanical engineers are often treated as inferior.  Al SD o, most of the ME duties are not interesting.

Intel has a very agressive, combative culture.  It has horrible infighting between teams where secrets are kept and sabetauge exists.  Management is often technically poor and politically driven.  Intel does not promote teamwork.

review_title: Detrimental workspace and low morale out of Intel mother
pros:
Good company, incumbent in the industry. But don’t let this false confidence tell you how the benefits for the employees are because from some time those were worsening every year,  the last couple years they retire the car sales fleet then with the following excuse .- the “industry” ecosystem was doing the same. I prove that statement is false. 

And so on at the office I heard comments as ridiculous as, “you can’t order a “hi end” cell phone because it cost $1,000”
cons: You have to be very careful Intel mid management will find ways to short sell the commitments with the employees. So if you does not adhere 110% to the policy they will take advantage to invite you to quit with out paying full the severance package

review_title: Intel is ok, but could be a much better place
pros:
Good company for engineers, specially electronics engineers. There are some interesting projects, depending on the area you work for, but some positions are mostly validation, which is not that interesting imho. 

Benefits are good, and the company seems to be very ethical, but corporate management (CEO, VPs, etc.), sometimes seem to be somewhat disconnected from reality, and allocate too much compensation for themselves, and what trickles down to the rest is not very significant, specially when compared to the tens of millions and hundreds of thousands of shares these executives allocate for themselves (with BOD approval)...

I wish some of these companies would really try to offer more fair compensation schemes, where engineers would receive incentives, like small royalties on patents/papers, etc....
cons: Has the typical big corporation problems.

review_title: Saturated... but good place to get your semiconductor badge of honor
pros: cutting edge in semiconductors.  No better place to learn about industry - and get a badge of honor
cons: no future in hardware - especially semiconductors.  And especially at a saturated business like Intel's.  So my advice is to learn what you can, get your badge (of approval) and move on greener pastures to reap the benefits.

review_title: Bottom line: You need to make a spectacle of yourself to survive.
pros: In IT business applications group, I can't think of a good reason.  It was a "what have you done for me lately" and 'look what I did' mentality.  Often, the pace unrelenting, expectations unrealistic, decision making incomplete.  Benefits were good.
cons: Personally I didn't enjoy the mentality and culture, very driven for results, yet was hard to see what was a result when many made a spectacle of themselves in order to shine.  Since leaving in 2006, almost all of those I meet who have also left didn't like the experience and found themselves mentally or physically unhealthy from the stress.  I believe the underlying culture is flawed, and likely unable to change.

review_title: Ok, but has gone downhill since joining ~ 10 yrs ago
pros: Good benefits & pay is decent.  Get to work with some of the most advanced technology in the world.  Challenging work (at times).  Opportunities at times to try new things and move around within the company.
cons: Work life balance has turned to mostly all work (weekends / nights have been very common) and as a salaried employee there is NO compensation for this.  Stock options have been worthless for last ~ 9 yrs.  Feels like a job and not a career anymore.   Lack of training.  Opportunties for raises and advancement very limited in recent years and has more to do with situation (boss / department / company growth) and not actual individual performance.

review_title: Great place to work unless you're in ATTD
pros:
Great package overall.
Lifestyle is very relaxing.
Open environment.
Very casual dress code.
Facilities offer great things like on-site gym, medical facility, cafeteria, softball field, basketball and volleyball courts.
People (other than some management at TMG) are pretty cool.
Multicultural (it seems like a UN meeting everytime).
cons:
Compensation ($) wasn't great unless you have higher degrees and not even then.
Management at ATTD has a lot of flaws and they're not very open to change.
Workload at ATTD can be a little too much very often.
Not everyone is up to date when it comes to technology, so you have to deal with that.
Some people might be to hard to deal with.

review_title: A "team" of "self-centric" type A personalities isn't working.
pros: There are two reasons people work here.  First so they can tell people they work at Intel.  The main reason is they to pay a little more then other companies.
cons: Everyone is out for themselves, no team work.  Technical people spend half their day in meetings.  This is so that the third of the company that does nothing has something to report out.  No boundries on the hours meetings will be scheduled or the numbers of hours you work.  I survived another year is a coming saying, very sad.

review_title: Overall positive experience
pros:
- Interesting products.

- Many smart and experienced people to learn from.

- Flex hours and telecommuting contribute to a good working environment.

- Unlimited resources at your disposal (software licenses, compute farms, 3rd party tools).
cons:
The cons listed here probably apply to most large organizations so take this with a grain of salt:

- It takes forever to get promoted; salary stagnates and falls behind industry average.

- Too much bureaucracy and far too many meetings that don't accomplish anything.

- Going the extra mile often gets unnoticed and goes unrewarded.  This leads to a feeling of apathy and eventually demotivates the employee.

- Seemingly endless supply of poorly supported in-house tools with little-to-no 
documentation.  There's a bit of the "not-invented-here" syndrome that results in the reinvention of the wheel.    Having said that, there are sometimes legitimate reasons for sticking legacy tools but I feel that too often the effort required to maintain such a tool isn't accounted for (i.e. reuse isn't free in most cases).

review_title: Not as great a place to work as one may think...
job_title: Technical Marketing Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
*  Above-average salary, especially in Oregon, where most non-Intel salaries are below what they should be as compared to the cost-of-living.
*  Resources to get your job done are usually available with ease.
cons:
*  VERY unstable place to work.  Intel has started and killed soooo many project, products, and divisions.
*  Too many layers of management
*  Too many bad managers; people who never should be in management positions
*  Annual review process is very cutthroat and highly subjective.

review_title: Great opportunities, but hard to do them without lots of patience
pros: Opportunities to grow, large projects, exposure to the latest and greatest. Those that know what they are doing are committed and work hard, which is always a huge motivator for others.
cons: large bureaucracy, lack of accountability, managers lack experience in web world. There are too many people in charge who have been around for too long, and there's too many people around who have no idea how to run business now in the 20th century where business has significantly changed in the last 10 years. Intel attracts some of the brightest in the engineering world, but not necessarily in others parts of the company. Also, we rely too much on our agencies, you hired us, let us do our jobs!

review_title: Spent 37 hours a week on conference calls - whoo hooo
job_title: Human Factors Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Money was a big factors in why i took the job, other then that, not much else was good about Arizona except I met and maintain three strong friendships from there.
cons: I was there during the huge layoff period and anyone with any sense could see that things were going down hill fast, yet no senior management would provide a straight answer.  Actually listening to senior management made me sick, "it hurts me every time I have to layoff people . . .  ." not as if any senior management was really ever laid off.

review_title: Intel is an OK place to work
pros: Although the pay is great, Intel asks a lot from it's employees.  I enjoy, personally, many of my co workers.  I really like living in Portland - there isn't many finer cities in the USA.  Overall, I'm pretty satisfied with my current role and management structure.
cons: Intel seems to change organizationally a lot. Middle management seems to have political infighting that is completely unnecessary.   I prefer a place where people work together better and where the communication between employees are better.  Intel also tends to be a bit scattered and not very disciplined when it comes to getting work done.  Things are done fast in my area, but not very well thought out.

review_title: Meritocracy This Is Not...
pros: Benefits are definitely above par, most managers are flexible about when/how you do your work if you aren't in the Fab. However there are micromanagers, if you aren't willing to stand up to them they will control you. If you have the right person backing you, you can move up quickly.
cons:
Intel Finance is not a meritocracy, they spend a lot of time saying this but it's not true. You can be the best analyst in your incoming class, but if you have a bad manager you won't be any where near the quickest to move up. Head scratching hires occur regularly.

Intel Finance also does not value individual talent. Intel wants cogs to fit into their holes, regardless if individuals have valid points or data supporting their thought process it takes a ridiculous amount of data to even get someone to listen.

review_title: Software Engineering Manager/Program Manager/Scrum Master
job_title: Scrum Master in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Excellent benefits, this company gives you all the tools to complete tasks.  High level of engagement with all the teams I interact with, I rarely wait for a response, even from employees that are located in other Geos.
cons: The biggest con I have is not knowing the direction that Intel is taking, which for a tech giant is somewhat understandable but does leave me wondering about the future.

review_title: 10 year Veteran: Review
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel is a big company and you'll more than likely still have a job even when the economy is bad.
cons: compensation has been stagnant for the last 10 years.  It is not competitive relative to silicon valley.  As a matter of fact, it is considerably lower than the rest of silicon valley.  Promotions are not based on meritocracy as they claim on your first day of employment.  Intel is a large company and key decisions are made too slow.  As a result, Intel is consistently 'shooting behind the duck'.  Management is a bunch of outdated, unmotivated, risk adverse group of folks.  Combine all that together and we are always behind market trends....for example, we missed the boat on iPhone and wearables.  We are always playing catch up after the market is way ahead.  We are not innovating hence the stock price will always remain the same.

review_title: Like a mini, very bureaucratic government
job_title: Program Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Some great managers (if you're lucky, you'll get a good team with a supportive manager, if not, really sucks to be you), great employee resource groups, awesome D&I corporate team, annual chocolate day
cons: toxic work environment, need to ask for permission from 34358384 stakeholders and get everyone and their mother's buy in before moving forward (Intel has a very low risk tolerant culture), not supportive of young people and the development of employees, lots of terrible managers (micro managers), good ole' boys club, you seriously need to be there for 20 years and connected with the right people in order to move into a leadership position.  Terrible cafe food in headquarters.

review_title: Work life depends on your manager.
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Flex time, but it depends upon the manager you are reporting to. Ability to work from home when needed. Time to scale for new projects is very quick and you also have Intel University where you can learn about different areas in electronics.
cons: Work can sometimes be very grueling and during RTM there is a lot of rush. Sometimes a lot of employees feel stressed. Ratings and reviews are the only way to live your life, and you have to be on constant guard to maintain a good review.

review_title: Force Curves = Your career depends on giving negative feedback on your peers.
job_title: Senior Patent Attorney in Hillsboro, OR
pros: The people are mostly very cool, have great ideas, and work very hard to develop them.
cons: Most of the hard work is fighting with others.  Sometime it is simple education about the issues, but more often than not it is ownership and credit.  The annual performance evaluation system only lets you rate your immediate manager.  So you can't reach the poor managers above.  You can submit voluntary evaluations, but they aren't anonymous and can be ignored.  Special projects, not your day job, is what gets rewarded.  And lots of people game the system and give negative feedback on their peers to reduce their scores - because everyone is forced into a curve.

review_title: Meritocracy is alive and well at Intel.
pros: There are always an endless number of challenges available to work on. The stakes can be high, it is especially rewarding to realize that a small project or change you make can easily save the company millions of dollars. Variable is quite good, but sometimes it as though the stock does not correlate to the outstanding job we do.
cons: Work-life balance can be a challenge. To be really successful you need to work 60 hours a week. Management will still respect you if you choose to work only 40, but you won't get the promos and big raises. There are always people who are willing to sacrafice their personal life to get ahead.

review_title: Intel Corporation -- stay for a resume-padding job, then leave for a real career elsewhere
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Hmmm... large company, resume name-recognition, free coffee?
cons: Bureaucratic mess... decision-making and matrix-type management often entangled by political agendas and vendettas.  Not a place to advance a career.  Doesn't match up to the careers available to new college grads or MBA's from top schools say at Google or Wall Street.  Often, grads from top schools leave because they realize most of the senior people at Intel are from much lesser backgrounds and don't share the fast-tracking mindset and career interest.

review_title: No longer the Intel that I was proud to work for
pros: Benefits, Sabbatical/vacation, access to latest technololgy, the people.
cons:
Intel today is not even close to the Intel that I started working for in 1992. Ranking and Rating is a joke especially if your not the managers fave!..and while on the subject of managers, during my last 7 years there I had at least that many managers, however, there wasnt one of them that really knew how to manage, unless being one of  the Good Ol Boys qualifes someone to be a manager. 

But what is most phenominal of all is after someone has worked there for the better part of their life, at some point you become a target and once that happens, its over. I use to wonder why people that had worked there for years, one day, they werent there anymore. No explanation, nothing, just gone...........

My advice for folks wanting to work for Intel.............have a plan B.

review_title: Great company.... if you can navigate the politics
job_title: Wireless Systems Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great technology and people to work with, and good compensation/benefits. Exposure to different technologies
cons: if you don't know how to navigate the politics, the constant re-organization of groups will hurt you / your career. Tendency to keep same managers in place / rotate them, rather than empower some of the rising stars who have proven themselves in various areas. Skills vs. positions for some of the managers will make you check your sanity. Some managers focus on maintaining their headcount at the expense of growth possibility for some of their team members (they will sacrifice you for their own benefit). They have lost some excellent talent to competitors due to the above.

review_title: A good company, smart people, poor management and diminshed vision.
pros: Flexible work hours and environment. It's a big place and with some work you can move around and find your spot for a while. You never stop running into amazing and smart people. Intel is a power-house of brains!
cons: A lot of management. So much brain-power yet it sometimes feels like a Ferrari stuck in 2nd gear. Corporate management has lacked vision for many years. Recent lay-offs-by-spreadsheet and lack-luster stock performance impact moral. I feel we are turning more into a factory than a place of research and innovation.

review_title: Okay
pros: Intel pays well and the benefits are good.  It's also a very large company with lots of different jobs.  Many campuses to choose from.  New Mexico, to Cali, to Oregon.
cons: Most of the jobs require way more education than is really needed.  Half of my time at Intel, a chimp could have been trained to do my job, if it weren't for the cleanroom environment.  Management treats lower employees like they are meaningless and have no value, even though the managers appear to do very little.  Everyone is scared for their jobs now and no one is happy it seems in any position, at least any of the ones that I converse with.

review_title: Good, if not great, place to work
job_title: Network Software Validation Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Pay was excellent, as were the benefits. Having a sabbatical every 4 or 7 years is so great, and the vacation policy is very good, too. Worked with some outstanding people, and the overall atmosphere (when people aren't getting laid off) is generally positive. Work/life balance in my division/role was also quite good.  Diversity is also excellent at Intel.
cons: Despite risk-taking being a corporate value, it seemed like upper management wasn't very good at it. Was fairly well-practiced at lower levels, though, at least in my department.  Organizational intertia was difficult to overcome when attempting process improvements in certain aspects of the business. Also, too much reliance on internally-created tools makes it difficult to translate experience if you find yourself suddenly forced to look for employment elsewhere.

review_title: Poisonous Atmosphere in InfoSec
job_title: Information Security Specialist in Folsom, CA
pros: Great Salary. Free coffee, though it says Starbucks it tastes nothing like it. Free bananas. Can get training without travel fairly easy.
cons:
Every interview since leaving Intel said having Intel on the resume in the local job market is a bad mark on your record.
Toxic environment in InfoSec. Failed leadership, bad managers, cut throat environment with people sabotaging your every chance at success so they look better than you so they aren't the one that gets cut in the "lay off ten percent at every review cycle" rule. Anyone with any skills has ran like heck to get out of the toxic environment. This job is a career ending move.

review_title: No opportunities for growth
pros:
- Large teams to support complex projects
- Job stability in certain groups
- New graduates have a good amount of time to transition from academia to industry
cons:
- Terrible organizational management
- Lack of transparency
- No recognition for high performers unless they know the "right" people
-  Human Resources department is a complete joke. A very close friend of mine had this happen to them. This former employee worked as part of a dysfunctional group that was not contributing anything to the company. The group had no technical leadership and no vision from the management. When the employee decided to quit because they got a better job offer, the company accepted the resignation and after the 2 week notice period including training other team members, chose to cancel the resignation and terminated this person on their last day of employment despite receiving Successful and EE reviews consecutively.

review_title: Plenty of opportunity
pros: Plenty of opportunity and great benefits at Intel. Finance provides great upward mobility along with work life balance that is difficult to find when I talk to my peers at another companies. The next closest one is Adobe. If you don’t like finance, there’s opportunities to move to operations.
cons: AZ has a big site, but Oregon is the main site. At some point if you want to keep moving up you need to move to Oregon or Santa Clara.

review_title: 85 - 90% of the employees can coast by and be successful
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: 85 - 90% of the employees can coast by and be successful. If you are not interested in improving your skills, but keeping a reasonably decent salary, Intel is a place to consider.
cons:
If you are interested in making a difference in the industry, and take pride in doing the best work you are capable of, don't expect to be rewarded for it. 
Those who are successful at Intel can expect a 3% raise.
If you have some competence in a particular field and try to support your team by making a reasonable, well thought out recommendation in your field of expertise, you should expect to be criticized, stonewalled, but most generally ignored by individuals with less experience, and whose primary responsibility at the company is pushing paper around in infinite circles in an attempt to validate their own job security.

review_title: Good for RCGs but not for lateral hires
pros: If you get a chance to work on projects from other sites, it will be much more challenging and interesting than working on home projects.
cons:
First Level Management is really not capable of leading a team. They became managers, just after going through couple of projects. They dont know to plan, organize and no vision of even 3 months. The longest they can see is probably 1-2 weeks. Unfortunately, these are the people whom the upper management relies completely for taking their decision.
In case your work is noticed in other sites like Israel, US, they appreciate your work honestly. Indian management fail to recognize and respond only when their US counterparts praise.

review_title: Good top management, poor middle managers.
pros:
Top managers are frank. Benefits are reasonable. Good starting company for college grads.
Some company policies have good intentions.
Company finance is well managed.
cons:
Each site has its own culture. Too much politics in some sites. 
It has annual rank and rate performance, used by poor managers to get rid of unfavorable people to satisfy quota.
To much bs presentations to managers for their corresponding bs presentations to their managers for their advancement. Wasting engineer's time and diverting their attention from technical development.

review_title: Truly a great place to work- Amazing culture
job_title: Industrial Engineer in San Jose, San Jose
pros: Work-Life Balance, Great Benefits, flexible work & hours depending on who's your boss, it's like a University and you get to take a lot of courses, you have access to all of the learning & knowledge that a corporation like Intel has available. Open door policy- you can talk to anyone, irrelevant if it's a simple Supervisor or the Site Manager. Great focus towards the employee as a person. Company values are great.
cons: Very steady organization- which can be good but it also means close to zero promotions. Not a good place to grow vertically, they focus on "horizontal development". Very big and is currently changing a lot trying to catch up to the market. Salary increases are not good right now due to the company's situation.

review_title: Good company in the 1990s and 2000s. Internal high level politics not visible to outside world resulting in instability.
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Undeniably the best company to start one's career... Many opportunities to learn, move to different type of responsibilities, great pay and compensation, etc.
cons: Of late, not being able to get a foot hold in the low power market has started a large chess game type internal politics where pawn sacrifices are being made with the hope of long term prospects... It appears however it might be too late. Hopefully it will not end up the Motorola way.

review_title: Learned a lot in a very organized company full of intelligent people
pros: They are very disciplined, professional, competent people and a lot of excellent project managers. Standards are high and the work is challenging. There is a culture of getting the job done rather than doing the hours and the flexibility of working from home was good in my department. I never felt like I was doing a boring 9 to 5 job, it was a lot of hard work but with the working from home it didn't feel so bad. My team was also fun and friendly.
cons: Swindon isn't a great location and the offices are a bit sad, catering is terrible. Sometimes the company is too process driven which could be stifling in certain jobs. Not enough turnover which means the company doesn't learn from others.

review_title: Good to work ..but keep options open
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Sacramento, CA
pros: technology leaders in the world of semiconductor. At this time intel is going in all the fields so to learn about any new technology that will be shaping the future in terms of wireless and chipset this is the place to work.
cons: Management is really poor. The upper level is not able to see the engineering morale and the reason of its being low. the main reason of this is immidiate managers. Its not that all the managers are not employee friendly but as they control your focal sometimes they think that they own you and you work for them not intel. It will be better if upper management spend some time in seeing which managers are not coming upto there standards and feedback should be taken from engineering staff not from the fellow managers.

review_title: Nice exterior, lemony on the inside.
pros: Flexible time, bonuses. Challenging environment. People believe that you work for a great company that has a role in changing the world.
cons: Unfairness, payscale is on the very low end of competitive. Brain drains are common. Company does not care that their time and money invested in forming top performing employees and future leaders, simply exits the door in a zinch, because another company offered them a better salary, but on the middle to upper end of the "competitive" range. Costs are cut hiring very young and inexperienced employees. Lots of money is wasted on corporate visits, but simple perks as traveling on business class for a 48 hour flight is a no-no. Many things tend to point that scrooges run the company.

review_title: You can learn alot, but be prepared to work long hours and make sure you have a good manager
job_title: Technical Training Program Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good benefits and generally you work with very smart people that you can learn from. You will be exposed to working with people from all over the world.  In the right position you can have an opportunity to travel and provide input on strategic direction.
cons: In the wrong position you can work very long hours and not get the recognition that you deserve.  It all depends on your manager. You will most likely struggle with work/life balance espcially if both you and your spouce/partner work at Intel and you have small children.  The company tends to run in boom/bust cycle as far as spending on projects/employee development.

review_title: A Mature Semiconductor company, good for experience building but not career growth
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good resume building experience as everyone is familiar with the company.  Able to change jobs internally (when the company was growing) to gain a variety of experiences needed to further your career.  For the most part, people there are capable and motivated to do a good job.
cons: Jobs are very compartmentalized so if you stay around, you'll have to have several jobs to get a well-rounded experience.  The core business of microprocessors is run "by the book", so there's not a lot of room for creativity or initiative.  New business areas have been mostly a failure and Intel has exited most of its prior attempts at diversification into communications, cellular wireless, and optics.  Many layers of management and review serve to make decision making slow and cumbersome and minimize innovation and risk-taking.

review_title: Intel jumped the shark.
pros:
Good work/life balance. You don't have to work 80 hours/week.
There are almost always clear, well articulated objectives.
Each person is reviewed based on their own individual performance.
Very disciplined work environment.
cons:
Dinosaur economics.  Chip manufacturing used to be a growth industry, and it isn't anymore.  So, there is little opportunity for career advancement unless someone up the ladder drops dead or retires.

Pay is at best "poor" compared to the alternatives out there
It is no longer a fun place to work.  

Intel is run as if it were a $40 BILLION small family business.  Only the opinions of a handful of top execs, all of whom have worked together for 30 years, really matter.  Everyone else is just a supplier of data.

review_title: Circuit Designer
pros: Very smart and dynamic people. Great opportunity to learn and develop. A well know brand name that opens up doors anywhere in the world. Most employees are young and outgoing. Many of my close friends I met through Intel and stayed ever since.
cons: Large Corporation with very intelligent and motivated people which makes it a bit harder to get ahead and be recognized. Although most employees who do a good job receive some kind of recognition.

review_title: Can be a technically exciting place to work.
pros: Technical work can be very interesting.  Large benevolent company with the resources  to provide many benefits to and opportunities for employees.
cons: With the exception of microprocessors, Intel has been ineffective at entering new product areas.  Not clear how long business model can continue to be successful.  In spite of attempts to re-structure, streamline and innovate, improvements in decision making and risk staking continue to fall short.  Many senior managers are very political despite attempts for improvement.  Recent publicity and actions regarding business and marketing practices by the EU, the FTC, etc are embarrassing to employees.  A lot of internal training on conducting business in an ethical manner which emphasizes the importance of how thing are perceived as well as their legality.  Given this, how did Intel manage to attract so much negative attention?

review_title: Intel Corp
job_title: Business Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros: They did provide adequate training and believed in continuing education.  They also tried to promote worklife balance and community volunteer programs to support the local schools.
cons: Intel has gone through a lot of up and downs affecting job stability-- there were a lot of lay offs during my time at Intel making it a very stressful place to work.  Did I mention it was a very stressful work enironment? HR is cutthroat and when they need to cut numbers will find ways to get rid of people so they don't have to pay any severence.  Further, promotion/raises were far and few between; however you could always count on getting additional duties and responsiblities as they with out the promotions/pay raises because of personnel cut backs.

review_title: Mixed bag
pros: Generally good culture, benefits above average, best transistor technology, many smart colleagues, free drinks, fruits and fun events. Quite agile for a 100K+ employee company but at a cost (see below), willing to get into new businesses, learn and compete.
cons:
Intel has been around a while and that has meant changing directions and getting into new businesses. The cost is cyclical hiring and layoffs. Rather than punishing the leaders that made wrong choices its the work force that suffers more.
Mixed quality of management. Manufacturing and technology development generally has a rough culture, the culture is promoted by the higher management and valued as a way to generate new ideas but realistically just causes passive aggressive behavior. 
Some VPs are busier with internal empire building than actual business strategy to benefit Intel.

review_title: Your Manager and Partners Make ALL the Difference
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: You get to work with some of the smartest people on some of the most interesting technologies.  Its a company that can drive changes in multiple industries and countries.  Figure out what you are passionate about, get on the right project, work hard, and make a difference while enjoying your career.  Lots of new leaders, mgrs, and employees coming in from many other companies is creating aculture that is MUCH more open to innovative ideas and approaces than in the past.
cons: Work for the wrong manager or the wrong project and you'll burn out in frustration.  The company is going through major transitions, so roles and projects can change for the worse (or the better) very quickly.

review_title: Top three company on the planet.  Work hard and grow
pros: No stupid people.  Annoying and weird at times, but highest concentration of intelligence anywhere in the world.  Everyone is best in their field.  Lots of internal movement between groups.  Perqs and work environment are better than even what you've heard.  Most jobs are very flexible.  Manufacturing and R&D for Manufacturing are like the military if you like that.
cons: Complex place, decisions are hard and can be slow.  Not a place to relax.  Hard on your psyche- everyone is amazing and like all jobs resources are limited so you can feel average or below average even when being told you are doing great.  A lot of people need counseling because they aren't used to being told they can do better.

review_title: Good opportunity but heavy on politicss
pros:
Good benefits. Work like balance can be a challenge for network specialist. 
Good management / perks / appreciations / RSUs/ health benefits and etc
cons:
Heavy on politics, group-ism, nepotism just in a day to bear. Hard to get personal space as you need to be constantly on your toes for political relevance. 
Saw lot of good and talented people leave because of it. 
Promoting / getting projects because of politics and  not because of talent
Killing talent rather than nurturing it - what a waste of this organisation

review_title: Your life depends on your manager
pros: Great place to work if you get along with your boss and coworkers but mostly just your boss so pucker up- It's only reality. Health plan and benefits are okay.
cons: Pay is meh, so just expect it to pay your bills and you won't be disappointed. If your manager treats you like poo then you're screwed. I've known people who have left because they have beefs with their managers. Like I said, if you get along with your manager then everything's peachy so you'll need to do some "smoothing work". If you two don't get along, time to say goodbye because you're not going to last without manager backing.

review_title: Not worth investing your time, build seniority with another company.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Better than being unemployed.  Free drinks in the cafe.  The people are generally nice.  The managment could be more clueless but not by much since they are approching absolute zero.
cons: Insane pressure to meet ridiculous schedules set by incompetent managers.  The bathrooms in C7 are too small and smell pretty bad.  The new cube configuration is a mess, the walls are so low there is no privacy.   Low moral due to long hours and poor T-Comp.  Most employees would leave if given a similar job at another company.  The stock options are worthless.  Sub par employees are made managers because of the people then know or of the pictures they have.

review_title: The good things are really good, and then there is the downside!
pros: It's great to work for a company on the leading edge of technology. Risk taking is rewarded even if the risk fails. Work/life balance is a priority and encouraged at all levels. Communication from all levels of management is excellent. It really is ok to question the decisions and motives of Sr. Management and we have open forums to do just that.
cons: Although they say they encourage teamwork, the process for salary increases/stock is based on individual performance and managers compare us to our peers performance, which can be very subjective. Retirement benefits are nonexistant. If you're and engineer it's a great place to advance, if your not it's just a good place to work.

review_title: Mostly good people; most managers suffer from King-Complex instead of focus on talents of team members.
pros: The work is challenging in the best sense of the word.  There are constant puzzles to solve, and you can see your work has applications and that is very satisfying.
cons: Efforts of the Admins are very often unseen, under-appreciated, and they are frequently treated with disrespect.  There's a snobbishness at Intel among its managers.  Too many systems get in the way of being immediately effective.

review_title: Great place to work .... if you end up in the right team
job_title: Senior Product Development Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Intel has been like a University to me. You learn and grow alot in a very short time. Since It's a semiconductor business the industry is fast and aggressive. If you are passionate for your career and are young and single Intel is the place to be.
cons:
Alot of politics on the processor side of the company. People are trying hard to let others down and shine themselves so they don't receive an IR. 

Pay increases can be slow, unless you are competitive and really put in the time and effort OR you change job roles internally frequently.

Job insecurity: there will be re-orgs and you will need to outshine to keep your current job. It is possible that you are a valuable asset but the project get's moved or cancelled so you have to hawk internal openings all the time. Not a great feeling if you have a family to feed.

review_title: Slow wage growth if you have been here long
pros:
Sales has a car plan with free cars +insurance + gas (unlimited)
Many jobs to rotate through without having to leave the company
Development Opportunities to try out new roles while others are on leave or Sabbatical
Sabbatical !!! 4wks every 4yrs or 8wks every 7yrs
cons:
CEO has poor regard for people
Secretive layoffs
Sales was told we would get more people...then they cut 100's
Too much nepotism..but claim meritocracy
Yes -Men managers brown nose and do not reward on merit, reward on brown nosing and favorites
The longer you are at Intel, the more your wages get compressed. New hires come in at wages that are much higher than what you had to beg and sell your sole for (not that I'm against people getting a good wage, I think its a slap in the face to all that are loyal and get a 1% raise).
Low decision making skills from managers

review_title: Middle management is poor
job_title: Graphics Hardware Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Decent work life balance, soda is free in the cafe, folsom cost of living is lower than other city locations but that may also mean fewer options on relocating to folsom area
cons: Intel middle management values you only until talent acquisition, once that is done, even after contributing to the company year after year, people are paid poorly and substandard compared to the market. Middle and lower management is useless and relies on constant politics to stay afloat. Funds allocated by the CEO for meritocracy are consumed by middle and low management or just allocated to their favorites. Even women are treated unfairly, women with children or childless women, they are both second class citizens inside Intel. No change on that till to-date meritocracy is largely abused.

review_title: Agency Inside: Toe the Line and You'll Be Fine
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: They're aspirational: Executives see themselves as a thriving, creative, leadership organization. They pay well, with decent benefits. Pet projects can be well funded. As long as the staff keep their heads down and follow direction, they keep their jobs.
cons: Agency Inside is just another in-house comms department that's top heavy,  political, and lacks the ability to affect meaningful change. A few folks in the inner circle produce some interesting work. Otherwise, much of the staff are relegated to production-level assignments. Everyone from group CDs on down complain constantly and bitterly. They're discontented, frustrated, and dispirited. If you're not among the inner circle, be prepared to be treated dismissively and disrespectfully. Internal clients regard the organization as a useful in-house resource, but certainly not as strategic partners, and definitely not as trusted creative drivers.

review_title: Just another peon.
pros: Flex-time.  Get your work done and they won't focus on when you clock in and clock out.  Quarterly offsites for team building.  Always something new to work on.
cons: Soulless environment.  Gray cubes, gray walls, gray floor.  All the hallways are enclosed so you need to make an effort just to find a window to look out of.  Tuition reimbursement is rigged.  Unlike companies that do tuition reimbursement from a centralized HR, they control it at the department level budget.  So you must present a case that it will help your immediate job,  despite it helping further your overall career.  So if you are looking for them to pay for a grad degree, don't count on it.

review_title: Work/Life Balance
pros: Great Work/Life Balance; you can telecommute whenever you need, and there's an outdoor basketball court and gym you can use at any time. People are very smart, and there's a lot of opportunity to move around inside the firm between different opportunities. Good culture, and you're at the best semiconductor company in the world; everyone respects the brand when you look for employment elsewhere (if you choose to leave).
cons: offices are the definition of cube farms; feels like a dilbert cartoon. The company is mature, so the stock isnt going to make millionaires out of anyone; management needs to restructure their compensation plans to reflect this new reality. Its a huge company, it can be frustratingly slow in some of the bigger projects to make your mark or really contribute (although there are smaller prohects you can jump into that have better opportunities if you can find them)

review_title: Big company trying to become more agile
pros:
Opportunities to work with some of the most brilliant people in the chip design industry (who also often happen to be some of the nicest...)

Flexible work schedules for non-fab employees

Paid 8 week sabbatical every 7 years

Good benefits/pay -- automatic retirement contribution from company (not a match like most)

Work/life balance is reasonable in most positions -- company seems committed to improving this even more.
cons:
Slow cumbersome bureaucratic decision-making process at all levels.  The company has tried to fix this at the corporate level but the results have been mixed at best and have not really made it down to rank-and-file employees.

Poor project-planning and project resourcing.  Constant crisis-mode operation is the result.

Review process based on bell curve and arbitrary HR quotas.

review_title: Total disorganization.
pros: The technology itself is mildly interesting.
cons: The Sales Director is an engineer and has no sales background.  Management is extremely condescending, non-communicative and very disorganized. The person put in charge of mentoring me wouldn't return my emails and phone calls for 3 weeks - and I was working remotely from home. No training was offered until week 6, and I was forced to present at IT shows in front of 75 MSPs with absolutely no training or preparation. When they finally gave me one hour of training, my boss IM'd me when I asked a question, "Don't show weakness." He didn't care if I actually learned, just wanted himself to look good. The order process is archaic and fulfillment is dicey. I started to lose confidence that we could actually deliver what we were selling. This is not an easy sell or ramp-up. Travel is required almost every week. All in all a horrible experience and this was the worst treatment in my professional career.

review_title: I have a lot of happy and memorable events at Intel, this company is an ideal company I ever had.
job_title: Material Specialist (Stores Clerk) in Cavite, Nueva Ecija
pros: Best reasons to work at Intel is the Intel Values that the company has. The company's priorities are the safety of all employees. They know how to give rewards to all dedicated employees. And even involvement to the community works.
cons: My downside in working Intel Corporation is only  when the management decided to close our site and transfer to other country.  It's really hard for us to accept the reality that we are no longer an Intel employee.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: Sabbatical every 7 years rocks
cons: Too much middle management, too rigid telecommuting policy, slow to react, blinders

review_title: A great place to work
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great place to work on a variety of projects and receive global experience.  I can honestly say I was never, ever bored and was always challenged to be my very best.  The company values constructive confrontation and is very data driven so you need to be able to thrive in that kind of environment to succeed.  Intel also has a great sabbatical program which helps make up for the challenges in work/life balance.  Overall, I'm very proud to have had the opportunity to work at Intel and recommend the company.
cons: Work/Life balance can be challenging; however, I believe this is probably true of most global technology companies.

review_title: Enter at your own risk....
pros: Travel benefits and in-house training.  Additional certifications are encouraged.
cons: Highly dysfunctional work environment.  Does not promote based on work effort and ethics, but favoritism towards certain employees regardless of their lack of competency.  Very political based on certain past/present lead auditors allowed to infiltrate based on cut-throat anticates.  This organization continuously has to be to told to hire minorities at the corporate level (although overall Intel is not known for endorsing behind closed doors).  A lot of new employees immediately want out.  Jobs/careers are threatened when managers become privy of those not adapting to the concentration camp environment.  Management is corrupt and known for throwing employees under the bus when their (mgrs) mistreatment and unethical behavior becomes an issue.  Have denied employees training when training budget was available.

review_title: Good company, decent benefits, presently rudderless
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Great environment with access to lots of smart people.
Good, challenging work and the opportunity to move around the company to see what different parts of the business are like.
Okay pay, good bonuses sometimes, sabbaticals are great.
Give back to the community and opportunities to volunteer.
cons:
Schedule, schedule, schedule...at all costs!
Began using restricted stock unit levels as an additional method of providing a negative ranking.  This was not universally understood, and if you switch jobs within Intel, you could (I did) end up with a low stock rating for an otherwise good performance.
Political correctness and diversity at all costs - it made it difficult to find or hire qualified people, and ultimately made it hard to get our jobs done.

review_title: Great Place to Work and other lies they told me
pros: Guaranteed overtime every week due to working a compressed schedule.
cons:
Poor management. Definitely likely to be the first "thrown under the bus" if you aren't one of the "favorites" on the team. Bureaucracy heavy and slow to change. Say they want input but usually not responsive to said input. Asks for many contributions and volunteering for side projects with little to no compensation for additional work. Usually work that is supposed to be done by someone else but who doesn't want to be bothered with it.

Bizarre company culture. Talk about mutual respect and diversity yet encourage an atmosphere where finger pointing and blaming others takes precedence over actual accomplishments. Those that do accomplish are seldom rewarded while those who point fingers seem to be rewarded for pointing fingers.

review_title: Great work life balance
pros:
Work life balance
retirement contribution around 5 percent (depends on each year) without you anything contributing to 401k
You can change internally between teams easily compared to outside. In fact intel opens many position to hire only internally.
cons:
Not fast paced
Not a good place for software developers
This is not a software company
You hear people saying "Intel does not know how to release software"
You can still survive, if you don't do the job
Focal - year end review is joke - My manager almost promised me will give grade increase, but at the end he said that upper management changed it, even though he recommended it.
Cloud - Does not have cloud infrastructure like AWS or AZURE.
Pay is not nowhere near to market. I was surprised intel pays low compared to other big software companies.

review_title: Overall, Intel rocks!!!!
pros: Working for Intel teaches you self discipline. Because you are out in the field, you are your own business unit. The fact that management trusts you and values your ideas and input makes working for Intel extremely rewarding.  The amount of knowledge that you gain is priceless. Also the fact that you're working with and are associated with the best minds in the business is a huge bonus.
cons:
As a contractor, you don't get benefits like medical aid, pension. Also working through an inflexible agency is also puts a damper on things.
Because the people are such a tight knit clan, it's difficult for a newcomer to fit in.

review_title: Good place to work, challenging engineering problems, ability to influence entire industries
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in DuPont, WA
pros:
- Open, honest, consistent communication (and lots of it)
- Very disciplined
- Process oriented
- Results driven
- Strong company / corporate culture across all sites
- 2 month paid sabbatical after 7 years of hard work
- Well defined technical career ladder
cons:
- Not enough customer focus
- Inability to be agile
- Too much focus on process chokes innovation (particularly software)
- Work environment can be stressful due to focus on results
- Myopic business focus (it's always just "CPUs, chips, semiconductors..."; that's all management seems to understand)

review_title: Challenging work but very demanding work environment
pros:
Varied and challenging work.  Some of the practices and initiatives are truly leading edge.
Plenty of opportunities to manage your own career by moving between different functions although it is getting tougher to make this happen.
Pay and benefits are good.  Big imporvements being made to the working environment.
cons:
Work/life balance.  It's close to 365 working days in the year.
Meeting & email overload.
Too many decision-makers make it difficult to get work done.  Somebody is always intruding.
You're expected to know the detail of EVERYTHING.
Too much of an old-boy network at the very top of the company.  The most senior leaders have been working together for decades.

review_title: Intel is going through another strategic inflection point
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Ability to move up is limited, but there are plenty of opportunities to move laterally.  A lot of employees seem to telecommute since some team members may reside in different Intel sites and time zones.
cons: Employee morale is the lowest it has been in 20 years.  Intel has a history of investing in a lot of projects, but only to cancel them later.  It is not uncommon for a veteran employee to have the scars from several projects that have been cancelled.

review_title: Be ready for layoffs!
pros: Great pay, time off, and health insurance
cons: Crappy schedules, a lot of technicians get stuck working nights 7pm-7am and cannot get off of them. You have to work weekends and holidays all of the time also. Lately raises have been very little or none at all. Biggest of all, you have to worry "will I have a job next year, or will I have to move to another state just to hopefully keep it if I am lucky?".

review_title: Challenging work rewarding environment
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Work with exceptionally bright, driven people to tackle problems on the very forefront of technological and manufacturing and capability.  Outstanding resources available at this firm to help you achieve goals, and technically-oriented management is engaged in helping clear hurdles in your way.  Be an important part of one of the most technologically advanced organizations on earth, one which directly impacts the way billions of people engage each other and the world around them.
cons: The demands of 24x7 development and manufacturing can be a lot to bear for anyone, it can be hard at times to handle all the challenges coming at you at once.  Sort of like drinking from a fire-hose.  With large scale (100k employees) comes bureaucracy - sometimes there's too much red-tape.

review_title: PC Marketleader has a hard time to adapt to the Smartphone age
pros: I have met a lot of smart people at Intel. The diverse setup of sites allows you see many different places, if you are interested in that. The company is (still) producing a lot of cash which makes a somewhat stable company
cons: The growth in PC and Server market is limited. Intels market share in the mobile industry is very, very small. The setup of Intel is very vertical, you got a lot of silos. To get things done, you need to include/involve many departments which makes progress sometimes very cumbersome.

review_title: Great company
pros: If you like technology and you want to be part of one of the companies that actually define the future of the world, Intel is the place to be.  They treat people very well, and invest in the employees Career Development.
cons: I think the company has lost some important opportunities in the last decade, and needs to redefine itself to continue being as relevant as it was in the past.  At the same time, I'm confident they will get it done right, because a healthy business paranoia and being able to change are part of Intel's DNA.

review_title: Safe company in the downturn economy
job_title: Design Engineer Lead  in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The size of the company make it safe, stable working environment for engineers, especially during the economic downturn. Intel is a big company, so you may have more chance to move around different departments if you like to switch careers and persue a new career. The overall compensation is average among the industry. every 7 year, you earn 2 month sabbatical, nice vacation for a break from everyday work.
cons: the benefit is not the best in the industry, company stock performance is below average during the last several years makes the stock option worthless. typical work faces bureaurcracy and many unnecessary meetings that reduce people's productivity. The company and project team is too big, engineers force to learn only specific area and stick with it, lose the chance to undertand the breadth of the overall design.

review_title: Great work culture, great place to learn...
job_title: Undergraduate Technical Intern in Folsom, CA
pros: There are a lot of smart people at Intel. The projects are cutting-edge and interesting. Intel provides a library of knowledge to get up to speed. They provide great benefits and work balance (sponsors a lot of fun events for employees to attend). Brand recognition. Good future outlook for the company.
cons: Much of your experience at Intel will depend on which teams you work with. I was blessed to have a great team who bring enthusiasm and ideas to work everyday. I have heard completely opposite things about other teams. There is a lot of process -- meetings, deadlines, presentations, logistics. A lot of redundant work goes around in the company. Heard promotion process was not as fair as it should be... depends a lot on your manager and what projects you work on in order to move up.

review_title: Job stability is plus. Job stress could be very high-very low based on job. Salary is not the great
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: If you are a hardware engineer, you would love it  because you could be designing one of the most complex things in the world. Job stability is something that you would like.
cons: Based on which group you work on your stress level will vary. Could be very bad. Salary is not the best. You can easily find someone beating the intel salary if you are good engineer.

review_title: Mixed bag
pros: Intel is the technology leader in the semiconductor industry.  As a recent graduate, you will get a ton of training and be well prepared on how to solve key industry issues.
cons: The experience you have will vary significantly with the area where you work.  If you work in the technology area, TMG, you are likely to have a position which is geared to recent college graduates, where your work is highly specified and very controlled.  After a few years, this will get old and you won't like it.  The Copy Exactly model for process transfer is stunning in its success - however, it crushes any creativity and teaches you to do as you are told.

review_title: Mixed bag
pros: Intel is the technology leader in the semiconductor industry.  As a recent graduate, you will get a ton of training and be well prepared on how to solve key industry issues.
cons: The experience you have will vary significantly with the area where you work.  If you work in the technology area, TMG, you are likely to have a position which is geared to recent college graduates, where your work is highly specified and very controlled.  After a few years, this will get old and you won't like it.  The Copy Exactly model for process transfer is stunning in its success - however, it crushes any creativity and teaches you to do as you are told.

review_title: Great Place to work and it will keep you very busy
pros: Challenging Environment.  Advancements are (mostly) merit based.  Competitive pay and good bonus structure.  Very good benefits.  Easy process to take days off or a personal day. Great and smart peers.  Managers are technical and (mostly) can do the job of those they manage. Great system for managing personal information, purchasing, scheduling, pay stubs, benifits etc.
cons: A sizable portion of group leaders and lower level managers have poor people skills. The environment is very stressful, and often the stress takes a toll on employees.  HR does not understand the interactions of a very smart and focused engineers.  HR expects all of them to exhibit interpersonal skills they do not have (and knew they did not have through the hiring process).  Poor pathways to develop interpersonal skills and limited role models.

review_title: Challenging Technical Environment with Management Inconsistencies
pros: Great pay and benefits.  Great people with strong technical skills and a culture of execution
cons: Management practices are not uniform and could be greatly improved.  The employee review process is driven to be contentious with the assumption that all managers and/or organization will have a distribution of poor performing employees, and thus forces improvement discussions in the annual review to meet assumed distributions

review_title: Do you like having multiple managers?
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Bellevue, WA
pros: Decent salary if you negotiate well and compare with local employers (at least in Bellevue), Good Dental Plan, Lots of resources for learning, Company shuttle if you live in serviced areas, Discount on PC parts, Free beverages & snacks,
cons: Politics, Turf battles, Low ball offers at hiring time, Lots of Late Night Meetings, Employee review system is opaque and always changing, Lots of reorgs (had 7 managers in 1.5 years), Employee reviews difficult with so many managers, Constant fear of layoffs coming from above, Small salary increases, No Christmas Party, Few team events, No fitness benefits on smaller sites,

review_title: Big company, lots of bureaucracy
pros: Lots of changes over the last 10 years, a lot of focus in stock performance than anything else. However, I am very thankful for the opportunities it has provided me over the years; from starting in the factory to getting a bachelor to then a rewarding IT job to then a master, I owe Intel my entire professional career. The compnay is pushing efforts around improving management and empowering employees, yet some areas seem to be disconnected from the rest of the company. This is a company that rewards high performers and, recently, punishes "riders."
cons: The reminiscences of ACT, the painful layoffs in 2015 and 2016, are causing struggles today. While the company preaches about developing its workforce, managers prefer technical skills over soft skills forcing many employees to leave the company.

review_title: Intel challenges its workers; Tries to compensate them, but not quite there yet
pros: Challenging work. Training opportunities. Global travel. There is a certain pride in saying you work for Intel even with the recent antitrust activities against Intel. I have a great manager and, if you have one of those, then life can be very good.
cons: Having to defend it all the time because of all the anti-trust suits. Long hours are expected and not rewarded. Little support for alternative work schedules or telecommuting. First level managers can be excellent, but 2nd level managers have always lacked any type of skill.

review_title: stressful and worried about your "ranking" every day
pros: great education and training opportunities
cons: stressful and more concern about performance reviews "ranking' than getting the work accomplished. If you were not on something visible enough to make it on your performance review most wouldn't engage in the work since it wouldn't make it on their focal.

review_title: Financial Analyst
pros: Good medical, 401k, and other benefits. Culture is around maintaining a 8-5 so good focus on work/life balance.
cons: Promotions are based on tenure, not performance. Lot's of emphasis on process and bureaucracy. Hard to move around the company, there is a lot of structure in place. You get slotted where the business needs you as opposed to a part of the business you think is interesting.

review_title: Vast company, many resources, highly political
pros: Opportunity to work on projects with some serious scale. When Intel decides to move in a particular direction it's a juggernaut. Stable company, good salary.
cons: Political, bureaucratic, meetings and processes valued above all else. Review process leads to backstabbing and internecine warfare. Ludicrous focus on placing junior people in jobs they aren't qualified to do. Very small scope for genuine long term technical career, attitude is move 'up' to management/architecture or move out if the company

review_title: Good place to work
pros: A place you can go and work for many years and have a reasonable work-life balance (if you find the right teams).  Being a big company allows you to move around and make career changes without leaving the company or uprooting your life.
cons: Upper management seems to make big mistakes at times by pouring tons of money for years past when it's clear they should end.  Focal and first line managers can be fickle and arbitrary at times with brutal results. Quiz the team you join about avg hours worked/last reorg/managers weaknesses/how well teams deal with conflict and get along.  Employee growth/training has been getting squeezed and reduced lately.

review_title: I've always been able to work on exciting technologies.
pros:
Great work, ok perks and a lot of open and inclusive communities to engage with and feel part of something bigger. The company is currently pushing to change its outdated culture which I find exciting but long overdue. 

There's a great number of very smart people to learn from and advance your career.
cons:
Accountability from all directions! Not just top-down. Having a good manager is usually down to 'luck', and this can lead to a lot of frustration, career stagnation, lack of acknowledgement, recognition and promotion -which overall affects employee retention rate. There needs to be more management accountability from the bottom up and provide appropriate channels for employees to voice their concerns and be heard  for an effective culture transformation.

Promotions are usually very hard to get, even at the lower grades. Furthermore, promotions are limited in count, so belonging to a high-performing team will make it even harder.

review_title: Great Place to Work
