pros: Intel pays very well and you get to work with a lot of great people.   I am often amazed that I am working among them.  For me, the annual reviews have always been a positive experience.   Intel rewards accomplishments and the rewards are substanstial.  I have seen a two-fold increase in total compensation since I started working 5 years ago.   The benefits are great.   If the stock would start to move a bit, it would be that much better.
cons: It is huge!!!   There is a lot of visible waste in any large company like Intel.   It is not a place to be if you want to climb the corporate ladder quickly.   Also, because it is big, if you are looking to get rich on stock benefits, don't count on it.

review_title: steady salary
job_title: Technical Marketing Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: There are sometimes layoffs, which are relatively infequent, but if you understand the politics (which are not rocket science, ie "everything is absolutley great!" ) they will effect someone else rather than yourself.
cons:
Boring, no advantage for average employee to try to encourage innovation. But bet (and lose) a few billion on WiMax or "Software Solutions(?)" and you are lauded and rewarded for being a great "risk taker". 
I don't really like making effort biting my tongue rather than explaining to a numskull that he/she is a complete numskull. 
Don't need any engineering talent if you can create decent power point slides.

review_title: Great overall.  Small team spirit that is occasionally stifled by the necessities of bearacuracy.
job_title: Software Engineer Intern in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Ability to work on interesting projects that will touch thousands/millions of people internally/externally.  Competitive compensation and an appreciation for work/life balance.  Never met a bitter person and everyone from senior managers on down was willing to give you the time of day.
cons: It is at this point a huge company and even though you might not appreciate this on a day to day basis, Intel's size will shape the types of projects you will work on and how much flexibility there is for change.  If you don't abide meetings and having upper level management occasionally second guess your work, Intel might not be the best place for you.

review_title: A result oriented company regardless of level. Responsibility and accountability is clearly defined.
pros: A very dynamic company with well defined task-oriented culture. Therefore, employees are managed based on results instead of methods. Strong emphasis in integrity and safety. Benefits are great as compensation other than basic salary could make up as much as 35% of the total compensation.
cons: Job scope could be limited as Intel requires employee to be the content expert in certain areas. Employees, therefore, have the depth but sometimes lacking the breadth. As a result, skills obtained might not be useful outside of Intel. However, Intel encourages employees to seek jobs within the company and thus, improving the breadth and exposure.

review_title: Excellent place to work
pros: Intel is a good place to work. Managers in general are given sufficient freedom and support to make an optimal workplace for employees. "Work-life balance" is held in high esteem, though some job roles end up having trouble getting strategic employees the time off that they are due.
cons: In Manufacturing, it can be difficult to move to another group; if you would like to try out a new job role, it can be tough to get that allowed. Intel seems to be "over the hill" so-to-speak and is reflected in the evolution of bonus programs.

review_title: Times are changing
pros: There are many talented capable people working at Intel. In the right management situation I was able to grow, learn and be creative unhindered. I was allowed to build a cohesive design team who worked well together.
cons:
Intel is a big company and there are some bad apples and management practices. As Intel grew over the last 15 years the politics also grew. I have witnessed managers making data driven design decision that contracted the data. I have seen managers play favorites and discriminate against more capable workers who might threaten there position. 
Not all managers practice organization development and will hinder their own employees growth for there own benefit.

review_title: Virtual World why not Intel
pros: Great people, Benefits, and work experience with exciting projects. Great learning experiences on leading architecture especially if you like ongoing challenges.
cons: Virtual offices view is that Intel divisions (other than sales) are not allowed. However the reason given for this is very weak and yet a few managers still have them. While Intel is known for HW, there is a lot of other areas like SW development that can easily be accomplished in virtual offices. Virtual offices allow more flexibility, less downtime, less noisy employees impact and better productivity. With the ability of voice / video bridges it's very easy for people to communication as required just like walking over to someone's cube. Managers should have the discretion for employees.

review_title: Not a great place to work, currently
pros: Has traditionally been an innovator/sector leader with excellent engineering staff with competitive total compensation.
cons: Used to be a great place to work. If you performed well, you could count on long term employment. Under the current CEO/CTO that is no longer the case. Age discrimination is rampant as is the tying of executive bonuses to diversity hiring. In order to meet quotas, non-diverse/older employees are being walked out the door by security for having merely successful ratings in the last focal, but lower than average stock grants (not traditionally used as a performance metric). The system is rigged.

review_title: Pros & Cons of Working @ Intel
pros: Great People, Great Benefits, & Exciting Potential
cons:
Terrible Power Politics & Thick Ineffective Bureaucracy
Broken Technical Pipeline
Wasted Potential: Talent & skills are often not utilized due to competing personal agendas,  flip-flopping direction & instability from constant reorganization

review_title: Successful in spite of needing a cultural shift
pros:
Great scale, product and momentum
Great business results
Good people
Willingness to invest in tangential opportunities to grow
cons:
Grinding bureaucracy 
Executives seem more concerned with their advancement than the success of the company 
Telling the truth and and working together for the company's success have become fundamental issues  which is surprising if you are a veteran of culture that made this company so successful.
Execution a real issue and in the current culture this leads to finding blame vs. banding together to solve.

review_title: Not a google!
pros: If you like extremely structured work environment and a place where you can pretty much choose what you want to work on, Intel is the place for you. Ofcourse since its 'work' its not as glamorous as a trip to the amazon, but its a means to get there. If you keep in mind that work is just that and not a path to enlightenment or nirvana, you will be ok here.
cons: It is pseudo hierarchical like in old days! :) What your manager thinks of you matters. Be his/her friend and you will sail through. Protests, confrontations, rebelling are not accepted and will have undesirable repercussions’. Change is not natural here and attempts at it look and feel forced.

review_title: Working at Intel is similar to a state job with longer hours
pros: I work at Intel because it is close to home, there are lots of different job opportunities, it offers stable employment and I enjoy my immediate coworkers.  I also have a great deal of flexibility in my work hours and work location.
cons: Intel is very bureaucratic, the culture is a very tops down management style, in general I would say they pay below the going rate for similar jobs elsewhere.

review_title: A company thats coming of its age...and holding it together well...
pros:
Breadth and Depth of technical aspects. Almost everything related to Electrical and Computer Engineering is done here.
The company takes good care of its employees.
Impact that its products have created and continue to create on over all world life.
The possibilities that stand ahead
cons:
People outside the company expect you to know everything about a processor. Intel does much more than processors and not everyone at the company works on processor.
The immediate management atleast in the India is not always good enough to handle their job well. Employees go through problems because of this.
The level of agressive competition is high.

review_title: It really is a good place to work
pros:
I love working on leading edge technology and with a company that has the resources to make things happen.  There are also many different career paths that one can take, and career advancement has not been a problem. 

Management is very flexible to accommodate life circumstances.  Pay is very competitive with bonuses and stock factored in, and the sabbatical every 7 (or 4) years is a great benefit.
cons: The bureaucracy that accompanies corporations of this size can be frustrating.   Things that small start-ups can do in weeks take months here.  This leads to the constant drumbeat of doing more in faster time and with fewer resources, although this is probably not unique to Intel.

review_title: Senior Software Engineer
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Intel continues to dominate the  market in the high-end due to its  superior  process technology.
Several firmware and operating system groups enable this x86 server market. Working in those SW-related groups certainly enables you to make a difference in the market.
cons: Projects are staffed for 1-3 years and then disbanded, with engineers having to find other opportunities in the group or the company. There is a fair amount of politics and there is no real recognition of your contributions unless you belong to the in-group of "brogrammers" favored by the chosen managers. Very little gender diversity at senior technical level despite upper management being female.

review_title: Sr Software Engineer Mobile Communications
job_title: Senior Software Engineer II in Bangalore
pros:
Decent salary,  SPP, RSUs, QPB and APBs 
Additional benefits like Volvo Buss Pass and Broadband reimbursements,, Zim, Play area, onsite clinic, world class facilities, well connected office location.
Decent work culture.
Several opportunities to grow in Technical ladder, great exposure
cons:
Quality of Work ( Service oriented , Core or Cream of the technology definition and development outside of India)
Skewed work life balance (My division operates in High pace environment)
Heavy focus on spending constraints.
Average conviction and  poor success of Management in changing the status quo throughout the hierarchy.

review_title: Intel, Great place to work or NOT?
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Challenging work environemnt, if you are looking for a challenge every single day and do not like to be in a boring job, Intel is the place to be.  Every single day employees are challenged and it is up to you to respond and drive your success.
cons: Work life ballance.  You may think you have time to yourself and there is a work life ballance, but I am always looking at my Blackberry, or finding myself reading e-mail at 11:00pm before I go to bed, or at 6:00am before the kids get up.  Intel gives  you the tools to stay at work even if you are at home, traveling or on vacation.  These tools diminish the work life balance.

review_title: Marketing Specialist
pros: Cutting edge tech, innovation, creativity and informed risk taking highly encouraged and supported. Decent pay. Good benefits. Management takes personal responsibility for fostering learning, optys for employee growth and ensuring job satisfaction. Tries to keep work life balance in play even though everyone is quite busy.
cons: Not enough people to accomplish desired tasks. Most find themselves unofficially working 24-7 and stressing about finding time to do everything at high quality level. Average wont do. Can be incredibly stressful.

review_title: Has been good to me so far
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Large company with every type of technical role and challenge available. You can get involved in almost any type of project you can imagine.
cons: Erratic hiring and firing practices keeps the employees guessing. Program and priorities seem to change on a whim from the highest level and too often not backed up by money and staffing to make the program actually succeed. Can be frustrating but there's almost more work to do.

review_title: Don't Turn 50 If You Want To Stay At Intel
job_title: Technical Project Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: Hard workers can advance quickly at Intel. I received two promotions and more than doubled my salary in my first six years there. I also had the opportunity to travel the world and learn a great deal about my field from working with real professionals.
cons: Intel manages to a balance sheet. When the company doesn't meet earnings, employees and sometimes entire groups are let go and their jobs are moved to India. Also, if you are 50 or older you are 2.78 times more likely to be let go when layoffs occur. (This is based on Intel HR statistics.)

review_title: Product Marketing Manager
job_title: Senior Product Marketing Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: Very good additional benefits and work-life balance programs.  Employee Stock Purchase Program lets you invest 5% of your pay in Intel stock at a 15% discount.  Program to help pay for backup child care if your kids are sick and can't go to school.  Intel contributes to your retirement / 401k account regardless of how much you contribute.
cons: Strategy is constantly changing and the company cancels projects/products all the time.  Intel needs to place big bets on a few up and coming technologies and they stick with it.  So many product cancellations means they never get new products to market and will eventually get left behind by other technology companies.

review_title: Great Company
job_title: Anonymous Employee in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros:
- Compensation is very good and company is always searching to understand market position
- high technology and smart people. customers love the products and when you understand how company works you can find good resources to support your customers
- chance to make difference - in your team; in your country; for your life.
cons:
- politics - favoritism in all levels, be a friend of right person is more important than your tracking record of results. It does not sustain you there, but can prevent you to be there!
- bureocracy - being a manager for many years and looking behind the curtain I started to be skeptical about meritocracy, evaluation systems, HR process... Managers spend a lot of time in bureocracy that could be better use to motivate teams and be closer to customers

review_title: Good plan, mediocre execution: Intel struggles to evolve from old school to cutting-edge.
pros: You can move around to different positions and learn new skills. The benefits are outstanding and the compensation is very competitive. In general I think Intel tries to do the right thing. It often fails in execution.
cons: Politics, politics, politics. The downside of allowing people to move around with sometimes little experience for positions is that nepotism and the good-ole-boy mentality maintain a grip on the culture. Very demeaning. Also, because of the way Intel structures its review process and pits employees against each other, this environment doesn't breed collaboration but extreme competition. This creates silos and the hording of knowledge.

review_title: Great Place to Work for Experienced People , Challenging New Technologies and Excellent Work Life Balance
pros:
1. Work Life Balance Tops it -- No unecessary pressure at all
2. Decent Compensation and good benefits
3. Overall Good Feel at Work place - Most of them have worked 5-10 yrs 
4. Good projects and ownership inPre-Silicon Verification in India
cons:
1. Managers are in a transition phase - either they are way too technical that they micromanage or they arent technical at all which makes it difficult to explain
2. Most people are from tier-1 colleges and US returns , strong ego barriers and less flexible - will face issues for sometime smooths out over time once you prove yourself

review_title: A challenging ambient for creative and hardworking minds...
job_title: PCB Design Engineer in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros:
Working as Lead has the opportunity to interact with many experts from several teams (power, thermal, mechanical, manufacturing, hardware, signal integrity, etc.), and this allows you to develop technical skills quickly.
If you are able to survive to 1 or 2 projects (as lead), you start to see the complete picture of project development. Over time you start to understand the limits and scope of the role to make a platform board a reality.
It is really challenging ambient.
Most of the people are willing to provide support and help when needed.
cons:
Too much work, some times have to work overtime.
Really hard to maintain work/life balance.

review_title: It was a good company.
pros: It is the best place to work environment! Best things: Casual dress code, relaxed working hours with option to work from home, gym to use, atmosphere, lots of benefits and rewards, lots of parties and social activities. Good graduate atmosphere. I couldn't think of any bad things about the company other than a lot is expected from employees, but this is a good thing in my opinion.In short, I'm extremely happy in my graduate role and have a lot of fun both in my job and working for Intel. I would highly recommend it as a place to work for graduates.
cons: There are not much compensation and benefits. Can get carried away and spend too much time at work. A lot of old processes and new ways of thinking are some time shut down immediately.

review_title: Very good company, good benefits, just too big and not much pizzazz
pros:
Very good work-life balance - atleast my position is around a 40 hr work week. 
Good pay - not the greatest but enough
Good benefits - good health benefits
Try to make some fun - got a lot of things going on internally sponsored by employees as well as the company
Very smart people and many people you can learn from
Keep very flexible schedules
cons:
Politics - some people just don't have your back
Company is just too big so lots of collaboration and communication inefficiencies
Too slow - many times trying to play catch up
Hardware oriented company and not many software options or company focus on software
Culture in my opinion is very boring and dry - not exciting at all

review_title: Cometh the hour, goeth the (wo)man
pros: Intel made a pledge to hire under represented minorities and women.  And they beat that pledge by over a year.
cons: They now need to focus on inclusion. It is a very toxic place to work. They do not actually want to change they put the burden on the minorities and women to assimilate.  Whats worse, the women do not support other women. It is the least supportive culture I have ever witnessed. In the past year more senior women have left than have been added. They make excuses for each and everyone who has left without reflecting on the root causes.

review_title: Toxic environment at Ronler Acres
pros: Smart people.  The money gets spent in Oregon, so as long as Intel does technology development there will be an Intel in Oregon.
cons: Ronler Acres is the most toxic environment environment in all of Intel.  An unwritten but well known policy is to hire recently graduated PhD’s from Top Tier universities and then work them 24x7.    About 65% will last the first 5 years.  The site continues to propagate the salt mine culture throughout using the cultural paradigms that the only thing that matters is getting results at all costs (i.e. sacrifice self, family and coworkers for results) and being “tough-minded” (which is a green light to toxic individuals to be vicious and excuse their behavior as being “tough-minded”).   A great example of those values is M.M. who leads process transfer and infrastructure.  How HR allows her to stay in her role, much less “employed” is amazing.

review_title: Great for a couple years to gain experience but hard to move up
pros: Intel is fast paced, results oriented and you generally work with very smart people.  It is a great learning experience in the first couple years.  Intel also invests a lot in training so you can take all kinds of classes to fill out your skill set.
cons: It can be really hard to move up since Intel isn't growing rapidly.  Senior management seems checked out.  It is a very aggressive culture which can be hard for some people to succeed in.  A lot of people are promoted based on who they go to church with rather than their merits.  This is especially true in the Oregon locations.  Intel was an awesome company 10 years ago but I would think twice about joining now.

review_title: A Survivor work place
pros: Even the base salary is lower comparing with other companies, with the bonus and stock options, the total compensation is still better than others.
cons: If you don't socialize and gang up with anyone, you will be gone really soon unless you are a super super player. After each anual review, your are ranked not only by your boss but by other engineer in the same project. The environment is very stressful if you are new because most of the time you have to be on your own. You have to be aggressive to get your task done.

review_title: Cannot innovate their way out of a wet paper bag
pros: Good place to learn how to navigate corporate life. Also, they are big on process.  If you've worked for organizations with little or no process this is a good place to learn from, but don't stay too long if you've got a creative bone in your body.
cons:
Not accepting of people who present new ideas.
Pay only lip service to the concepts and practices of "Innovation."
Rewards and management structure have created leadership who is not innovative or willing to take risk. It's created a leadership structure based on cronyism or 'constant alignment and agreement with leadership.'

review_title: lots of politics, no career growth, but work/life balance not bad
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
comparatively easy to change groups inside Intel, once you have stayed in Intel for a while
work/life balance is not bad, as long as your boss is reasonable
I  hear some people get good compensations, bonus is generally good
cons:
if you are senior already, not much growth career-wise
culture is very different from outside of Intel. if you join Intel with outside experience, expect a long time to get adjusted to it.
lots of politics, not just managers, all the way down to junior level engineers.
technical people are not valued
If you have a bad manager, all Pros go away. HR really doesn't care. Upper management probably don't care either.

review_title: Great place to work!
pros:
Highly ethical in running business. By and large, fair practices and less room for politics.
Intel shows in many small ways they care for their employees.
Senior Managers demonstrate career development of their employees by example.
Once you put in real hard work and some years, your pay zooms because of the Total Compensation - bonus, stock, RSUs, apart from salary.
This is NOT a place if you are looking for a laid-back work life!
cons:
Career growth prospects can be limited at senior levels. Of course, this is mitigated by the fact that Intel is a large company and if you are open, there are lateral growth opportunities to challenge yourself.
People have Work-Life Balance -- "Work" comes before "Life" :-)

review_title: Good Company with good focus on Employee, treating employee real asset
pros:
Great people, good management, great company culture and values, 
Good Compensation, taking care of past performance, and companies commitment to future of employee.
Unlike most of the company, they give stocks as RSU, apart from being above market in salary. Bonus is always more than what is the eligibility
cons: Want to warn employee against getting stuck in a kind of work for long time. Employees should keep moving in company to make sure there new ideas and learning continue while the company and employee meet shareholders expectations.

review_title: Good, stable company with right fundamentals
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Sacramento, CA
pros: The company has a great history and its a matter of vision and focus coming together for executing any top technological product; sound faith in management and employees. Being large organization, diverse career paths and options for hardware as well as software engineers.
cons: The culture can vary across teams and local management, but have larger faith on top management. The career opportunities are good but growth can be slower than expected. Few teams can expect or push for very competitive hours and work-life balance comes down to an individual preference instead of culture of some teams.

review_title: Run, don't walk, from here if you're a woman
pros:
Trying to improve family benefits
On paper, they provide excellent benefits with regards to employee discounts, continued education, etc. 
The shuttle is great
The company seems to care( on face value) about diversity and hiring people from a breadth of backgrounds and generations
cons:
No shuttle in the Bay Area
Inflexible management (insist on working from cubicle - no flexibility to telecommute)
Biased management - older teammates are given telecommuting privileges and are listened to; newer teammates, especially younger female ones, are patronizingly ignored or given menial tasks
Old men's club - so much for all the diversity initiatives. Retention is terrible

review_title: Run, don't walk, from here if you're a woman
pros:
Trying to improve family benefits

The shuttle is great
The company seems to care( on face value) about diversity and hiring people from a breadth of backgrounds and generations
cons:

Old men's club - so much for all the diversity initiatives. Retention is terrible

review_title: Software Engineer Grade 5
pros:
I was fortunate to work with very smart people and a great manager.
Get to work with the latest Intel technology.

Good health benefits, yearly performance reviews, profit-sharing bonus, stock purchase program, 3 weeks vacation, sabbatical after 4 or 7 years.
cons:
Every group at the company is different and they generally don't communicate with each other well.

There are often several groups competing for the same projects and if you don't get the good projects, you won't get promoted, (without minority status) no matter how hard you work.

Massive bureaucracy slows development and hinders innovation since time is being spent checking boxes and not doing actual work. This will vary from group to group. I was lucky to rarely experience this; my friends were not as lucky.

review_title: Good Company to work for.
job_title: Fab Automation Support in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great benefits, onsite gym/cafe/free fruit,tea and soda, co-workers are great. Easy to move to other positions. working cross-dept was great.
cons: Lots of managers have no idea of what they are doing let alone manage people. At least in my group i worked for, all they care about is the numbers and how to present them so it makes them look good. Intel hires people mostly based on their degree. When the new CEO took over, things started to change downhill. company sold off potential successful groups and keeps sticking to it's bread and butter.... their manufacturing capability. Stock purchase program got cut in half, health plans changed, bonuses changed...

review_title: Wonderful company to work for except for few concerns
pros:
Great technical talent within the company. Have worked with some of the intelligent minds in the industry
It is like a conglomerate of small companies in one. You have lot of opportunity to move to different teams and learn something new. The company is very open for engineer rotation
Employee benefits are great, personal favorite 8 weeks of paid bonding leave when you have a kid for both men and women. 
They  trust you and WFH is very common. Especially for women they give a lot of flexibility with the work hours to take care of the  family
cons:
Changing the processes here is very slow due to long management chain and size of the company.
each team has narrow area of focus, if you want technical breadth you have to move around to several teams and will take a while Vs working in a small company

review_title: Intel - where Finance is a valued member of the management team
pros: My favorite part is the fact that Finance is an integral part of the decision-making process.  We don't just crunch numbers, we aren't just in the room to answer questions.  Our opinion is valued and sought after to ensure management makes the best decision possible.  We are truly part of the management structure of the company.
cons:
We are spread out.  You can oftentimes work with someone for years and never meet them face to face.  
Intel has been slow to adopt work life effectiveness solutions as a whole company.  It all depends on what group you work in and who you work for.  It's left to manager discretion.

review_title: Glass Ceiling
pros: Good benefits if you work hard.  Intel tried very hard to maintain the number of employees during downcycles so that people do not lose their jobs.  Therefore they are a very stable company to work for, especially in manufacturing. There are good managers as well as bad, but good managers are very understanding with the employees who want to maintain a life as well as those that want to work hard for the company.
cons: Can be difficult to get an engineering job if you are a technician, Intel seems reluctant to hire from within.  Feedback is sometimes hard to come by, but that is up to the discretion of management.

review_title: Intel Swindon Nice people
job_title: Web Project Manager in Swindon, England
pros: The people you will be working with are genrally good, the location is great and convenient for M4 canteen is excellent there is a thriving social life its always busy and there is plenty of variety.
cons: The management are not that good at either directing or managing giving the impression of inexperience. The offices are made like cube world which is fine if you like working in a "pig pen" but for most people is unpleasant. For a technology company they use some of the worst computer equipment I have used at any company I have ever worked for, every employee gets a laptop but generally they are at least three years old and of an extremely inferior spec.

review_title: My honest, personal and frank view
pros:
1) Work life balance and excellent campuses
2) Giant in Semiconductor field - We get to be part of something big no matter what project we are in
3) Any work/technical problem- we find infinite walking libraries, who can give solution
4) Job stability
5) Exploring different roles and finding a job which suits your skill is easier
cons:
1) Not the best pay in Industry, if we start and grow as a fresher
2) Too much of parallel teams doing same work
3) Too many employee's who have stayed for long time and try to jump into freshers work
4) Recognition is very bad. In the sense that wrong people take credit instead to credit going to person who did the work

review_title: Not for those who are innovative and like learning
pros: Steady income and good work life balance. If you want a job it's a great place as they have lots of reserve cash.
cons: Managers/Leaders more worried about their careers than producing innovative products. There is a general fear of being innovative and failing.  There are lots of groups who compete against each other for projects. This creates tension between teams and as a result they don't help each others. Very odd way of managing business.  Annual review process is more of a popularity contest than rewarding people for strong results.   Their pay is typically less than most hi-tech companies.  Sadly, best days are behind them.

review_title: Overall, Intel Corporation is a great employer
job_title: Technical Project Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Because it is a larger company, employees are able to move around and find positions in different departments.  Sabbaticals are a great benefit - not many companies offer this (8 weeks after 7 years or 4 weeks after 4 years of work).
cons: Like most big companies, as Intel grew in size, the employees became less 'human' and more 'numbers'.  Layoffs in 2015 and 2016 impacted many employees worldwide.

review_title: Good company but new management is killing the company and morale
pros: Great benefits, great pay.
cons:
Way too many managers.  Someone has to kick the bucket before you move up the management chain.  

Current change in senior management had created a distrusting environment.  If you don't do what your manager says or follow their politics, it doesn't matter if you're doing the right thing, you will have a target on your back.  So many of my friends got laid off not because of their poor performance, but because of their disagreement with the managers' directions.    

True human nature had revealed in much of middle management. Middle managers, if you shoot an unarmed individual in the back, don't worry your manager will have your back.  This, like it or not, will be the new normal.

review_title: Something changed in 2014
pros: Still attract enough smart people who don't know what's going on inside the company.
cons: After several years' of PC revenue decline, the company has drifted into a toxic mode. Layoffs unfairly target over represented groups of White or Asian males that are over 40. But if you are in the clique, you should be able to get by by making a few slides, checking some emails and attending several meetings everyday to claim you've driven a program, managed a project, led a team, influenced a decision, or refined a process. There are lots of people with fancy titles that doesn't know much beneath the colourful boxes in PowerPoint. In the meantime, managers are asked to fill the quota for Under Represented Minority in order to match the college graduation demographic data. The CEO is mindlessly pursuing what's on the cover of magazines like IoT, drones, wearables by acquisitions instead of making real engineering efforts.

review_title: Great, but old school
pros:
+ Great work life balance
+ Good colleagues
+ No micromanagement
+ Great brand to associate with
+ Enough opportunities to grow if you are in Singapore or the US
cons:
- Slow and complacent; most people have been around for 15 years or more
- Americas team is inward looking. Limited engagement and 'superior' behaviour
- HR is pathetic - on boarding process is loose and no one seems to care about it, or follow up (at least in India)
- Investment in employee is limited
- Offices are pretty depressing looking

review_title: Intel Finance
pros: Great opportunity to learn, intelligent co workers.
cons:
Lack of trust in leadership: For example, was told by manager that I got a particular rating for Focal because all the Premium ratings went to URMs (under represented minorities) . If this is true, why are ratings constructed to penalize those that aren't URMs? If it isn't true, why aren't managers taking ownership and providing constructive feedback to those that need it? 

Lack of cooperation: Since ratings are on a bell curve, many analysts in the same grade compete for ratings, which results in an constant "outdo your peers"  environment and not sharing information.

review_title: Accounts payable
pros:
Processing the invoices of vendors, we receive various invoices from various companies vendors on a daily basis, SAP software is used for processing invoices and for the payments to the vendors.
Mastered Direct posting of PO, Non PO Invoices and Credit Notes through Business Workflow.
Maintaining a Quality check on team’s performance on a daily basis & reporting to the Mgmt.
Ensuring that SLA parameters and TAT are met consistently.
cons:
Handling mails in a professional way and replying for queries well within TAT.
Production daily planning, work load balancing and effective utilization of resources.
Provide training to new joiners and updating the desk procedures regularly.
Interacting with client directly through scheduled daily,weekly Business Conversation.
Expert in all 3 way and 2 way match invoices postings
Rectified escalated accounts payable issues from employees and vendors.
Resolves collection and invoice discrepancy matters.
Suggested process improvements to secure prompt and regular receipts for the organization.
Knowledge in all import payments.
Tracking No PO No Pay Exceptions.

review_title: 16 Years at Intel
pros: Big company with many opportunities. There are lots of smart people. Good training opportunities.
cons: Lack of integrity of the management. Intel benefits look good on paper but are not honored by middle management. Intel has a crisis culture that burns people out. The internal bureaucracy is mind boggling and often costs vast amounts of time for the simplest tasks. The work spaces are loud and there is limited janitorial staff. IT services make the DMV look efficient. Work days are filled with useless meetings during which most employees ignore the topic to send email. Public humiliation is considered good leadership by management.

review_title: Place to Work
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Recognized brand means it's easier to do business with other companies
Global presence
Industry leader and influencer
Lots of process
Very smart and motivated employees continually challenge thinking and assumptions
Deep pockets for projects
Work/life balance (IF your manager allows)
cons:
Meritocracy in theory only
Too many middle managers intent on building fiefdoms and competing with each other
Many products and programs (Viiv, Intel WebOutfitter Svc, etc.) are neither strategically smart or well-planned or executed
Too much job redundancy across groups and divisions
Drab gray walls and cubicles
You're at the mercy of your manager
You must always manage up
If you want work/life balance, be prepared to give up career advancement.  Not all managers embrace work/life balance, especially those with unemployed spouses.

review_title: A large number of opportunities to move around in different areas
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Beaverton, OR
pros: If you can overcome bureaucracy, their is lot of interesting stuff to do and learn. You can switch job roles pretty easily. At least recently they have defined a reasonable technical career path.  This is a very technology focused company and technical people are valued. Initiative is highly valued. Finally free soda/drinks.
cons:
Bureaucratic and slow moving in some areas. But, that probably comes with the size. The size also implies that you can get frustrated with getting approval of your ideas and making them real. Hands on work is valued less than power point slides in many organization. Bad looking cafes and cubes. Minus points for bad looking campuses. 
Due to the huge size many people can just coast by doing nearly nothing...

review_title: Work for Intel for 1-2 years max then bounce to bigger better things.
pros: To get great experience in what not to do.  Intel will help prepare you for your next job.  Intel is a great training ground.  Its like working for Sean Combs, if you are able to survive you can do anything.  Its a great place to intern at as well.  THey actually has a great marketing program.
cons: Management does not listen to anyone.  They treating women like crap for the most part especially in ADT.  Intel's rating and ranking sucking.  It does not encourge teamwork it only encourages back stabbing.  I have person seen fellow co-workers health weaken over the course of a year.  I have even seen managers work together to sabotage another teams work.

review_title: If you want to work in a mega-company, this is a good one
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Edison, NJ
pros: an overall competent work force - it pushes you to have your act together. Intel has a great reputation which makes it easier to talk to other industry leaders about cooperation and planning - they want to work with Intel. In other companies I have worked for, I end up spending too much energy legitimizing the company before we can get to the substance of the market and cooperation.
cons: hard to feel like you are making a serious difference if you don't work on Job 1. A very large proportion of people (especially in marketing) do something other than CPU's for computers, but that vast pool of people spend a lot of time justifying their existence - since, other projects within the company except processors is a rounding error to the quarterly performance.

review_title: No respect shown for external experience, means it takes years to advance.
pros: Intel has great senior management and knows how to drive a market. They weather storms very well without layoffs fairly well.
cons: Internal managers do not know how to interview, making advancement and job changes very difficult for those with less than 5 years experience at Intel. People are assimilated into Intel. It is not a people company. They provide good benefits but don't build relationships with employees. Thus, even the creative jobs are driven more like a factory operation.

review_title: Great Place To Work, an Intel value & a reality.
pros:
Your career there is what you make of it and management will work with you to ensure your career develops how you want it to.

Intel emphasizes work-life balance and provides great benefits, generous vacation time, team-building activities and even a 2 month sabbatical after working for 7 yrs.

Management makes it a point to know about the open-door policy, where you are welcome to ask questions to Senior level management, no need to go through your direct manager if there is every an issue of concern.
cons:
Some co-workers outside of my group have expressed that they were required to work overtime and did not receive the expected recognition for their work.

A lot of this depends on the team you are working for, if they are short on head count and personality of the manager.

review_title: Good till you get your green card
job_title: Analog Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great with Immigration. After you graduate, join Qualcomm or Intel to get your green card. There are very few companies which are this good at getting you a GC. I know that Qualcomm is the fastest. Once you get the GC, wait for 6 months and join a company where you get a real analog job. This advice is for Indian and Chinese immigrants. For others, if you care for the quality of analog job, this is probably the worst (Qualcomm is hopeless too). You must join Silabs or Maxlinear for good analog/RF. Linear tech is the best for ADCs.
cons: Very poor quality analog jobs, lot of politics, unstable business and organization.

review_title: It's not a place for normal folks
job_title: Embedded Software Engineer in Bayan Lepas
pros: Benefits and compensation is great. But long term employees ALWAYS and never fail to see that. Exciting opportunities and work is always challenging but that depends on what you're working in. Cafeteria is not bad and in some buildings awesome. It's an old campus so expect some facilities to be aging. Nevertheless, it's really a Great Place To Work, as long as you have a great manager
cons: It's not for everyone. And the way the company is structured you always fall into the trap of only knowing the thing you're working in and lack the bigger picture point of view. The hiring process can be too lenient so expect to have incompetent people or people with poor teamwork spirit joining you. Some managers can be too aggressive but I guess that's a good thing else some of the Gen-Y will never learn.

review_title: Not much of growth prospects and became highly political
pros: Big organization, exposure to various technologies related to core and smaller processors. World wide teams will provide lots of exposure to these technologies. Internal/lateral moment allowed (subjected to same hiring process of an external candidates.
cons: Lots of organizational changes keeps you on your tows. Recently it has become much more political. I have had a fair amount of exposure to politics at team level, group level and even corporate wide, everything disguised in various means. Incompetent management at all levels and if you disagree with the management, even though you mean good, be assured that they will be after you. In order to survive one has to dance to the tunes of the management chain, be a yes man and not really needed to be very talented or experienced employee.

review_title: Intel Mobile Communications, Very Good technologies, but lots of stress, lots of managers
pros:
Employees get very good opportunities to work on latest technologies in Intel Mobile Communications. 
Benefits like transportation, food and other things are good, in fact really good compare to other companies. Some team has very good work culture.
cons:
Lots of pressure. That too for new employees not much support is given, as most of the team will have one or two high performing senior guys, whole team will depend on them. Hence, knowledge is not shared equally among others. Those high performing guys also loaded heavily.  Because more competitions with other companies in Mobile Technology industries, lots of pressure and very tight deadlines. Work life balance is not good.
Lots of expectation from managers. One employee will be managed directly and indirectly by multiple managers.

review_title: Good company but going through some upheaval
job_title: Senior Systems Architect in Chandler, AZ
pros: Intel has been a great company to work for over the years. I was fortunate to work under excellent management during most of my career. The company has very high ethical standards.  My managers built high-performing teams by hiring talented and dedicated employees, fostering an environment of innovation and respect for all team members, providing clear goals and removing roadblock when required, and motivating the team by rewarding teamwork and excellent results.
cons: The current upheaval created by BK's purge of 12,000 employees has reduced employee moral and in some cases created a bit of a "Hunger Games" atmosphere. I expect morale to improve once the purge is done and Intel gets back to a more teamwork oriented environment.

review_title: Great Team, but Company May Be in for More Pain
job_title: Product Development Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
1) I had some really awesome teammates and they made it all the worth while coming into work everyday
2) Great benefits, hard to compare to any one else
3) Always something new to learn
cons:
1) The work life balance often skewed towards more work, especially in manufacturing
2) Paralyzing amounts of bureaucracy at times
3) Bad decision with not jumping on mobile several years back may be setting them up for more future down swings
4) Not always sure where they're headed since they're trying to re-brand themselves as a user experience company
5) The politics can be really toxic

review_title: A good company for the right kind of person...
pros: Intel is in the process of successfully transitioning from a PC company to a silicon powerhouse in adjacent markets including Memory, Comms, IOTG, Data Center, Automotive, etc.  Its future looks bright, and it is competitive with others in its category in terms of being a great place to work.
cons: To succeed in the huge transformation Intel is undertaking it has been ruthless in reducing costs/personnel in some areas to fund others.  Job security is not a given, and that creates a certain amount of stress in the workplace.  Executive management is excellent, but middle management, perhaps, less so.

review_title: So disappointing.
pros: High salary (for where I worked) compared to region.
cons:
One will spend far more time asking for permission to DO something then actually every doing anything worthwhile. Leadership appears to chase one technology fad after another over the past few years. Worse, immediate management rarely has the courage to allow workers to anything that has a chance for failure. Adding to the disappointment is that leadership is not really open or honest with the work force (the most public one is why the last CEO left; plenty of news outfits saw this too as well).

Terribly political environment with company re-orgs essentially the norm. Expect lots of red tape. Getting promoted is tricky for most past a certain grade.

review_title: Working at Intel
pros: Best in the business.  Very challenging environment. Get to work in the cutting edge of technology. Always pushed to raise the bar. All in all this is the place to be if you want to work in a place which tweaks your geek bone.
cons: Very stressful at times. Takes a while to get used to work load and number of hours you have to put in initially. Need to know how to manage work and personal life properly or can be disastrous. Heard of many people getting divorced because they dint do a good job of that. Definitely not a 9 to 5 job. The work and stress levels which everyone is under keeps them on the edge and not very sociable. Lots of meetings. Half the day is spent sometimes in meetings.

review_title: Typical large corp that's perfect for people who want to cruise until they retire
pros: Good benefits, rarely need to work over time, only need to work on the same things that you're good at over and over, the name "intel" gives you good negotiation power with vendors
cons:
Unless you just want to cruise through until you retire, you get bored pretty easily.   You work on the same things that you're good at over and over. 

The performance review process is pretty much a joke that's not even close to fair.   It largely depends on how good your manager can fight for you in the review sessions.

review_title: Racist, not meritocratic, making really talented engineers doing the trash work
pros: None. Nothing at all. Zero.
cons:
1. The biggest problem in Intel, is a position called TCE (technical Consulting engineers) - basically white people who don't actually want to code, getting promotions on the ability to talk in public. 
2.  Employees with a masters degree wanting to get a promotion are made to do the trash work. That is - generating reports, writing tests.
3. White people given priority in terms of promotion, compensation, career opportunities.
4. Women at Intel who promote themselves as women in tech are basically white women being TCEs or Managers. No woman Principal Engineer or similar in the department I work at.
5. Work life balance = 0.
6. Absolutely no way to switch between teams. My senior manager emotionally blackmailed me to not switch teams in times of crises.
7. Smart Engineers paid less, people willing to bootlick paid a lot. - They should probably post bootlicking as a required skill.

review_title: Intel Inside: Hot garbage
pros: Reasonable TCOMP, but nothing remarkable.
cons: Unfortunately Intel does not innovate anymore.  Nothing apart from client/server CPU projects get any resources or attention.  Initiatives to expand to other markets are based entirely on management fiat with little support, so when they inevitably fall behind or management changes they get canceled.  Employee development is nonexistent.  It's nearly impossible to 'break in' to any reasonable technical career path unless you want to move to Oregon or Santa Clara -- all other locations are entirely ignored for 'real' engineering.  I've had several managers over 15 years; a couple were really good but on the whole they have been wretched -- no vision, no people management capabilities, no support for development, and unbelievable micromanagement.  Forget working remotely.

review_title: Intel is a great place to work
job_title: Senior Market Research Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Satisfaction of working for the global leader in its industry, and being well compensated for it.  Opportunity to work with talented, motivated colleagues and peers in a global organization.  Working on challenging issues that provide an opportunity to grow professionally, with the resources needed to meet those challenges.
cons: Dealing with the occaisional bureaucratic processes necessary at a large multi-national company.  Difficulty of advancing at the higher job grade levels, as competition is high and increases as one advances.  Finally, the pervasive attitude that an engineer without marketing experience can be put in a senior marketing position and be successful, while the opposite consideration of putting a marketing person in an engineering job would never happen

review_title: Get in, get the most you can, get out while your still young
job_title: Shift Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel will give you the experience to succeed in other companies, it has a high stress level, good for resume, good medical benefits, good group of people to work with, good chance to see if you can cut it in a work place that only values results
cons: People aren't important, people fall last behind stock holders, analyst, fabs and tools.  There is poor recognition, poor stock plan, poor advancement, poor mentoring, poor training, poor promotion paths for all junior exempts.  Technicians are even worse off.  This is a results company that doesn't listen to it's people or doesn't care if they are content because of the large supply of new people knocking to get in.

review_title: Still a good company to work for.....
job_title: Process Engineering Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Intel provides plenty of support for career development at all levels and (for the most part) requires all employees to continuously improve (year over year).  Intel supports and typically encourages work/life effectiveness (flexible schedules, working from home, sabbaticals, etc) and has improved its "focus on results" recently.  Intel's management by objective is close to Hoshin planning and to a very large degree managers are required to support meritocracy (the top 5-10% get 3x raises of the average joe).
cons: There is, at best, highly varied competency in middle management and diversity is often rewarded above competence.

review_title: Indifferent after 10 years
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: If you're fresh out of school or nearing retirement.
cons: They seem to intentionally weed folks out after a few years.  They lose the people the need and keep the ones they should shed.  There is no concern about people burning themselves out until they do burn out.  Very political environment, and each department seems to have their own versions of the once vaunted Intel values.  Layoffs occur quite frequently, except they're called redeployments.  It's quite exhaustive having to deal with the constant downsizing of groups.  Tends to throw money at projects up front, but then the money and support trickles away until you find yourself with a skeleton team that is still expected to deliver.

review_title: Great place to learn and get out
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Excellent training. Huge knowledge base if you know where to look. Relatively good job security. Some really competent engineers around you.
cons: Very tough to advance in career unless you become a clone of super-paranoid managers. It's a very one-dimensional place. Few engineers here have a sense of adventure. Very risk averse place, too. Bland style and management is a bunch of drones. Annual ranking and rating ("Focal") can be an exercise in absurdity quite frequently. In summary, the culture works for Intel. It might not work so well for you. So learn everything you can and get out after 2-5 years.

review_title: Intel Process Side: Not a place for talented, smart & ambitious people
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
All my comments are related to Process & Develoopment Side Only:
1. Stable Job (especially in this economy)
2. Compensation is decent
3. Good Data Analysis Skill Developments (if you are interested)
4. Good understanding of Matrix management
cons:
1. Very Mundane Work
2. Very very limited vertical growth. Only way to go up, if your manager moves out
3. Work LIfe balance is not good
4. Very high pressure (mainly created by management for not the right reasons)
5. Everybody is paranoid! No RISK TAKING (though its our company Value!). Innovation is just dont exist even for a PhD level employee
6. Management prefers Work Horses rather than Smart and Creative People
 In nut shell: if you are samrt, ambitious, driven: ITS NOT THE PLACE FOR YOU.

review_title: Intel Process Side: Not a place for talented, smart & ambitious people

pros:

2. Compensation is decent
3. Good Data Analysis Skill Developments (if you are interested)
