 In nut shell: if you are samrt, ambitious, driven: ITS NOT THE PLACE FOR YOU.

review_title: It all depends on the manager and site you are at...
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Rio Rancho, NM
pros:
Competitive Pay
Cutting Edge Technology
Stock Grants and good bonuses
You are surrounded by talented, dedicated and intelligent co-workers.  
Good prospects for the company.
cons: Rio Rancho Site has serious issues with its management at all levels.  They have a large disconnect with their technical people.  They feel the need to work them into the ground without recognizing their hard work.  Risk Taking and independent thought are highly discouraged by the managment.  Mode of work seems to be crisis based.  Everything is a crisis or it is ignored.  Most of the managers are technically incompetent.

review_title: Big Stable Company = Slow Advancement
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: lot's of projects to work on and many brilliant minds open for collaboration. if you are motivated, you can make anything you put you mind to become a reality!
cons: career advancement is very slow. the salary you start at is about what you will make in 5yrs with minor inflation adjustments (almost keeps up with inflation but not quite). after 5yrs i still earn a salary less than new RCGs (recent college grads). it can be depressing when management expects me to train them.

review_title: It is a company that you get back what you put in; don't expect to be handed anything without working for it!"
pros: When the company does well financially they do a really good job of sharing that with the employees.  Don't let others fool you; the TComp portion is significant and should not be ignored.  You may get a slightly higher salary somewhere else, but you will make more money overall at Intel.
cons: Upper level leadership can be lacking at times.  There is rarely a solid push from high up to direct the company and mid-level project managers can have a larger impact than upper management at times.

review_title: Not a good place to start a career
pros:
- Job security
- Work life balance (many folks work less than 40hr/week)
- Many types of roles available
cons:
- Many jobs lack potential (e.g., avoid design automation role, since being an expert of Intel's in-house tools does not make you employable outside of Intel)
- Project cycles can be much longer (e.g., 4 years) than at other companies (e.g., 1.5 years)
- Large headcount for each project means scope of entry-level role is small with large overhead spent on communicating within the project and with other projects at Intel's many sites
- First-level managers hinder rather than help subordinates develop, and uses Intel's mantra "You own your employability" as an excuse for inaction

review_title: A golden cage - but not a good place for a talented software developer
pros:
Good salary. Excellent conditions. Very good infrastructure.
Work with lot of smart people (but also with some morons).
Very efficient employee evaluation system allow you to advance early in your career by just doing a good work without needing to fight for your right.
cons:
You often feel like a meaningless screw in a giant machine. A software team may produce nothing for 3 years and nobody will care because it is a hardware company.
Projects are closed left and right or just change their definition too frequently rendering your efforts worthless. At some point you can no longer progress by just doing excellent work and your future will be determined by your skill in office politics.

review_title: Great company to work for
job_title: Software Development Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
* Cutting edge projects
* Compensation is excellent, base salary, annual bonus, quarterly bonus, RSU & profit sharing
* Medical & Dental are good
* Really do care about their employees and willing to invest in training & tuition 
* Flexible working arrangements 
* Extremely smart colleagues raise the bar for you every day
cons:
* Company is looking for direction in the post PC era & struggling to find its way
* Many organizations are working on the same thing which causes confusion and conflict
* Core business is declining, still a $40 + billion company but the high margin business of the past is not going to last forever
* Matrix based organization & overall size does not allow for fast moving development

review_title: At intel you truly own your career
pros: There is no dearth of jobs @ intel. if you are hard working and know what you want to do, there are enough opportunities to make it happen. Intel is flexible so you can achieve better work life balance. Intel is trying hard to get quicker in its turn around time on products so if it continues to steer in the right direction its going to come out flying colors in the years to come.
cons: Intel is trying to get lean because of which it is laying off some very good engineers who are not a part of the primary site. There are some internal site politics also which doesnt allow this company  to make right decisions quickly.

review_title: Design Engineer
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: good for college grads to get started and gain experience. less pressure than other companies in the industry. some sites are better than others. find out the good sites and managers early or you will be stuck in hell. change group as soon as possible if team is not as expected.
cons: high bureaucracy level, forced bell curves at raises that are super low, over the years the company is taking benefits away to produce high earnings. Bad management most of them are highly technical with no leadership skills at all and poor decisions. Those who rose to top in the pentium era do not want to adjust to fast paced mobile industry just sit their time out. so new employees suffer.

review_title: Engineer
job_title: Product Development Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Company had a lot of good benefits with total compensation.  Place was good to work for and has a lot to offer if you want to try different things (jobs or projects) while staying with the same company.  They offer a lot of flexibility to employees for getting their work done, whether it is flexible work hours, being able to occasionally work from home, or time off.
cons: The company is a meritocracy, so it has a "what have you done for me lately" mentality.  If you are not careful, you can get caught off guard by it.  It is possible to have a work/life balance, but depending on the job, it may require a lot of overtime (especially true for a salary worker).

review_title: System Engineer
job_title: Systems Administrator in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good health benefits and perks (i.e free coffee, soft drinks, occasional free ticket to various events/shows through random selection).  Quarterly/annually bonus depending profit for that quarter or year.
cons: No work and life balance, high pressure place to work.  Good place for young and newly graduate to get experience and has the energy to work long hours to keep up with tight schedule and product deliverable.  Seniority does not matter and what matter is how fast and how much you can produce/deliver. Can be challenge to some middle age folks for long term health and work life balance.

review_title: Not What It Used To Be
job_title: Manufacturing Tech in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Great pay for the area and great benefits. CWW is awesome because you don't have to take any time off for appointments during the week.  They have the Great Place to Work program that gives perks like VIP concert tickets and sporting event tickets.  Sabbaticals.
cons: This site is very political and plays favorites. Supervisors are more concerned with protecting their friends then the people who actually work. They are also not on the factory floor enough to see who is really working and who is always out on "break". They come in once or twice a shift for maybe 30 minutes, you can't really know your people in an hour a day for a 12 hour shift.

review_title: You own your employability
job_title: Senior IT Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: My work is interesting and I like my manager. The company is a pressure cooker,  but you will be rewarded if you work hard.
cons: Worklife balance is almost nonexistent.  I spent many early mornings and late evenings meeting with people from around the world.  If you don't have an understanding significant, you're going to be in some trouble.

review_title: Recognize what you say you value
pros:
Challenging work.
Diversity & inclusion aspirations.
Smart colleagues.
Competitive salary.
cons:
Diverse employees are expected to invest significant time driving/supporting internal diversity initiatives in addition to performing their core job responsibilities, yet diversity results carry little-to-no weight in the performance review.    

Crude approaches are being used to determine who will be laid off in the name of expediency which results in loss of critical talent with little/no notice.    

Constructive confrontation has become largely tops-down only.

review_title: The Borg: You will be assimilated
job_title: Senior Engineering Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Decent pay and reasonable amenities of a large corporation.
cons:
Last few years have clearly communicated that employees are seen as interchangeable drones.  Culture has clearly communicated that there is no loyalty from the company to the employee, and most employees are living in fear of the fickle and arbitrary definitions for layoff criteria.  
Even in the "good old days" of years past, meritocracy is little more than a lame buzzword used to justify forcing management to fit reviews to bell shaped curves regardless of team size (you fit 3 people into a bell curve and decide which one to give the shaft).

review_title: Good work culture
pros: Many perks and benefits. Although salary and increment are not fantastic, but adding up the many bonuses and stock you receive throughout the year, your annual income is actually at par with your peers in other companies who are earning fat pay.
cons: There is a yearly managerial survey that is optional and supposedly confidential, your manager will ask you to complete it. But such bottom up feedback about managers can get you in trouble, especially in Asian sites like Malaysia. Typical Asian mentality managers probably are not as open to improvement feedback, as their counterparts in US. When my manager managed to guess who gave what results and feedback, she took it very personally.

review_title: feedback from > 10 year Intel veteran
job_title: Business Development Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Disciplined decision making and the opportunity to impact the whole computing ecosystem.  Intel like most big companies allow you to make career changes without changing employers.  From a benefits perspective both the sabbatical every 7 years and their 401k contributions are awesome.
cons: Intel is no longer a growth company.   The layoffs in 2006 were handled in a random and unprofessional manner which shattered the morale of the company. The real culprit was senior management being distracted with the Itanium processor while AMD out innovated Intel with Opteron to grab 30 percent of the server market share.  Intel is now attempting to grow by reentering the stand alone graphics market (which it failed at miserably in the mid-90s) and selling millions of Atom processors at $10 each.

review_title: Great place to learn, if you can tolerate the micromanagement
pros: Cutting edge technology and so much to learn - this can be a very good stepping stone to a very successful career. Opportunties are plenty, but one has to be self driven. Don't expect management to actively get involved in career development (although that is changing as well).
cons: Everyone wants to solve problems. Even managers are evaulated on their particular contribution 0 it is not enough to say that you enabled your team to achieve great things. Micromanagement is rampant and decision making structure is not good.

review_title: Intel Overview
job_title: Level Two Maintenance Tech in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Intel is a giant in the semi-conductor industry and offers a pretty good amount of job security other benifits isclude: 
good health benefits,stock options, 401k, IRA, Education reimbursement, bonus 3 times a year based on profitability. Compressed work week schedule (Alternating 3/4 day work week)
Approximately 19 paid work days off per year through a combination of vacation holiday and Personal Absence

Intel has provided a great work environment with the implementation of their "great place to work program" which allows a feel of home at the office or in the FAB. This  program provides access to:

 a basketball court, gym, computers for entertainment with internet access, putting green, 
movie nights and themed dinners, a diverse menu in the cafe` and flat screen televisions throughout the building.
cons:
It is easy to become stagnant in your career development,
Room for advancement is limited; however, lateral moves and raises are available

review_title: Application Developer
pros: 8 Week Paid Bonding Leave, Sabbatical, Vacation.  There are a lot of perks like the employee purchase program where you can buy CPU's and other PC parts for cheap.  They have free beverages in the cafe.
cons: Not a good place for an Application Developer. They will always prefer to buy boxed solutions rather than build systems in house. If you like to write code and you are not a low-level C or assembly programmer then your contributions will not be appreciated.  A lot of the work they call Application Development is actually just implementing 3rd party software.  They have a lot of misleading job titles.

review_title: High Volume mindset in a TD environment
job_title: Technology Development Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Relatively good, market matching benefits, can obtain good work life balance with the correct manager choices...though that could change with the restructuring recently occurring.  MANY opportunities within the company and you can utilize company resources to develop yourself professionally with the right manager and position.
cons:
Low general pay unless you start experienced, not quality focused in the assembly areas, the fabs and assembly areas are too disconnected with the way they are run making synergy impossible.
Company is too involved in Political correctness marketing and needs to refocus on the business it is in.
Headcount is rarely at a sustainable level...expect to do multiple other peoples' jobs, if you plan to get anything done.

review_title: Somewhat confused
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Toronto, ON
pros: Intel is a great company as it is amongst the elite tech companies that originated in Silicon Valley.  You can count companies like Google, Microsoft, and Apple as peers, with similar salaries and benefits.
cons: The problem with Intel is that it currently has somewhat of an identity crisis. Its core chip business is plateauing, and it missed the boat on mobile, so it is trying to expand into other verticals such as wearables, VR, IoT, etc. by making acquisitions. Unfortunately, Intel has such a bad track record with acquisitions due to cultural baggage that there simply isn't any hope to incubate something big beyond their old "we're a chip company" mentality.

review_title: Great firm, Lousy people
pros:
Intel provides best in class facilities & perks. Work-assignment depends heavily on immediate Manager.  No one stops you from learning stuff or trying out POC's. Flexible working hours & above all, Excellent processes. 
Extra-curricular activities & ulimited trainings
cons:
What goes unsaid is, your work just doesn't get you anywhere. Your Manager can make/break you.  Lots & lots of bureaucracy, to the extent like what Robin tells Gordon in Dark Knight Rises, ... processes becomes shackles, ..

So much that
you work on a project for 6 months & at the end you are not recognized for the effort, coz your name was not in Excel. Happened twice in 2 years. 

All you get is "Sorry, can't help". 

if you are stuck in a loop, you are just gone.

review_title: Intel isn't everyone's cup of tea particularly if you are interested in getting the job done quickly and efficiently
job_title: Senior Manager/Director in Santa Clara, CA
pros: large company; market leader; unlikely to go under any time soon
cons:
Huge overhead to getting even the most simple things done; far, far too many meetings with no substance
Huge teams needed because of the inefficiencies
Disruptive and some times very unpleasant politics
Too many low quality people all wanting their say
Too many "influencers" and not enough "doers" in the senior ranks
Insufficient leaders or people willing to take responsibility
Poor decision making in the senior ranks
cliques, cliques, cliques
far, far too many meetings with no substance
design through power point
design through committee
design through reviews
far, far too many meetings with no substance

review_title: Huge Company, Sometime little to do
pros:
Experience with well recognized company
Most people are nice and actually know what they are doing... managers had been with the company for 10+ years
Outfitted labs
Easy shipping and receiving process for large servers
cons:
Very large campus with crowded cafeteria at lunch... prices are just OK, I've seen better
Layoffs of middle management, it was a bad time to be a business major for awhile; however, the company is doing significantly better on the processor front now.
I dislike not having work to do at work, often it felt like they hired me to do a job that had no constant workload, just a week or so of hell and then 3 weeks of reading up on server software while hiding in my cube

review_title: Mixed bag - mixture of nice and sometimes ugly atmosphere
pros: Intel is a very well recognized company, with a lot of H/W and S/W companies eager to work with Intel. Working as a software engineer at Intel makes the bridge between the Intel H/W and S/W world out there. Need to be rather careful about what to say and what not to say about what's coming in the future.
cons: Like any big corporations, Intel's decision making and job ladder advancement tends to carried away by the bureaucracy. Sometimes, politics wins over the engineering decision. If you are a die hard engineer, horn your political skills to survive.

review_title: A very fruitful learning experience and ability to work under intense pressure
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: One of the best companies that provides myriad of opportunities and a single product is capable of generating over $1B/year. Experiences at Intel Corp is well recognized by other companies even beyond the technology sector.
cons: As the company is very big, some pockets of organization tend to be very political and it is easy to get lost in such a big company.

review_title: Very Employee Friendly Company
job_title: Human Resources Manager in New Delhi
pros: Work Life Balance, Flexibility, Great Products, Decent Pay. The Org has a heart and thinks of employees. There are good practices and processes followed for welfare of employees.
cons: Bureaucratic, needs time to bring in innovative practices, Very Centralized approach - it does not operate as a Global Organization. Intel by virtue of its History and line of work comes across as a bureaucratic org. Plus its a large organization that can make employees at time feel lost or overwhelmed. One soon realizes that an important attribute to have to succeed and do different roles in the org is networking. This can leave some frustrated.

review_title: Intel's increment fully depends on your manager
pros: Flexibility, job rotation, ethical, openness,
cons: Promotion and Compensation, very much depends on whether your manager likes you and promote you. There are some managers who are biased while some managers are "weak" and don't stand up for their employees. I lost my job 2 years ago and was forced to a new job which is of lower responsiblity in the same group although i asked for a package. Thus I was forced to find another job that is suitable and had to go through many interviews, without anyone helping me. Basically HR employees are expected to help others but who is helping HR employees?

review_title: Mixed bag
pros:
Disclaimer: This is a very large company so my experience may not be the experience of others

Pros: 
1) Well-known name, looks good on your resume
cons:
Disclaimer: This is a very large company so my experience may not be the experience of others

Cons: 
1) No work life balance in the  fab. Long hours. Expected to always be "on call" on weekends, nights. Cannot plan vacations because you will probably be called in at last minute.
2) Forced employee ranking system, decided mostly on politics and your relationship with your manager rather than  objective performance. This makes your coworkers your competitors and they are loath to help you especially if you are new in your job as you are their competitor. They even have yearly "attrition goals"
3) Not much time given to training. You are responsible for your own training and pestering other people (your coworkers/competitors) to train you.
4) You are entirely at the mercy of your manager re: looking for other jobs within the company.

review_title: Life at Intel was good until BK
pros: I loved working for Intel. I always worked with smart and courteous people and we got a lot of things done. Heck, we could even telecommute back in the day without anyone raising an eyebrow.
cons: When BK took over as CEO, working at Intel was no longer rewarding. A lot of people were hired from outside the company (Intel is known for promoting from within), which isn't necessarily a bad thing but some folks that didn't share Intel values slipped through the cracks. That's when I got a new manager who turned out to be a micromanaging narcissistic bully. It was horrible working for him and he was the worst manager I had ever had in my nearly 30 year professional career.

review_title: Used to be an amazing place to work
job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros: I got to work with some exceptional people from around the world at Intel.  In addition, they were very generous on send me to training and they paid for my Masters Degree.  The work is very interesting and challenging.
cons: Eight years ago, people were considered a valuable resource.  Now they are disposable cogs in a corporate machine.  Major layoffs are happening every year for the last 8 years.  Most analyst jobs are RCG and overseas.  Most of the high quality people I worked with left Intel.

review_title: I used to love it
job_title: Technical Project Manager in Folsom, CA
pros: Depending on the team and management, great place to work. Lots of small perks that try to get the employees excited but seem to fall a bit short. Lots of opportunities to grow in any direction you can imagine.
cons: Management seems lost at all levels. it seems at times that hiring the best managers with people skills are not even considered. There are some great managers but they seem to get lost in the sea of mediocrity. Recent layoffs have left quite a bad morale with the employees and its clear that senior management cares a ton more about the bottom line than you as an employee.

review_title: After 5 years at Intel
job_title: Software Engineer in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: Intel provide ample learning and professional development opportunities. The people who work there need to know hardware, operating systems, compilers, and things more complicated than say, HTML and Javascript, so you tend to find a very different crowd to that you see at Facebook or Google or other web companies.
cons: Intel is good at hardware, and they stay close to that, instead of venturing out to areas that can produce a lot of revenue, such as software and services. This often creates an atmosphere of stagnation, and low morale, especially if you are a high achiever.

review_title: all depends where you work...
pros:
Pay is okay for location, (but raises are very poor). 
If you have a good manager and group, it can be okay, but if you don't it can be really bad!
cons:
People don't seem to matter much anymore. Used to be very different. Now all about stockholders. Very little perks other than bonus now. And it seems every group is at risk of some cuts or reductions. Just not a "great place to work" anymore.
Raises very poor last few years. Not even keeping up with inflation!
Supposedly new focal system coming online, but not much hope for it based on early information. 
Many people have been leaving for other high tech with better bennies and treatment of employees. Intel is an old dinosaur!

review_title: Paid well but need to devote all your time to work.
job_title: Hardware Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: At Intel you are compensated fairly well compared to other similar companies.  At a big name company you also get the recognition and respect when you tell your friends where you work.  Deep pocket also means when your group is dissolved for any reason, it is likely you can find something else (instead of getting laid off altogether).
cons: Little to no work-life balance.  People seem to compete how much more time they spend at work.  Risk taking is not encouraged and solution to many management problems seems to be "work longer hours".  Company is so large that a lot of legacy has to be supported and have to go through lots of bureaucratic red tape to get anything done.

review_title: Intel culture implies you need to be a jerk to be successful
pros: If you like a fast pace and a place where nobody sugar-coats anything, then Intel is your place.
cons: Career opportunites and growth are limited.  Employee review process needs big improvements.  Teamwork is encouraged, but you are rated on individual performance.  Sometimes doing the right thing for the company is not a good idea for your personal rating.   Employees are usually treated as and asset not a person.   A lot of folks here think that the Intel culture means that you need to be a jerk to be successful... and maybe that is true.   Of course that means that there are a lot of jerks working here.

review_title: stable company but not the most exciting
pros: Intel is a profitable company that will always be there with many sites and opportunities for transfer.   Process technology is cutting edge and they obviously have the resources to compete with anyone.    Intel will still be around in 20 years unlike a lot of other companies.
cons: There is too much bureaucracy.    Very cut-throat environment.  Compensation is just ok but benefits and bonuses sort of make up for it.    Work/Life balance is sometimes good and sometimes not so good especially at the end of projects.  Promotions can be very political and subjective.   Employee morale is just average compared to other places I have worked at.

review_title: Smart and competent coworkers, not sure where to go from here.
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: Working on cutting-edge technology, with smart and diligent coworkers. Note that my position is in a more "central" department within the company, and is therefore more rewarding. I do note that a few more experienced employees here seem somewhat disillusioned with their work, but they work in supporting departments. Otherwise most people here are very focussed, and don't waste much time at work on trivialities. Intel somehow manages to make thousands of engineers work in a more-or-less coordinated fashion on one very complex product, which is no small feat.
cons: Company growth is limited, and so are career advancement opportunities. Horizontal career shifts are recommended. This is a bit of a minor issue (and probably a common one too), but cafeteria food (in Oregon) is pretty awful.

review_title: Big changes over the years, but still a solid and exciting place to work
pros:
Diverse technical challenges
Can work on everything from chips to software without changing companies
Benefits and compensation are excellent
Super people to work with
cons:
Intel has (IMHO) struggled since the bubble of the early 2000s, keeping a higher percentage of very senior people (management and otherwise) while laying off more junior.  Now, growth for more junior folks is constrained by the crowd at the top.
The company has struggled also to get a handle on any "right" strategy for addressing the handheld (and now tablet) market.  They're on the third or fourth (at least) attempt and it would be great for them to get it right.

review_title: For a Designer, PC Client Group not a great place to work
job_title: User Experience Designers in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Lots of cool technologies in the labs, brilliant co-workers. If you like to keep your head down, work on your own, and don't really care if what you're making will ever effect real people's lives, then this is the place for you.
cons: The top tiers of management seem to all pursue their own agendas rather than push the most innovative ideas. The best ideas and technology often get pushed to the side in the midst of so much political climbing and bureaucracy. Every suggestion, idea, prototype, and strategy is subject to long meetings where your idea is ultimately deemed great and yet ruled out.

review_title: Great company, valuable reputation, not-so-easy culture
pros: You are part of building the computing history of the world, and contributing to it. Great total benefits package. International presence. Lots of opportunities within the company for lateral movement and exposure/experience building, if you are not concerned about upward mobility and salary increases. Excellent reputation. Enduring company.
cons: You're just a cog in the wheel. Terrible bureaucracy and politics in many pockets. Limited upward mobility, unless you know how to play the game. Frequent and sometimes pointless re-orgs. A large percentage of management is unskilled - individual contributors who were good at what they did and got promoted to that role they are unfit for. This has gotten better, but still a ways to go. Culture is dominated by type-A personalities.

review_title: Potential to be a great company again
pros: World leader transforming how the world works through personal computers, servers, and cloud computing.  Endless technical challenges, opportunity to work with cutting edge technology, bright enthusiastic co-workers.  Every seven years - Intel gives an 8 week paid sabbatical in addition to normal vacation.  Good bonus structure, ability to buy stock below market prices.  World-wide company with great exposure to different cultures.
cons: Too big, over-staffed, and moves slowly to new market opportunities.    The budget and head count allocation is based on prior year with some various, typically flat to down.   Organizational structure inefficiencies spreading projects to too many world geographies causing delays to product entry or quality issues.

review_title: One of the most challenging companies I have ever worked for.
pros: You will be challenged every day to do things you may have done before, you know well as well as things you have never done and will have to learn fast, to become the expert.  This is required and again, you will be challenged and sometimes it is a lot of fun.
cons: Intel can become your life.  It is an incredibly demanding company and if you let it suck you in, the will demand so much time, you will loose more and more time from your personal life.  You may even end up doing what I did and sleep with the company cell phone by your pillow.  Intel has plants all over the world and you may have to respond to issues 24/7.

review_title: Disappointed employee
pros: Great coworkers who make working there bearable.
cons: The company has lost its soul.  It recently laid off many employees with no eligibility for rehire as a regular full time employee..on the basis of performance.  Many of these employees were rated successful at performance review, the kicker being that they were impacted because they had a slower STOCK rating.   Nowhere does HR guidelines say that having a lower stock level would be grounds for dismissal.  To cap that, the company is hiring back these workers into the same job, working on the same project, days later as contingent workers.  So they are bad enough to be laid off, but perfect to continue working as a CW - imagine the savings in bonus, benefits etc.  BEWARE of this company.

review_title: Manufacturing Technician
pros: Great schedule, compressed work week with lots of time off.  Good pay and great benefits.
cons: Managers are hit or miss, some are great and others incredibly poor.  You're lucky if you work for a good one, your career will soar.  But get stuck with a bad manager and watch out, all your hard work will be for nothing.  Also, hirings and layoffs are very unpredictable.  The moment Intel announces a bad quarter people start talking layoffs.  Then, at the very same moment, job postings appear on the career page.  They announce layoffs while at the same time post new jobs.  It's very unpredictable.

review_title: Stable employment but mostly old and not so challenging projects
pros: Stable position, no problem with scheduling vacation days or going on sick leave, flexible work time, sometimes working with the latest technology, free access to online courses, quarterly and yearly bonuses, lunch cards
cons: Some of the tasks are really boring, working mostly with not-so-good legacy code brought from the US after lay-offs which results in stagnation... Company is dropping project from US to Poland  even though there is not enough space to pack this amount of people(once there were mostly rooms with 3-4 people but know these are packed and new offices are open space), mostly poor yearly base pay raise

review_title: Great place to work...
job_title: Technical Consulting Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: Intel is a great place to work. It is a world leader and there is great fexibility at work. Compensation can be very good if you care to negotiate  while joining and they need you badly enough. There is no deferential treatment; the CEO to the RCG - all sit in similar cubes and are provided the same resources.
cons: Values hard to practise in reality. The real value of the very elaborate process of rating and ranking employees during focal is questionable. But I suppose that is true in all companies of that size. I have seen disgruntled employes in several groups who were unhappy about their dead end jobs. Once again, I think this is true for all big companies. It is not possible for everyone to have a spectacular growth path.

review_title: Great place to work, if you fit in.
pros: Great work culture, people quote the 'Intel values' to justify their actions and decisions. Decisions happen fast and gets communicated across the globe very fast. Good facilities for mobile office working. Opportunity to work with some of the best minds in town... the sheer quality of people will show that Intel quite often manages to hire people overqualified for the job, but then you are in good company. Pay raises can have big variation depending how well your performance is rated - best performers can get up-to 3x the normal ones. Strong emphasis on technical path as well as managerial path for career growth.
cons: Too many meetings can sometimes be tiring. Work culture is very competitive,  quite often hurting team-spirit. Lot of politics and sometimes, you have to make a lot of noise to be heard.

review_title: not a bad place to work in
pros: i worked in intel somewhere in 2000. my opinion of the company was that it was a very open enviornment and i could simply talk to anybody about most things - even the senior most management. and imo they were pretty much willing to give me whatever responsibility i wanted - so i think career options were pretty good too.
cons: i think the spanner in the works as with most indian companies is the hr. i am not sure why hr is so powerful and dominant in indian companies. i have worked in the usa and europe for many years and hr are almost invisible there. but in india hr seem to be omnipresent and very powerful - often to the disadvantage of the company.

review_title: Great Company but only if you fit in with their needs...
pros: Great opportunities so long as your career goals align to the business needs. Very flexible working hours and lots of hidden perks that is probably taken for granted and only seen if one leaves to another company
cons: Very difficult to move to other parts of the company to develop one's career. Other positions typically need to be filled with someone that is already an expert rather than someone that needs to grow into the position - understandable since the tight deadlines mean that it is very difficult to find time to train someone up into a new position

review_title: Values its employees, but slow to address market dynamics
job_title: Product Marketing Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Great place to work. 
The company really does value its employees. 
Relatively flat organization, making higher ups relatively accessible. 
Opportunity to move around within the company and try out different roles.
cons:
Takes ages to make progress on any issue. Very slow pace when it comes to making progress on anything.
A redundancy of people. 100,000 give or take. Why did they hire so many people? Because they try to pigenhole everybody to a very small task, which result in the need to hire more people for the remaining small tasks.
30,000 finance employees in a 100,000 high tech organization? Are they crazy? This is not an investment bank. The ratio, at best, should be 1/10. 
If you are not in Santa Clara or Portland, then you will have little visibility and may limit your upward mobility.

review_title: Great Place to Work, Interesting Challenges, Difficult Work-Life Balance
pros:
Intel takes care of their employees with a good base salary compensation package, fairly decent raises for the first couple years, and the work provides opportunities to contribute to the company very early by embracing the "sink or swim" mentality.
Also, the sabbatical program is one of the nicer perks. Every 7 years Intel provides an 8 week paid vacation for all Blue Badge employees.
cons: With high demands at work, balancing the demand between your professional responsibilities and your personal life is very difficult. This is most evident in the engineering side of the company. There are long stretches of where the workload is extremely high as a project gets closer to one of the major milestones. It is so intense that there's a catchphrase that most employees significant others use: "the Intel widow".

review_title: Like other big company
pros:
- Work life balance is pretty great. Flexible in managing your schedule most of the time, except close to deadline.
- Many opportunities in the company because there are so many different departments to choose from. It's possible to move horizontally to another position.
- Working on the next generation technology.
cons:
- Like other big company, bureaucracy is a big problem. Decision is slow.
- Even though base salary is comparable when you join, the year to year raise doesn't keep up with inflation.
- Depend on your group, promotion could be hard, because everybody is trying to earn credits to be visible.

review_title: Intel - does it worth it?
pros:
flexible hours - work life balance is great
friendly people
not feeling pressure
Intel does not fire 
convinient
your salary is getting bigger every year (which is convinient, but on the other hand, you cant ask for a raise midyear)
cons:
far from home
salary is ok, but not great, I can get a lot more outside Intel.
Lately, Intel started to fire people, so you always feel like you are the next to be kicked out 
hard to advance in the ladder

review_title: Senior Program Manager
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Austin, TX
pros:
Great place to grow your career. Lots of opportunity to change paths, careers, focus. Very data driven. Wonderful place when new to industry, lots of friends who work hard, play together, and have fun.
Company enabled me to have a great home, raise 3 kids, put them through college, and set me up for retirement - although a bit early.
cons:
Changing tactics with new Qualcom management influx. Out with the older employees, in with the new diversity employees. Work-life balance tough, it's great when you are young but drives you out over the long term.
Too much politics, if you are lucky to be in the right group, things are pretty good. But don't miss deadlines.

review_title: Company focused on hardware development with ad hoc software processes
job_title: Software Engineering Manager in San Jose, San Jose
pros: The company offers great benefits and stability to work. Company campus and infrastructure are very cool, you can enjoy of on site gym, soccer and basketball fields, great cafeteria service with quality food for all choices, additional services like on site doctor, dentist, physical therapist, beauty salon and laundry.
cons: Unless you work close to manufacturing processes or your scope of work is related to that field you will find your organization is not very well organized. Tools in various systems from hiring, payroll, people management and project management are quite legacy and ad hoc processes support them. In the Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC) you will find a lot of practices behind industry standards and the development process is not supported by mature standards or applications that help you with source control, code review, build and release management.

review_title: Place where you can do everything besides top-down decision
job_title: Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: A place you can propose whatever you want  as long as opportunity  just beside you. Job secure will be there as you are agile enough to accept any challenging until end of your life.
cons: Intel used number to cut their talents without really know what is the talent needed for their business, A person who always make use others result and more exposure will  be the one climb faster than those who  really good in productivity and high technical .  This will make company lose a lot talents where really no idea what will happen for its future....

review_title: It was grand really
pros:
The pros: 
Pay was good, 
Got encourage to work on side/passion projects that were still for company,
Interesting work and problems.
cons:
The cons:
Silo'd and didn't really hear what other departments were doing, when you did it was through managers with a lot of technical information stripped out.
People would get protective over there projects and would try trample you if you had parallel thinking and were working on the same problem.
Some engineers would look down on the technicians

review_title: Great company with some issues typical of a large organization.
job_title: IT Support Specialist in San Jose, San Jose
pros: The company has an excellent reputation and it is a badge of honor to work for it.  Its core business is fascinating and almost literally powers our technological society.  There is a very good compensation package and plenty of sites, departments, and positions that could in theory allow for career changes/growth while staying within the company.
cons: There is excessive bureaucracy for certain processes, and the company's emphasis on safety regulations can be extreme at times.  Teams and departments within IT tend to split into "silos", reducing opportunities for collaboration and career advancement.  The company's great reputation allows it to pay lower salaries than lesser-known companies do.

review_title: Industry leader but doesn't compensate employees like it
pros: Intel is the leader in the industry.  As such, you get to work with a lot of really smart people.  There are many opportunities to try different job roles on many different projects.  Management has been very flexible when it comes to work/life balance.
cons: Accomplishments as part of a team go unrewarded.  Individual accomplishments rule and you must find a way to stick out or be the one to take recognition for a team effort.

review_title: With the right manager, an unbelievable experience
pros:
Intelligent people
Fantastic Benefits
Sabbatical
Great working conditions
Exciting work
Ability to move around
cons:
Your Intel experience ends up being entirely guided by the management structure in your position.  I have worked in 4 positions for more than 7 years now at Intel.  My first two managers were absolutely fantastic and made the work I was doing meaningful and rewarding while treating me well.  The management structure in my most recent position is abusive, micromanaging and setting us up for failure.  

Grab one of the good groups and Intel will be the best company you'll work for.  Otherwise, keep an eye on the internal jobs board.

review_title: Did I make a mistake?
job_title: Process Engineer in Rio Rancho, NM
pros:
Many resources available.  Average compensation.  Work can be challenging and interesting.
We perform some state-of-the-art work.  Facilities are well kept. Ability to change careers without changing position may be a draw for some.
cons: Many long hours are not worth the slightly above average compensation.  Working in manufacturing is like being a military family.  Moving from place to place so that Intel can minimize expenses and maximize profit.  Hours and expectations would be impossible without a stay-at-home spouse.

review_title: Commodity Manager
pros: I love the challenging job.  It is impressive how projects are critical for leading edge design, tight schedule, lowest DPPM, and challenging to provide the best customer experience.  Employees are extremely intelligent and from the best universities.  Intel is developing custom silicon that is changing the world.
cons: need complex problem solving skills.  Employees need to balance work/life.

review_title: Competitive environment
pros: hard working employees are rewarded well. if you have a strong work ethic and are a hard worker, you will be rewarded well for your efforts. Intel rewards on meritocracy and not longevity. they value great place to work, risk taking, results orientation, customer orientation and discipline. everyone is encouraged to think outside of the box and add value where they can. intel is big on diversity, environmentally consciousness, and volunteering
cons: while management claims to run the company transparently, there are clear indications that this is not true. There are wide spread issues of trust with senior management that impact employees willingness to step outside the box and try new things for fear of what may happen. this is not consistent across all managers or levels but it exists in every group.

review_title: Getting worse and worse
pros:
Flex working hours
Can switch roles quite easily
cons:
terrible HR
Layoffs based on HR excel files not on real performance
Terrible 360 degree feedback
Everyone are underrated and underpaid at least in Poland
Employer does not fight for employee if he decides to leave.  
no innovation, only execution of what is invented or started in US
Significant outsourcing

review_title: Big Companies have its advantages
pros: The biggest perks are typically the "big things" this company can afford. Sabbaticals every 7 years, company jet to other US locations, free fruit/drinks. Good salaries. People can work here for a while if they choose to.
cons:
Top talent is usually removed to make way for cheaper talent.

Intel senior management does not respect or value cost centers like IT. As a result, support gets worse every year - to the point that employees are typically left on their own if they have support needs. 

The cold grey cubes are slowly disappearing for bright, small cubes. Which is better?

review_title: Intel offers diverse career opportunities for professional growth
pros: Intel offers diverse career opportunities for professional growth.  Its culture based on results orientation though stressful, allows good sense of accomplishment.  It offers reasonably good compensation with bonus & 401K matching program.  It also proivdes flexible "work from home" option for work life balance.
cons: Intel is a large corporation with lots of bureacracy and slow growth.  It is a place with a strong focus on "what have you done for me lately" instead of "having fun & great place to work".  Layoffs known as "Structure & Efficiency Effort" is a norm, not a last resort.

review_title: Good company, but depending on your manager you might have to put in a lot of hours. Research groups great to work in.
job_title: Graduate Intern Technical in Chandler, AZ
pros: Excellent, challenging and interesting work. A lot of bright people. Culture of constructive criticism promoted: can be seen as good (if you're argumentative or self confident) or bad (if you would prefer discussion to debate). Generally though, this is a place that helps you develop self-confidence and a high work ethic. Great place to start a career. So many training resources abound.
cons: You are expected to get your work done no matter how long it takes. Good incremental results are not necessarily acknowledged until the project is about complete.

review_title: Intel is an above-average place to work.
pros: Benefits packages are very good, as are profit-sharing and stock benefits.  Most department managers are more than generous when it comes to work/life balancing and flexibility with work schedules, though this largely depends on the individual manager.  There are many perks and services available to employees, from on-site dry cleaning or massage to day care to raffles for concert tickets etc.
cons: Salaries are fairly pathetic for the expertise and performance required by Intel to be considered a "valued employee".  The annual review system is archaic, cumbersome, and requires a distribution: even in a group of high-performing employees, the manager must deliver one for burnt offering.

review_title: Great place to work
pros:
Good work life balance. Relatively Flexible hours. Most managers are nice ones. The organization culture is pleasant and usually the atmosphere is relaxed and not aggressive. The organization tries to encourage initiatives and innovation.
You have a chance to work with and on the latest hardware platfrom before they reach the market and since that this is a large organization, opportunities for role change and relocation pop up from time to time. 
Intel provide many benefits for the employees. To name few of them: Yeary bonus of between 1-4 monthly salaries (varies according to the company success), private health insurance, competitive car leasing program, shares participation plan, extended vacation each 7 years
cons: As large corporate,  the  bureaucracy sometime can kill you or the area you are working on. Some roles require international conference calls on the evening hours.

review_title: Intel is a Great Place To Work
job_title: Electrical Hardware Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Co-workers often go out of their way to help you with learning something new if they've had experience with it.  My group personally allows a large amount of freedom regarding working from home, taking vacation/half days, and daily working hours.  There is ALWAYS an Intel employee that is an expert in the thing you want to know.  The trick is finding that person and nabbing them for some 1 on 1 time.
cons: Office culture can be a bit bland if you only take what you're given.  But if you find a group of friends (fairly easy for Interns and college grads) it can breakup the day well and keep things interesting.  It's rather intimidating starting in such a large corporation, where it's almost impossible to know everything that's affecting your project.

review_title: It's a machine
pros: Decent pay, the sabbatical was nice. Opportunities to grow if you're willing to put in the time.
cons: Employees are tools and expendable at any point in time. The new CEO is subject to whims without looking into what is really taking place in the trenches (example: this summer's corporate restructuring. Intel no longer has a strategy for success and doesn't really know where they should turn. The minority hiring initiative is a smokescreen so they can say they are doing good things and hopefully keep the press and analysts happy with them.

review_title: Manufacturing Technician
pros: Great benefits, sabbatical, compressed work week (12hr shifts, 4 on 3 off - 3 on 4 off), bonuses, profit sharing, vacation and PA time.
cons: Get your money coming in because pay raises are terrible 1 - 3%. Intel is known for shedding older workers during times of layoff (age group: 60's, 50's, 40's in that order). They do not value longevity and the experienced people who were instrumental in getting new products ramped up in the fab.

review_title: Technical Program Manager or Hardware Engineer
pros: Open and collaborative atmosphere.  Access to senior executives in open forums.  Opportunity to collaborate with quality hardware, software and manufacturing folks to influence direction of computing globally.  Opportunity for both broad technical engagement or deep dive, depending on interest of individual.
cons: Corporation no longer encourages virtual / remote collaboration, odd since Intel helped enable this capability.  Teams are expected to co-locate to core Intel sites or risk termination.  Working remotely or from home used to be considered a work-life balance perk, but no more.  Non-chip design salaries are a bit below industry standards.

review_title: Great place to work but ..
pros:
Can learn a lot, meet intelligent people, do interesting work.
Sabbaticals, 4 weeks vacation after 10 years, at times, a good general flexibility in hours, location.
cons:
Will ask you every year for your career goals, draw up plans but there is little in the way job assignments are done to support goals.
Managers at times can be confident & lost.
Yearly pay seems to be tied to a table somewhere in HR, the employee contribution for a year might be high but pay still tied to some table.
People who write patents all the time will get rewarded and promoted to the sky.  Does not contribute to team goals, achievements.
Employees at times may pay the price for managers that fail to plan and resource adequately.  Paid in long hours, paid in skipped years for raise due to fail of team.

review_title: Waste of time, not for qualified engineers
pros: Salary, incentives and bonuses are among the best in the industry
cons:
Everything else. It's not a place to work but to indulge in politics. Unqualified people are everywhere and worst of all, occupy top positions.
No one is aware of what they are doing but they have been a part of Intel for decades.
Work-life balance? Forget it. You are paid to work round the clock and if you don't, you get into the bad books of the management.
I have not seen any other company where people scream at each other on a daily basis. Intel had no culture or values. 
Intel brags about being a great place to work but then, is fraudulent. I quit in a years time as I am an engineer and would like to do a job suitable for me

review_title: A fantastic place to work for your internship
job_title: Co-Op Automation Engineer in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Fantastic training, good salary, good working hours, good surroundings, enthusiastic colleagues.  Opportunity to see how processors are made, involved very much in the running of your department.  A great social ethos as well.  Lots of social events arranged by the company and paid for by the company.  You are rewarded very handsomely when you do something well.  Given constructive feedback.
cons: Some cynicism among some colleagues.  Its not a major issue though.  Everyone is extremely enthusiastic about their work.  Not entirely sure what the purpose of having so many managers either.  It's easy to get left behind and be ignored though.  Always keep yourself in focus of management around you.

review_title: Satisfied not ecstatic..
pros: The work environment tends to be very stimulating and fast paced.  Things change very quickly, which keeps you thinking.   I tend to feel challenged often and am presented with new projects and tasks that allows for my skill set to grow and develop.  There are lots of resources provided for health education, such as seminars and collaboration with the Mayo clinic.  Lifestyle coaches are available too.  Work Life balancing is prominent in some groups, but not all.
cons: Silo'd organizations, poor communication between groups, competiveness can be extreme. Experience of employee is very varied depending on the group that they work in.

review_title: Was a great company, at one time.
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Overall benefits are good.  Pay, bonuses and return on equity contribution to 401K plan were excellent.
cons: Every year the company purges 10% of the workforce.  Each supervisor is required to rate 10% of his/her employees as underperform.  This is presumably to rid the company of the lowest performing 10% of the employees and works to a degree, but often times, excellent performers get swept up into this and terminated because a supervisor has a personal issue with the employee.  Funny thing is, upper management is not subjected to the same program.

review_title: Change for the better not the "LEAN"
pros: Free coffee and soft drinks. I have also learned and witnessed senior managment at its worst, so I know now not what to do, if I ever so do.  Knowing that without and beyond any reasonable doubt there are more fools above me than below brings warth to my heart and a smile to my face.  Making it further up the bureaucratic food chain is like coaxing a banana sandwich from an ape, it can be done, you just need to out think them.
cons: Senior managment seems to be "past their prime".  The ideas flowing from the top down about staffing or other simple tasks for senior managers to perform or forcast for are poorly executed.  More managers than technicians seems to defy even human comprehension.

review_title: Flexible and international company with lots to offer, but easy to get lost.
job_title: Human Resources Business Partner  in Hillsboro, OR
pros: The people who work here are intelligent, the company is very large and has global presence, which provides the opportunity to work on an international level. Flexibile as far as hours, working from home, and there is no dress code. Very laid back.
cons: It is so large that you can feel kind of lost or unimportant. Also, reorganizations happen very often so one never really knows what to expect next. Feedback only comes once a year officially, so it's kind of hard to know what you're going to hear. Not all managers are "people's people". Lots of people who are suckups are promoted, because they get the job done. Doesn't matter what they're like as people.

review_title: You own your own job
job_title: Hardware Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Interesting problems to work on coupled with a track record of success.  When Intel executes well, you feel like you're contributing to making the world a better place, since it has such an impact on the entire computing industry.  I was proud to work there.  I felt that my destiny was in my own hands.
cons: The corporate culture prides itself on being confrontational.  This can be a good thing, but sometimes the people that do the best are the ones that are the most confrontational (most visible in a fight).  Endless grey cubicle farms.  Internal competition can end up making you feel like a cog in a great machine.  Stock has been in the doldrums for almost 10 years.

review_title: It's a hard company to leave.  They take very good care of you
pros: Year after year, Intel is listed as on of the top companies to work for.  I started working there with the intent of only staying 3 years.  12 years later....yeah, I'm still here :).   Work/Life balance is a major factor for why I stay.  i can work my own hours, either on site or at home as needed.  Granted, your mileage may vary, depending on your role and your manager.  Your rank and pay are determined by meritocracy, which I believe is the most objective way to manage your pay among your peers.
cons: It's pretty unanimous that pay is low when compared to competitors.  Intel loses a lot of good talent because of this, especially when venturing into new businesses.

review_title: Good benefits, decent work
pros:
- Benefits, especially SPP and bonus opportunities are nice.
- Gain some culture, the chance to work with people from all over the world
- Depending on the group your work can be challenging.
cons:
- Definitely feels like a large company, a lot of process and overhead
- Room for advancement can be slow after initial promotions
- Way too many "new" programs introduced that function similar to if not the same as existing programs. Limit these because you put a lot of time and effort into stuff that is hot for a short period of time and fades away. Less is more sometimes.

review_title: Great place to start a career
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer Grade 7 in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
People respect your career choice. Once you get in, it's rather easier to switch between teams of your interest if there's an opening. You get to work with a lot of smart people, and depending on your team, you get to work through the entire product cycle, from how the product's features are defined, implemented, volume validation, to debugging the manufactured product in one of Intel's labs. 

Debugging the actual product is really stressful, but you learn so much in such a short amount of time. You get to appreciate good design, and especially design for testing techniques much more
cons:
Product cycle can be very long. 
A lot of management changes recently
A lot of in house tool changes recently

review_title: Semiconductor Leader
pros:
Lot of Opportunity
Option to switch across Department within Company
Work From Flexibility
India Center is growing
Female Employee are option for flexibility
cons:
Tools & Methodology Internal In House (sometimes different Vs Industry Standard)
External Tools are not used much. Recent Times Migration has started.
Too many meetings with similar Agenda which wastes the productive hours.
Multiple layers  Manger Level Hierarchy for Tracking Activity which could be simply be tracked at 1-Level Manager / Leader.
Performance in Meeting is more valued than actual  Performance on Task/Implementation. Many times real technical get hidden behind these Meeting Expert Technical Leader who otherwise could have added higher value to the Intel Products.

review_title: Becoming just another large corporation
job_title: Project Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Large corporation, reasonable stability. The sabbatical program is becoming unique at other companies, but is still part of Intel culture.
cons: Intel expects exempt employees to be available 24X7. Manufacturing is especially bad at this. Intel used to pride itself in being different for its employees, now it's just becoming another large corporation.

review_title: In Benefits Cutback Mode
job_title: Technical Project Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: Opportunities to have impact are plentiful; dress code is very flexible; communications are very direct from upper management; good support for diversity within the organization
cons: Job growth possibilities constrained by hiring limitations and "redeployments" (lay-offs); established benefit programs taking a hit due to decreasing corporate profits and misses in getting products into the market; inflexible telecommuting and work-life balance attitude by Senior management

review_title: Large company at crossroad
job_title: Senior Hardware Engineer in Hudson, MA
pros: Like most of the large company, well rounded benefits, bonus can be significant at higher grade level when Intel is doing well.  Opprotunity to work with lots of interesting people.  Chance to learn a lot.  Company likely to stay around for the forseeable future.  It has commanding lead in the process technology and pc/labtop/server market.
cons: Lots of meetings.  Structure can be rigid.  Depends on your job role and manager, may be hard to move up to higher levels.  Stock is stagnant for past few years as it's trying to break into phone/tablet market and hasn't succeed.

review_title: Facilities Project/Program Manager
job_title: Facilities Project/Program Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: I spent 19 years at Intel before being offered an enhanced 'retirement package'; one time offer never to be offered again!  Intel is the 'best company' to work for and enhance your career, but you can't be lazy or out the door you go sooner then you think.  In my 19 years, I had more opportunities then I would have had in another company due to my agressiveness, willingness to work hard, and wanting the challenges Intel offered me.  If your driven, Intel is the place to be with strong top down leadership managing a truly successful company!
cons: No Cons for Intel or their leadership.

review_title: Overall a good place to work.
pros: Great benefits program and good compensation.  The schedule is a compressed work week, which gives you really long weekends every week.  This also means that you get overtime every shift, and if you work night shift, a 16% differential in pay.
cons: The job is not challenging.  Some people may think that is a good thing, but most nights I feel like I am underutilized and that my skills are diminishing.  I have a degree in electronics, and I do next to nothing technical at all.

review_title: More challenges ahead
pros: Great compensation (for Portland area, anyway), excellent engineering culture, able to overcome many business and technical obstacles and remain profitable, unmatched ability to scale precision manufacturing.
cons: Lack of senior management vision to make the engineering and business model changes needed to succeed in software and services. Too many people jumping on small opportunities and trying to be perceived as leaders. Not enough hands-on experience and understanding of the latest tools (at least on the software side) on part of management. Company seems to be pursuing many objectives other than its traditional engineering-driven business imperatives and risks being overtaken by more nimble competition and the end of Moore's Law.

review_title: Intel Lab job review
pros: Great benefits and pay. Being at the forefront of new technology allows the use of top of the line equipment for EVERYTHING. Never having to deal with tools or machines breaking due to age is a great way to deal with the stress of the job.
cons: Management expects too much. It is a very numbers based job / company and management asks for more and more each new process. Some jobs are extremely time extensive and management doesn't recognize the difference and asks for unreasonable outputs.

review_title: Business Analyst
pros: It's a job.  They don't care about their employees so why should their employees care about them?
cons: It is absolutely unacceptable for a company as large as Intel to wrangle tax concessions as they do and then to turn around and fill jobs with temporary workers.  Intel fills the same jobs for YEARS with temporary employees in order to avoid hiring permanent workers.  This allows them to allocate "head count" to cover their totally bogus employment numbers, since temporary employees are not considered part of "head count."   It's time for Intel and other corporations to pay their fair share of taxes and actually employee the people in our communities instead of stealing wages and using temporary employees.

review_title: frastrated but have the faith still.
pros: It is the most successful semi-conductor manufacturing company and enjoys much hogher margin than others. It encourages to tak risks and do not blame on failures. It invest a lot on software, technology and platforms. so there are planty of fields to choose from if you are bored in one area. It does not lay off so much although recently it has been doing that. But it is still much better than others. many people left happy with a big seperation package.
cons: Not enough care about people and sometimes stupidly process oriented. It is the best at process technololy, and is just so so at other areas, including CPU design. However, most people in Intel do not realize that and are so arroggant.

review_title: If only the pay matched up...
pros: The atmosphere is great at Intel and the people are nice and friendly. There are always people around that's willing to help. There's the team activities that is nice and people are generally open to meeting up after work to have fun. The management system also works well and there isn't much politics around  which make things easier to do.
cons: The pay and the benefits are definitely on the low side. The other problem is the cramped cubes, they are so small it's just uncomfortable in them. The gray color everywhere doesn't help neither. People also like to talk in the aisles which bothers other people from working.

review_title: An experienced employee view on Intel (16 years w/Intel, 25 years in industry)
pros: An egalitarian and practical company  that produces some of the worlds most miraculous devices that nearly everyone can afford.  Has a strong culture of results orientation and doing "the right things right".  A flat organizational structure with open communication.  Filled with super smart people focused on producing technology that is transcendental in the details (think atomic level), yet practical and useful in the end consumer applications.
cons: A large organization, Intel can be challenging for the individual who wants to 'tinker' and experiment outside of the bounds of a business focused result.  While individualism is valued, team work is important in this environment.  A strong, active policy of "disagree and commit" is the key to understanding this cultural dichotomy.

review_title: Solid, stable and uneventful. Not great for people with very high aspirations.
pros: Lots of stability and job security. Facilities are good. People are generally kind. If you're decent at what you do, you can go at it for years and have the freedom to do it your way. Internal HR/payroll processes are seamless.
cons: Over-focused on execution, limited room for innovation or professional growth outside the "approved" course. First line management are generally nice guys but incompetent magisterially. No real interest or focus on employee development. Too many processes with too much time wasted mundane things. Complete addiction to e-mail: many managers spend 90% of their time in front of Outlook.

review_title: Great place to work, if you join, target the larger sites
pros:
culture values open, direct communications
employees generally help each other
good overall compensation package
lots of very smart, driven people
once in the company, you can move around and try a lot of different things
work/life balance is acheivable, outside of crunch times
cons:
Uncertain business outlook.  Majority of revenue comes from PCs (a declining market).  Working on building up the other businesses but they are unlikely to be as profitable.
Many very complex products are split across sites and timezones.  This isn't abnormal in itself, but in Intel's case the site splits are sometime arbitrary and/or politically driven.  It slows the company down.  Also, many groups have grown too large and have slowed down as a result.

review_title: We make logic, but certainly don't use it!
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: If you do find yourself in the right job then all the benefits and compensation is pretty good
cons: Challenges include finding the right fit for skills, lack of direction, unable to retain top talent, corp politics play a big role in how and what is worked on. many mid level managers make intel a slow moving ship. There is a lack of creativity, risk taking, innovation. Engineers in Fabs over worked and have no life .. ability to move into new position is near impossible/

review_title: Fantastic supportive high tech company!
job_title: Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Intel funded our startup division Intel Media and eventually spun it off to Verizon.

Intel made sure we had the right talent and resources to really innovate.  

Fantastic benefits, ESPP, stock grants, bonuses, work/life balance.  I really am proud to say I worked for Intel.

There is a employee cash bonus and accelerator.

The culture is that of get it exactly right and be respectful of others.
cons: Intel really missed on the mobile window and is now trying to catch up.  The stock performance really reflects that.  Intel is a great, long term place to work.

review_title: Excellent company but marred by middle level managers
pros: You will get a chance to work on the cutting edge technology and face challenges that no one in the industry has seen before. Work life balance, Inclusive Culture and Employee development are not just buzz words; but followed by letter and intent. Great benefits and retirement benefits depending on your country.
cons: Even though a lot of management clean up has been happening/happened in the recent years, the company continues to be dragged down by certain middle level managers that are either technically paralyzed or signup for far too aggressive targets just to please their bosses. Employee burn-out is quite common, and most common cause of attrition is bad managers.

review_title: Rough work environment while company reorganizes
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Good at technology adoption.  Salaries and bonuses are competitive.  Intel is a prestigious brand name and can be a positive addition to resume.  Social and event type perks are good - drawings for sports tickets, concerts, etc..
cons: Just cut 12% of workforce and all groups are struggling to get work done.  Will likely be overly competitive for a couple of years.  70% of employees are rated successful but to avoid most recent round of layoffs, you must be above that for last 3 years - which is statistically unlikely.  Top heavy management. Company doesn't have a clear vision for growth and will cannibalize the workforce in an effort to grow.  Constant shifts of IT workforce between geographic locations leads to unstable applications and poor security practices.

review_title: Worth working for...
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
Overall benefits package is good, Share allocation and Bonuses are above industry average.
Great opportunities to move groups and get good experience.
Great opportunities to travel.
cons:
Like most large companies, there is a huge variation in the work environment between groups. Some groups are fantastic to work in, others are like the ninth circle of Hell. The design group in Ireland is generally a nice place to work.
Base Salary is below industry average.
PC industry as a whole is on a downward trajectory.
Many of the processes are outdated and slow to change, mainly due to the size of the company.

review_title: A great company gone bad
pros:
Some of the smartest people in the industry
Amazing technology
Great benefits
cons:
Culture has taken a massive nosedive in the past 5+ years.  Especially under BK's leadership.
They start new businesses only to shut them down before they have a chance to take hold.  Example... if they stayed with Intel Online Services, they would have been the AWS of the industry.  But they lack patience and continue to sink money into projects only to kill them about 1-2 yrs later.

review_title: A lot to learn if you have the right mindset and an urge for problem solving
pros:
Brand value
Flexible working hours and work from home feasibility
Intel has transformed from PC centric to data centric company. As Intel offers solutions to a wide spectrum of market problems there are plethora of opportunities to explore and find the right fit that matches your skills and passion
cons:
Stock options are not appealing
Intel is not in the Ivy league when it comes to compensation
Intel being so huge the culture is varied from team to team. An Intel employee tag does not necessarily qualify a person being part of an amazing work/work-life culture.
It is hard to get relocation from India to other countries

review_title: The Good and the Bad
pros:
* Good Work-Life balance
* Pretty good salaries when including the bonuses.
* Stability
* Large company so you can try to switch roles.
* No age, sex, or pregnancy discrimination.
cons:
I can only speak for my Intel site and the product I was working on. Intel is a huge company and things can vary greatly.
* Terrible food at the dining room.
* Reducing expenses by removing snacks from the common area.
* Cheap on equipment for employees (SSD upgrade (no kidding), low quality screens)
* Low level programming isn't for everyone.
* Legacy Code
* Large company and products that have been around for years so it's hard to change things.
* Not much fun perks

All in all - compered to the non-hitech work places, the conditions at Intel are great.

review_title: Poor work-life balance
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Extremely demanding place to work, but it's great experience for a first job out of grad school. Above average compensation for early career, although raises don't keep pace. Excellent benefits.
cons: Can't be overstated--poor work-life balance. Poor opportunities for advancement. Aggressive and combative culture. Work day monopolized by useless meetings. Ineffective/tyrannical leadership from top to bottom in PTD.

review_title: Good company overall
pros: Decent pay and very good benefits. Most of the people are very good at their jobs, which helps me get my work done efficently. My immediate mangager is excellent, a people person who basically leaves me alone to do my job (much appreciated).
cons: Typical large corporation mentality, execs get a ridiculous amount of compensation and the rank and file is kept to the "just satisfied" level. Bonuses are good, but the formula is continually adjusted to keep them down (even when we have a great quarter). I've worked for the company for 12 years and miss the times before the "bean counters" took over. They have been slowly whittling away our pay and benefits.

review_title: Good place to work for a large company.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: A big company with many opportunities for either advancement or to try different things.  Pay is pretty solid as are the benefits.  It would be better if the stock would actually move.  The sabbatical at 7 years is a real positive and keeps people around if you make it to year 4 or so.
cons: As everyplace else, politics play a role at least somewhat in Promotions/Raises.  It is a little more of how you present yourself than what you actually do.  Depending on the group you are with, hours can be strange and/or difficult, you might be working both ends with Europe in the morning and Asia late in the afternoon and at night.

review_title: Intel is a challenging place to work, but has some flaws in the way engineers are managed.
