pros: Challenging environment.  State of the art technology to work on.  The best hardware and software tools in the industry. Great online and classroom education available.  There is always an expert available to help with any technology.
cons:
The twice-a-year performance review is actually set up to rate one's performance based on input from his peers and results in pay based on ranking amongst fellow employees.  At first glance this may seem like a good plan, but it results in people giving poor reviews of some of their peers so they will end up ranking higher themselves.
Management is always pushing for more output from employees.

review_title: Great place to work, but not for artists
pros: Intel has good reputation. It is world leader in semi-conductors, hardware, reasearch. Intel has excellent salaries, good benefits, work/life balance.It is great place to learn and grow if you at in the right group and ig you are an Engineer.
cons: Although Intel is making advances in graphics, it is not a place for artists. Artists have very little to contribute and are not mentored or guided properly. the work we do is not valued or evaluated as it should be. There are a ton of management issues, very poor planning and they are very bad with managaing artist's time and talent.

review_title: Becoming a nightmare of backstabbing paranoid asskissers
job_title: Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Technology industry, pays better than non-tech companies in the area.
cons: Absolutely no teamwork or collaboration.  Everything is a zero sum game - for me to do well, someone else has to do poorly, reality be damned.  It's becoming less and less about how competent people are, and much more about who's ass you kiss, and who you are friends outside of work with.

review_title: A place where you can have a big impact
job_title: Business Development in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The center of the computer industry and probably the best of the chip companies to work for.  Large number of very smart, hard-working people.  Very good total compensation package.  Management takes extraordinary measures to avoid large layoffs.  Ability to gain experience in multiple disciplines.  High ethical standards.
cons: Lack of growth limits upward mobility.  Large, geographically dispersed organization and long product design cycles can make decision-making complex and slow.  Strong corporate culture (also a pro) contributes to resistance to change.  Work / life balance has improved in recent years but still has a ways to go.

review_title: Good Perks, Pay, and Benefits.
pros: Good Pay, Smart Co-workers, Good Perks, Good Benefits. Very socially conscious company that is the #1 purchaser of renewable energy in America. Created the world's first conflict-free semiconductor. Spends millions on education initiatives. We make the technology that makes the world go round. I and most Intel employees are Very proud to work for this company.
cons: Lots of Bureaucracy, Much of senior management is staid and stuck in the past. Leaders are timid, too slow moving, and often yes-men/women. Paul Otellini and his crew COMPLETELY missed both the smartphone and tablet market and the company suffered big time as a result and is still suffering. After Otellini resigned unexpectedly, Brian Krzanich got the top job and has done very well so far.

review_title: Good Benefits, not much chance for promotions
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer Grade 6 in Portland, OR
pros: The benefits package, and pay is quite nice.
cons:
I believe it is impossible to get a promotion (as a white male) while maintaining a good balance between work and life. All of the people who are promoted are either single, and spend all of their time at work, or are about to be divorced because they spend all of their time at work. 

If you hate your wife and kids, and love to work all the time. You can easily escape them here. 

Also, there are no internal transfer promotions. If an employee is in a group that is stagnant and not growing, they cannot join another group at a higher level and get a promotion.

review_title: One of the best tech companies to work for.
pros: Lots of opportunity for advancement,  You will also have the opportunity to take you career in other directions from the place you started.  In other words, you can start in IT, stay for 2 years and than go into a software development group or chip design and apply different skills that you may have.   You will get lots of training.
cons: Work / Life balance is an issue, I know it was for me.  I ended up spelling life "INTEL" and although I didn't, is a good way to burn out.  Something to watch out for.

review_title: One of the best tech companies to work for.
pros: Lots of opportunity for advancement,  You will also have the opportunity to take you career in other directions from the place you started.  In other words, you can start in IT, stay for 2 years and than go into a software development group or chip design and apply different skills that you may have.   You will get lots of training.
cons: Work / Life balance is an issue, I know it was for me.  I ended up spelling life "INTEL" and although I didn't, is a good way to burn out.  Something to watch out for.

review_title: Overall good company to work for
pros: Working from home, autonomy, benefits are good, challenging work environment, smart co-workers, Intel University
cons: Bureaucratic, Difficult to see impact of work in the grand scheme of things, hiring primarily driven by diversity quotas rather than hiring the best person for the job.

review_title: Business Analyst America's Operations Org
pros: Nice people, fun things to do because they want you never leaving campus.  Good benefits.  We're better until new CEO arrived.
cons: Lower level management is useless.  Intel fires who they consider "old" people, then 2 days later hires boatloads of recent graduates who, some don't even know what a CPU is.  Lost a lot of good talent in 2014/2015.  New CEO not fun.  Intel is cheap. Pay for our own "teambuliders" Really?   No commission for those who do the grunge work so field gets fat commissions.  And if you don't fit the hipster nerd profile, prepare to get walking papers.  Lastly, way too many meetings.

review_title: good life/work balance and salaries, bad bad management.
pros: Lots of benefits, the ones you can usually find with a typical software US corporation, stock, pretty flexible with life/work balance. You can go up on the technical side, but you need to find support from trusted US engineers.
cons: Lots of local managers trying to do anything to go up in the hierarchy, favoritism, the usual Romanian style of "steal while you can", including young ones which should be the future of Romanian management elite. Most managers have no ideas, make assumptions with no backup, spend money recklessly, hire lazy friends of theirs.

review_title: A constant change (mostly positive)
pros:
Very high salary and bonuses.
I work with great SW/FW/HW engineers. It's a big pleasure and privilege.
During the last few years there was a significant investiment in our Gdansk campus. All major engineering groups have presence here: Data Center Group (servers/cloud/telco/networking), VPG (graphics), PEG (client, chipsets), IOT group. This gives many options for technical and career growth. There is a good chance you will work on a "bleeding edge" product.
Much was done to attract women to R&D organization. They are recognized here (it's a 'pros' for them).
Very good location, many commute options.
cons:
Open space in most of buildings in campus.
Performance management - it really can be done better. Other big IT companies changed it already.

review_title: Great people and benefits!
pros: You will never be bored...or lack work. As with most large companies there are pros and cons but the level of expertise and intelligence you will come across far outweighs the cons. I have been very well supported and given amazing opportunities just within my first 2 years of working here at Intel. If you like challenges, hard work, and constant change this is the place for you.
cons: Have experienced some bureaucracy and hierarchy in some groups at Intel, and in general the corporate culture can dramatically shift depending on your manager and business group. Nothing ever sits still - orgs change structure, tech focusses change and people move around a lot. So don't expect everything to keep stable and constant, but change is also fun and exciting! Must keep that mind-set to work here.

review_title: Sr. Software Engineer
pros:
- Great place to learn cutting-edge technologies
- Nice overall compensation
- Nice offices & benefits
- It has an area dedicated to help the community (Community Team)
- You can develop a "career path" inside the company
cons:
- Not a software company. Most project never see production ever.
- Not a very clear direction given by directors and managers (at least for Software Division)
- Anual performance review based on meritocracy can be very subjective. It 's also  counterproductive to teamwork itself as in the end you need to end up competing with your colleagues for the same amount of budget.

review_title: Great company if you are in the right job
pros: Great culture and values in the company. Intel places a very high value on integrity and it is a very well run and organized company. When Intel focuses on serving its customers it does a great job. Since the core of Intel is manufacturing, itʻs wonderful to work at a place where there are clear work hours.
cons: The biggest problem I experienced was an attitude that Intel knew better than its customers what they wanted. Intel had a real bad NIH syndrome problem. This led to overly complex solutions and products that didnʻt alway serve customer needs. Parts of the company have been addressing this since then, but it was an uphill battle while I was there.

review_title: Horrendous disregard for work/life balance
pros: The pay is great, and benefits aren't half bad either.
cons: There is absolutely no regard for work/life balance, to the point where supervisors tell their supervisees that the key to success is to sleep less so you can work more.  The workplace culture is toxic, and the job is not as advertised.   You're expected to be reachable 24/7, even in the middle of the night and on weekends (including scheduling regular meetings on Sunday mornings), and thus can never escape.

review_title: It's NOT In-Hell
job_title: Senior Applications Developer  in Hudson, MA
pros:
Professional training was great, in order to cater to our customers (manufacturing/fab), every one in automation was given appropriate training to serve better.   Got an opportunity to take on multiple tasks, roles and projects giving an opportunity to explore options in the same department.  Most all of my co-workers were great. 
There are always ups and downs up overall we were challenged and over all good experience.
cons: Growth opportunities depending on location is rather stagnant.  Even though people took on several project and different roles -project management, system analyst, programmer and DBA and was ranked well, the title and salary was not very satisfactory.  Here is also no opportunity to move to different departments to pursue other opportunities.

review_title: Great place to start my career.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Intel is of coarse a very well known company. And also a leader in its industry. Intel seems to be very stable even in the midst of this economic recession.  Company has treated me fairly well. We get free fruit and drinks, no Google meals, but its better than nothing.  Also compensation and benefits are competitive.
cons: Intel is a very large company, so sometimes it feels like your work is lost in the sea of all that Intel does. That is me speaking from a entry level position. I'm also a software guy and I foresee it being difficult to navigate a technical career. If you are a hardware person this is the place for you though.

review_title: Be careful of leading "out of the box"
job_title: Business Development Manager in Redmond, OR
pros: Good opportunity to understand the direction of the industry because Intel is the center of the semiconductor (microprocessor) industry.  Internal information flow to and amongst employees is good.
cons: Little to no opportunity to expand the influence of Intel in broader areas (outside of microprocessors).  Intel initiated several attempts to lead in the systems area and failed.  They also attempted to move into Data Cetners and toys, and failed.  Fundamentally, these were good and profitable ventures, yet these ventures did not have profit levels of the sole sourced (monopoly)microprocessors.

review_title: Great company
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Very dynamic from a job opportunity perspective - they know you'll work your best in a job that you actually want to do; internal job transfers are fully supported. Strong cultural values which are often brought up and help justify decisions. Great work-life balance (albeit there is always a ton of work to do). Good benefits, decent bonuses. Lots of training available, both on-line and classroom.
cons: It's a huge company, so decision making is often dragged out even with their focus and attempts to increase decision velocity. LOTS of meetings because projects are generally so big with so many stakeholders - can be tough to balance talking about the work versus actually doing the work. Very often difficult to hire externally because of near constant desires to maintain or reduce headcount - "do more with less."

review_title: Wonderful balanced approach to work, personal growth and aspirations and WLE
pros:
Rewards and recognitions are many and well-deserved across organization.
Open and fair pay and work. Exhaustive review of pay and performance.
Promotions based on performance, interest and ability.
Work life balance is one of the best in the industry. Very open and flexible to implement what works for an individual as long as work is done.
Company invests a lot into the employees in terms of training, development and environment.
Is one of the fastest to adopt new technologies, approaches and concepts into practise and proliferate it throughout even though it is a large organization.
cons:
Tight compensation compared to industry. Can get much better pay elsewhere in industry many times.
High egos based on division/designation for many instances.

review_title: Unfair layoffs in July, 3.3K new jobs in Sept?
job_title: Senior Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Was a good company for a long time that took good care of their employees. Good benefits, healthcare, 2 month paid sabbatical every 7 years, etc. Stock options were given as an extra incentive over a 5 year period to convince employees to stay long term, plus extra for promotions.
cons: New president laid off thousands of older 15-25 year veteran employees within a few years of retirement who were the backbone of Intel's success for many years. Then turns around and opens 3.3K new jobs (according to GlassDoor's count) for new college grads.

review_title: Intel Company Review
pros:
- Lots of opportunities to work on advanced technologies- always at the forefront of technology
- Can change fields/jobs within the company quite easily- so you can get to do different things
- Good work/life balance and good salary package
cons:
- As company grew, big company mentality set in- with people more intent on saving their behind than taking risks and taking delivery
- Company does not have patience to live through the growing/scaling of products/ideas in any area other than hardware.
- Although very big development house in software, real software executives do not exist- so they don't understand software well. The people working on it will get frustrated.

review_title: Senior Sotware Engineer
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: good benefits and facilities (fitness center, on site health center and vision center).  Co-workers are smart and dedicated.  Intel does have work-life balance listed in its corporate values.
cons: Poor senior management decisions have led to the decline of intel's competitive edge.  Black box focal review system.  Recent 2016 layoffs have resulted in poor morale amongst remaining employees and caused a sense of mistrust towards upper management that is likely to stymie risk taking, innovation and reduce worker effectiveness.

review_title: Big recent changes due to new head
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Top notch people, lots of freedom to do skunk works stuff, very merit based
cons: Recent top level management shifts have removed the founder's protections against arbitrary management decisions, making it easy to summarily dismiss someone without cause. Recent "house cleaning" has been very byzantine. A lot of very exceptional people dismissed surprisingly.

review_title: Good place to learn, but not well compensated
job_title: Graphics Hardware Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros:
Definitely learn a lot more than you initially thought.
Technically good managers and micro-architects who are easily approachable.
cons: Fast technical ramp, but low promotional aspects due to deep levels of hierarchy. Mediocre salary/ compensation for the amount of work that you do -  best-in-class work expected, but the compensation doesn't seem to be Best-in-Class - people's morale droops when they're hammered with work without proper compensation

review_title: Decent place to work and learn
job_title: Senior Staff Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Interesting products, interesting technology - you just need to keep your eyes and ears open. Good learning opportunities. There is always someone who has some insight into what you want to know or learn - find him/her.
cons: Bureacracy, too many meetings over the phone. Working with so many different geographies becomes a pain really quickly, and kill productivity. Also having to have early morning or late night meetings.

review_title: Fair but needs improvement
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Good research facilities. Good opportunities for continuing education. I like the campus like environment.  I also urge you to be sure Intel is a place you want to work. It is a fast-paced, highly-political, and unstable employer. It has a history of getting into new businesses but not sticking it out for more than a few months or maybe a couple years. Intel has destroyed virtually every company it has acquired. It lacks upper management leadership to choose a strategic direction and stick with it. In the recent -- and ongoing -- job cuts of over 10K people, it was 100% mid-managers and lower and individual contributors.
cons: Management sometimes out of loop. Not well informed with regards to employee needs.

review_title: For smart, driven people, Intel is a great place to spend 10 years of your career...but probably not too much more.
pros: Intel generally hires very strong people.  Company is very focused on competing and winning in the marketplace.  Products are some of the most complicated human inventions and makes it easy to be proud to work for the company.  Pay quite well, particularly in good times.  Very open and trustworthy senior leadership.
cons: Large company with a number of people who have stayed too long.  Congested organizations makes moving up challenging but not impossible.  For large majority, not a place where more than 15 years makes sense from a career growth perspective.

review_title: Intel is a 1960 style corporation.
job_title: Principal Engineer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Good compensation, good benefits, adequate time off.   The overall compensation plan may be among the best in the high tech industry.
cons: Slow moving, risk averse, POLITICAL.  The entire company is drive by how cute powerpoint presentations are and very little can be accomplished without that.  A graphic artist could get Intel to commit to spending a billion dollars, where an engineer with good technology could not begin to get a commitment.

review_title: Great Place to Work... depending
job_title: Graphics Hardware Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros:
Intel Corporation is AMAZING.
Good Pay but great bonuses and stock.
Great benefits.
Sabbatical every 8 years.
Flexible hours and work from home options.
Good ability to "move around" in the company
cons:
It really depends on the business unit you work for... some are better than others.
I found management on the Graphics Engineering side to be fairly bad.  It's hit or miss.  I personally had 2 levels of good management, but had to deal with some other groups that were poorly mismanaged and it began to affect my every day.

review_title: Great benefits, but advancement is only for the insanely ambitious
job_title: IT Finance Analyst in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great health care, very flexible work arrangements.  I loved my immediate boss and her boss.  I loved being able to work with so many smart, nice colleagues (that we're peers).
cons: Tight-fisted with spending on training.  If they pay you a salary, they expect you to do an insane amount of work and make it look easy. A lot of the managers, all the way up to the president and CEO are callous, arrogant, and short-sighted.

review_title: The skinny on Intel/TMG
pros: Solid company that is making strides at improving work life balance.  New programs to help mothers and fathers of newborns is incredible
cons: The company is over-employed and could benefit from strategic positioning and/or head count reductions.  As your career advances, it is hard to move around to different areas of the company.  It is hard to stay aligned with the boards long-term strategy.

review_title: Could be a much better work place!
job_title: Senior Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Leading semiconductor manufacturer bar none
- Has involvement in every aspect of ongoing technological innovation
- Extremely good hardware, firmware engineers
- Great health package, excellent on-site workout facility with great classes, free fruit, coffee/tea, sodas
cons:
- Lot of politics for advancement
- Unless you are part of an anointed group, you can work hard all you want but stay in place
- Too many meetings
- A powerpoint company
- Everybody tries to take credit for the work a few people do

review_title: Intel IT
pros:
I worked at Intel for 21 years:
- Great people, all local and remote teams I worked with really made it a great place to work.
- Good benefits, profit sharing, stock and bonuses when the company is doing well.
- Good work conditions in general.
cons:
- Some management seems more focused on their upward mobility than their employees.
- Work environment was good, but was getting more compressed as the years went on (to an extreme point).
- Even though the company was making record profits year over year the general feeling was that we were barely making it (especially in IT).
- A lot of outsourcing to India and Costa Rica. We lost good people to this year over year and never understood the ROI.

review_title: Process Engineer
pros: Great Salary Great benefits as expected from Similar brand names companies.
cons: Process Engineer life is extremely difficult. No work life balance is expected from you. It is just published as theory. You are expected to work extremely hard just to be counted in as average sustaining engineer. If your manager is bad (which is most of the time) your life will be miserable. Here managers in process technology side are ones who have been promoted because they had worked extremely hard (deprived of sleep) for 6-10 years. Such managers will also expect the same from their engineers. It is golden handcuff with good salary with no measurable future growth unless you give all your time to work.

review_title: Less Bureaucracy than most big firms, lacking decisive planning & direction
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Austin, TX
pros:
- Many intelligent people
- Low on bureaucracy, due to many managers being working managers/former engineers
- Great working environment
- People who work there generally have positive attitudes
- Relatively stable company (despite recent layoffs)
- Produces easy-to-identify product
cons:
- Difficulty planning for the market and picking the right projects
- Rarely set aside time to innovate
- Not enough software skill at the company
- Stuck in the idea of "grades" for pay/promotions (which is common for many big companies, to be fair)

review_title: PTD Process Engineer
job_title: PTD Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Compensation; benefits; freedom to come and go as you please as long as you get the job done; lots of different job opportunities with a company so big. Tons of smart people to work with and no lack of money to complete projects. Felt they did TRY to make life good for engineers but the nature of the beast is just 24/7 go-go-go-go and that will never change. It's too expensive to have down time.
cons: Can be brutal hours; completely dependent on the group you are assigned into and what they do. Turnover is high. Work-life balance can be difficult especially if you have small babies and want to be a dad who isn't always "on-call" or having to be on your laptop. Data always needed yesterday for quick "data turns".

review_title: Seriously Ethical
pros:
Great pay and benefits
Good Leadership as far as the eye can see
The most genuine impression of interest in the wellbeing of the employee I've ever felt. Everything from work-life balance to calling out peers and higher ups for ethical or unsafe behavior. 
SERIOUSLY!! They're basically begging you to utilize the "open door" policy in order to improve the overall adherence to their Code of Conduct. 

It's a breath of fresh air.
cons:
It's in Arizona... It's quite hot. 
Nothing else that I've seen yet. 
Perhaps their focus on Social Justice will turn out to be excessive.... We'll see.

review_title: Stressed out environment and a majority of people unhappy in their jobs
pros: Heath insurance, on-site resources for employees (health center, dentist, gym, bank)
cons: Stressful environment with unrealistic goals that burn their employees out. There is no work/life balance for people in supply planning or operations. We were monitored with daily work limits and daily micro breaks we were supposed to take. If we went over the the computer daily limits or didn't take our breaks we would be on watch with management. Trying to manage balancing the excessive workloads while being under our working time limits was a constant struggle.

review_title: Good company, too many politics
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, San Jose
pros: I think that the growth opportunities, if you really want to achieve a specific level (specially on technical side) is always possible to get.  Sometimes you have to fight with politics and bureaucracy but if you really want to get something you have a good opportunity to get it.
cons: There's a lot of politic games because the company tend to compensate the individual achievement over the group or division. So everybody is worried and fighting about how to get his/her own successful personal project, no mater if you have to pass over a colleague.  Thats is for me the worst part of work for intel.

review_title: Elephant got the dance floor back - when will it dance now?
pros: brand, comp & benefits, nature of work, facilitation of career growth/changes, recognition & feedbacks, work/life balance, senior leadership
cons: failed in new businesses causing share price to stay at similar level for long time. Need to find an alternative to CPU biz. Transforming from memory to CPU was executed flawlessly with complete focus from entire company under the able leadership of Andy Grove. As it was a question of survival there was no question of lack of focus. The same is not true in the new business areas being tried for last few yesrs be it communication or consumer electronics...Intel is yet to achieve big success in these new areas...

review_title: Intel:  A very competitive place to work...
pros: Opportunities to show your stuff.  But you better have and A game there, it's very competitive.  If you crave competition, you'll do well.  Compensation used to be great when the stock was booming, now it's not.  There are shares handed out and that helps, but if they don't go anywhere, it's not much help.
cons: It's hard.  You have to always perform your best.  If you don't, you will feel it.  The best shuffle up to the top and the others fade away.  Every once in a while they will clean house but that's when it gets bloated and often is too late.

review_title: Intel: Stable but dull
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Intel has an excellent focus on their core business, building processors. Their bonus program pays twice a year consistently. The is a high degree of job stability. The change from stock options to restricted stock units was a move in the right direction considering that Intel is no longer a growth company.
cons:
If you are not a staff engineer or high, the compensation is better else where. The is also an extreme political bias towards individuals with advance degrees.  

There is a corporate culture that you should feel honored simply by being employed by Intel. This leads dissatisfaction simply due to the ease by which a better paying position at an employer that actually recognizes ones contribution can be found.

review_title: "Great Place to Work" is a company value
pros: Intel is a good previous employer to list on your resume.  There are definitely benefits to working for such a large corporation and there are many people who have worked at Intel for 15+ years... a relative rarity in the industry.
cons: There are definitely drawbacks to working for such a large corporation.  The average length of time an employee stays in their job position is a little over 1.5 years.  Be prepared to move around within the company.

review_title: Not good at all - predatory environment very resistant to change
pros: Hiring quotas in effect for women and minorities now so women can now get hired easier
cons:
It's like high school - groups are in cliques - the "Indian" clique, the "Asian" clique, the "American" clique - the Women at Intel "clique" - they even eat at different lunch tables like high school and there
are even unwritten social interaction rules that no one will ever admit to. Predatory managers out to make their quarterly targets no matter what admit they have no "interpersonal skills" no time for that softskill stuff - it shows in the culture - rude, mean, uncivilized - not progressive at all.

review_title: Manufacturing Technician
job_title: Manufacturing Engineering Technician in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Compressed work week, 12 hour days is a plus to increase your wages by 13% over the base salary, Benefits and quarterly bonuses. Great place to work outside the factory, free beverages and fruit.
cons: Is you are a tool engineer in the factory it is a 24X7 hour job. If you are a maintenance technician you will spend all your time in the factory doing PM's since they dont staff enogh per shift only the manufacturing techs who run the product.

review_title: Good Company, Difficult Times
pros:

- Organized and structured work

- Great people

Even though, Intel provides a very stable work place, the company was going to a difficult time, letting a lot of people go, cutting jobs, closing down sites, etc.

Cons:

- Upper management usually drives the project
- No ownership of your work

review_title: Higher pay to endure politics and sarcasms
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Kuala Lumpur

- One of the best C&B in Penang and Kulim.

review_title: Doesn't feel like top tier company

1. Work life balance
2. Brand reputation
cons:

3. Very few useful benefits

review_title: Meetings and emails are main themes of the business hours.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Well known company.  State of Art technologies.  Great in-house trainings for employees.
cons:
Too many meetings, too many emails, meetings during evening hours and weekends.

The dispersed workforce across different continents squeezes meetings to family hours and makes work/life balance a challenge.  

The annual performance review system causes headaches for both management and individual contributors.

review_title: Good place to start a career, but options are limited after a few years
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Intel is a big, stable company.  The likelihood of getting fired/laid off is limited (not impossible).  The benefits are pretty good (work/life balance, casual dress, discounts, etc) and pay is mostly competitive.
cons: Intel is big and bureaucratic, and decisions always seem last minute.  This can be pretty frustrating when you are trying to get something done.  With the recent headcount reductions career growth has slowed severely.  So it's a good place for a few years, but then you pretty much have to move on to another company to get ahead.  This is only going to get worse over the coming years.

review_title: Find a good fist line manager and you will enjoy Intel...
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Cutting Edge technology, market leadership, strong financial position.  At Intel, It is extremely critical to have a good first line manager.  They have a great deal of authority and autonomy ... this works very well if you have a good relationship with your manager.  Managers handle vacation approvals, promotions, career paths, visibility, raises, and overall job satisfaction... if you don't like your manager, or if they aren't backing you up ... you need to move into another group.
cons: large organizations always have excess baggage.  Intel is a process company first, and a processor company second.  If you aren't in process, or processors, then it can be very difficult to feel valued. (That's normal, companies value the revenue makers.)

review_title: Intel is a great company to work for if you are on the right team.
pros:
I have been at Intel for over 13 years. I started out as a technician in the Fab and now work as an engineer in an IT Factory organization. I can say that I have had some great times and some miserable times at Intel over the many years. You may read some bad employee reviews about Intel here or at some Intel "hate" sites. Also, you may read some great reviews. I can truthfully say that they are all true, good or bad. 

Intel is a huge company that spans the entire globe and is divided into hundreds and hundreds of departments that are further broken down into smaller teams or groups. Each of these teams or groups are manged by individual managers often referred to as GL's (Group Leaders) who have their own management style. There are also other layers of management for technicians etc., but too complex to explain here. The point I'm getting to here with this explanation is that the "Intel" experience for each individual employee depends heavily on their manager. Each manager fosters/creates the culture that exists within each team or group. I've had some managers that did not have a clue how to treat people with respect or appreciate the hard work or contributions that individuals or teams would make. There were some managers that did not even have a degree or even experience managing people. In my opinion they belonged working scrapping gum off the pavement under some bridge and they probably could not even do that right.

On the other hand I have had some great managers that even turned into personal friends. I have had managers that were visionaries and great leaders that recognized and truly appreciated the work their team performed. Other managers I've had were OK and did a good job and let you do your work without bothering you or trying to "micro-manage" your tasks. Some managers I've had were clueless and you could probably not even come to work for a few days or tag on an extra week vacation and they would not even know you were gone. Some managers I've had would "work from home" also known as WFM. You would go by their cubes and there would be notes on their white boards from a week ago that they did not even erase yet as they obviously were not in to work as they were suppose to be.  

As you can see there is a very wide span in management skills, integrity and capability. I did not even start with other employees yet. There are some that are nothing but brown nosers looking to get on the good side of management in preparation for the infamous Intel R n R process also known as Ranking and Rating. Some employees are great and a pleasure to work with. Overall, most (90%) employees are easy going but beware some are out to back stab you every chance they get. 

The key to surviving at Intel as I have for all these years and hopefully for more years to come is to know the system and use this to your favor. Any system can be defeated if you know how it really works. Intel is highly political and also highly technical this is the key. You have to be a politician and also technically sharp. This applies regardless of your job function; technician, engineer, manager, developer, marketing, etc. Always get to know your manager and fellow coworkers and adapt to each job role you are in. Don't compromise your own values or integrity but just  be wise and sharp at all times. When you find a manager and team that you feel are most like you personally, ride the wave! You can be very successful and be promoted very quickly. Managers often move around so beware of this also. 

Overall I give Intel 3.75 stars out of 5 as I feel Intel does not always pay fairly or treat people fairly and does not respect your time off from work. 

Intel has some good benefits, including:

1. Five + different health insurance options

2. An on site Health and Wellness Center with free yearly exams- they even give you $50 for completing their wellness exam

3. Free unlimited drinks 24 hours a day including, tea, coffee, and soda, decent cafeteria with most meals costing about $5.

4. Free fruit, apples, oranges, bananas, etc. But only one a day though...

5. A vast discount program for many different local and national companies, including Dell, HP, Sony, etc.

6. 401K contributions of about 8% of your gross pay. Not bad, you don't even need to contribute to get the money.

7. An eight week paid sabbatical every seven years.

8. About three weeks vacation a year plus holidays, more or less depending on years of service.

9. Unlimited sick days for salary workers. Beware though as some managers will not like if you call in too much. You may also find yourself having to make up for the time off if you have project deadlnes...
cons:
Every employee at Intel dreads the R n R process that must be done on a semi annual or annual basis (depending on the group and country, etc) for every single employee. The R n R process is suppose to reward the employee who has done more than just come to work and performed their job. I know this sounds crazy. You think- I come to work, work hard, show results, am productive and perform my best and I should get a raise. Well, Intel doesn't think so. This is the number one thing that I think should change and that also causes much distress and dissatisfaction among Intel employees especially engineers. The purpose behind the method used by Intel is to weed out the weak and poor performers who do not innovate or provide continuous improvement. So, what this means is that 40 hours a week at Intel is often not enough to please management. 

As I stated above the pay at Intel is not always fair. Intel will often pay new workers off the street more than someone who has been working at Intel for years. I have often found myself training someone who had less experience than me yet they were making 10% more than I was...

1. The ranking and rating process is a joke. Yet managers will swear on their grandmothers grave that it is fair. I have managers who are friends of mine tell me how it really works so I know the system very well. It is very subjective and relies heavily on human judgment and perception which is inherently flawed. As I said before get to know your manager and his or hers likes and dislikes and tread lightly.....

2. Base pay can be better now that Intel stock is worthless and profits are down which impacts bonuses.

review_title: Nuetral
pros: Job is stable, you really have to mess up to get fired or layed off.
cons: Don't plan on getting good raises here in manufacturing.  I worked in both the engineering group and the manufacturing group and manufacturing is by far the worst for raises.

review_title: amazing place to grow!
pros:
Your career there is what you make of it and management will work with you to ensure your career develops how you want it to.

Intel emphasizes work-life balance and provides great benefits, generous vacation time, team-building activities!
Management makes it a point to know about the open-door policy, where you are welcome to ask questions to Senior level management, no need to go through your direct manager if there is every an issue of concern.
cons:
Some co-workers outside of my group have expressed that they were required to work overtime and did not receive the expected recognition for their work.

A lot of this depends on the team you are working for, if they are short on head count and personality of the manager.

review_title: Lumbering giant fighting bureaucratic mud
pros:
Intel provides good pay with decent health benefits. Along with nice insurance plans there are decent gyms with many classes each week. 
Intel's sabbatical program is a welcome respite from a few years hard driving.
Most development groups allow for very flexible hours.
Travel opportunities are good - especially at the shuttle sites. International travel for a lot of roles exists too.
cons:
There is a particular rigid bureaucracy with many groups battling to maintain their fiefdoms. This leads to lots of mundane tasks needed to get things done.
Few people have big vision, and few opportunities to influence it

review_title: One of the best places I've ever worked!
job_title: Legal Counsel in Santa Clara, CA
pros: One of Intel's core values is being a great place to work, and it shows!  The people are friendly, the work is interesting, and the company as a whole really respects work-life balance.  Job rotations are pretty common, so you can get exposure to a wide range of work.  And Steve Rodgers (the GC) is very focused on career development of everyone in the legal group.
cons: Location isn't ideal.  Sometimes the engineering-driven culture (especially all the acronyms) can be annoying.  The company is big, so expect some bureaucratic hassles.  Also, people tend to stick around, so it can be hard to move up in the organization.

review_title: Dog-Eat-Dog
pros: Benefits, opportunity to work on technology.
cons:
Salary: slow vertical climb.
Performance management deliberately used to foster high-performance dog-eat-dog competitive survival environment and ethic.
Management follows an unspoken template to foster paranoia and competition, and eventual distrust between peers.
Workers are used at the expense of health and life, and then disposed when their usefulness has run its course.
Workers are constantly subtly faced with the threat of job loss.
The ability to politically maneuver the navigation of one's career is key.
Meritocracy is secondary to conniving astuteness.
Clear delineation between management and workers.
The promotion of work-life balance is a facade.
The employment of integrity boils down to money. Integrity has no place in the human context.
Any plan to work for Intel only for one's whole life span will eventually limit their career and notion of ethics.
Working for Intel is worth the experience to understand life.

review_title: Intel Review
pros:
Good benefits
Good work life balance depending upon team/manager and job function
cons:
Many - no career growth for women, minority representation at higher levels.
Faulty focal performance review process
Risk taking is not honored positively and constructively

review_title: A great place to Work
pros: This is a great place to work for any one. You get lot of benefits as a Blue Badge employee. for eg... In Bangalore - You get Bus Passes which can be used in any BMTC bus, You have multiple things available in Cafe for free, You have multiple outdoor courts to play Basket Ball, Volley ball etc...
cons: I had worked in Intel for Some 10+ Years and under many managers. Most of them were pretty good. But some times you get managers which are not cutout for the job or not capable enough. I think it is with all the companies.

review_title: Perfect employer
job_title: Engineer in Ho Chi Minh City
pros:
safety first, which is a priceless trait for a manufacturing company 
data-driven, which is good for people with math and stat mindset
continuous improvement in all aspect of the business, good for people both engineering and management oriented
transparent management and career path for everyone
hands on with engineering marvels on a daily basis. I really missed those days. 
professional and ethical managers, leaders
cons:
For ATM sector, the systems are engineered to be nearly perfect, therefore there is not a lot of room for improvement or engineering fun
can be easy to feel bored or looked down upon
salary in some countries are low, however it is still on par with local market price

review_title: Great Pay and Benefits
pros: The pay and benefits are good
cons: Some people are stuck in the same mentallity that screwed the company over in the past. There is also often not one unified goal. A good amount of employees have PhDs, but there is a resistance to experimentation and change so the PhDs are going to waste since experimentation is the whole point of a PhD. Lots of politics and buzz words

review_title: Intel is a great place to work
pros: It is a company whereby integrity is given  the highest priority. Employees are performance rated based on results and there is a strong work life effectiveness. Intel values its people and cares about their development by providing opportunities wherther on site or in different countries.
cons: The culture is very distinctly American  and there is a set process of doing things. It is open, direct and believes strongly in constructive confrontation...Bec of this, it is slightly harder for some people from Asian cultures to fit. Also, decision mking is very US centric.

review_title: Big and Stable
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Top name in the industry with broad opportunities.  If you want solid work experience in the hardware industry, Intel is probably one of the best places to work.  If you are very ambitious and would like to see growth quickly, Intel may not be the place for you.  Just the facts.
cons: Too big a company which makes it hard to grow (as a company and as individual) .  Lots of politics that may hamper efficiency.  Unequal pay that favors new hires.  Intel's salary is not the best in the industry.  So, do not over expect (that way you may be pleasantly surprised).

review_title: Still an interesting place to work
pros: Smart people and a challenging work environment.  Also, the work life balance is pretty good.  however you will need to plan on bringing your "A" game to compete with teh accomplishments of others.  Accomplishments are genrally well recognized and publicly communicated.  There are multiple big problems to work on and fix.  In general, as you move up the organization you can directly influence the outcome of massive decisions.  Also, there are plenty of opportunities to make a name for yourself with good work.
cons: Intel has not been a strong growth company for soem time, but compensation structure is still that of a growth company.

review_title: Stay away from Intel
pros: I cant think of one reason to want to work for Intel. It used to be a great place to work. The company has changed so much from being worried about its employees to more of how they can make a buck. Moral has never been lower.
cons: Its a large company and you get lost in the cracks. They make billions in profit every quarter and have cut more programs for the employees than I can count. There pay is not competitive to others in the same industry. The pay is not even competitve between employees. I have the same qualifications and do the exact same job as some of my peers and I am paid 7$ a hour less than my nearest peer. And it has nothing to do with my work ethic. I have never recieved anything less than a exceeds expectations on a performance review.

review_title: I've been at Intel for a very short time so this review is not really complete.  Will add to it in the future
pros: pay and benefits are good.  the facility has some decent amenities for the employees -  fitness center, reasonably priced cafeteria, etc.  Employee safety is a primary concern.  However, even though work-life balance gets a lot of lip service, you are expected to meet the goals no matter what the consequences to your life outside Intel.
cons: Even at this early date in my Intel career, I can see the layers of bureaucracy keeping people from being all they could be

review_title: Great place to work
pros: Intel compensates their employees fairly.  There is a good variety of interesting and challenging work so I can see myself staying at Intel for some time.  Intel has been very good to me in terms of work-life-balance and starting a family.
cons: As with most large companies you aren't always able to see how your work effects the company.  Your manager is the person who will fight for you to get a promotion.  If you have a great relationship with your manager and do an okay job you're more likely to get the promotion vs. a person who has a bad relationship with their manager, but does a great job.

review_title: Contractors Paid Well
job_title: Contract Senior Technical Writer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Reputation, quality of employees, and cutting-edge, consumer and business hardware (products)
cons:
As a contractor, I was treated well; however, my position was sent overseas - I heard about full-time technical writers who lost their jobs to contractors (like me), so perhaps it was somewhat fitting I lost my job to an overseas employee.

Dealing with employees in China and India seemed to impede process and progress; language barriers and general lack of product knowledge (on the overseas employees' parts) is not being examined enough - efficiency is taking a backseat to profit. Out of a team of engineers, only a few were good due to their ESL difficulties.

review_title: Truly a great place to work!
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Intel is a world leader for a reason.  They have a strong company culture that emphasizes individual  responsibility.  There is plenty of room for growth for those that seek it--but don't expect it to be handed to you on a platter.  Work hard and work smart and you will grow and prosper.
Note: I only worked on the Engineering and Development side--I really can't say anything about manufacturing and production.  That is a world apart.
cons: Since it is a big company it can be easy for mediocre talent to burrow into a niche and survive for years.  But eventually a re-org will come along and root you out!

review_title: Intel is a good company to work for.
pros: The company has great benefits and keeps you busy with new things to learn. The company is a 24 -7 operation so the shifts are 12 hours. The nice thing about this is you will get a lot of days off during the week.They do make a good effort at the great place to work for all employees. Good bonuses and stock participation plans.
cons: Always layoffs to think about due to the economy. May have to work nights, weekends, holidays. It used to be a place where you could grow but now it's all about the numbers.

review_title: when good is never enough
pros: Decent salary & benefits, flexible work conditions depending on your boss (although WFH options have been restricted), and learning opportunities (if you can make/find the time).
cons: Focal (annual performance review) - where employees are ranked & rated with the bottom 5-10% told they need to improve or be shown the door.  It's the craziest thing I've ever seen.  TWWW office environment (short-walled cubes - think fishbowl) has elevated the noise & distraction level.

review_title: Software Engineer Review (Grade 5-6)
job_title: Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
1- Job security is very high. Firing is very low although in 2014 they have done some layoff through an attractive voluntary separation plan. 
2- Laid back culture. High degree of freedom in terms of project goals, implementation methodology, working hours (almost nobody ever questions attendance in meetings/work)
3- Excellent cash bonus and stocks for senior employees (Grade 7 above)
cons:
1- Base pay is less compared to other employers. Not a top payer.
2- Upper management is slow in decision making, lots of reorganization happens and lots of duplicate efforts for a single area.
3- Slow rate of promotions, career growth.

review_title: At cutting edge of technology but work, work, and more work
pros: Cutting edge technology, quite good salary, flexibility at work, like the concept of "own your employability", management sensitive to problems of women with families and allows a lot of flexibility. Overall the workplace environment is very good. Friendly and approachable management. For some one who wants to learn, there are no limits. Job rotation is quite common and encouraged.
cons: Too much work, shrinking deadlines, difficulty in work-life balance, too many reorgs, middle level management is not technical in many cases,doesnt sometimes understand the problems and incompetancy at the middle level.

review_title: Software Engineering Manager
pros:
Work with great people on interesting projects 
Good benefits
Projects with real impact on worldwide scale
Work life balanced encouraged (although sometimes hard to achieve)
cons:
Work life balanced can be challenging with teams across the globe and work that can include late night or early morning meetings.
Very specific corporate culture that may not be a good fit for all, things are done "The Intel Way"
it's often surprising how resource constrained projects can be despite the company be very profitable. 
It's not a software company at heart so being a software engineer at Intel can sometimes be frustrating due to lack of software relegated practices and management tools

review_title: Uncompetitive Salary
job_title: Graphics Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good work life balance. Open culture. Stable job.
cons: Uncompetitive salary. I was an engineering manager and I had no control over the salary of my staff. It was all decided by the organization. Promotion is too infrequent. Only 8% of the organization is allocated for promotion every year. That is once in 12 years on average. The new hires get closer to market salary but the existing employees only get nominal increment and cannot even catch up to the inflation rate, let alone catch up to the market salary. Many talented engineers had same complaints and left.

review_title: You learn a lot but the environment is very negative.
pros:
Once you work at Intel you can work anywhere. 
Great to see the process transfer of technologies.
cons:
You do 100 things right , one wrong and the wrong one seems to count more.
Zero respect of personal life, expect to work Saturday and Sunday and into the night on a regular basis all for the glory. 
It's a huge behmoth of a company and everyone is a number, very difficult to get ahead.  
Management has little technical knowledge and seem their only role is to slavedrive reportees.
Very difficult for experienced people to succeed who enter the company .  
Once you total the hours worked, the good salary is probably below average of anywhere else.

review_title: laid off for one bad revew
pros:
Good place to start your career.  You will work with brilliant people on challenging work.  You will learn a lot, quickly.

Some groups show good work/life balance.  Depends on the group and its manager.

Good pay and benefits.  Intel will actually pay out on those bonuses.
cons:
Expect annual layoffs to continue.  One bad review and you're out.  Past performance history doesn't matter.

Business will be challenging for foreseeable future.  Expect hiring freezes, layoffs, etc. to continue.  That will probably impact raises going forward.

CEO and senior management ignored industry trends for years.  Intel strongly committed to x86 even where it doesn't make sense.  Expect bad product decisions to continue.

Overall I can't recommend Intel.  Bad culture, bad management, and bad business forecast.

review_title: Trying to evolve beyond incredible legacy
pros: Good people for the most part.  Very smart technical and world class research. Big idea / big vision place that will recognize thinkers.  Very progressive supporting under represented classes.  Fairly transparent executive team - better than most companies as big as Intel.
cons: Failure to translate vision into action.  Very impatient with new business opportunities due in part to unrealistic expectations.  Executive management is pandered to by senior management: the latter has a hard time delivering bad news and/or setting realistic expectations.  Needs to undergo further downsizing to clear out mid/senior exec level.

review_title: IT Enterprise Architect
pros: Competitive benefits and compensation. Great people to work with and people are passionate about the work.There is a persistent push to get the best out of employees and at the same time, work life balance is real good. Wiork life balance may vary across various business units. Definitely a world class company with lots of potential to move around if you are good at networking.
cons: Bit too heavy on the process and good ideas require lot of influencing to be heard.  Lot of emphasis on soft skills and may not be good if you are technically oriented.  Real talent and expertise not fully utilized and get caught up in planning, process and people management inefficiencies.

review_title: Boot Camp
pros: The training was first class. Some of the skills I learnt - presentation skills, meeting organisation - I'm still using today. Likewise for some of their processes - e.g., effort estimation.
cons: It really felt like a constant bootcamp. Eyes on you at all times. An expectation that you'd always work late...and reply to emails in the evenings and weekends. And the reviews​ picked on anything "wrong" you did...that was used as a stick to hold over your head. Overall..pressurised, unrewarding, stressful.

review_title: Great engineering company with great engineers
pros: Intel attracts great people, and works on great problems. The combination creates an ideal place for an ambitious product-oriented engineer to work. I enjoyed working across four decades with Intel and would not trade it for anything. Intel's world-wide reach, employees and resources are hard to beat. Intel works you hard, but the rewards are numerous.
cons: Intel's never gotten high marks to be easy to work at "near the top" - the company is relentless at being paranoid and focused on adapting to the marketplace to survive. The alternative for such a large company is probably failure. Working at or above Director level (above Directors are VPs, Fellows and the CEO) is brutal. Below Director is no cake walk - but is generally more focused on delivering products.

review_title: If you're young and you need to pay student loans, start at Intel
job_title: Web Project Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Intel has an exceptional benefits package.
cons: The review structure is beyond ridiculous. It forces team members to compete against each other and sponsors an environment of favoritism. Intel wants you to devote every second of your life to them, yet at the same time wants you to change jobs every two years to prove your adaptive and eager to learn. All that hopping around creates a near constant state of confusion and chaos.

review_title: R&D Engineer
job_title: R&D Test Engineer in Aloha, OR
pros: Great folks I worked with. Peers and 1st level management. Iranian mafia not included. They only looked out for their own.
cons:
Company does not care about their employees. They say one thing and actions are opposite. VP says "yes" to look good in a large group, then tells the person who can make the decision to say "No".  Abuse of power. 

If you are over 35, you are a target. 

Intel is going down. No loyalty or trust from their most loyal employees anymore. 

So depressing and discouraging to have given 20 years to the company and thrown out like garbage. Ranked as a 2 or 3 every focal. Was a productive employee, and to find out the bleeding blue is for nothing.... heart breaking.

review_title: Great benefits, but work/life balance is nonexistant
pros: Good experience in the tech industry, Great benefits.  There are great career opportunities to be had, the new adoption assistance is great.  Very safe place to work.  Great sabbatical program that provides for 8 weeks of paid time off (in addition to vacation) once every 7 years.  Really gives employees a chance to refresh and refocus on who they are, not who they have become.
cons: Comparative low base pay, very poor rank and rating system.  Too much focus on both diversity, safety communication is pretty much preachy.  Employees that should have been fired for poor performance end up sliding by for at least 2 years due to the Ranking and Rating system

review_title: A powerfully motivating experience, if you can take the stress.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel provides excellent opportunities for learning at the cutting edge of technology.  Most of the time you will experience a good balance between competition and teamwork with other employees.  Though management sets high standards for achievement, "Intel culture" helps you find your way through the competitive environment with workshops and useful negotiating skills.
cons: Working at Intel can be stressful at times, and some groups are brutally competitive.

review_title: It really is a great place to work.
pros: The benefits are excellent and complete. Management has an open door policy, which works really well most of the time. The newest performance review process focuses on your individual accomplishments throught the year vs. your job requirements & goals.  There are quarterly (corporate) bonuses as well as quarterly organizational bonuses. The company employee stock purchase program gives at least a 15% boost every quarter.  The employee discount programs provide savings on most major branded items and at major outlet stores.  The health & wellness program is also very comprehensive. (with a local workout room at most locations.)
cons: management changes - layoffs - review process.

review_title: Good place to work if you are relatively competent and accept that career growth will be slow and difficult
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The pay is good and if you are reasonably competent in your area of work and in a group with a good revenue stream, you can pretty much retire in the company if you choose. Work life balance is also satisfactory.
cons: Growth opportunities are very hard to come by. Intel is a shrinking company in the US and therefore it is hard to expect vertical career growth unless you are lucky to be in a the right place at the right time.

review_title: Keep moving that stock price up, efforts to improve morale working
job_title: Technical Marketing Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Hi Tech stuff, fast pace, never boring, never on the same assignment too long.  Once you get hired, you will just be whisked along on the hi tech roller coaster.  Sr management communication to employees is good - you feel like they level with you.  They are starting to become more concerned about employee morale - free drinks/coffee at all Intel campuses amongst other things.
cons: Very competitive, high expectations, declining US headcount.  Try to stay away from TMG - product divisions are generally better and more satisfying to work for. Only get to telecommute one day per week.  No pension.

review_title: Laid back place to work with good people
pros: Laid back atmosphere and work flexibilty as far as time off and work from home.  There is strong brand recognition and lots of opportunity to work in different roles if so desired, in different geographical locations.
cons: Low relative compensation and somewhat silo-ed businesses.  There are situations where one business does not know what is going on in the other businesses.  Although Intel is an enormous multinational corporation, more efforts should be made to make businesses aware of each other's business processes and models.  In the current environment there is a lot of confusion when different analysts from different businesses have to sit down at the same table to define a single uniform process to be adopted.

review_title: Intel
pros:
-Flexible work schedule.
-Good benefits.
-Good career development tips.
-Experience of problems working for a large organization, where people have a hard time convincing others. Can get a few leadership lessons with this experience.
cons:
-Most groups are disconnected from what others do.
-There is some amount of duplication of effort among groups , not very efficient.
-There is a lot of politics at the higher levels of management, if you don't work for a team on the
stronger side, chances are your team won't get the recognition it deserves.

review_title: Good Experience
pros: I've been there for over 7 years (right out of college). Great people and benefits.  Compensation is good.  Lot's of work/life flexibility - i work from home 1 day a week and am able to take extended lunches or leave early so long as the work get's done; that being said, when it gets busy it GETS BUSY and you can expect to work very long hours.
cons:
Outsourcing/offshoring US jobs - moving jobs to Costa Rica, creating low moral for those who "survived" this round and/or who's jobs are currently being evaluated for offshoring.
As others have said, tons of red tape.

review_title: Great company to work for, Amazingly talented people
job_title: Engineering Leader in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Very open / candid culture 
- Very talented people (world class experts on the topic at hand)
- Management open to moving people around, so you get diverse sets of experiences
cons:
- Currently (mid 2014) uncertain future. This poses a challenge on many levels throughout the corporation
- "Pie" is not growing, so politics is
- Like any large company, it all depends on your manager. So be sure to pay a lot of attention to who you are reporting to. Within the company, your experience will vary a lot

review_title: Incredibly ethical but trapped in the past
pros:
Exceptionally intelligent co-workers
Incredibly ethical business practices
Excellent benefits
One of the few companies who offers a sabbatical
In a position to change the world
cons: For an extended period of time, the senior management has been lacking in vision.  With the change to Brian Krzanich, this is changing slowly.  He is attempting to implement systems that scan the market.  Unfortunately, there is a very entrenched belief that silicon is enough.

review_title: Incredibly ethical but trapped in the past
pros:
Exceptionally intelligent co-workers
Incredibly ethical business practices
Excellent benefits
One of the few companies who offers a sabbatical
In a position to change the world
cons: For an extended period of time, the senior management has been lacking in vision.  With the change to Brian Krzanich, this is changing slowly.  He is attempting to implement systems that scan the market.  Unfortunately, there is a very entrenched belief that silicon is enough.

review_title: Validation Engineer
pros: good history, wide variety of products and positions.  able to move around within the company
cons: Intel is aiming towards mediocrity.  As a company, values ethnocentric tunnel vision rather than taking advantage of the global talent pool it has at its disposal.  Its middle and senior managers are disconnected from the technologies their teams are developing, and in fact really more like program/people managers.   very few place much emphasis other than basic lip-service to technical excellence.  resources are scarce, priorities are unclear or change on a daily basis.  its a mess...

review_title: Financial Analyst
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Chandler, AZ
pros: Great environment to work in with great people at the analyst level. Free drip coffee and fruit. Great benefits and the cafe food is great. The next group of finance professionals are some of the best talent in the industry.
cons: A finance controller should never say they've never done financial analysis before and if they do how did they get there? This can be frustrating when your boss doesn't know the bare minimum and can slow down the decision making process due to financial daily debates with someone who doesn't know basic finance principles.

review_title: Great company, world-leading technology, competitive pay
job_title: Senior Software Architect in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Good pay.  Not top of the industry, but competitive
Lots of interesting research and new technology and projects
Great co-workers
A very organized and predictable review process for raises and promotions
Unlimited promotion opportunities.  Grow as high as your competence level and willingness to sacrifice your time and soul for the company.
cons:
Depressing gray cubes, often just large enough for your chair and computer, and often with short walls.  Your surrounded by noise and your co-workers will enjoy your conversation with your family.
Don't allow remote workers at this time (I was laid off because I worked remotely)

review_title: Engineering Technician
pros: Work with latest technology, work in safe environment, work with smart people
cons: Best to have as high as a degree as possible before working here, not easy to be promoted after joining, lack of opportunities for advancement unless you're an engineer, work with people who have egos and many who don't have good social skills, work with a lot of foreigners who can't speak clear English, too much emphasis on diversity, managers don't have time to be managers most of the time, too many meetings, atmosphere of fear from layoffs, bad manager can ruin your career

review_title: so much overhead
pros: good benefits- good terms for pension and such, little perks, bonuses.
cons:
the employee rating program is so stupid. getting a raise is always a factor of how many good workers work around you but also in differrent areas of the department. so even if you do your job 200% you might not get a raise.

Intel expects you to do a lot of crap which takes up much of your time. participate or lead different pointless forums, events and such. as a developer you are distracted 90% of your day and have to find the time to code.
Also, Intel moves very slow in terms of cutting edge technology. I kept feeling like it took so long to finish a project once it was ready it was irrelevant.

review_title: Don't waste your life its not a great place to work.
pros: Health benifets, bonuses, free fruit
cons:
Killing you slowly 
No progression for techs
Engineering think that above techs and won't listen to feedback. 
Engineers can find root causes so a lot of unnessary workload
Long shifts
Only way to move up is to hang your peers. Same with focal
Shiney exterior not the same when your in there.
Staff events are geared towards day workers. Shift workers always get the short straw even though they are the ones who keep the place running. 
Forget holidays if your in a low head count area.

review_title: Terrible company to work for ..
pros: Good (not great)  learning experience.
cons:
Too much politics, People work like donkey. 
they focus more on competition rather than co-operation. 
no work life balance.

I am surprised to see people can work day and night for others, I was Entrepreneur left it to live peaceful life for sometime & joined job but can't believe foolishness that people can work so hard for others.

review_title: 22 year employee / great job and benefits
pros: Very stable employment with a few exceptions over the years. Nice facility (Ronler Acres). Leading edge technology.
cons: Unless you are highly educated (PHD), it is very hard to earn a 6 figure income. While that may seem like alot to ask for, living in the area has gotten very expensive over the years. "Good" raises are 4% and average raises are 1-2%. They dont seem to be keeping up with inflation. Depending on your functional area, stress can be very high. Having the ability to deal with that stress is a must.

review_title: Intel does a great job at providing employees a good environment to work in but career growth is challenging.
job_title: Technical Marketing Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Intel actively pushes work life effectiveness and I can freely come and go in my group as long as my job gets done. Intel also pays competitively and they put money in your 401K for you based on profit. Intel is number one in most industries they are in and continue to push to stay that way.
cons: Because Intel stock is not performing a lot of people are forgoing retirement causing everyone to age and fewer younger people to be hired. It makes it harder to grow in the organization and move up.

review_title: Great place to work!
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great compensation!  Large enough that you can move around inside the company and get lots of experience in different areas.  Free drinks!  Movie nights!  My group has been very flexible about vacations.  Even though we only get 3 weeks of vacation, we can always take a little more if needed.  Sabatticals are great too.
cons: The stock doesn't seem to go up very much.  Focals can be challenging for those not in the top 10% because only the top performers get big raises.  The rest either get very average raises or none at all.  Seniority doesn't count for anything, it's all based on what you know and who you know.

review_title: Work long hours and get lots of experience
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good place to see a lot of different technology. You can get to know people with other specialties and learn new skills. New opportunities for success arise all the time, but you have to rise to the occasion and aggressively pursue the task at hand. Don't get distracted by all the little things that happen during the day. There are many great people at Intel and everybody has the same goals most of the time.
cons: Long hours and sometimes without recognition. Management is interested in results, but they can go off on a tangent and demand things that don't really help us achieve our goals at all.

review_title: "Sink or swim" mentality pervasive
pros:
Employees are often able to branch out and experience challenges outside their core role
Opportunities to work on special projects arise often
Most employees are encouraged to grow skills
cons:
Fast pace never lets up, new infrastructure rollouts are constant
Communication between manager(s) and their report(s) is limited, and often too little too late
Most employees, including managers, are not rewarded for effort, cooperation, or clarity
High level priorities change constantly so there is little chance of comprehension, resulting in chronic stress and guesswork
Review process is completely arbitrary, rewarding the flashiest sounding accomplishments and those best at "driving others"

review_title: Best experience of my life
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: amazing collection of talent and resources.  Lots of resources.  great environment.  employees are very spoiled and have a sense of entitlement, it feels amazing to be a part of the rich, winning team.  Pay is excellent, development is excellent.
cons: bureaucracy.  Finance penny pinches and controls management decisions.  Intel might spend 100k buying out someone that is being laid off, but in the same quarter will cut team building budgets from $20 a head to "try potlucks"  and similar things.  It breeds a frugal culture, but is often very silly.

review_title: Good colleagues, but too much politics between groups
pros: The work was often interesting, partly because the designs were technically challenging and the products were going to make a big impact in the market. The design tools were good, though not always the best. The rest of the design staff was of pretty high quality, as were the research groups. Pay was good for those with good reviews, very good for those doing well in senior engineering levels, but only so-so otherwise.
cons: Groups in different parts of the world (and different parts of the US) have to collaborate often, and it's hard to keep trust between people who don't know each other. Inter-group politics can be nasty. Sometimes the strategic decisions by top management were mystifying, but that's probably true in all large companies.

review_title: Great Career Company
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Chandler, AZ
pros: Seems to be fairly stable and consistent. For someone with a family and a mortgage you can be confident you aren't going to run into major surprises.
cons: Not the fastest paced company. I have heard (never experienced, full disclosure) of companies that let high fliers zoom through the ranks, which seems a little bit beyond our organizational structure. Anecdotaly, my previous mentor was considered a "rising star" but left the company because opportunities where not materializing fast enough.

review_title: job
cons: lenghty rounds                                                                          .......

review_title: Operations Manager
job_title: Operations Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great team of managers that work hard to support one another in improving their management styles and increasing productivity for the facility.
cons: It is a shift work position, very rigid schedule for a salary position that doesn't allow for flexibility during the day.  They say they hire the best, but then try to pay the best with less than average salaries.  Cubical city, if you don't like cubicles with loud neighbors then don't work here.

review_title: Sr Test Engineer
pros: Good benefits, good experiences, nice travel, some good perks and recent good diversity
cons: Silos is a big deal in the company, no connection to business costumers or needs and left alone technology groups doing nothing to improve. R@D is none and low individual career focus. Friend to friend kind of leadership and relationships are more important than knowledge and biz to innovation etc. Practices of manufacturing are the bread of everyday.

review_title: Don't expect too much!
pros: Had a great time overall, enjoyed the majority of my role and got on with a lot of people there. It is what you make of it. Bonuses are good.  Work/life balance is also good.
