cons: Slight gender discrimination, the males tend to get more opportunities to progress career-wise. Long term career hard to have for ambitious individuals unless you are happy to relocate to America. Information not given transparently. Managers tend to prefer those who are 'compliant'. Things take a long time to change - too long to keep up with the changing market.

review_title: Inflection Point
job_title: Systems Validation Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: It's a large diversified company with a great technology portfolio, many opportunities for development, and a great variety of working environments.
cons: It's never been a warm caring touchy-feely place to work, and the corporate culture is taking a turn for the downright toxic.  This company will happily burn you out and discard you, if you let it.

review_title: Good at making things, poor at managing people
pros: Intel has excellent salary and benefits and when you find someone who has figured out how to work within the system, that person can be a powerful ally.
cons: Physical work environment (offices) tend to be noisy, dirty, and distracting.  Best assignments, rewards, and perks go to management's friends and favorites.  Management is not taken seriously as a discipline.  Work-life balance is virtually non-existent in spite of years of effort and a proliferation of programs.

review_title: Perspective from long time former employee
pros: Highly professional company with an extremely talented community of employees.  It is a demanding environment where you will have the opportunity to contribute fully, and learn and grow in the process.  I learned many skills that now I have left, I realize were ground breaking that I took for granted at the company.
cons: It is a very big company and it operates in a virtual world where email and phone conferences are the norm.  Teams are rarely wholly located in the same office.  Management skill varies, some managers are excellent others don't understand what management is and act like chief individual performers.

review_title: Good company but No further growth as an Engineer
pros: Good company, great history, employee friendly, You get stocks, free travel
cons: No vision recently, New CEO cutting down lot of benefits, first 3-4 years of Stay is good but further Growth is a challenge. You don't have higher technical roles available in India or Asia regions and it's tough to justify. Where as company can't give your a scope, they expect to keep showing a difference every year. Intel is no more what it was like 7-8 years back with less hike and more moving to a service based organization structure

review_title: Glad to have left
pros:
+ Good salary and bonuses
+ Smart co-workers (generally)
+ Resources and headcount for projects deemed priorities
cons:
- Toxic culture and review system breeds infighting and mistrust at all levels
- Burdensome processes and politicized, centralized decision-making ensure that pet projects of favored pets receive funding while good ideas die on the vine
- A hostile, passive aggressive, highly political environment.  Trust no one.  Especially your manager
- No clear direction for Intel's future.  Years of virtual monopoly, too many Intel lifers and heavy reliance on "strategy" consultants have robbed the company of innovation, customer centricity and vision.  
- The knives are out for external hires.  Benefits of outside knowledge and experience outweighed by threat to rank in the FOCAL pecking order

review_title: IMO
pros:
Great flexibility and work life balance if you have the right manager. Many opportunities to work on various projects to keep your job interesting. Tons of groups and events to participate in. 
If you are lucky enough to work under the right manager and team, its an amazing experience to be part of Intel.
cons:
Some managers don't let you work from home as they do not trust employees. 
Too many org changes to keep up with. Never truly secure in your job, always have the fear hanging over your head that cuts are coming down the wire.

review_title: Great pay and benefits, but too much walking.
pros: Intel offers great pay and great benefits. Most people work a compressed work week which is much better than standard 9 to 5. Lots of room for career growth.
cons: Too much walking. The Intel RA campus is extremely large and you must walk for 5 to 15 miles each day.  Traffic is bad, especially if you live further east from campus.

review_title: Large corporation with excellent products trying to maintain relevance and avoid commoditization
pros: In good times, there are abundant opportunites  to take on different roles every few years. The ability to work from home and flex time are supported in many roles and groups. Bright and talented  coworkers. Interesting job opportunities and results orientation.
cons: Very demanding and competitive environment, often requiring very long hours. The performance review system is brutal which can create peer tension. Career opportunities are limiting from middle management on up. Not an overly friendly or personal atmosphere.  The physical environment is extremely cold...gray walls, gray carpet, gray cubicles.

review_title: OK but not the best the firm to work for
pros: It's considered as one of the largest firms in the world with well-known products. The company provides a series of benefits inside and outside work for the employees.
cons: It's very difficult to plan things ahead [unless when on vacation] for some positions within the company that require having on-call pager at all times. Quite disappointingly, some managers reward their employees not solely based on their performances. Career advancement for the employees is not always be the main focus for some managers. There has been effort recently to improve things in many ways to increase employee satisfaction rate but it will be quite long ways to go. The stock has been performing poorly in the past few years.

review_title: Intel's use of older employes rivels Wal-Mart's
pros: Great benefits. The pay is ok but does not keep up with cost of living. The try to keep employees working.
cons: They make promises which are not followed thru. They say your pay and promotions are based on performance but are not. Intel claims they want employes to speak up but when you do you get into trouble with management. They claim to have open door policy but when used you face retribution from management. Worst of all they use age discrimination when it comes to training, pay, and promotions. Go to HR and you are told keep mouth shut or HR will make sure you get no promotion. They use older people for cheaper labor. Intel seems to know how hard it is for older people to find employment and uses this to it's advantage.

review_title: Intel's use of older employes rivels Wal-Mart's
pros: Great benefits. The pay is ok but does not keep up with cost of living. The try to keep employees working.
cons: They make promises which are not followed thru. They say your pay and promotions are based on performance but are not. Intel claims they want employes to speak up but when you do you get into trouble with management. They claim to have open door policy but when used you face retribution from management. Worst of all they use age discrimination when it comes to training, pay, and promotions. Go to HR and you are told keep mouth shut or HR will make sure you get no promotion. They use older people for cheaper labor. Intel seems to know how hard it is for older people to find employment and uses this to it's advantage.

review_title: Case study in 'great' to 'good'" ... to 'mediocre'
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Best manufacturing systems in the world, incredible discipline, laser focus on quality
cons:
Product lineup is very narrow and architecture would fail without monopoly position.
Conformist culture, terrible cost management, very poor capacity planning.
Managers are bland and uninspiring -- the more robotic, the better your chances.

review_title: Contingent workers are second class citizens.
pros: Profit sharing, smart co-workers and environment, educational benefits. Project work can be quite interesting, exhilirating and challenging. Regular Intel employees get free fruit and soft drinks, exercise facilities, showers. Large cafeterias with wide varieties of food.
cons:
These comments take into account my experiences both as a regular employee and a contingent worker.

"Blue Badges" (regular Intel employees) are expected to work long hours and are often worked far beyond what anyone should work. As a former blue badge in the 1990s, I worked for almost 2 years without ever seeing my children except on Sundays - Intel expected me to be there. Laptops are routinely issued to Blue Badge employees so that they will put more hours in when they are away from the office. The ranking and rating system is designed so that it is possible for a manager to sink an employee's advancement opportunities without ever consulting the other managers and team members the employee works with. This happened to a handful of my co-workers and was quite demoralizing.

"Green Badges" (contractors) are second-class citizens, barred from any activity or benefit that could be considered a job perk (example: can't shower - so don't think of riding your bike to work). They are barred from reading much non-secret material on the company's internal website - for fear that they would feel too much like employees and sue for better benefits.

This place is more than frugal -- it's cheap. For example, the toilet paper here is like sandpaper. I've been waiting for my cube to be vacuumed for a month. No such service is happening. I can't find out from anyone how to get my floor cleaned.

review_title: Good engineering, really smart people, really harsh environment
job_title: Physical Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: You are truly working on the future of electrical engineering - everything you touch here is cutting edge.  People are extremely driven and diligent.  There is a drive to achieve and be the best in our field that only the very best companies have.
cons: It is a harsh environment - I don't want to say there is "backstabbing," but there is certainly a lot of pressure put on all employees.

review_title: Competitive, Stressful and very bad work/life balance, bad mental health
pros:
Good to be if you are part of the senior management team, have your way around that and know some of the key players personally. They give you small tokens like free fruits, free orange juice (on wed only) and free coffee to let you think that's it's a good place to work. 

If you want exposure to technology and tools, this is the place.
cons: Annual focal review enough to kill. Although you are performing above average but still lowest in ranking in your team, you will be rated below expectation and be under close supervision. Too competitive and unfair for good performing employees that lacks communications skills.

review_title: Good run, finding it hard to move around in job functions....
pros: Great Benefits, Challenging work, Aggressive, Open culture, Senior Management open to change and learning from mistakes, risk taking attitude, fast paced.
cons: Very aggressive co-workers, your performance is reviewed against co-workers, middle management is hit or miss (some are horrible and some are great), aggressive schedules, hard for engineers to move in other job functions without going back to school. Manangers try to hold onto people and are more worried about getting their tasks done than about careers of people reporting to them.

review_title: Wonderful, diverse group of professionals with whom I was honored to have worked.
pros: Industry leader in space with a rock solid balance sheet and a good corporate culture.  My direct managers were always thoughts, attentive, and interactive.
cons: A big company where it is easy to feel lost in the hub bub.  Not all managers were cast from the same die, and some rotten tomatoes did get into the mix from time to time.

review_title: Great People, Great Company
pros: You get to work on great technology. The projects are good and the jobs are exciting. Peer culture is usually friendly at engineer level. You get appreciated (mostly) for the good efforts, recognition culture is encouraged. GPTW (great place to work) activities are encouraged. You get more or less the compensation amount specified in the offer letter (though you will receive some of it in form of stocks), unlike some companies where CTC and in-hand salary may vary much.
cons: The growth may be slow compared to peer companies. Depending on group, the work pressure may be more. Decision making for project is usually slow.

review_title: Mixed Bag
pros: Ability to move around the company relatively easily. Competitive salary and benefits. Management is a mixed bag - I've worked for some of the best and some of the worst managers in my career here.
cons: "Work-life balance" sometimes feels like lip service. Intel's infamous culture of "constructive confrontation" is under scrutiny with efforts to make it a "kinder, gentler" company. Not sure that will help Intel succeed the way it has in the past. Employee review system is highly broken - it results in a lot of politics and back-stabbing.

review_title: Intel was a great place to work...not anymore!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Good benefits and somewhat flexible hours.
cons:
Everything is fire drill!  More work, less pay, no thank you! Management constantly looking for ways to terminate employees especially in the uncertainty of the NM site. Lack of promotions opportunities within NM site.
The real deal - Arrogant and headstrong double level managers  are extremely uneasy to deal with and very unpleasant most of the time.  Forcing employees to leave Intel or seek other job opportunities away from their organization.  Unfortunately, when you raise issues to HR of your management issues no actions will take place on your behalf.  Sadly, you will blacklisted for there on.  Intel HR protects Intel ONLY!  Be very careful if you decide to choose this employer.

review_title: Pretty on the outside
pros: The yearly and quarterly bonuses are a nice benefit. Many of the other worker bees are nice and easy to work with. The free fruit and sodas/coffee are a nice touch.
cons:
Too much tribal knowledge, acronyms, etc. Documentation storage (reference manuals, etc) is inconsistent, stored across different sites. Finding information about what you are working on is very difficult. Many people in the PC CPU groups are very condescending towards other groups. Way too many managers and not enough contributors. Teams are spread globally, so that means your work day can span from 5am to 10pm. Underfunded, understaffed, aggressive schedules that are micro managed by several managers not even in your chain of command.
The facility itself: Nice covered parking garage, but over crowded. Not enough bathrooms per the number of employees (not exaggerating, it's bad). The cafe is very disappointing.

review_title: Only the name.  It's really ugly behind the courtains.
pros: Good, passionate engineers. If you're on the right spot, there is a lot to learn.  If you're lucky to have a good mentor, and if interested, you're learn a lot. Pay is ok, but nothing special.
cons: The most political place I've ever saw. Career advancement is possible only if you're in the right "circle" and manager's parrot. Level of hypocrisy is unbearable. Military structure with absolute zero trust in the worker bees. Hard working is punished, if you're good at office politics, you'll be promoted.

review_title: Employees - Intel's greatest asset
pros: Intel was definitely a great place to work on leading edge technologies.  The knowledge gained there was definitely reflective of working in a world-class environment.
cons: The culture has changed.  People worked there because they wanted to be there and at the end of the day, the products were the best that could be delivered.  But my last few years there, it was less about what the market needed and less on quality. It was time for me to leave.

review_title: Not for Software Engineers
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Tel Aviv-Yafo
pros:
Good place if you are interested in low level Embedded/System software development.
Stability - although this was drastically reduced in the past few years.
Impact - working on products which reach millions.
Cross geo - get to work with teams around the globe.
Good work life balance.
cons:
The company sells H/W and all the priorities are derived from that - software is not a core business.
Bonuses are not really bonuses they are essentially integral part of the salary and a way to reduce social benefits payment.  
Total compensation (with bonuses) for Software Engineers is mediocre and not really competitive today.
Bureaucracy - tons of emails and meetings which waste your time, every significant change requires a long string of approvers.
No coherent vision/strategy for the company - frequent and pointless reorgs.

review_title: Good company.  No longer a great one.
pros: Strong culture, much of which is healthy (big focus on accountability, integrity).  Many excellent business management processes (but also some that paralyze decision making and slow progress to a halt).  Generally up-to-date technology and pleasant work environment.  Good benefits, pay, and bonus program.
cons: Culture tends to reward individual achievement over collaboration, which tends to lead to some unhealthy dynamics and ugly politics.  Abrasive, occasionally abusive, behavior sometimes condoned, mistaken for "constructive confrontation."  Can be tough place to join mid-career, as culture and processes very ingrained, and fresh ideas not perfectly adapted to Intel's long-time rigid processes will go nowhere.

review_title: Great place to start, but may or may not be for a long term career
job_title: Soc Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: For those who are fresh out of college, it's a good place to start. Lot of tools, flows & infrastructure, and lot of things to learn. Especially forgiving if you're a fresher, and lot of help available.
cons: Removal of performance ratings & stock levels, and removal of clear written records about who did what, thus 'averaging out' employees. And removal of 360 feedback, which leads to favorisms driving performance ratings. Not much incentive for those who are too dedicated or too technically good, or those who take all the risks to innovate something, but prefer to be discreet

review_title: Appreciate Intel while they are still here in the USA!!
job_title: Manufacuring Technician (Nikons) in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Pre determined work schedule that is consistent. Travel. Benefits--many choices/options to choose from and/or update as your health or home life changes. Your choice to take advantage of growth opportunity..i.e mentorships, classes (on or offsite) meetings with supervisors/management. Fitness centers. (2) Safety oriented atmosphere--never do I feel that my health/welfare is at risk, despite the presence of deadly and/or toxic chemicals.
cons: If one is honest and mature in the answering of this question they will realize that there is NOTHING to complain about. This is my 2nd career after 24 years in DoD R&D at White Sands Missile Range. Intel is paradise in comparison.

review_title: Good place for aged people or someone who like working under instructions
pros:
fair market salary 
wonderful SPP program
attentive to individual employee professional development
considerated for new college graduate
cons: slow raise and internal transfer for IT.  This is especially very true if you are located in one of those sites that are considered flat or no-growth.  People tends to work by book in IT and you don't have recognizion until you made some terrible mistakes.  Although they encourage risk taking, the front mangement will define the bottom line.  Too much process which make a simple change takes forever.

review_title: Great Place to Work is not just a slogan here!
pros: Working at Intel is what you make of it.  You have the opportunity to advance in your career and grow.  I have held 4 different positions at Intel ranging from entry level technician to Network Engineer in the last 12 years.  I have worked in AV, Lan support, VOIP, network Security, Wireless and other technologies.  It has been great!
cons: As I said before, Intel is what you make of it.  Some people work tons of hours and kill themselves.  This is not necessary at Intel, but you have to learn to push back and manage your workload.

review_title: Overall, good place to work.
job_title: Finance Specialist in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Senior leaders are very transparent mostly and willing to make changes to adapt to the marketplace.  Intel also really does try to listen to the employees as much as they can and try to do the right things both for the employees and the community and the world in general (Intel is world class in ethics and corporate citizenship)
cons: It is still a big company with the pros and cons, you need to work to stand out to make your accomplishments known.  Can be hard to move into people management roles.  The culture can be abrasive and rude in some groups (which may be a good or bad thing to you).

review_title: Don't take a D1DR process engineering position. Really - it isn't worth it.
pros: The base salary is competitive. That is about it. Maybe free fruit? But the pay really isn't worth the pain. It really sucks.
cons:
Slavery. 24/7 oncall and you will get called. Not enough technicians or engineers on any shift to get everything done. ZERO work life "effectiveness." You want a life/free time? TOO BAD. Regularly work 80-100HPW.

Intel claims to "pay marginal and bonus high" this isn't true. 

Also - new hires regularly make more than engineers with 3-4 years of experience. New hire salaries increase with cost of living. "Standard" raises for successful employees do not. 

Only reason to take/keep this job would be if you needed a green card.

review_title: Intern Experience
pros: I had initially been a little upset to work at Intel after hearing about other interns at other company's experiences. However, after a while, I learned that Intel's work life balance really is the key thing that separates it from other companies. It still has the old feeling vibe, since it has been around for a while, but my social life is very separated from my work life, which is very very nice, because that is not the case for many other tech companies in the area.
cons: No free lunch is a little sad, but it's okay. Not too many benefits, I injured myself and went to the nurse who was very unhelpful, and just gave me and ice pack and didn't even bother looking at my injury

review_title: Great place to work in manufacturing software development
pros: Work has world-wide impact. Flexible work environment for many. Strong focus on personnel diversity. Most roles are aligned in one way or another with manufacturing, so if you love manufacturing, it's a great place for you.
cons: Most contribute a small part to the huge impact of producing microprocessors to the world. Very competitive employee population in terms of skill, so you must work extremely hard to advance your career. Many software roles are in teams that are relatively isolated and focus on specific manufacturing needs.

review_title: Boat loads of high achievers
job_title: Quality and Reliability Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
* surrounded by very highly technically capable engineers
* big company
* good compensation
* flexible work arrangement if manager agrees
* free drinks and fresh fruits
* highly interesting and challenging projects
cons:
* big company
* top-down project timelines (unrealistic and stresses out people)
* meeting-heavy
* horrible IT support
* more time you give, they will keep taking it... so if you don't put a brake on it, you will become overworked and burn out quickly (you have to put a limit yourself since they won't stop you from overworking)

review_title: Demanding, but rewarding
pros: Job is demanding but you are working with smart & dedicated people and everyone is driven to deliver to the best of their abilities. There could be a few free-loaders around, but they usually get found out and weeded out quickly.
cons: Project-based environment, so work-life balance takes a back seat during crunch time. However, management gives time off after project is done. So I guess this may not be a con. But if you are looking for consistent time-in-time-out, that's not gonna happen here.

review_title: A mix of big, somewhat interesting, but too bureaucratic
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Large company.  Many collaborative projects, some with highly qualified engineers; Flexible hours. Intel has its own shuttles flying between major West Coast sites.
cons: Too much bureaucracy: planning, reporting, reviewing.  Managers of technical groups are not always technical.  Too many people are packed in huge buildings.  Salary is likely lower than it is in major (Bay Area) companies.

review_title: Program Manager
pros:
Sabbatical every 5 (1 month)  or 7 years (2 months).
Job change every 1 year min.   Some opportunities
5% of pay for reduced stock.  It use to be 10%.
Medical Dental Vision benefits in line with major companies.
cons:
Layoffs, buyouts, redeployment seems to be a common yearly occurrence now.
Forces diversity efforts that are even massaged during the annual review period.  Stocks back in the day was a big benefit, however, the stocks are no where the value that they use to be 10 - 15 years ago.
Talent is leaving the manufacturing sites to go to the Internet of Things sector.

review_title: Early days - empowered, phenomenal company, later days less than astute management severely reduces the experience.
pros: Good fellow workers - some bright people that make coming to work all worth it, interesting products.
cons: Poor management and lack of technical prowess has severely diluted the company from its capabilities.  It appears there are goals  that are of greater importance to the company than what it was founded on.  The grading system can be very disproportionate as well as workload and responsibility. But again this is present under poor mgmt but there are some  good mgmt.  In general a lack of emphasis on maintaining a technically great place to work.

review_title: Continue to embrace outside ideas and finish the change that is underway.
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Albuquerque, NM
pros: If you are coming from a top engineering school with a Ph.D. Intel is a great place to work with high compensation and great opportunity for technical career growth. There are extremely interesting scientific challenges and great opportunities to solve tough problems.
cons: There are pockets of visionless and deeply incompetent middle managers. Coming in to Intel with outside experience has classically been treated with hostility, but that seems to slowly be changing.

review_title: Doing great things, but have to learn to fend for yourself
pros: Great time off benefits 3 weeks to start and 2 month sabbatical every 7 years. Large company where you can find a lot of different jobs to try out.
cons:
Can be a very agressive place to work. Though not as bas as years past, most people are confrontational. If you are shy or have trouble putting your foot down you can get walked all over very quickly. Management tends to allow these confrontations calling them "being direct" with one another. 
Due to the large size of the company you can often have situations where your boss does not even live in the same state...or country!

review_title: inconsistent management and politics otherwise loved my job
pros: high technology, good reputation, good policies and compensation, freedom to do advanced research, lots of very smart and capable people
cons: There have been great situations and terrible situations.It may be a function of shrinking the US employee base to move offshore but in the past few years there seems to have been a lot of irrationality and turf defense, making it a tense place to work for many.

review_title: Struggling to transition to a company that can deliver value through software
pros: Strong Financial position and market leader in semiconductors. This is a tech person's mecca, you will be rewarded for your technical abilities. If they are strong you will prosper and have the ability to do as much as you can handle!
cons: Becoming beaurocratic with leaders who do not understand how to manage people, lead or inspire innovation in software. Cowboy development mentality prevails and lack of accountability enable poor performance by organizations. Like any company be careful where you go as organizational politics and discfunctional work environments can limit your ability to contribute.

review_title: Challenging work, great coworkers, good mature culture, but bureaucratic
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: I like the work here, it is very appropriate yet challenging enough for my career development. Coworkers are very smart and helpful, and the work culture is very positive and mature. Recently Intel has also been trying harder to create a fun place to work.
cons: Bureaucracy can really bog down decision-making. No matter how much Intel tries to clear up the red tape, it always seems to come back. Also in my opinion, Intel could do better in adopting more industry standard tools and letting go of its not-invented-here mentality.

review_title: This company takes care of its employees
pros: The benefits are great, the location (Oregon) is fantastic, and you feel like the company is investing in you as an employee. They care about your career almost as much as you do. They want you to be happy.
cons: It's a big company, and it could be easy to get lost. You need to carve out your little niche, get to know some people above you and at your same level, and take ownership of your own projects to get ahead.

review_title: Happy to have job but tired of the real culture
pros: Good pay, great benefits. Casual dress code. 15 years in some things haven't changed at all.
cons: Getting along more important than good product. Ranking process means high achievers seen as threat to others' reviews. Pressured to not push for needed work from others. Talking the talk more important than getting things done. ('Fit' more important than function). And who you know outweighs what you know.

review_title: Great company if you like a challenge and can handle a high pressure environment.
pros:
Intel is a great company for a stable job. They're not a startup type company where they throw around money on events, but they provide good stability. Intel a culture is based on results so they do out pressure on you than some other companies. 

Pros would be good benefits, stable job, huge company of over 90,000 employees world wide. 
There is a lot of options to move around the company and they encourage it too.
cons: This is a large company so it's easy to get lost.  If you've worked in a smaller company there is a sense of you know everyone.  There isn't that sense of closeness except for your group or org.

review_title: Rollercoaster ride
pros:
Excellent medical/dental/vision benefits.
Great opportunities for advancement if you are sophisticated at navigating a highly matrixed environment.
Flexible vacation and sick time that really does honor family emergencies -- as long as it is a true emergency.
cons:
Extremely long working hours for mid-range pay for non-technical exempt workers.
Too many levels of management for size of organization while cuts keep happening at the independent contributor level that makes for very, very long work days and the necessity to put time in on weekends.
So much "process churn" that it feels like a constant rollercoaster ride.

review_title: Was a great place to work
pros: Big company! Provides a lots of opportunities to switch within the company. Great place to work! Some groups promotes great working cultural - which will let you strike a good balance between innovation and your routine technical development/delivery
cons: Lower salary. Too big to change the directions. Some groups have too much process orientations. Some people have been there for 30+ years - who may have point of view which may not much align with the new generation of engineers.

review_title: Engineers are overworked
pros:
Good benefits - bonus programs, health insurance, little added perks
Always something to work on
Lots of different opportunities throughout the company
cons:
...Again, always something to work on. As an engineer in manufacturing, you are never "done". There is always more looming. 
Overworked, underpaid. Pay is less than industry standards. Extra hours, on-call requirements add a load of stress. No time to separate emotionally and mentally from work. 
Layoffs - little notice, widespread
Annual review process is generally considered terrible, unfair
A lot of talk of "work-life balance" but actual expectations don't support this

review_title: Software Engineer at Intel
pros: Work as Software engineer in a company who gets money from Hardware is an interesting challenge, not everybody can get what this really involves but once you got it it becomes an interesting job. You can take advantage of work with a big team of very talented people abroad a lot of years and being part of a system made to do great things.
cons: Being a giant company things are slow and sometimes not the most optimum, at same time this become an opportunity area that you can deal with but it will depend the team you are in.

review_title: Intel Corp from a career employee
pros: Great technology, great products, great history, great employees, strong leadership up until current CEO. Great place to work if you are in silicon development.
cons: CEO Brian Krzanich is a mediocre leader. The hiring of Murthy Renduchintala was a mistake. Intel has been diverging from it's long history of promoting from within, which has demonstrably been more unsuccessful than not, based on the longevity of external hires, their performance, and many other factors. The most recent reduction of workforce was the most ill-conceived, ill-executed in the 48-year history of the company.

review_title: Smart people, big problems
pros: You will work with dedicated, intelligent, hard working people.  Benefits and pay are great.  Problems to solve are complex.
cons: Top leadership isn't.  Have recently cut back on looking for what is next to double down on 4 "big bets." which is tactical but not very forward thinking.  Employees should be worried about competition, but instead are worried about what management is going to do to their team next.

review_title: Intel is trying... but there are issues.
pros: Every one is generally really smart. They want to do the right thing. They have superior technology. Their diversity aims are working and more representation is increasing better skill sets & options for career mobility.
cons:
Most of the time they have zero understanding of real customer requirements and they have a lens of what they believe is the right thing to do without alot of data on why... 
There is alot of politics. 
But mostly there is a lack of constructive confrontation so everyone often talks behind your back and you find out often too late or in a way that is not helpful and you are basically screwed.

review_title: Software Engineer
pros:
One can work on great products.
The pay is OK.
No micromanagement (in the team I work with, this of course varies greatly by team).
Pretty much every upper level manager was an engineer before stepping into management roles, they understand products, they understand the work that goes on in the trenches.
cons:
The location of the main Gdańsk office is horrible - long commute. A boring building outside they city, boring rows of employee desks in open spaces, no colors, can't open windows. Like a cattle farm. But I guess that is normal for such US companies.
The second (much smaller) office in Gdańsk is in a pretty good location in center though.

review_title: Intel is a great place to find and grow your career path.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Intel is a large, diverse company that can provide growth opportunities for people with varied career goals.  They are very open to letting employees change jobs when it provides growth opportunities.  

It is very rewarding to be part of a project that can potentially change the world.  Most of the groups I have been on are filled with great, fun-loving individuals.
cons: Like any large corporation, Intel has it's share of bureaucracy that is sometimes frustrating to deal with.  Also, it is sometimes difficult to remove an under qualified employee once he / she has been at Intel for over a year.

review_title: Intel, great place to rise if you are aggressive.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Compensation to stress ratio is very good. Excellent opportunity to advance if you want to. It is a big company, so there are a lot of areas to move around to. Moving to new areas is supported if you are not happy in your current area. There are many sites to work at, so you have a variety of locations that you can live in. Bonuses are significant, so as you advance, bonuses become more significant to your overall compensation.
cons: Big corporation, so you can get lost. Need to be proactive to advance. The decoration is a little sterile. Everyone has a small cubicle, so don't expect to ever get your own office.

review_title: He does not come across as an honest leader.
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great and smart people to work with. Great learning environment for someone new to the industry. Nice corporate culture and events. In the Semi conductor industry, intel is not only a world leader, but it is also one of the most stable companies in the high tech industry
cons: too much work, always bring work home. Like other tech companies, intel has a heavy work load that it passes to its engineers. compared to other companies, intel is known to pay less. Also, it is hard to leave intel once your there. (that could be viewed as a good thing)

review_title: Found your self in other company -  Numonyx ,  flash memory Intel and ST micron spin off join venture
pros: If company has an  interest in you , you will get all you need to reach goals to succeed in your job  (training , study option on company pay , relocation... )
cons:
No sentiments to loose very skilled personal , time/money invested, employees that were inspired by  Intel  values and did all for company success , many of them just found them self fired , sold as part of the dying flash business . 
At the same time Intel preferred to hire new employees to it's new 300 mm Fab .

review_title: Great people, interesting work, good benefits, mediocre recognition
job_title: Product Development Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros:
Interesting and engaging work
Great financial and health benefits.
Good bonuses and stock options
Lots of opportunities for lateral motion within the company -- they expect you to learn different parts of the business and eventually take on more responsibility
cons:
Recognition for individual efforts is a bit spotty -- if you've done something you think is great, be sure to champion your accomplishments to your manager.
Some of the bonuses are tied to vague, quasi-measurable things that are beyond the control of any individual employee. This is offset a bit by the RSUs given out to reward individual performance after annual reviews.

review_title: Good company, good management, stagnant industry.
pros: Intel is a good employer and goes to great lengths to show their appreciation to their employees.  Overall, i think Intel is a well run company with a strong culture and good management.
cons: Salary and benefits are ok, but other "perks" are somewhat behind other tech companies.  Intel painstakingly benchmarks its salaries against other companies to make sure it is competitive...but just barely competitive.  The annual performance review process is the most demotivating and demoralizing experience an employee can go through.  Intel is also a very top heavy organization leaving little opportunities for advancement beyond the first few rungs of the latter.

review_title: Good technology, good engineers, rigid culture, dull atmosphere.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Many very smart people, lots of projects and areas to work in.  Location choice (between California, Oregon, Arizona, Massachusetts, and a few smaller sites).  Option to work from home at least some days.
cons: A lot of bureaucracy: weekly and monthly status reports.  Not a lot of initiative.  Ultimately, it's a manufacturing company so that side of the business dictates the rules.  A lot of collaborative work involves participants in different sites and countries, so meetings, including regular ones can be scheduled at odd hours.  Massive buildings full of grey cubicles.

review_title: Work harder, not smarter...  there is no life outside of work
pros: The compensation and benefits are good.
cons: We are expected to work every evening and every weekend.  Holiday's too.  Work-life balance is non-existent.  I've never even heard the term mentioned.  Processes and tools make what should be the simplest tasks challenging and time consuming.  The organizations are overloaded with governance which stifles productivity and brings decision making to a crawl.

review_title: Strategic Planning
pros: Really smart people work there -- lots to learn from them. Leading edge technology company that can influence trends around the world.
cons: Turning into more of a cut-throat environment that seems to not be geared towards more seasoned employees. They tend to overinvest in some trending markets (e.g. phones) when it is clear, the ROI is not there and for other markets they pull-out before the full business plan can be implemented.

review_title: A Fine Company to work for
pros: Excellent Benefits: Health, Dental, Life Insurance, Managed Health Network, Sabbatical every 7 years or mini Sabbatical every 4. Extraordinarily focused on employee safety. Free fruit and drinks. Compressed work week with a 16% differential for night shift.
cons: Training is good, but often can be ignored, or devalued. Huge difference between groups within the company. Research and development is an engineering driven group and can be hostile towards technician/worker bees, High Volume Manufacturing is management driven with Engineering input and is much more suited towards the employee.

review_title: Intel Security Group - Don't work here.
pros: The checks clear and the comp and benefits are good.
cons: No one has the company's best interest at heart. Everyone (especially sales) is only in it for themselves, has zero integrity, zero accountability, zero understanding of what it means to be a team or work in a sophisticated technology company and not a start up. I am perplexed the, at times, flat out unethical behavior of the sales team. The lying, not only to people internally but to customers. The lack of professionalism is rampant. The good 'ole boy mentality and exclusionary culture, especially to women and minorities. I'm amazed that Intel hasn't fired everyone and started over from scratch; as it seems that may be the only solution to expel the stench and stigma of the McAfee culture in this cesspool environment.

review_title: Agile Project Manager
job_title: Agile Project Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: Excellent benefits package, including cash bonuses and stock options. The "doers" are extremely smart/intellectual people and it is an honor to work with them.
cons: "Command and control" old school of management, despite many attempts to change that. Transition Change Management challenges left and right, as the company really wants to reward the many years of sacrifice offered by those managers and is making every effort to re-train them.

review_title: Competitive company with notable accomplishments that can hopefully continue to make meaningful improvements
pros:
• Great work benefits (retirement, health benefits, etc.) which is expected from a top global company
• Admirable company that strives to exceed expectations every quarter
• Always in the news for good stories and accomplishments
cons:
• Corporate hive-mind culture — many people are just cogs in a well-oiled machine that can emphasize in more team comraderie
• A lot of bureaucracy  and red-tape when it comes to roles and responsibilities
• Many good, intelligent workers are overworked and many are under-compensated for the work they contribute
• Yearly performance review program needs improvement

review_title: Great people, demanding management, nonexistent training
pros: Pay was good,  good benefits, lots of chances to work other departments, and volunteer opportunities.
cons: My OM (operations manager) was demanding, clueless, and has NO idea what their MTs are doing, never watched what we were doing.  Never suggested any type of training, can't deal with admin issues nor deal with tense or disgruntle workers.   My OM was a young fresh out of college grad with NO MANAGEMENT experience.   Training for my module was non existent, we were "training" and working the floor at the same time... which can cause problems.

review_title: Being inside "Intel INSIDE"
job_title: Platform Applications Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Its being great so far. Work - Life -Balance is almost perfect.  Alot of thing s to learn and lots of Veterans too. Innovating and expanding business portfolio to include other technologies and not just Chips. With the BRAND name you can Expect only the best from the BLUE TEAM. glad to be part of the BLUES!!!!
cons: Dont have anything for now.

review_title: Great Employer
pros: Great team, which came out of a start-up, very flexible work hours, good atmosphere, cutting edge product, leadership has high aspirations and drive to make this a world-class team. The campus itself is nice and provides a lot of amenities on-site.
cons: Probably one of the most corporate companies in the semiconductor business, which brings a fair amount of red tape and inflexibility. Flow of information is still inadequate. While the campus is nice and well connected, it is also a good bit outside of Dublin.

review_title: Being inside "Intel INSIDE"
job_title: Platform Applications Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Its being great so far. Work - Life -Balance is almost perfect.  Alot of thing s to learn and lots of Veterans too. Innovating and expanding business portfolio to include other technologies and not just Chips. With the BRAND name you can Expect only the best from the BLUE TEAM. glad to be part of the BLUES!!!!
cons: Dont have anything for now.

review_title: Great Employer
pros: Great team, which came out of a start-up, very flexible work hours, good atmosphere, cutting edge product, leadership has high aspirations and drive to make this a world-class team. The campus itself is nice and provides a lot of amenities on-site.
cons: Probably one of the most corporate companies in the semiconductor business, which brings a fair amount of red tape and inflexibility. Flow of information is still inadequate. While the campus is nice and well connected, it is also a good bit outside of Dublin.

review_title: Hope the stock gets to 33!!
job_title: Senior Information Security Analyst in Folsom, CA
pros: Name recognition, international business exposure, great people to work with, exposure to leading edge technology, can jump around in jobs, realy good training if you take advantage of it and work life balance is achievable.
cons: Not too many, but don't expect upper management to tell you what is really happening.  Ethical behavior in other countries questionable.  The golden 90's were a lot of fun, but seems like just a place to get a paycheck since 2001.  Expect China to start producing x86 clones at low costs for their citizens as decisions regarding intellectual property development and access are business driven to low cost geos to produce.  Oh wait, it's already happening http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loongson.

review_title: Not for those who like working with human beings.
job_title: Industrial Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: If you want to design microprocessors or semiconductor technology, this is the place.  The technology is as good as it gets, though it can be difficult to pursue new ideas within the existing bureaucracy.  There are advantages to working for a market leader in terms of resources, technology, marketing, etc.
cons:
People are simply meat puppets.  "You own your own employability" is the excuse for having no management investment in employee development.  It's a cold, competitive culture.

Only the paranoid survive is taken by many employees to be paranoid about their fellow employees rather than the competition.  It's so very big there are pockets of excellence and pockets of crap.  It's difficult to know which is which before you sign up.

review_title: The old Intel is gone.
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: There are/were a lot of smart people there and there are many interesting projects. When times are good, the bonuses can be hefty.
cons:
Management is overly risk-averse, worried more about a project failing than of doing nothing and being beaten by the competition. The old data-driven Intel is long gone and is now run by sales and marketing types, with decisions now based on the best sales pitch.
    Intel is no longer a growth company, with all the rewards that go along with it. The stock is unlikely to double in the foreseeable future as microprocessors become commodities and the huge profit margins disappear.

review_title: Great place to work, but you better be ready to go for it.
job_title: Senior Hardware Systems Engineer  in DuPont, WA
pros: Successful company with lots of opportunity worldwide and a history of never quitting.  Employees are great to work with and most of management is pretty good as well.  Compensation is pretty well rounded, though upsides have been a little weak over the last years (options / stock performance)
cons: High stress, stock performance not great, lots of opportunity to work too much (have to make sure you keep a work/life balance focus).  Senior leadership does a pretty good job most of the time, but shows moments of indecision.  Lately there has been lots of focus on improving decision making, and I think that has generated some improvement.

review_title: excellent communications
pros: They have very competitive salaries when you factor in all the elements such as bonuses, stock plans, benefits, etc.  In particular, the bonus structure really rewards employees when the company performs well.  Full range of benefit choices and opportunity to customize to fit your needs.  The larger sites have thousands of jobs so there can be lots of career opportunties if you take the time to build a network of contacts.
cons: The daily workflow can be process heavy at times with lots of emphasis on metrics and indicators.  The annual performance review process, which I consider fair overall, still promotes individual achievements over teamwork.

review_title: Capricious treatment of contractors due to impatient management with unrealistic expectations
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Pay is above average, at least for contractors.  Ability to work on leading technologies.
cons: Getting set up to work in the Intel environment is very time consuming because of overly bureaucratic restrictions needing oodles of permissions to access even the most basic information needed to perform your work.  Access to documents and tools particularly difficult for contractors, with minimal help from company employees, for very complex systems and tools filled with undefined Intel specific acronyms and jargon.  Yet contractors are expected to perform useful work almost immediately despite the enormous information vacuum in which they are placed.  Don't be surprised if you are summarily canned without warning because an impatient manager thinks you should be able to skip the learning curve that always applies to working with new technologies and systems.

review_title: Wonderful job, until the money stopped flowing freely
pros: Great times with some great people,  Technician jobs really were not stressful overall.
cons: When the money flow was reduced, they couldn't remember how to entice their employees to help out and try to reduce spending. Their preferred to just cut jobs and send more work overseas, closing plants in USA.

review_title: Typical Big company, but stable and has plenty of room to move around
pros:
- Working on the design of high performance microprocessors
- Ability to move laterally and try out different department
- Flexible work schedule.
- Great volunteer and giving back to community program.
cons:
- Big company feel. It depends on your group. You could feel like sinking in the ocean trying to reach the surface for anybody to notice you.
- Everybody is trying to get themselves noticed as well. Competition could be fierce.
- Level of bureaucracy is high. Decision making process is pretty slow.

review_title: The best of companies out there ...
job_title: Lead Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
-Intel hire leaders, you are expected to be a leader even if that wasn't you title.
-freedom to accomplish and to raising your tone and speak up new ideas and tgoughts.
- management will let you try and fail and they will give you hands and support you along the way to make sure you are not actually failing. 
- owning the company atmosphere. 
- coworker support ideas  and will help you out if you shared them and you still the owner.
-
cons: The company scope is huge (cross platform, cross OS, cross devices, etc), things goes pretty fast and you need to keep up with market changes.

review_title: Not what it once was
pros:
Great benefits
Excellent salaries, bonus opportunities, health and 401k contributions
Vacation time of 3 weeks first year is OK
cons:
Hard environment.  Intel will suck your life away if you let it.  

Individual contributors are promoted to management without getting proper training.  Many managers at Intel have no people skills and don't know how to get the most out of their teams without resorting to aggressive behavior.

360 performance reviews are abused.  Managers can still override and color negatively any input they receive.

Intel Oregon has made a feeble attempt at making the company a better place to work by the perfunctory on-site salon, pool tables and work-out facilities.  Clearly trying to compete for young talent, but Intel will never feel like a Google.

review_title: Hardware engineer review.
pros:
Innovative company leads to top talent accumulation and development. Great place to practice and improve your engineering skills. Great work atmosphere.

Best compensations in town! Unlimited mayor medical insurance, minor medical insurance, stock benefits, two food stamp cards, and flexibility in working hours.
cons: Slow changes; don't expect financial increments in promotions or work rotations; a masters done while in the job doesn't land you a better position within the company. Yearly evaluations are biased towards perceptions; you need to do a lot of extra work to clear this up. Manager may not be the product supervisor or have little technical background to understand your work.

review_title: It was a better place to work 10 years ago
pros: The pay is better than average for the semiconductor industry, good benefits and some of the best heath care you can get anywhere.
cons:
Intel is a great place for people who are very driven and who like to work 24/7 and dare I say, are sociopaths. Consequently there are quite a few managers that fit the description. 

The company is slowing shrinking and there is a lot less money in microprocessors than there used to be. The jobs are a lot less fun as everyone has to do more with less.

review_title: QA Intern
pros: Good pay and benefits, even for interns. People are generally pretty friendly. Nice facilities with good selections of food from the cafe.
cons:
Lots of pressure to complete projects but projects often just get dumped in reorgs. This happened during my internship twice. If you're working in software, work with the expectation that your project will never see the light of day.

There's a lot of competition for attention without actually delivering anything. This goes with the prior issue in that people spend so much time fighting for attention and funding for their projects that the projects themselves are mismanaged and poorly executed.

review_title: Big company in fast-paced industry
pros: Intel is a large multi-national company so there is a lot of opportunity to move around. Compensation and benefits are at or above average compared to most peers. Work/life balance is better than some other tech companies I know.
cons: The competition in the microprocessor industry is getting fiercer and Intel has not been able to penetrate the mobile computing market (phones, tablets). Intel needs to adapt and innovate more quickly or they will continue to struggle. The culture is a bit old school (more like HP and IBM, less like Google and Apple).

review_title: Attention to Talents Out There
pros:
Pro: 
Free Fruits
Great benefits and facilities
cons:
Cons: 
Be very prepared If you are joining remote team
When you suggest something, they expect you to run it (not together as a team)
Quoting a senior direct org leader: " Intel do not owe you." 
Be very prepared if remote managers only wants contribution and expect you know as a newbie
Be very clear if you want them to hear you out to avoid them from selective listening or judgmental based on perception given (they will mark you)

review_title: Culture change
pros: Benefits are good ( bonuses, stock, 401k, health, etc), the work is interesting and can be rewarding, colleagues are in general great to work with
cons: Work-life balance is a large issue, especially given the change In tenor from management.  Job cuts using criteria that until the middle of last year was unheard of, and instead of using  the traditional "redeployment" pool to re-place the targeted individuals, people were terminated and walked out the door with no option to return.

review_title: Senior Process Engineer
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: In general, good teaming experience and people.  Peers are willing to listen to ideas and opinions. Challenging projects. Average opportunity to present your work and efforts to higher level management. Better than average salary and benefits package.
cons: Management heavy who lack listening skills. Often they do not follow up with agreements and stated promises. Worse then average opportunity system. Poor work/life balance chiefly due to the management communications, bad leadership, and indecisiveness. Atrocious annual performance review system and the way it is managed.

review_title: You'll learn a lot but you're more than expendable
pros:
Good pay
Good benefits
You'll learn a lot.
cons:
You're more than expendable. When management gets bored of your project, they lay you off, sometimes your entire business group, even when it angers their customers.

You deal with a ton of bureaucratic junk daily. 

You'll learn how to be a political waste of space faster than you'll learn good engineering. It's all about who you can throw under the bus to get ahead, not the actual merits. People will present your work as their own if you help them and aren't there to correct them.

review_title: Great.
pros: Friendly staff, management helped me push my internship goals to learn more about the industry, gave me enough independence to sink my feet in, but gave me enough support without feeling like i was drowning. My director let me sit in important planning meetings to really understand the organization, and allowed me to get the first try in creating media packets, and information packets to really get experience.
cons: I was there in a downsizing time, especially in the marketing department. there was definitely tensions, and i could see the beginnings of a subtle panic.

review_title: Great place to work.
pros: Market leader.  Raises above the fray and is a model leader in the industry, the company is constantly under attack from both competitors as well as lunatic enthusiasts.
cons: The size of the company has draw backs, especially in decision making process.  This has improved greatly over the past two years, but just size makes it difficult to

review_title: Overall good choice for employer
pros: Growth opportunities, competitive compensation package coupled with heavy work/life balance focus. Great people in a casual work environment. Intel values and culture are good, and it's not uncommon for personal lives to be improved from a (subconscious) propogation of the values to your personal lives.
cons: Stock performance. Competition for senior management to fill next CEO role tends to result in many managers disappointed and leaving the company. Ever since Andrew Grove stepped down from CEO in '98, the stock has been flat-lined. There are obvious challenges here, but somehow we need to figure out the secret to re-energizing the growth. I keep hearing Atom, but we'll see.

review_title: Fun Internship, not sure about full time
pros: Intel is a large company that has a lot of resources. As an intern I got to work on a cool project.  There wasn't much oversight as I was given an independent project to work on for the duration of the internship, so I didn't have much interaction with management. There was also a good mix of young and old developers.
cons: The workplace environment definitely needs improving -- the sea of cubes isn't exactly the most exciting.  There seems to be a lot of groups that have members in different locations.  There didn't seem to be any real perks, and as far as the intern experience goes, there weren't many organized activities.

review_title: Intern Experience @ Intel
job_title: Undergraduate Technical in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Biggest chip company. They are stable and have been making lots of money for a long time. The CEO seems to be doing a very good job.

The benefits are starting to get better, free pop/coffee now as well as free fruits.

I never experienced their health plans; but from what I've heard they are pretty good.
cons:
There are some good management; but there are bad eggs as well. The bad ones are slow and stupid and way too consevative. They try and understand things they have no hope in understanding. They imped the company's pace.

A lot of people here are conservative (which is a good thing), but sometimes too conservative.

review_title: Could be worse, I could be working in the Taliban
pros: Easy job, not much going on
cons:
Not much upside, not much downside either, 35 hours a week, some like it some don't, 1-1 meetings with your manager every week, could be a pain, uptight culture, speaking up is encouraged but be ready to be ridiculed by more senior people,

Overall it isn't the worst place to be but it certainly isn't better

Company restructures fairly often, about every 3 years just because they really can't seem to figure out what exactly they need or don't need, lots of new ventures but let's face it, if the ventures don't have x86 in the project name, 10/10 times it'll be a bust

review_title: Keep your resume updated!
pros: Industry Leader, emphasis on safety, sabbatical benefit, good employee bonuses, nice severance packages and notice to employess who were about to be laid off
cons: Average a layoff every 2 years, hard to advance, limited opportunities, job security unstable (unless you live in China.)  As a worker in the fab you are evaluated by people who hardly ever set foot in your work environment....hence they tend to have their perspective marred by brownnosers and extroverted personalities....great place to work as long as you do not work in wafer operations

review_title: Green badge vs Blue badge
pros: High tech environment, new technology happening all the time, nice buildings. lots of perks for Blue badges, workout room, nice cafe
cons: Green badges are treated as a sub-life form even though there are more green badges than blue badges on this site and Intel could not get the job done with out green badges. very poor collaboration between green badges and blue badges.

review_title: Finance Intern
job_title: Finance Intern in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great pay and great benefits especially as an intern. Plenty of intern events (taken out to many dinners/napa valley wine trip/beach trip). The projects are normally very interesting and even if they aren't, it's really up to you to talk to your mentor/boss about it or finish your deliverables so that you can move on to more interesting stuff.
cons: It can feel somewhat political at times especially within the financial department where you have to be very subtle and worm your way into making influential decisions within the corporation.

review_title: Challenging, High Pressure, Job Satisfaction, but pay can be improved
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Pulau Pinang
pros:
You get the chance to work in the world class, world leading team in CPU/Chipset designs.
Flexi hours allowed when needed.
Employee benefits are good: insurance, car loan and housing loan subsidy, free fruits
cons:
1. Schedule intensive
2. High pressure
3. Competitive, during yearly focal review, quota is normally set (~5%) that these 5% employees will be rated as BE (Below Expectation) and IR (Improvement Required). As the names imply, there will less than 1% or no increment for the 5% population.

review_title: Positive
pros: The company does a great job to support and take care of it's employees.  Whether it's career advancement and or education, to health, to work life balance.  The two managers I had the pleasure to work with supported me and my work and fought for me when my contract was up to keep me longer.  I defnitely felt like my work made a positive impact on the company.
cons:
Intel has a unique culture of work hard and play hard.  That culture tends to get caught up in over thinking and too many meetings.  It could be difficult to get any actual work done.  
If you don't like being walled in by gray cubes you won't like working there.

review_title: Engineering Technician
pros: Great company all and all.  Good pay.
cons: Intel has a very hard time promoting within.  I have worked here for 7 years.  All focals have been successful or better (Scale of 1 to 5, I rank 3 or better every year) never below successful.  I have a BS in EET.  I have worked the position of Engineer in charge of multi million dollar machines, and I cannot get promoted.  As much as I love Intel, I may have to leave so I can meet my long term goal of being a titled Engineer.

review_title: Great place to work!
pros: Intel's salary ranges are above average in the semiconductor industry. Great benefits with a paid 8 week sabbatical every 7 years of service. Intel's corporate culture is by far the best I've ever worked in. Work/Life balance is valued at Intel.
cons: I work a compressed work week schedule which I have learn to love and hate. I get 3 and 4 days off but during my work week I see very little of my family and hardly ever make it to dinner. I do get to make up that time on those long 4 days off on a short work week though.

review_title: Great work, good work-life balance
pros: Can work on top technologies, and there is a good chance to make an impact. The company has very good values. There is good work-life balance in the company.
cons: A large organization, moves slowly. Needs to be more nimble in the software category. Pay is average, but there are other benefits. Less number of job grades, so promotions are slow. Teams usually consist of few very good people and mostly average folks.

review_title: Flexible work, Very nice people and atmosphere, average to above average talent, average Pay
pros: flexibility to work in your own time or telecommute ; transparency and great leadership ; You wont get rich from the pay but the bonuses and stock options make you want to stay longer. Family feeling within your team and emphasis on your happiness, career etc. great incentive systems and multiple events.
cons: As mentioned, very nice people but many are looking for lifestyle work and it's hard to get excited or collaborate sometimes on a project. Not enough young buzz in the company, most employees are on the older side then other tech companies around.

review_title: Intel software engineer
pros:
1. Chance to work on cutting-edge hardware and influence hardware decisions.
2. More laid back (but that is changing now)
cons:
1. SSG (Intel's Software and Service Group) thinks of itself as a software company, but doesn't have the same attitude. This is abundantly clear when you visit real software companies.
2. Review system (called "Focal") is a pain. In addition, performance isn't always directly rewarded during end of year reviews (you could have a really super couple of years and still not get adequate recognition).
3. Pay isn't competitive with software companies.
4. Benefits -- no 401K matching for instance.

review_title: On average a good experience
job_title: Process Engineer in Rio Rancho, NM
pros:
Decent salary.
Excellent benefits and on-site amenities.
Cutting edge technology. 
Good work/company culture (for the most part).
Lots of technically excellent people.

On average, I had a very good experience at Intel (though I'd advise you NOT to take a position in NM but to instead go to Arizona, California or Oregon).
cons:
Cyclical layoffs.
New Mexico site is pretty much dead and waiting to be shut down (like the Massachusetts site).
Some managers are completely incompetent and are in position solely through political maneuvering.

review_title: A good 17 years
job_title: Automated Equipment Technician (AMHS) in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Pay and benefits were very good.  Facilities were well maintained.  Excellent Gyms.  Industry leader in products.
cons: Over time, Corporate Leaders have shifted from being more concerned about employees, to being more concerned about shareholders and profits.  Pay increase has failed to raise ant any level close to profit increase.  Different Fab cultures are radically different limiting ease of transitions.  Employee advancement is severely limited in direct relation to advanced education.

review_title: A good company to work for but a lack of trust among employees after cuts after cuts for years
job_title: Firmware Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great people, who work hard and get things done. A flexible schedule and yearly compensation discussion and increases.
cons: Management keeps cutting employees, fist it was employees who have never had a less than stellar year. and than it was just many teams and projects who work well together, but  over the last three there were over three rounds of layoffs and many employees are worried that their job will be next.

review_title: Great Work and Life Balance
pros:
- Great work/life balance (unless you work in the fab)
- Smart/competent coworkers
- Great company culture (friendly, open, and diverse)
- Growing young population 
- Lots of resources for growth and professional development
- Decent perks (although not as good as the Apples, Googles, etc.) 
- Decent benefits (although I hear they used to be A LOT better)
cons:
- not always challenging 
- slow upward mobility 
- risk averse company (feels a little old school)
- environment is boring even though the company works on really cool stuff
- management is not always direct/honest (i.e. they try to  avoid talking about the bad)
