review_title: Good company to work for
job_title: Senior Platform Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Opportunities to work on different projects and move around the company.  Learning opportunities abound.  Working with leading edge technologies and customers is exciting.  Flexible hours for jobs outside the factory. Working with different cultures along with international travel.  Casual attire.
cons: Meritocracy goes both ways and you may not always know where you stand if there is a corporate wide reduction in the work force.  Long tenure in the company can be a liability if your not moving up the career ladder anymore.

review_title: Good company to work for!
pros: There's a lot of transparency between business groups, and Intel being in almost most of the tech fields, you have the option to switch fields within Intel, or take up other opportunities part-time, in addition to your current job. You have a good forum to get yourself connected, known to a lot of people, network and improve. You have 1:1 mentoring sessions with top level management, architects to get good ideas for your career path. Overall, you have a lot of opportunities out here in Intel, you just need to learn to use them!
cons: Cons vary from team to team, from business groups to business groups, so you may not find that cons are consistent through out Intel's huge employment database.

review_title: Mixed Emotions
pros: Some of the highest caliber individuals with whom I have ever worked.
cons:
Layoff happy
Unclear chain of management in some cases
Work of the same calibwr is not always recognized equally
Discrimination for hiring and promotuon against white males (does not mean you won't get hired or promoted - it's just a little harder) - I actually witnessed a manager say to a group of white males employees on her team that they had two good candidates from a recruiting effort, but she was told it was better not to hire them since they were both white males, for one example.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: Great people, great benefits, great career advancement opportunities
cons: Executive leadership has become detached from the day to day reality.  Organizational politics rule the day.  Your career advancement depends on who you know and not on how good you are.  Organizational restructuring takes place all the time - within a year you can find yourself in 4 different organizations and under 4 different managers. The former CEO took a great company with a great culture and turned it into a place where people work out of fear for their employment and where mediocracy has become the norm.

review_title: Culture Transformation
pros: Huge company, lots of opportunity for lateral movement, great people at the peer level
cons: Low upward mobility, culture of hypocrisy WRT practice vs preach, mercenary executive leaders with low commitment to long-term, relentless focus on shareholder equity as driving factor for organizational success, lack of clear rollout of vision --> strategy --> execution, constant infighting and struggle for resources creates "scarcity mentality" and "resource hoarding"

review_title: Intel is a great company to work for!
pros: It's a great company that works on the cutting edge of technology, and it is really awsome to be a part of the corporation that changes the world, that makes life of billions of people easier, data more approachable, and moves forward science and technology in different parts of the world.
cons: there may be too much of bureaucracy, but it is a natural thing of a huge multi-national corporation, otherwise it may become uncontrolled, and may have losses. Also, working in a multi-country team might be not really convenient sometimes, as you have to deal with people from different time zones, and have to stay late.

review_title: "a place to work"
job_title: Business Development Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Very process oriented, for the most part good at "project management".  "Discipline" "Results" values are not just value statements, it is embedded into the culture
cons: Too many "silos" and duplication of jobs between divisions.  Everyone protects their turf. NIH (not invented here) syndrome prevalent.  Focal system, while "simplified" still a problem.  System forces managers to reward only the top 15%, and there is no ability to assign dollars, system assigns raises based on a fixed algorithm.

review_title: For chip design, there is no place on Earth better than Intel.
job_title: Senior Hardware Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: #1 semiconductor company on the planet. Intel has a lot of silicon design projects ongoing at any time. More than most companies. Intel has a strong focus on quality.  Always pushing technology as hard as possible (need for speed, no need for power). Great benefits.
cons: Everything is due yesterday. Everyone expects real time responses that are perfect. There's a lot of "analysis" which is unnecessary when the obvious is standing right in front of you. HR is still too powerful. IT is still way too big and bureaucratic. Too much money is spend on non value add programs like changing to "google like" offices.

review_title: Intel is a great place to work
job_title: Serior Technical Marketing Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: In the right group things can be Very flexible for work life balance ( working from home is a great thing that all employers should offer to their employees considering the price of gas ) .  You can changes jobs to get different experience and try new things .  The pay has gotten a lot better in the last few years and the bonuses are very nice .
cons: Learning to manage your time, because you can not out work intel .  The hours can be long if you do not speak up and make your manager understand what is going on .

review_title: Intel
job_title: Production Operations in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Training
Team work
Option of working in a number of different states
Over all great people to work with.
cons:
Pay is below market 
Stock is below market
Options is below market
Health care is crumbling
Focal review process is a big disappointment. Everyone is confused and upset buy it.

review_title: Good company to work for
pros:
Open atmosphere, encourage employees to give feedback
Company cares about employees and does its best to show it in benefits
Pretty good job security
cons:
Yearly review process can make it difficult for strong performers to move up quickly.  Can often take 3+ years to get a grade promotion, and pay increases are not great without the promo
Lots of type A personalities
Career Development is talked about, but is not done very well
They are willing to pay for education (which is awesome), but not willing to reward you for doing it.

review_title: Graduate Technical Intern
pros: Work Environment is awesome and employee satisfaction is very important for the company. The hierarchy is well maintained but more horizontal so that employees can voice their opinion effectively.
cons: The only downside I can think of is that Intel or any of the big companies are already well established. So, sometimes you may feel like you are one among the many whereas, in a Start-up company, you may handle many job roles and also feel that your work values more to the company's outcome.

review_title: Micro-managed mess. Reactive and not proactive
pros: Free beverages ? A very diverse work place?
cons:
1) NO TIME OFF, is the "official" Intel HR policy, hence the kissing up to be a favorite you can endless time off
2) Long hours because managers have no planning skills and manage by crisis, ego, and negative reinforcement, 
3) Far behind in technology. This shocked me. But when I saw things being done 20 years ago in their new designs I decided that this place is not for me.
5) No future direction. Intel missed the mobile technology markets and the PC will soon be gone and so Intel will soon be gone. Intel is in for a very bad future unless they can find another PC market. Right now they are lost trying to figure out where the future markets will need their chips.

review_title: A great place to work (except for small annoyances)
pros: Intel has the 'A Great Place To Work' as one of its core values, and it is very much aligned to the experience you have there. From the benefits down to paycheck, from professional experience up to the out-of-the-office activities, it is hard to find a better company to work for. This is specially true for the ones interested in professional challenges and self-improvement opportunities - there is always a lot of challenges and tasks.
cons: Many things depend on what team or what project you work. It gets boring sometimes, and the path up is not always that clear.

review_title: Great company going downwards, at least for now.
pros: In Intel, there are more opportunity to move laterally; the company tries to make it a good place to work; it has good healthy benefits; bonus was good but not good from last year and probably won't be good for a while.
cons: internal competition or job security mentality is very strong, collaboration is almost non-existence. career opportunities for senior technical people are not much. current Intel culture is different than Intel culture 15 years ago (from what I hear), current culture doesn't value people who do the work, even though the company value execution but more on the process than people. too much politics. pay is behind the market especially after you stay for a while.

review_title: Good company with a lot of opportunites
job_title: Senior Product Development Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Very large stable company. Lot's of good opportunities for an engineer. Huge R&D budget which keeps Intel on the edge of technology path finding. Interesting work. Decent salary, bonuses. 8-week paid sabbatical 7 years. Flexible on time off.
cons: Typical big tech company with high-stress projects, under-resourced, incredibly tight schedules with heavy pressure to deliver the impossible. Many employees are high-strung, burned-out and difficult to work with. Benefits have been declining year after year. All about the shareholder. Inconsistent distribution of compensation, raises and benefits. Competitive employee ranking and rating with politics.

review_title: Good Salary, Poor Culture
pros: If you are able to relocate to Hillsboro OR then Intel is an expansive and great place to work. The campuses are well kept and the people are very friendly. There are a lot of job opportunities if you are growing out of your current position and want to move up, take a side step or temporary assignment or change managers.
cons: Work/Life balance does not exist and the culture is very poor - there is a lot of 'back stabbing'. A majority of employees work 12+ hour days and/or on weekends consistently.

review_title: Senior Hardware Engineer
job_title: Senior Hardware Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: You get to do silicon design and get to know the most inner details of processors, architecture, and registers. The Health Insurance benefits are pretty good.
cons: Low salary. The managers are destroying this company and they are neighter technical nor hard-working. Too many H1 employees. The latest trend is to hire H1s or younger folks, get them trained, and then lay-off thousands of experienced folks. Because you are working on the most inner silicon details, getting a job outside is tough as other companies require high-level skills and not lower-level skills. Also because of experienced folks being let go, the project completion cycles do take longer but the upper management doesn't seem to care.

review_title: Good work-life balance, fair pay buts lots of politics in way of getting things done
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
+ Great work-life balance, hence long employee tenures (20+ years) at company
+ Fair pay for amount of work
+ Most positions are not that challenging work
cons:
-  Most positions are not that challenging work, so stagnation over time is not uncommon
- Lots and lots of politics, especially since company is not growing but shrinking so zero sum game for managers
- Your skills will deteriorate over time of dis-use
- Lots of people utilize process to avoid doing real work
- Lots of "status checkers" - people who don't do any useful work but rather aggregate and pass up status reports

review_title: "Intel is like fire...know how to use it"
job_title: Process Technical Director Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: They will take you right out of college (talent development). On-site services, cafeterias and especially gyms are great. Ronler Acres is a beautiful campus. Parental leave is not bad considering they're an American company.
cons: Work-life balance is up and down. In fab modules your off-call weekends are pretty secure but be prepared for long days if one of your tools goes down. When its your weekend on-call don't make any big plans and be prepared to go in if necessary. There is also a lot of midweek off-shift calls for tool owners; layer owners (who also own tools) get hit even harder. The quality of your group leader is extremely correlated to your quality of life....get a crappy one and it sucks. They can also be penny-wise and dollar-foolish. For example, in my case they sent us to vendor training out of state. Instead of sending a brand new engineer to the prerequisite course they skip you through to 'advanced' and then shorten that course by three days in order to save more money. I had been in the company for nearly a year and so caught on to the material pretty quickly, but I knew of a knew of a newly promoted ET who attended and didn't understand anything because he'd had less than a month in the position. So they will spend around 1500 just to get you out there for an interview, but then take that approach to training.

review_title: A good place to work
pros:
Good work environment, great food options at low prices, and a perfect place to develop your professional potential.
Work entrance flexibility, nobody is checking when do you arrive neither when do you leave as long as you deliver your work on time.
Working home is another option you may use when sick or when you have to attend personal issues.
cons: Green badges (Contingent Workers) are (quietly) discriminated in several ways, for example, GB must pay coffee, they have a low priority when reserving sports facilities and, of course, they have at least two managers: contractor employer and intel manager.

review_title: Nepotism and Favoritism
pros:
Getting anywhere requires brown nosing your way up the corporate ladder. It might be different in certain business groups, but more often than not, people will start something to get recognition and then kill it off before it becomes too difficult.

Success is based on what you can say you can do and not what you have done.

These are pros if you think you can succeed in this environment.

Okay pay, awesome health plans, good PTO, onsite gyms, onsite cafeterias, stock purchase plans that are as good as free money every few months.
cons:
Cafeteria is expensive.
The company refuses to use modern development principles and it's like moving mountains just to get people to use and understand Git.
Everything moves at the speed of corporate.

review_title: Start here but look for better elsewhere.
job_title: Applications Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel provides a great place to start a career. If you can find the right group to work for, you learn attention to detail and great discipline to get things done. They have a lot of smart people there and they all work pretty hard. Once you leave Intel, people respect the fact that you've been there especially if you stay in the semiconductor industry. There seems to be an "Intel Mystique" everywhere you go.
cons: Like all big companies, decisions take forever and it often adversely affects execution.

review_title: Come to learn, but leave before you become "Intelized"
job_title: Commodity Specialist in San Jose, CA
pros:
Intel is a great place for personal development. The company strongly encourages employees trying out new areas. The strong process documentation and employees sense of ownership ensures that you are trained quickly.

Teamwork and team playing is highly valued and rewarded. Employees are trained to challenge ideas but manage conflict effectively. This results in very productive teams.

Teamwork is highly valued and en
cons: The downside of the strong process orientation is that employees are at risk of becoming one trick ponies. There is a strong sense that the Intel way is the only right way. Employees tend to become inflexible. Employees leaving Intel have difficulties assimilating back into “Normal Society”.

review_title: Reasonable company with room for improvement
job_title: Senior Applications Developer  in Folsom, CA
pros: Technology leader. Availability of tools needed to do the job. Exposure to multinational business environment. Fostering of cultural diversity. Dedication to good causes (community involvement). Internal mobility (ability to change teams/jobs internally).
cons: Average compensation. Cubicle culture. No hiring strategy (hiring is ad hoc, always in a hurry without adequate time to find best candidates). Too much focus on processes (not quality of people). Too many reorganizations, which do not deliver on promises. Office politics is as bad as in any big corporation (probably not worst than most). Rather aggressive internal culture (may take time for people to get used to, although it seems better than it used to be).

review_title: It's a mixed bag working at Intel- Both good and bad apples
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Safe place to work, cutting edge products, top dollar compensation, many opportunities for growth.
Many very smart people to work with.
cons:
Focal performance reviews are arbitrary and grant too much power to manager.
Low trust among company and workers.
Declining stock prices as product line turns into a commodity.
Constructive Confrontation and Risk taking -- Two values that are not rewarded at all.
Creatively dormant.   Obsessive diversity efforts.
Your manager can screw up your career even if it seems fine one day it could slam you down hard.

review_title: Intel is a great company who continues to innovate and deliver results.
job_title: Undergrad Non-Technical Intern in Portland, OR
pros: It's an awesome company that's always on the leading edge of technology.  Plenty of opportunities for advancement and professional development.  At Intel, just about every job role under the sun is covered from finance to web marketing.  I like that Intel promotes internal transfers and rotation programs to expose their employees to a variety of different roles.
cons: Bureaucracy, people are hesitant to change, the attitudes among the people who have worked at the company for a while.  Intel is a company that gets stuck in it's old ways and often passes up new opportunities just to maintain the status quo.

review_title: highlights and lowlights on Intel Senior technical marketing engineer position
job_title: Senior Technical Marketing Engineer in Shanghai, Shanghai
pros:
Good experience gathering and knowdlege learning.
You can not only have a lot of opportunities to touch Intel core technical products , design, but also have good chance to deal with various kinds of customers to resolve their technical or business issues to make the deal done /closed. You can have a lot of chances to team work with account sales team, business development manager and high level management in the work. You will have good chances to prove your capacity to high level management so as to make you grow up rapidly.
cons: heavy work load and pressure from customer and business sales team

review_title: No life-work balance! Let  me rephrase: No life, all work!
pros: Good benefits. As long as you work out of the fab, it is a great place to work. Vault card!
cons: No social life. 24/7 work with no break. Compensation looks good but when divided by the work hours, it is less than minimum wage. Most management from engineering positions so they know nothing about human relations. Pushing rather than motivating by management! Mostly, new PhD level grads are hired to make sure they don't have previous experience to compare it with so that people think this 24/7 killing environment is "normal"! Another reason for PhD level grads to be hired is that fact that most new grads are international and if they don't get/keep the job, they cannot stay in the country: It is used very well at Intel.

review_title: One view from within
pros: If you're technical, Intel is probably a great place to work for you.  As a high-tech company we need technical folks for sure.
cons: If you're not technical and are on the services side of the house, Intel is becoming less and less a great place to work.  So much of those jobs have been outsourced or offshored, it's difficult to get basic services completed the right way the first time.  No offense to those who do the work; they're just not trained to do more than the bare minimum.

review_title: Great Place to work.  Couldn't image working anywhere else.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Sabbaticals
Bonuses
Salary
Work with really smart people
Work/Life balance
Ethical company
cons:
Recognition is by luck.  If you happen to be on a high profile project but do little work you are more likely to be recognized than if you do a ton of work on something not visible at the director level.

Focal process

review_title: Like working inside the world's largest Dilbert comic strip.
job_title: Senior Verification Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Pay is good but not great. Benefits are excellent. Bonuses are excellent. Many perks available for employees of such a large company.
cons: Intel is a very high-pressure workplace. They cultivate what they refer to as a "sense of urgency", which translates into expecting everyone to do the work of two people. If you're a Type-A hyperactive overachiever ADD anal-retentive overbearing control-freak workaholic who doesn't mind essentially turning your life over to the company, you'll do fine. If you aren't, you won't. It's a huge company, and the bureaucracy is absolutely ponderous. Everything is all about rigidly defined procedures, and yet it's extremely difficult to make decisions because nobody wants to take responsibility. If you have a good manager there, life is tolerable; if not, it's hell on earth. It has a reputation as a sweatshop, and it's well-deserved.

review_title: Great Place to Work
pros: Compensation is on par or better than other companies and the bonuses kick compensation over the top. The culture is very much focused much more on performance than a simple "hours worked" philosophy which very much benefits the productive employee. There are many site amenities, from on site doctor's office, work out gym, to a great recoginition systemt to allow employees the ability to give small monitary recognition for a job well done making Intel a great place to work.
cons: As with any cutting edge technology company, there are highly stressful times that must be worked through. The rest of the culture makes these times seem at worst bearable to at best actually pleasant.

review_title: Great work life balance, competitive pay, fun colleagues, but quite bureaucratic
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Work life balance is second to none with flexibility for telecommuting a norm. 
Great Place to Work programs provide employees with perks to local businesses and events to drive up employee moral.
Very smart people that you're working with on a daily basis.
Global network provides opportunities to work with people worldwide and sometimes relocate
cons:
Bureaucracy is common
Large organization slows down decision making with number of stakeholders needed to get buyoff

review_title: Most sites are OK, but steer clear of the Austin site...
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Austin, TX
pros:
The work life balance is heavily tilted to the 'life' side; vacation is on the honor system, and tele-commuting is encouraged.
Nice Cafe` with subsidized meals for breakfast and lunch.
cons:
If you enjoy design or verification, look elsewhere.  This is a pure execution environment where the when,where,and how is dictated and creativity is not tolerated.

While informed 'risk-taking' is a documented value, few are willing to discuss alternative methods, flows, or tools, even when presented with quantifiable benefits (including industry standards)

Constant restructuring under the same leadership weighs heavily on morale and often times career changes are made without the input of those effected.

review_title: A corporation on the decline
job_title: Pre Silicon Validation Engineer Gr 8 in Austin, TX
pros:
Lots (and lots) of free time and the food in Austin is great.
Once you get used to it, it is entertaining to watch how many people it takes to screw in a light bulb.
cons:
Morale is low, and management "can't understand why"
Unwillingness to adopt industry standards, external tools, innovate or even listen to new ideas.
Each project spends months, and millions, re-creating the wheel without sharing with other projects.
At any given time there may be two to three groups all duplicating effort - with no mind share.
More often than not it takes several engineers and a manager or two to accomplish what a single engineer does outside of Intel.

review_title: Great Place to work
pros: Open, collaborative and Friendly work environment. Performance review is purely based on merit. Senior management provide good career opportunities to employees. Possibility to try out various job functions.
cons: stereotyped as laid back by outsiders. Especially in the Valley some people think employees at Intel are not as passionate as employees in Google or Facebook. I'm not sure how this reputation was built. But I sure wish to break this.

review_title: Can be technically challenging, but you will be treated like crap
pros: The work - when you are allowed to do it - can be quite challenging.
cons: Be prepared to be jammed into - if you are lucky - a 6x6 cube with 4ft walls. No privacy, no ability to concentrate. Be prepared for too many middle managers who are all too busy trying to justify their existence and pay rate, and therefore make tons of pointless busywork. Be prepared for hardline positions that are supposed to be based on data, but are really based on fiefdoms and a fear of people being discovered as incompetent decision makers.

review_title: Great execution in legacy markets, but slow moving into new markets
job_title: Engineering Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Good work life balance
- Opportunity to seek jobs across many different disciplines in manufacturing, and product related fields.
- Lots of processes, and systems facilitate decision making in legacy business
- current CEO is making the right noises in public, and is following up with some decisions that
cons:
- slow moving company.
- too many decisions makers when trying to launch new products/services/internal tools etc slow things down
- poor and ineffective managers are not moved out quickly enough
- compensation is not great in comparison to the market

review_title: Take advantage of opportunities
job_title: Director of Product Management in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Big company that has a diverse range of job and career options (technical and non technical).  Take advantage of this when opportunities present themselves.  If you don't, you could paint yourself into a corner.  Opportunities are there though.  Pay and benefits are relatively good.
cons: Different business units work very differently.  A mix of new employees (at all levels) combined with the old guard leads to cultural clashes from time to time.  Budgets are tight.  Acquisitions have not been successful in the past.

review_title: General Review
job_title: Security Researcher in Santa Clara, CA
pros: They pay well and have good insurance. The work load here is less than I've had at other top technical companies.
cons: Rather old school company. Somewhat risk adverse in terms of adopting new technologies to improve products as well as internal business tools and processes.  Affecting change takes much too long. Too hierarchical.

review_title: Product Management Director
job_title: Product Management Director in Santa Clara, CA
pros: You are surrounded by a lot of really smart people who are passionate about their roles. Because the brand is so strong, opening doors with potential customers is typically not a challenge, but...
cons: ...actually executing against all the potential objectives that could possibly be brought to market appears to be a herculean task. Lots of talk. Not so much action. Actually, this is a function of long product development cycles at a large company. It would be nice to see more near term action. Also, re-org followed by re-org followed by re-org.

review_title: Senior Technical Marketing Engineer
pros: Intel has lots of new technologies. One can always find something new and interesting as long as he or she likes to learn.
cons: The latest layoff activities destruct the trust between managers and employees. People don't know whether their jobs will remain tomorrow.

review_title: Opportunity to Grow but not as fast
pros: They are one of the oldest Silicon Valley companies. But even so they spend a lot of their money on R&D. Good benefits not top dog but still good. Fighter attitude.... others have already faded but they are still there
cons: They do not really believe in telecommuting even if you do not have to be onsite. Older employees are at risks of getting canned. They tend to run acquisitions into the ground, so my advise if you are acquired try to get a job inside the parent company

review_title: Working in Intel finance
pros: Work life balance, pay per hour worked is good, benefits are great (health insurance, 4 week sabbatical every 4 years, paid paternity leave, etc).  I really enjoy working at Intel
cons: Ability to move up past a certain level in the company is getting more challenging.  The recent change to try and consolidate in a few sites has meant a lot of good talent has left.

review_title: Intel is a great place!
pros: Big company, lots of growth opportunities and ability to move from one job to another, one department to another.  Culture is very "show me the data!"  In general, very egalitarian.  Politics kept to a minimum.
cons: Big company...bureacracy....  Some departments are very risk averse (but others aren't).  The annual review process is no fun at all.  Also, the company will take all the work hours you choose to give.  It's easy to burn out.  It's up to you to maintain a good work/life balance (they'll let you, you just have to limit yourself).

review_title: Business Operations Analyst
pros: Great benefits (pay, healthcare, legal plan, stock options, stock purchase plan). Challenging work with very smart, driven people. Pay is higher than average for Sacramento Area. Great perks/drawings for sports/concert tickets at Golden1 Center and other local venues/events. Onsite cafes, vision services, and dental office.
cons: Competition is high for choice assignments and positive exposure.. Yearly focal/review process can be brutal. Some managers expect employees to be on call and work from home/check email nightly. Employees are expected to move up or out. Too long in a grade level or job (even if you like it and perform well) is looked at as not performing well. Recent downsizing which disproportionately hit women and people 50+.

review_title: And old company with future, if they pull it
job_title: Product Line Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Stable, high salary if acquired externally, lots of funding, 9-5 job, free-time, good for family life, not many surprises, many acquisitions in the last couple of years, innovative technologies in the horizon.
cons: Old, high level of bureaucracy, limits to professional growth, there is little accountability, it-matters-who-you-know, moving in between groups it is related closely to your contacts rather than your talent.

review_title: And old company with future, if they pull it
job_title: Product Line Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Stable, high salary if acquired externally, lots of funding, 9-5 job, free-time, good for family life, not many surprises, many acquisitions in the last couple of years, innovative technologies in the horizon.
cons: Old, high level of bureaucracy, limits to professional growth, there is little accountability, it-matters-who-you-know, moving in between groups it is related closely to your contacts rather than your talent.

review_title: Huge Company, Many Cultures
pros: Intel is so big that you can probably find what you're looking for somewhere at the company. There are many different groups that do different work and have different work cultures. There are resources to learn, grow, and develop IF you seek them out. There are some really great, smart, helpful people, but again you may have to go find them.
cons: Just like there are good places at Intel there are a lot of bad places. Some groups have terrible work-life balance. Many managers are not trying to develop their employees. Some systems and ways of doing things could use efficiency improvements.

review_title: The good and the bad.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: It's a big company with many projects going on that you'd never think Intel would be involved with.  Ability to work on many different things if desired.
cons: With a huge company comes huge politics.  Politics go all the way to the individual contributor.  If you just want to write code you won't do well here.  You have ot play the political game in order to survive and grow your career.

review_title: A behemoth trying to be nimble
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Intel is a great place to work, and allows lateral movement within the company. Risk taking is very decently promoted and valued - allowing individuals to gain exposure and experience in multiple areas. The company does a lot for the community - volunteer and fund--raiser works are well supported. Flexible work hours, telecommuting, vacations, leave of absence for personal reasons are all well supported. Senior engineering staff is among the most talented bunch of folks in the industry.
cons: Too large a company, makes it bureaucratic. Promotions/performance appraisal gets lost in the process. Being a large company, decision making process slows down as well.

review_title: Work hard; get rewarded
pros: The company strives to support a healthy Work/ Life Balance, while employees are rewarded for results -- a fairly good meritocracy. Intel strives to promote personal growth. With a great tuition program and its in house training program is very good.  Overall a very good company to work for, however the culture has seen some change over the past several years and is not the Intel of old.
cons: Be prepared for longer work hours. After the recent headcount reductions upward mobility has become more limited. The company is trying to find itself. Is is a still a growth company or is it a mature company with lower future growth.

review_title: Highly political, fast degrading workplace
job_title: Senior Staff Software Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Since they are a monopoly, more likely to be in business and hence your job is less likely to disappear in economically hard times.
cons: HIghly political, highly clanish atmosphere.  Engineering competence is necessary to advance; but is not sufficient to advance.  You have to know the right people in places.  The politics is subtle. If you do the right project, you get the exposure and rewards. But you don't get the right projects.  They do politics where your projects are allocated.

review_title: Software engineer's perspective on Intel
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: There are lots of interesting problems to work on and someone who wants to develop new tools can work closely with many users. The library resources are very extensive and helpful in my research. It is exciting to work with the newest technology and help in developing tools that only a small number of people in the world get to work with.
cons: There is a lot of bureaucracy and there are a lot of silly training classes to take. It can be difficult to find others in the company who do similar work to yours (for example to find collaborators). The competitive environment can make it difficult to start collaborations.

review_title: Challenging in a good way
pros: Great peers who support you in every way. Lots of room to move around if you are not particular about location. People are open and one can talk to anyone in the org. There is politics like in any other organization, but there is lot of room to be heard also. Lots of mentoring from senior management if you want to go that path
cons: Workholics work here. So balance between personal life and professional is non existent. Lots of A type people working so lot of pressure to stay ahead in your game.

review_title: GPTW
pros: Intel has a lot of intelligent people who have a wealth of knowledge.  The salaries at intel are competitive, and probably around the market average.  You get full benefits and a decent retirement plan.  Every site has an onsite gym and other things to get a break from work.  If you don't like to sit in a cubicle there are many common areas where you can work.
cons: Intel location are not particularly the best,  Like any large company you can be lost in the crowd.  Some groups offer rotations programs.  Due to the size of the company some jobs are small in scope and you are unable to see the big picture.

review_title: Highly focused, challenging and exciting research at Intel Corporation
job_title: Technology Development Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Research performed at D1D fab is one of its kind on the planet and it sets up land mar for its competitors. Highly focussed research
cons: There is not time bound research. Work is 24/7. Sometimes you get to sleep 2-4 hours per day for two weeks straight. Being on call is a part of life, however it is challenging during vacation period like independence day, memorial day, thanksgving and christmas due to the availability of limited resources. Sometimes, there are no technicians to run the tools/machines.

review_title: Good company turning their back to their employees
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Interesting work for hardware and software designers. Decent salaries and benefits.
cons: Recently the company decided to move all engineers from conventional cubicles (which have been shrinking for years) to semi-open work spaces which are not very accommodating to the work that requires concentration. What's even worse now they want to get rid of the notion of personal cubicles and let all engineers share a single pool of cubicles (per team) on first-come first-served basis. Engineers are supposed to vacate the cubicle even when they need to leave for two hours (say, for a meeting). The company wants to save a few cents on real estate at the expense of ruining work environment for employees.

review_title: Once upon time a great place to work...now struggling to be relevant
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Built upon a history of great culture. Talented people with lot of potential. Resource rich company. Still commands tremendous respect from outsiders when it comes to chips. Everyone still wonders how could Intel have missed the mobile revolution.
cons: Grown too big and is slow to change. Redundancy and too many veteran employees "waiting in the wings" makes it hard to have a fulfilling career and upward mobility respectively.

review_title: Outstanding opportunities for the highly technical and aggressive engineer willing to put in long hours.
job_title: Technical Program Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great technical place to build a career. However, you need to plan your own career path and aggressively follow it to the T. No one at Intel will shepard you along or mentor you.
cons: Annual review system is a forced percentage process for every department in the US for full time salaried employees. No matter how great the group or team is, there will always be 5% at the top selected for promotions or great salary increases, and 5% at the bottom assigned an Improvement Needed status.  Although promoted heavily, there really is no such thing as work-life balance at intel. Your work is your life... period.

review_title: Good company for electronics engineers. Not so good for software engineers.
pros: Great work ethics and development opportunities. The site facilities are very good and you can find smart people around you. The compensation package is competitive in the market, although you can find better options outside.
cons: Although it is one of the biggest software companies in the world, it is strongly focused on its hardware. I found several software engineers working more in electronics than in developing/designing software. So maybe your software engineering skills will not grow very much here.

review_title: Process Engineer
pros:
great pay and benefits
good place to start career for RCG, lots of stuff to learn
cons:
On call, you can be called at any time, e.g., 2 am at Christmas eve and New Year's eve
Hard to become technical strong, it is more of routine job, not suitable for PhD
Bad management in fab, too demanding for engineers and too easy to technicians, engineers accountable for any mistake by technicians, but technicians do not report to engineers

review_title: Engineering Technician in the Manufacturing Group
job_title: Engineering Technician In TMG in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good Benefits, solid pay and steady work specially when in the manufacturing group.
cons: Standard bureaucracy of a large company. Changes happen quickly, with little to no insight until after the fact in most cases. Everything is a number #1 priority.  Even though work is steady opportunity for advancement is minimal, and changing job roles is even more difficult when coming from the technician field.

review_title: Automation Engineering Tech
pros: Decent pay, used to have breaks... Most of that is gone now in the Rio Rancho facility.
cons: Constant threat of firing, episodes of lower level managers HITTING employees (One made the news, others I witnessed didnt) refusing to act on smell that was found to be a rather large hydrofluoric acid leak, singling out employees for either more work out of scope if talented, removal if not, constant physical threats, (joking or not, they are not useful), managers who constantly lie for no good reason, basically just pure insanity. They have mental health professionals on staff to keep down suicides. That should tell you something.

review_title: Finance
pros: They hire really intelligent people. They have a world class manufacturing process. Finance has a good rotation program so that you can get different experience. It's a good place to get work experience. Generally, the pay is good and it's above average for Oregon.
cons: With the recent workforce reduction in 2016, it's uncertain what the impact will be on career opportunities. Not sure if employees will hunker down and stay in place, or if there is an upside where there will be opportunities if there is the hoped for growth.

review_title: Not the company it used to be
job_title: IT Business Analyst in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Lots of opportunities to change positions/careers; competitive salaries; great employee benefits; lots of training/learning opportunities; diverse workforce
cons: upper management is not transparent in their plans or decisions; does not feel as if older employees are valued regardless of outstanding performance; lots of bureaucracy in decision-making at pretty much every level (not lean); risk taking is not really supported - Intel does not walk the talk - and the fear of failure is part of that.

review_title: Pretty good overall
pros: The pay is good, there are lots of career growth opportunities, job stability is a lot better than most technology companies, there are a lot of learning opportunities and the management is committed to creating a diverse workforce.
cons: Out of all all the tech companies I've ever worked for, Intel has the weakest and most incompetent IT department ever. All they ever do is push useless restarts and worthless updates to people's computers. We have to restart our computers all the time and many times it gets in the way of doing our jobs. They should just get rid of the IT department and outsource this function.

review_title: Was a great place to work
job_title: IT Project Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: Lots of opportunities to explore various career opportunities and grow with the company.  Generally speaking the people at Intel are amazing to work with, and they have some good internal training resources to help you grow your skills.  I also appreciated the work life balance I usually had....but when working across international sites it sometimes proved challenging.
cons: If you work on geographically dispersed project teams (which is becoming the norm in most roles) its hard to have work life balance when you need to meet with with all of the project team members.  And most recently, the business environment is very stressed out and you never know who will be next in their mass layoffs.

review_title: No real consequences for senior management
pros: Great staff, interesting projects, the ability to find an area of interest within the enormous range of possibilities, some flexibility in time
cons: Slow moving decisions, enormous amounts of wasted effort as senior management again and again decides to invest in the wrong area, in the wrong way, at the wrong time. Discouraging sense of being on an enormous vessel heading in the wrong direction. Since ACT, employees have no faith that their work effort has any effect on whether they'll keep their jobs.

review_title: Maintenance Tech.
pros: Gourmet cuisine in lunch café,.. Awesome break rooms with pool tables and massage chairs..Gym at your disposal..Everything you could want!!
cons: The usual power struggle by a handful..who should have schooling on how to conduct themselves, when given a little  authority. You have to deal with that mind set in any work place unfortunately,  and its always hard on someone when they are new and could use a hand up! ..Also when I first started they tried a new program on fast tracking the training..It was pretty awful and didn't work out well for them or us..The training shouldn't be fast tracked. I am sure they have much better training and trainers now though..as it was a pretty progressive place!!

review_title: Software Engineer
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Nizhniy Novgorod
pros:
Quite good compensation on local market
Interesting projects
Health insurance/sport/food compensations
cons:
Work/life balance

Annual focal
1. motivates to work on "beautiful" focal report to throw dust in the manager's eyes and less on real contribution in Intel success
2. very focused on visibility accomplishments - manager can be easily misguided by reports which contain such things although real work was done by other less visible team members
3. too much time between performance reviews - if results are roughly known in advance and they are below than expected then there is no any reasons to work hard till next review year
4. it is unclear how decisions are made (are there any clear numerical metrics or it is personal manager's decision)

review_title: a frustrating place, so much potential not realized due to scale and lack of focus
pros: There are some great people there who are putting in effort to drive the company forward. The hours are more manageable for people with families.
cons:
So many layers and overlapping of job functions generating spin can be demoralizing. This leads to factionalism and inefficiencies. There are quite a few people who are phoning it in or are simply not qualified/driven enough to be effective in their position. That probably goes for any company of over 100k employees, tbh.

Doesn't have the vigor and focus of a younger technology company. Conservative environment. Feels rudderless at times.

review_title: Great job for flexibility
pros:
Plenty of PTO and compressed work week schedule.
Opportunity for advancement. 
Ever changing work place as new methods of production are introduced
Campus has great food, gyms, and onsite optomitrist/dentist
cons:
Very large organization, must do a lot to stick out from the other techs
Job can feel mundane and routine some days, which may or may not be a con
To some degree, feeling of being expendable. Intel recently let go many technicians and hired new waves of techs, myself in that wave.

review_title: Great place to work if you work at your own career development too
job_title: Product Marketing Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel treats their employees as valued assets, generally.  Feedback, openess, total compenstation and benefits are very good.  Intel values and promotes employee growth and it is relatively straight forward to move within the organization.
cons: It is a LARGE organization complete with bureaucracy and insider language.  Only big intitiatives seem to get up a head of steam.  And even those are very slow to develop.  Nimble start up it isn't.  If you have a good manager and are in the "right"  BU you'll do well but there are many backwater depts and technologies where you could languish.

review_title: Slowly turning the huge ship in the "right" direction.
pros: Some level of freedom to set direction for your career.  Many opportunities in such a large corporation.  Worldwide company allows one to experience different cultures and visit many places around the world.  I do think the current management is trying to make life better for the employees.
cons: Huge corporation that can get very bogged down in bureaucracy.  The performance management program does not foster good teamwork, instead it becomes each person for themself.

review_title: great people, varied opportuntiies, strong w/l balance, commitment to community
pros: great people, varied opportuntiies, strong w/l balance, commitment to community (support for volunteering, etc) .... SABBATICAL (8wks plus your vacation that year, every 7yrs).  I've also really enjoyed the opportunity to move to different sites over my career and different groups.  People are very open to mentoring if you ask.

review_title: Intel is a decent place to work and a great place to launch a career.

review_title: Generally well-run large company.
pros: Intel is number one in the world with its principal products. It has great market position and financial strength. You can be proud to say you work for Intel. Total employee compensation and benefits are very good relative to other companies. Intel's senior management approach business, employees and community ethically. Treatment of employees is generally very fair.
cons: Like any very large company, you need to master politics to survive and thrive. The last several years have been difficult to identify chances for career growth due to the realities of the overall economy. Also, the location here has been on a slow decline, as Intel worked toward shutting it down and offshoring many functions.

review_title: Really depends on your immediate group and other factors. For some people it's great... for others, not so much.
pros:
All of this depends heavily on your immediate manager, their manager, your group and the higher business group your in. If you have a good manager (which everyone will tell you is rare) then it can be an awesome place to work. If you have an okay manager (pretty likely) then the other benefits and pros can get you by and make you happy.

- They pay about 10-20% more than other employers, in addition to getting 3 additional bonuses a year. 
- If your manager supports it and your tasks allow it, you can get 1-3 work from home (WFH) days. They're also pretty flexible about hours (I know quite a few people don't get into the office until 10am.)
- Casual: jeans, t-shirt and running shoes is the standard
- High level managers give quarterly business and division update meetings so everyone gets insight into how their job fits into the big picture and has an understanding of the markets and initiatives.
- Unique/Good benefits:
      - Stock Purchase Plan lets you put up to 2-5% of your paycheck into an account that buys you intel stock, discounted at 15% once every 6 months.
      - The 3 (4 weeks if you've worked there for 10+ years) of vacation time is a "recommendation" not a hard and fast limit. Depending on your manager, you may be able to take a few extra days. 
      - Get (pretty significant) corporate discounts on hardware and software
      - Everyone gets a Passport card (Vault level... not that great of a selection, but still a benefit_
      - Has it's own airline between sites (that's just kinda fun)
      - Free financial counseling and good site-by-site activities, initiatives, etc.
-  Will pay for a significant part of your next degree (A friend of my got a masters and Ph.d for free via Intel), a lot of available internal training (depending on what you're looking for)
-  Some groups will try to keep you from moving on and growing, but the majority of Intel is very big on helping you get new opportunities
- You can go talk to anyone no matter what their level is at any time ("Open Door Policy"). In addition,  people you've never met before are very willing to meet up to tell you about what they do and mentor you (that's unique I think, and very awesome)
cons:
- Too darn big to know it's rear from its elbow - for some people this is exciting, for others it's just frustrating.The corporate values are awesome but the company is just so big that it's impossible for any accountability. This means there are some really bad engineers/managers that just hide out in the company or managers that run their groups like weird little "fiefdoms" (another employee's word) with their own values (or lack there of) and policies.
- Here's another policy that blows: you find a job on the internal jobs website and apply for it, your manager gets an email immediately informing them that you are job shopping. 
- A lot of the newer leadership has business rather than engineering background, but the ones that do have the technical background are AWESOME.
- Casual: jeans, t-shirt and running shoes is the standard - this was on the pro's list too... it is awesome most of the time, but for those of you that like dressing up for work or feel more professional/productive when you wear slacks or business casual, prepare to feel very slouchy all the time. A lot of times dressing nice will result in everyone asking you if you have an interview today.
-  Lack of communication across different groups  
- Performance Reviews (called "Focal") can be really unfair. Every employee in a group is compared by grade-level then rewarded (or punished) on a bell curve. If your whole group is solid, someone still has to get the bad grade. The bad grade makes for extra work and sometimes ties you down to your group longer.
- Hire & Fire tendencies. Intel goes through swings where they need hardware engineers or they'll just die so they hire a ton then realize a year later than they don't need half those people any more. Then they'll go on a software engineer hiring binge then lay them all off again when they realize they hired too many. Some business groups are better at this and Intel as a whole is getting better, but it still happens sometimes.
- Intel's values are all listed on the back of employee badges. One of these is "properly staff and fund projects" - not a chance on that one. Most of the groups I know of are understaffed, under a serious time crunch all the time and are constantly being evaluated about what they're billing.
- I had a 1:1 with a pretty senior person last week, he said "this company's a bunch of ***holes, you have to have a pretty thick skin to survive here". I've found that to be true some of the time. But there are also some genuinely awesome folks.
- In some groups there is some heavily guarded tribal knowledge, with poor documentation and no training for new employees.

review_title: Good and bad
pros: Intel can be a solid workplace depending on which campus one is working at. Having worked at more than one Intel campus, the mentality and demeanor of employees at the workplace can change depending on the site.
cons: In Oregon there seems to be a high level of cliquishness and the tendency to turn away from those that don't fit in with the group think mentality. Some individuals are worse than others at making others look bad rather than working on raising themselves up to a higher level of performance.

review_title: You own your own agenda inside Intel
pros:
- great culture overall, esp. the meritocracy
- competitive compensation package
- willing to share company success through stock purchase and assignment..
- open and fair working environment - everyone sits in a cubicle of the same size, including CEO!
- innovation and IP creation are much encouraged inside Intel
cons:
- middle management sometimes can be a mess
- hiring is somehow too loose, esp. on good economy environment, resulting in getting many incompetent employees
- does not know how to do software business well

review_title: Great Place to Work
pros: They treat their interns just like full-time employees giving technical hands-on experience in helping the company grow. Some students even publish while working during the summer.
cons: Finding a good manager is always a matter of "luck" at any company. I've worked here three summers and had 2 excellent managers, and one not so excellent one. Overall I'm satisfied with my experience though.

review_title: I am an atomic layer chemical vapor deposition maintenance and operations technician for Intel Corporation.
job_title: Manufacturing Equipment Technician in Chandler, AZ
pros: Intel has great starting wages. They are willing to give people with no semiconductor experience a chance. Great Bonuses and Stock purchasing programs.
cons: Horrible raises that will not compete with inflation no matter how much work you do above your pay grade. Little to no trust in technicians to make a decision, everything requires engineering approval. Too many systems that require lots of work to perform very small tasks.

review_title: Great company with a harmful internal culture.
pros: Intel is successful due to its manufacturing prowess and very smart people it hires. They have a rich culture of process and lots of resources to make things happen.
cons: "Constructive confrontation" is rarely as constructive as Intel execs would like to believe. Multiple times working here I found myself the victim of unprofessional attacks on my character that have never occurred anywhere before or since in my multiple decades of career. Intel employees compete with each other, and it shows in the way they treat each other.

review_title: Worried over direction of the company
pros: You have the ability to work on interesting projects with some very smart coworkers.  The pay is decent but it depends a lot on your manager who has 90% of the impact on raises, etc.  You can work on silicon valley projects from Portland, Phoenix, Sacramento, or Austin.
cons: The company has really shifted with BK as the new CEO.  In some ways that's good, such as his willingness to be more pragmatic in which markets we go after, but in other ways it's a real concern.  There is a feeling in the company that I come across nearly every day that BK doesn't really care about normal employees.  This was especially evident after the most recent layoff.  People that were rated successful but given slightly less stock were laid off and told they could never come back.  Their direct managers had no say in the matter.  It came down from corporate.  It didn't make sense to most employees but BK didn't seem to understand that at all.  This was especially evident in the employee face to face where he basically said they plan to do such things again in the future and he thought it was a good thing.  It makes you think that we're going to continue to see actions that come across as heartless.  There is especially a concern among more experienced engineers that Intel will find a way to get rid of them by 50.  It seems to be part of the system.  The last thing that is hard for a lot of people is the new diversity push.  If you are in a diverse workgroup (technical female, black, hispanic, native american) it is great.  But for whites, indians, and asian males it's seen as a real frustration.  Whether in external hiring, or internal promotions Intel has shifted to a very discriminatory culture.  It's done in the name of trying to overcome unintended bias but it seems to be overkill and has a really negative effect on the vast majority of employees.  In the past, we tried to always ensure our hiring pool was diverse, but we chose the best candidate.  That is changing.  It's more about making sure we get a certain percentage of diversity in gender and skin color than hiring the best person for the job.  That bothers a lot of people in the company and causes us to be slower because we're not always getting the right skill sets on the project.  One thing that is ironic, is that rather than hiring African Americans or Hispanic Americans, they tend to hire Africans or South Americans.  Foreigners that are going to school in the US just like their Chinese and Indian counterparts.  The difference is the color of their skin.  Many times these are great people, but it is ironic that we claim to be trying to help those in the US that are underrepresented but instead we just hire people from overseas that look more like them.  So, if you fall into one of these categories, it is probably a really good time to join Intel.  There will be more opportunities for you there than potentially any other company.  But if you are a white, indian, or chinese male I would think twice.  You'll probably find yourself getting really frustrated.

review_title: Process Engineer
job_title: Process Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Wonderful benefits and great people to work with. I went through 3 managers and though each had different management styles, they were all fantastic mentors. My team was diverse and easy to work with. I enjoyed the training style and loved the challenges thrown at me.
cons: Nature of the job is to be very vertical so it's hard to move around. The other is the on call culture. Intel doesn't pay for extra time spent being on call. You can take more vacation days, but in some cases I would prefer more pay.

review_title: Intel is more like the government
pros: Good benefits and reasonable pay although average for industry
cons:
Intel is like a government agency with a lot of politics, red tape, and multiple layers of management who take a long time to make a simple decision. 

To get ahead you must think and act like a politician, i.e. be rude to others and/or throw them under the bus.

There seem to be a lot of favoritism especially those from India who tend to favor their own in hiring and working with. This is important due to Intel regularly laying off once to twice per year, hence if you get a bad review or don't get along with your manager you are gone.

Overall Intel is not the company I envisioned before joining which was a high tech, engineer driven and this is why I left as soon as I could!

review_title: Silicon Architecture Engineer
pros: Strong engineering culture and a lot to learn. Lot's of smart people. I think if I was fresh out of college, it would be the perfect company.
cons: It's a huge company so it can be difficult to gain visibility and very hard to understand the organization. Work can be very slow at times. I'm sure this depends on the team, business unit, and site you work at, but there is a lot of meaningless busy work. Benefits are not that great in my opinion.

review_title: I learned a lot from this company and I'm happy I'm not there anymore
job_title: Systems Validation Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
There are a lot of opportunities to move around within the company.
Generally you're working with smart people on cutting edge technology
Decent work-life balance
cons:
Too many initiatives, management's communication with other employees doesn't build confidence.
Promotional marketing to keep employee morale up is bogus. (A coworker's picture was placed under a title 'Talented Program Manager' and that person wasn't even doing Program Management)
The focal / ranking and rating systems prevent successfully performing candidates from getting recognition besides the standard raise and stock

review_title: Stands on shifting sands
pros:
Challenging work
Plenty of resources to go around
Organized and well structured
Limitless potential to learn
Potential to expand your horizons by dealing with people from multiple cultural backgrounds
cons:
Uninspiring CEO
Constantly shifting its strategy and execution
Horrible record at mergers and acquisitions
Bleeds money on projects / products destined to go nowhere

review_title: Terrific cutting edge EE associations; excellent pay and benefits; horrible work/life balance with high turnover. Wear y
pros: Best overall association with some of the highest level scientists out there. Extremely competative between internal teams, but this brings out the talents and creativity of everyone. Salary plus bonuses and stock participation plans are very good compaired to the industry.  An 8-week sabbatical every 7 years for all full time employees is terrific and seems about right timing-wise, because most employees are entirely burned out by then and need a break.  Senior leadership is very strong at Intel -- what I would consider true vision-generating leaders. And the open-door polocy to talk with any of them is real. Not quite so with first-line managers (see below).  When faced with mid year or year-end layoffs (see below) Intel does a terrific job of offering very fair and beneficial separation packages, rather than just walking the poor individual to the door with a cardboard box of cubicle pics and mementos. Generally, the employee is given a 3-month notice that he or she will be going into a "pool" and then an HR specialist is assigned to help the individual find another like-job somewhere else in the company. I would say this is successful maybe 50% of the time. If the employee decides just to leave then and not look for another internal job, the separation package  typically ammounts to 1-month for every year worked in exit pay, plus other benefits such as extendede insurance coverage etc. Layoffs and department cutbacks do frequently occur, but In my opinion, Intel does a very good job of helping exiting employees if that time does come.
cons: No work/life balance no matter how much Intel tries to tout their improvements here. Intel's demands and expectations on their employees' time is still extremely high. Seriously... on-the-job heart attacks are commonplace with the stress of getting product developed and out the door. Intel has a very old workforce with more than 50% of their US-based employees qualified for retirement. The various HR programs and overall emphasis is on hiring NCGs suggests that Intel is really wanting to replace the old guard with new younger (less expensive) blood. It's really a young man's world at Intel and getting more so every month. While senior leadership at Intel is very good in my opinion, the 1st line managers are generally groomed and trained to be tough results-only intimidation driven supervisors. Unfortunately, there is a very common and very strongly adheared-to year-end review policy for managers to promote only the top 5% at year end, give average reviews with near-zero raises to 80% of the team, and run the bottom 15% out the door. These are forced numbers that are very serious, and managers who don't hit them are really put under the microscope.  If the team is all extremely good with nothing but top performers, there will still be a 10% - 15% out-the-door move. Perhaps this is also true at most other companies; I don't know as I've been here for 22 years. But every 6 months I see an aweful lot of great talent walking out the door.  Overall career opportunities are there, but only for those who work extremely hard to get noticed, contribute, and are quite frankly good at office politics. You also neet to be very flexible and willing to take job location moves at the drop of a hat.  Thinking you can progress succcessful at Intel while staying at the same geographical location your entire career (or even 3 to 5 years for that matter) is unrealistic. Nobody at Intel will help you with your career, and with all the top-petigreed talent around, it's quite frankly very tough to complete. There is a reason Andy Grove founded Intel on an "Only the Paranoid Survive" philosophy. It's as true today as it was when I started at Intel. A really terrific place to work as long as you can sink your nails in, hang on, and not get thrown off during the many, many challenging and turbulent political times.

review_title: Great company but limited career opportunity
pros:
Some very smart people and a decent collaborative culture, engineer driven and stable environment. They work to try to develop their people and promote from within - which is good from the perspective of the individual contributor. Decision making is based on a form of democracy - with the option to Disagree and Commit if there is an impasse and someone feels like they would be held accountable for the failure of the decision. There's a lot of vaporware being done internally though - the decision to proceed or cancel a project can be very perplexing at times as it can be more of a political decision than a practical or strategic one driving the outcome.
Total Compensation uses a form of profit sharing to bring the overall $$$ package above the median - in great business years it's well above the median, but the last couple years have worked out to be barely above median comp. At this time, the company is restructuring the bonus calculations and payouts - its being sold as a simpler and easier to predict model for employees who count on the bonus, but there's a lot of distrust and general feeling is that the overall comp will drop as a result. Still, the Intel Retirement Stock program is one of the best in the industry -- average annual deposit can be up to 7% of your salary in stock grants to your Fidelity account.
cons:
Once you achieve a middle tier grade level position, the promotion engine gets incredibly slow. In fact, most people will be content once they reach a Grade Level 8 since there is no pressure anymore to be promoted beyond that. There is one more grade level beyond that which is considered an Individual Contributor or non-executive level - once you hit Grade Level 10 you no longer abide by the rules afforded lower levels - but your annual "focal" (review) doesn't have very well defined goals to work against or be measured against. 
From a task or project perspective - reviews are terribly subjective since you could meet expectations on your normal duties, but create a brand new multi million dollar business from scratch as a self driven initiative - and still only end up with a Satisfactory or Expectations Met review result with a meagre salary increase (cost of living) and a token quantity of RSUs. Health insurance is ok - High Deductible program is heavily promoted, and for single or childless couples it's a great deal. With kids, it works out to roughly the same - the HSA makes up for the premiums you would pay for your family to be covered.
Decisions to promote or cut projects can be really opaque - some projects are allowed to live on unexplicably, while others get cut for no good reason. Similarly when RIFs are called for - some engineers get the package for no reasonable explanation, while there is still considerable deadwood floating around the various teams known for being great places to hide out and :"rest and vest".
Speaking of decision making - there is a culture that has been taking hold of "analysis paralysis" - meeting upon meeting to decide to have another meeting prior to making any decision regardless how harmless or pointless the issue could be. Its become a frustration point for many people within the company, but the sheeple mentality and the fear of raising concern or objection (see below) keeps everyone's mouths shut for the most part.
For all the Constructive Criticism that is touted as being company culture, people get upset if you are simply frank and honest about situations and contributions. In any company arseholes shouldn't be tolerated, but just communicating reality to someone who is under-performing or calling someone out on the carpet for missing a commitment can result in a reprimand from your manager.

review_title: Contradictory opposites
pros:
Note: My work was in the "administrative" area, as opposed to the "technical" or sales/marketing areas - each area is very different, so this only applies to the one I know. Plus, I'm coming from "management", so all the factory tech and related jobs could have totally different conditions. 

Intel is a bundle of contradictory opposites; for every great attribute (and there are many), there's a directly related not-so-great attribute. Probably all of it is just normal for a large corporation in today's world, by the way. I'm listing the pros and cons in the same order, so pro #1 aligns with con #1, etc.

* Meritocracy is genuine - if you produce superior results, you get superior rewards. Contributions outweigh mere seniority.

* Employees are treated very well - amenities, benefits, career development and training, HR oversight of managers, consistency of policy application, work/life balance are all very good for a manufacturing company. Pay is always a little below the best, but company and personal performance bonuses more than make up for it.

* The company fights through seemingly impossible market and industry challenges and succeeds - over and over. Even when they weren't there first, when they do attack something they do it with everything they've got.

* Intel is a huge company, and they actively encourage and facilitate employees to move around between the business units and job functions (but not so much between locations) as part of their career development.

* Intel can be a great place to work, but you have to do most of the work to make it that way.
cons:
* Meritocracy is easily manipulated - if you are good at managing your manager and getting "visibility" that you can dress up as superior results, you'll usually get away with it because likely as not your manager is a generalist who doesn't know much about the actual work you're supposed to be doing. Also, seniority counts for nothing, and as the years go by you'll be pressed very hard to be better, faster and more current than the most recent 25-year old MBA grad they just hired.

* Employees are treated like hamsters on the wheel. Last year's contributions were great, but what are doing to improve on that this year? Right before performance reviews everyone scrambles to get superficial "wins" to dress up the annual assessment, and it works.

* The company can't change at the bottom as fast as management at the top thinks it can. Then, when they don't see the movement they're looking for, they tend to make over-corrections. What they don't realize, however, is that the middle management has been shining them on about implementing the first round of changes (see "advice" section).

* Many people spend more time internally networking and job jumping than actually contributing; somehow senior management allows itself to get taken advantage of in that way. 

* Intel can be a great place to work, but you have to do most of the work to make it that way.
