job_title: Senior DevOps Engineer in Portland, OR
pros:
The benefits are great; stock purchasing, free fruit and caffeine drinks.  I was grateful to have a job during the recession that was never in doubt.  I have stayed as long as I have due to this security.  It was great to have access to crazy powerful machines and brand new tech.

I learned a lot, mostly by my own initiative, and worked with some great people.  Made some lifelong friendships.

Intel sent me on several trips to conferences and visit other sites around the world.  It was a lot of fun.
cons:
I worked on a software team at Intel and after 8 years and several projects I can claim that Intel doesn't know how to do software!  There is little appetite to get better at improving any, all aspects of building software like professionals.  Sure the company pays lip service, but does not follow through with meaningful changes.  If you want to build software like a professional, look for a career elsewhere.

The focal review system is stupid and incredibly unfair.  If you speak out against your team's behavior or practices, expect to get noticed by your first or second line manager and punished at focal time.  You can contest your treatment, but because your fate was determined by all of the managers horse trading for the limited resources to give out every year, you can't effectively refute the unsubstantiated claims.  In short, you have to play the political game well and often.

Recognition is sporadic and arbitrary.  Early on I received a Division Recognition for setting up a server for the org to use.  My team, who didn't help on the project, and I all received the award.  However, later when we achieved something much more significant, nothing.  We even mentioned this to management, but still nothing.

Hiring is broken at Intel.  The one time, out of 8 tries, that we hired someone on our team was when every member of the team said, don't hire this person.  However, the manager did anyway because it was perceived that we would lose the req and this person could plug one hole on our team.  It was a disaster.  The person never did more than the one thing, did not even do that well and brought negative attention to our team within the org.  Furthermore, when we asked for additional headcount to meet our commitments, the headcount we had including this person, was always used against us.

There is often pressure to hire whomever you can, whichever resume you have in front of you now, because the req can close at any time.  This wasn't an irrational fear either.  Many times we would be moving through the process, only to have Intel Corporate to come through and set a hiring freeze.  This is stupid.  It should be that if the team has been given permission, headcount, to hire, that they should be exempt from these hiring freezes, at least for 45 days or something.  However, it is not like that and the unintended side effect is that teams will hire substandard candidates just to fill some headcount.  Do that several times and the org is infected with wrong people.

Another problem with hiring is the equity and diversity push Intel is making.  I am all for hiring diversity but not at the cost of talent and productivity.  Make every effort to get the diverse candidates into the pool of applicants.  However, now Intel will hire some non-white tech female(for example) and tell an org you can have this person for free, won't tally against your headcount, if you can find some place to put her.  This is not how you build a strong capable team.  To do that, you need to find as many candidates as possible, interview them and take the strongest person regardless of race or sex.  I understand there is discrimination.  However, I think engineers are quite often interested in grabbing the person that helps their team and their cause the most.

The way Intel handled this last round of layoffs was dishonest, stupid and damaging.  At focal every year your manager can affect two items, your rating and your stock bonus.  Performance is supposed to be reflected in your rating, NOT your stocks.  However, this year (June 2015) Intel decided to use the stocks as another metric to trim some employees.  Intel made several acquisitions of companies and apparently didn't like carrying over 100,000 employees world wide.  So they used the stocks.  So people with a "Successful" rating with the lowest stocks, Stock Level 4, twice in the last 4 years were let go.  The problem with this is that it is unfair and managers gave SL4 to their employees for a variety of reasons.  For example, quality is an adjunct function at Intel and so managers often gave the better stocks to their direct employees rather than the quality contingent attached to their team.  What was the result, the quality teams at Intel had huge loses.  I guess it's all for the best.  Quality concerns at Intel were always an afterthought.

Intel is a very conservative, Republican-like company.  That doesn't show up until Intel comes out AGAINST Net Neutrality.  In Portland, the company stance is particularly incongruous with the workers who work there, largely a liberal population.  To argue that internet connectivity is not as fundamental a utility as telephone was back in the day is being dishonest.  I understand that companies like Intel and IBM can draw straight lines from blocking Net Neutrality today to profitable sales for their companies, but we want leadership and principles from our company.  

Sadly, Intel is not a company with principles.  We have to take web-based training every year for ethics, etc.  Yet, Intel's upper management has landed us in court case after court case over the years for their unethical behavior.  Look it up if you;'re interested. 

Finally, a lot is said about work-life balance.  It is true that you can work a normal 9-5 type shift and survive at Intel.  However, I have never seen that behavior from those on the rise.  Everyone that has ever advanced at Intel has worked their butt off with 50 and 60 hour work weeks for years, including me.  That is the only way to get ahead, and everyone knows it, if doesn't admit it aloud.

review_title: Not Bad, But Not The Best
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Pro #1) Intel works hard to take care of it's employees, and they far exceed other manufacturing companies, though they come up short when compared to the software industry. Perks are good (not great). Middle management seems to be encouraged to take care of their employees (they encourage you to use the parental leave program, encourage you to take vacations, are generous with sick time if you are really ill).

Pro #2) I never (really) feared for my job at Intel. As a Software Developer, I had plenty of opportunity to move around. In the event of a layoff (called 'Redeployment'), Intel typically works with you to find you another job within the company.

Pro #3) The cafeterias are great, not the best (and not free), but the fare exceeds the average lunch counter. 

Pro #4) The insurance is generally excellent, Intel even offers up to $10k (lifetime) for fertility treatment. Though if you have a family you'll find the only reasonably priced plan is the High Deductible HealthCare plan (or Kaiser, I guess, if you don't mind Kaiser). They drastically increased the price of the traditional PPO for dependents in the past few years.It's not on par with Microsoft, but considering that the majority of the employees aren't in Software, this is far better than the competition offers.

Pro #5) Most of the offices have been redone, so it's no longer the drab grey cubicle-land that it once was.(The downside to this is they are moving towards an "open office" concept, which means there are few places to concentrate when you are writing code).

Pro #6 ) Intel now allows employees some choice when selecting a laptop. If your individual manager allows it, you can get an IT issued MacBook Pro. (My preferred dev os is OS X, so I struggled a bit with Windows when I first started and even bought my own Mac to work on before they made this an option).If you don't have strong feelings about the laptop you carry, you probably aren't using enough. :)

Pro #7) One thing I really liked about the culture was the data before feelings mantra. Most of Intel follows the philosophy that as long as you have the data to back up what you say, then it doesn't matter if you are an entry level tech or a Senior Fellow (highest engineering rank), you can drive your idea forward. It's not always practiced, but it was practiced more than I've seen at any other large company.
cons:
Some background, if you are unfamiliar with Intel's inner workings: Intel is first and foremost a silicon manufacturing company. The core of the company is the TMG group, which controls all the factories (fabs), researches & implements new process technology (they are responsible for shrinking the chips year after year). The other major groups within Intel are the architecture groups (Server, Desktop, etc), which create the designs for the chips (which TMG manufactures), the Software Group (SSG), and IT. I'm leaving out a lot of other groups, such as Finance, HR, etc, because I have no direct feedback on them.

This background is important in understanding the dichotomy of reviews on Intel. The TMG side of Intel is a huge manufacturing company, which employs a ton of skilled technicians, engineers and material scientists. The average employee on the manufacturing side only has experience with manufacturing, and it's military like precision. The other companies that the tech's have worked for are generally other manufacturing companies. That isn't a disparagement of these people, they are the lifeblood of Intel, but Intel isn't competing with Google to hire them. Many of these folks thought the addition of 'Free Soda' to the perks was a bold step (this was done around 2008). Intel is constantly waging a war of providing just enough perks to keep the software people from bolting, without spending more than they have to. I'm not trying to make that sound negative, it is what it is; they're a for-profit company.

Con #1) The perks aren't that great. If you want to make your friends jealous with the posh treatment, Intel is not the company for you. If there are other things you like about your Intel offer, then the perks are enough that you don't feel like you're working for a rust-belt manufacturing company.


Con #2) The non-manufacturing groups are lacking focus and execution. I can't count the number of projects that I worked on that were cancelled mid-development. I worked in the "new" architecture groups for most of my time at Intel (the groups responsible for designing tablets, phones, wearables), and was constantly disappointed by the lack of focus in the management. Whereas Apple might create the iPod and then iterate through multiple generations to get the first shipping product, then iterate that product on the market until they have a runaway hit, Intel management seemed to prefer to toss a bunch of things at the wall to see what would stick. Worse, if they were throwing spaghetti at the wall, they wouldn't even bother to boil it first. They'd toss a package of dry noodles at the wall and then declare that it would never stick. Not so bad, if you don't spend 6 months packaging up the noodles prior to that. I've worked in plenty of places that would cancel a project before release (for many reasons), but at Intel it seemed like most projects ended that way. Look at Intel's history of failed mobile OS's (Moblin, Moblin2, Meego, Tizen). I sometimes felt as though Intel was secretly running a white collar welfare program, designed to keep software developers off the streets and out of trouble.
 

Con #3) Intel's insides move very slowly. If you work within the system, you will die before you can accomplish anything. If you work outside of the system you risk being fired, but you'll at least have something to show for your efforts. Don't get me wrong, Intel has a lot of great people, but the system they have for rewarding employees (called 'Focal') is geared towards individual accomplishment more than moving the company as a whole forward. It seems obvious to measure an individual based on whether they completed their own key objectives, but in practice what I saw was a lot of "not my job" based behavior. I don't fault workers for this, but management needs to take a much better look at the goals they are setting to ensure that they are geared towards increasing productivity and delivering products that people want. My last year at Intel were spent trying to align my business unit with the company's stated best practices for software development. What made this difficult is that these services are hosted by Intel's IT group. Again, individually, I have a lot of respect for the folks I worked with in IT, but as a collective, it was impossible to do anything in less than a year. Application admins are reviewed based on their uptime, and not on the timeliness of new product offerings,etc; so if you have an existing dev process that requires a non-standard tweak to get it migrated, don't expect anyone to fall over themselves accommodating you. Worse, the IT Hosted Apps were ofter years behind the most release. Again, if you are a manufacturing company, that's great; no change means no chance of breaking. Software Development? That's not keeping up with the industry. 

Con #4) Egalitarianism is more a talking point that a real philosophy. If you aren't familiar with it, Intel prides itself on the fact that the execs don't have assigned parking or corner offices. Those things are true, but the execs typically have desks in corners with windows, and they have admins who will immediately stand up and approach you if you get near their desks. Also, each executive has a private conference room, so they don't have to talk where you can hear them. I get that there are real business reasons for this, but the executive privilege has been slowly eroding the egalitarianism in more mundane areas as well. The chance of you bending the ear of any random Fellow or VP, outside of a very controlled forum (such as the quarterly BUM) is pretty low. The culture/policies also draw a very thick line between the Blue Badges (regular Intel employees) and Green Badges (contractors). Again, there are good legal reasons why they don't treat contractors the same as employees, but the separation is much clearer at Intel than any other place I've worked.

Con #5) Intel is increasing their use of lower wage contractors for everything. Typically these contractors are L1 Visa holders from India. Some of these folks are great, but there are a lot who seemed to be learning on the job. In senior roles, most of my experience was with middle management wanting you to delegate much of your work to these contractors. It turns your job as the "engineer" into being more of a project manager. If that's a direction you want to move in with your career, then Intel is for you.

I could go on, but frankly this should be enough to help you know if Intel is for you or not. Good luck and god bless.

review_title: Excellent Engineering-Driven Company

review_title: Intern view of Intel
pros: Great work. Smart people. Great products to work on. review_title: very rewarding

review_title: Great learning experience
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Great name to have on your resume. You will be sought after. Use the latest tools and technology to design some of the most complex devices in the world. Lots of support and training available but you need to be proactive. Great benefits.
cons: Must be paranoid to survive. Information is only shared if you need to know. Must seek out meaningful projects and make sure your achievements are documented in time for the review. Review process can be rough if peers give you negative reviews.

review_title: Great place to work for those under 50.
pros: Good total compensation. Opportunities are abundant with respect to career and location.
cons: Review process is horrible.  It used to be a popularity contest among first level managers, staged behind closed doors.  Now it's even less transparent.  Once you turn 50, unless you are a well-connected manager, you become a target.  You will be urged to accept a voluntary separation package. Alternatively, you can stay and defend your job every year or two.

review_title: Great Company, Great Benefits
pros: Great Benefits, the culture is beginning to catch up with other tech giants.  A definite shift from old tired engineering company to cool, passionate, inovation driving technology and engineering company.  Who else offers 2Month sabbaticals every 7 years on top of vacation?  You OWN your career.
cons: You own your career....A good and bad thing, if you LOVE what you do, you can easily fall into the pit of working yourself to death, and overcommitment.

review_title: Overall, an amazing company to work for
pros: Smart people, challenging work, good pay and benefits, and a strong cultural aspect of respecting and valuing the people that make it all happen. It's a company really focused on leverage a solid set of core cultural values to deliver technology that will help improve lives. A great corporate citizen and leader in environmental issues. The employee base is proud to be part of Intel and achieving great things.
cons: Sometimes is can be hard to make internal moves without personal connections. But it is easy to build a vast network very quickly.

review_title: Good company, but still a large, slow-moving corporation
pros: For full-time salaried positions: Great HR practices, great benefits (3 weeks vacation to start, 8 week paid sabbatical after 7 years, great 401K & profit sharing), generous comp time if you work overtime and good attempts at fun extra-work activities. Theoretical opportunities for international assignments, but they're rare. Product quality is high, great technology lead over competitors, and company generally does the right thing (at least in the areas where every-day employees are involved). Pay is good (not great), and total compensation is targeted around 1 standard deviation above average. Lots of opportunities to move to different positions, so even if you're not promoted, you're not stuck in a job you hate for too long.
cons: Stifling environment when it comes to getting a change made or influencing something to be done outside your current function. Corporate politics are rampant at the mid-to-higher levels, and MANY decisions are made based on someone's ego rather than good business decisions. Company spends too much time and resources trying to forecast whether a decision will work, but too little time and resources making it work once they've decided. Company needs to grow into adjacent markets in order to grow stock price, and it's very frustrating to see crippling resource constraints imposed in these new areas that make it nearly impossible for them to succeed. As with many public company, too much emphasis is put on quarterly earnings rather than long-term strategy.

review_title: Process engineers are overworked and there are no clear boundaries
pros:
- Intel is on the cutting edge of technology, so what we make and how it's made is fascinating.    
- There are random and cool benefits (such as free fruit, free movie/sports tickets and 1 free CPU a year).  Also, the more typical benefits such as health insurance, ... is very good.
- Intel gives back to the community and the environment, there is a push to go green. 
- Intel is constantly trying to improve worker satisfaction. 
- They pay someone just out of school with a PhD very well.
- There is good job security
cons:
- As a process engineer because you are salaried there are no boundaries with the hours you are expected to work and 60-80 hrs a week is the norm.  
- Even when you are not on-call, you will be expected to sometimes wake up in the middle of the night / work on the weekend to work on your tool and this time is not compensated.     
- The on-call time can be very stressful and sometimes it becomes more like extended work hours and less like on call since solutions to problems can sometimes take many hours. But, you are supposed to get a some of your time back for being on call. 
- There is little oversight by senior management of individual group managers and because of this, some groups require more of their engineers than others (for example, some do not give the on-call time back). 
- When you have only a masters degree you make significantly less with the same work load. If you calculate your hourly rate it is more typical to that of a technician.
- Process engineers are treated as commodities that can be easily replaced.  The turn around is very high. I have heard around 50 percent at around 2 years. 
- Often the work we do can be quite routine.

review_title: Leave your intellect at the front door.
pros:
Pay is okay, but even poor workers who refuse to do their jobs thus forcing you to do it along with your own work, still get paid more or the same as you.
Opportunity to travel, if you don't mind relocating at 2 weeks or less notice, to anywhere there is a site, but not sure for how long, depending on business needs.
cons:
Good reliable employees are not recognised or valued...in fact the opposite are taken for granted. 
The job is tedious, monotonous, no scope for imagination or  creative thinking......yes certainly you may carry out a project you are interested in that may save the company millions, but you will do it on your own time, after you have done all your assigned duties, with no extra pay, and forfeit any lunchbreak and someone higher will still try to take the credit for your work.

Shift work is ridiculous, 33.33% extra barely makes it worthwhile, but if on day shift  you cannot afford to live or have a mortgage on it. 
Phd Graduates expected to work for 25-30k pa SALARY....never less than a 60 hour week. 

Teamwork is idealised but is non existent in reality, employees are encouraged to give anonymous feedback on their peers to management, lots of interpersonal conflict with international cultures being ignored.....
Those who shout loudest fare best in this company.

Not a place for women with families...management will try their best to get you out, by altering shifts at short notice, or trying to relocate internationally again at short notice, and again maybe dependant on business needs.
Glass ceiling really does exist here.

There is nothing definite about this company, until it is actually done, do not believe anything.

review_title: Do good work, take ownership and take on new roles periodically and Intel is a great place to work.
